discussion:
In June 1823 when Captain Kent visited Ruapuke in the Mermaid, he noted that most of the local people were away gathering mutton-bird from the southern islands. He visited Te Wera’s village at the Bluff which was very small and almost deserted, and Port William which was then the base for some sealers (including Thoms) under Captain Day in the Sydney brig Wellington. Kent also mentioned the drowning of the chief ‘Pihee’ and about forty others in June 1823 when their double canoe [‘unua’] broke up while returning from the mutton-bird islands. p39
Further west, the largest and oldest village was Pahi’s kaika, though it was much reduced in numbers as forty of its people had drowned in 1823 [see p38 above]. (Richards, 1995)

"Seismic waves had been experienced on the East Coast on several earlier occasions. In August, 1840 … a wave of this character threw H.M.S. Buffalo on shore at Whitianga (Mercury Bay) and wrecked her. Tokato block (between Te Araroa and Hicks Bay) was strewn with fish". (McKay, 1966):

According to McKay (1966): "Seismic waves had been experienced on the East Coast on several earlier occasions. In August, 1840 … a wave of this character threw H.M.S. Buffalo on shore at Whitianga (Mercury Bay) and wrecked her. Tokato block (between Te Araroa and Hicks Bay) was strewn with fish". The ship , Buffalo, was wrecked during a storm at Whitianga, on 28 July 1840. Riddle (1996)

On Wednesday [Oct 18] we had one of the heaviest gales of wind ever experienced here from the N.,W., accompanied by much rain and a remarkably high tide … (Wellington Independent 22 Nov 1848)

"William Greenwood (1967), in his account of the German missionary Riemenschneider at Warea, just north of Cape Egmont, describes an interesting although much less devastating parallel. In 1848, ... earthquakes caused a lot of damage both to the mission station and to Warea; and apparently, at the same time people saw huge waves at sea smashing up Maori sailing ships. Peter Oettli (2006, in press) fixes the date as the morning of 18 October 1848 at 4 a.m. ... and further mentions that the tide rose up higher at Warea than anybody had ever seen before.... The water flooded the camp of migrants, and waves swept away a woman (later rescued), along with her hut." ( McFadgen, 2007)

This morning [Oct 18] the tide rose to an unusual height, overflowing part of Lambton Quay and all those sections at the head of the Bay fronting the water and immediately adjoining the swamp. (NZ Spectator & Cook Straits Guardian 18 October 1848); on Wednesday there was an unusually high tide. Although the tides are at the neap, the tide rose over the beach-road, and flooded the lower parts of some houses. The continuance of S. E. gales would, in the absence of earthquakes, be enough to account for this, yet it seems to have produced a good deal of alarm. (Westminster and Foreign Quarterly Review, Vol 51, 1849)
see source event
[During the earthquake] The water of the river was dashing on the bank two or three yards about its usual height from the motion. (Hamlin, 1855)
discussion: This account clearly describes seiching in association with the passage of seismic waves rather than tsunami.

source_material: No known accounts of tsunami, see discussion next column.
discussion: Of a number of accounts of the earthquake and its effects in Wanganui given in Downes & Grapes (1999), none indicate the occurrence of fluctuations in water levels in the river. Further, a person who traversed the beach between Wanganui and Waitotara (west of Wanganui) the morning after the earthquake makes no comment on a higher than normal sea levels or any evidence that they occurred during the night (see Grapes & Downes, 1997). The tide would have been rising and at a mid-tide level by the time the tsunami generated in Cook Strait (vs any small effects from the possible uplift/subsidence along the Kapiti coast) arrived and hence, heights less than the high water mark (~1 m) at this time would not leave any trace. The lack of any effects up river at Wanganui itself suggest the tsunami along this part of the coast was almost certainly less than 1m, and probably less than 0.5 m.
obs_first_arrival_comments: Arrival time is based on the tsunami from deformation in Cook Strait, and ignores any minor subsdence/uplift along the west coast.

placename: Waitarere Beach [default location for coast between Wellington and Wanganui]
source_material: "[The Taranaki Herald] also says that in the road between Wanganui and Wellington there are cracks eight feet wide rendering it impassable, and in other places where the ground had been quite dry ... water was ... for miles two feet deep. We have conversed with persons who travelled from Wellington to Wanganui and back again, immediately after the earthquake on the 23rd January, and who solemnly declare that they never saw anything of the kind." (Wellington Independednt 28 February 1855)
discussion: The accounts of inundation being observed between Wellington and Wanganui offer little conclusive evidence of tsunami. However, the newspaper that denied that the main route to Wanganui, which was the beach in this era, was impassable because of ground cracks and because there was water across it, is known to have attempted to play down the effects of the earthquakes for political reasons (see Grapes & Downes 1997). Ground cracking, the seiching of coastal lakes, and liquefaction effects (sand fountaining and water expulsion) were common as far north as Wanganui. These effects, however common, are unlikely to cause flooding to 60 cm deep consistently over an extended area as described. Further, as a tsunami was observed as far as Waikawa Beach, it would not be unexpected that it was observable some distance further north. At the time thae main part of the tsunami from Cook Strait would be expected to arrive the tide was 2.5 hours past LW, i.e. near mean sea level. Hence to have flooded the foreshore the tsunami would need to be at least 1.4 m (0-HW + 0.6 m), less if the largest waves were later.
obs_first_arrival_comments: Arrival time is based on the tsunami from deformation in Cook Strait, and ignores any minor subsdence/uplift along the west coast.

source_material: In the morning [after the earthquake] we saw that the sea-waves had come up to the front of the house, leaving hundreds of fish stranded on the sand. (Bevan, 1905)
discussion: Bevan lived near the mouth of the Waikawa River, which in 1855 exited to the sea jointly with the Ohau River, probably through the large lagoon south of the present Ohau River mouth. The tide at Waikawa at the time of the earthquake was about 1.5 hours after LW and was not a spring tide. The expected travel time of the first arrival from deformation in Cook Straiit was just over 1 hrs, suggesting that, to deposit fish close to the house (presumed to have been at least 1.5 m above MHWS), the tsunami needed to reach about 1.5 -2.5 m above sea level at the time, dependent on when the largest waves occurred.
obs_first_arrival_comments: Arrival time is based on the tsunami from deformation in Cook Strait, and ignores any minor subsdence/uplift along the west coast.

source_material: [During the earthquake] Water in the [Motupipi?] river slapped from side to side against the banks. (Millar, 1943)
discussion: The water disturbance observed in the Motupipi River is clearly the result of a seismic seiche, not tsunami. No accounts of tsunami west of Nelson have been found, but the population was extremely sparse. Hence, a small tsunami may have occurred, but not been observed.

source_material: "At Paramatta [Paremata] there was a subsidence of parts of the harbour, boats that had been pulled up on the sand floating over several feet of water" (Fildes collection, unknown date); "fortunately the Mouth of our Harbour [Wellington] being too Small to admit its full force ... but from this impediment it divided itself, the greatest force entering the Next or Porirua Harbour. (Hort, 1855); after the earthquake the tidal flats at Pahautanui [Pauatahanui] were permanently raised above high tide, and were for a time noisome on account of putrefying shell-fish and other marine matter (Adkin, 1921)
discussion: There seems little doubt that a tsunami reached Porirua Harbour, but details are absent. As the tide was 1.7 hours after LW at the time of the earthquake and the travel time of the principal part of the tsunami was about 0.5 hr, the first arrival of the tsunami would have been at a tide level about 0.1 m below MSL, suggesting an elevation of at least 1.6 m at Paramata, possibly higher given the indication what it was higher than in Wellington, where at least 2-2.5 m was experienced in Wellington Harbour near where Hort lived. Greater heights were experienced in Evans Bay (q.v.). Decaying shelfish at Pauatahanui may have been deposited by the tsunami as much as by the uplift, which Grapes & Downes (1997) estimate was about 0.3 m.

source_material: "There was a coach being driven along this [Wellington to Hutt Valley] road when the earthquake came. The driver did not know what had gone wrong with his horses; he kept whipping them up, and they kept floundering about; the next thing he knew they were splashing in water, the sea was coming over the road. Next day there was [sic] fish all the way along near the road, left high and dry.” (Kilmister, 1932)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), HW occurred at 21:00 NZMT January 23, within a few minutes of the earthquake. The road to the Hutt Valley was not far above HW (see Figure 11 in Grapes & Downes (1997)) - waves swept over it in rough weather and the tsunami need only be a metre or so to inundate the road. There is no indication that is was any larger than this, or life-threatening. It is possible that later waves may have been larger, but unlikely given that no evidence was later presented of more significant inundation. Note that Grapes & Downes (1997) considered the tsunami to have three generation mechanisms within Wellington Harbour - sudden horizontal dislocation, differential uplift across the Harbour, and deformation outside the Harbour in Cook Strait.

source_material: "The Waiwetu River had a large mud bank on each side of it next morning after the earthquake. One settler informed me that in the early days fair sized craft used to sail up to Waiwetu River and one small schooner which was at anchor in the river at the time of the earthquake was found high and dry on a mud bank next morning the water having receded through the land being thrown up." (Iorns, 1904); "... in the Hutt district, from the rising of the water and the action of the earthquake together, the bridge over the Hutt River has been thrown down (NZ Spectator and Cook’s Strait Guardian January 25 1855; Jones, 1855a)
discussion: The stranding of the schooner, the creation of new sand/mud banks and the sideways movement of the already collapsed bridge (which was 2-3 km upstream) could be attributable to tsunami. However, uplift of approx 1.5-2 m occurred at this location, and extensive liquefaction occurred throughout the area. It is difficult to suggest possible heights - there is no indication of a tsunami exceeding say, 2-3 m generally along this part of the harbour as a larger tsunami would have washed over the nearby Petone beach and into the Maori Pa on the Waiwhetu Stream. The tide was within a few minutes of HW at the time of the earthquake.

source_material: No known accounts of tsunami, see discussion next column.
discussion: Fraser (1998) database lists "wave reported" at Nelson, citing Grapes & Downes (1997) and Downes & Grapes (1999). However, neither of these references have any accounts of tsunami at Nelson, Grapes & Downes (1997) speciifcally stating on page 339, " no changes in water levels are noted at Nelson".

source_material: Note: Lambton Quay was called The Beach in 1855. "immediately after the shock the sea had rolled in and flooded all the road along the beach" (Bennett, 1855); [Soon after the earthquake] the sea was slowly but surely bubbling over the breastwork and into some of the establishments [along Lambton Quay]. Women and children, half clothed, were rushing to and for, wringing their hands, praying and crying, afraid to stay within their houses, and terrified at the sight of the encroaching tidal wave. Many immediately fled to the Terrace for fear of inundation, but soon returned upon finding that the sea had receded." (Blake, 1909); "[During the earthquake, near corner of Lambton Quay and Mulgrave Street, while running to the Terrace] I could hear the waves dashing on the beach ... About two o'clock on the morning after the shock, I went down to the beach and there found alarm and confusion prevailing amongst the inhabitants, and very considerable damage done to property, and that the waters of the harbour had risen from two to three feet higher than they had ever been known to do, and had flooded some of the houses on the low beach" (Carter, 1866); " The first thing we noticed [early in the morning after the shock] was the extreme lowness of the tide; the sand extended far beyond its usual limits, and then all at once it was covered again by the sea, this advancing and receding of the tide took place three times in twenty minutes, and eventually left the harbour raised about three feet. The Beach where all the shops are situated was a miserable picture, few houses uninjured whilst many were perfect wrecks, and the contents of many of the shops were floating about on the water or thrown up on the shore." (Coote, 1855); "The tide at the time of the first shock was high and immediately rose several feet and flooded the streets facing the sea [i.e. Lambton Quay] several feet deep; it then receded lower than it was ever before known to do and afterwards for eight hours kept ebbing and flowing every half hour." (Drury, 1855); [p12] "... was walking along Lambton Quay when the first of three shocks took place. He was thrown to the ground, and while trying to rise the sea, carrying logs of wood and debris, rushed in, and lifted him off his feet…. The sea rushed into houses in Lambton Quay "to add to the general consternation the sea poured over the road on Lambton-quay, and entered the buildings along the waterfront. (Fildes newspaper clippings, dates unknown); "The tidal wave ... was very evident; thirty or 40 feet high in the straits, and Palliser bay; and even in the harbour 8 or 10 - flowing into houses across the road [Lambton Quay], some 20 or 30 yards above high water mark." (Fox, 1855); Accompanying the first shock was " a tidal Wave which washed into Several of the Stores on the Beach, fortunately the Mouth of our Harbour being too Small to admit its full force, or it most probably would have Swept all on the Beach as a deluge, but from this impediment it divided itself, the greatest force entering the Next or Porirua Harbour" (Hort, 1855); During the first or grand shock the tide rose several feet and flooded the floors of the shops facing the sea - the water then receded to many yards lower tide than had ever been known before even during extraordinary Spring Tides - indeed during the whole night the tides kept ebbing and flowing every 25 or 30 minutes….The tide at the first shock was high and immediately rose several feet and flooded the street up to the houses facing the sea - it then went down and receded lower than it ever was before known to do and afterwards until the following morning kept ebbing and flowing every half hour…. (Jolliffe, 1855); The tidal level appears to have risen some seven or eight feet and consequently overflowed Lambton Quay. A portion of the brick sea wall now in course of erection was destroyed. It receded almost immediately and continued to ebb and flow at short intervals (from 20 min to ?) during the remainder of the night ebbing far beyond Low Water Springs mark but I believe not again flowing after the first severe shock beyond the High Water mark…. (Jones, 1855a); The tidal wave appears to have risen seven or eight feet and overflowed Lambton Quay, destroying some part of the brick sea wall now in course of erection; it receded almost immediately but continued to ebb and flow suddenly the remainder of the night; the Barquantine grounded four times; it recede by many yards beyond the low water springs mark. (Jones, 1855b); In town the waters of the harbour were thrown across Lambton Quay, and flooded all the shops along the waterfront, causing everyone to seek safety on the higher levels. (Keys, 1919); "The sea was greatly disturbed by the succession of shocks and as its intrusion along the foreshore threatened our house, we scrambled up the back to Mulgrave Street [Wellington City], where the Cathedral now stands and found a number of people already assembled ther" (Matthews, ca. 1925a, similar in Matthews, ca. 1925b); "The immediate effect of the upheaval being, to set the water of the harbour rolling or flowing from each side alternatively to the other, with the result that first the sea came over Lambton Quay, and into the shops 3 or 4 feet deep, then it would recede, leaving the vessels in port aground at their anchors" (Meredith, 1898); "At 11 minutes past 9 o'clock, p.m., the gale still blowing strong, we felt suddenly an uncommon and disagreeable grinding, as if the ship was grating over a rough bottom. It continued with severity for more than a minute, the ship slewed broadside to the wind; we were then in 6 fathoms, so there was little doubt but that it was an earthquake.... Lieutenant Jones and myself immediately landed. We found the tide alternately ebbing and flowing…. But a more interesting and extraordinary phenomenon occurred (I say extraordinary, because no person appears to have observed it in the earthquake of 1848); for eight hours subsequent to the first and great shock, the tide approached and receded from the shore every 20 minutes, rising from eight to ten feet, and receding four feet lower than at spring tides. One ship, I heard, was aground at her anchorage four times. The ordinary tide seemed quite at a discount, for the following day (24 h) it scarcely rose at all…. We returned to the ship at 2 a.m., the tide having at that time receded about 4 feet lower than at ordinary spring tide." (NZ Spectator and Cook’s Strait Guardian February 7 1855); "I am inclined to believe that the upheaving which certainly did take place on the 23rd ult. was the work of that instant, and within the following 12 hours, when the sea was seen approaching and receding in such an extraordinary manner" (NZ Spectator and Cook’s Strait Guardian February 24 1855);" The tide rose about 4 feet above high water mark and where the beach is low the water was 1 foot high in some of the shops and then receded and rose every 10 or 15 minutes." (Pilcher, 1855); "the sea had arisen three times in a huge wave and dashed over the sea wall and up to the houses along the strand, finally receding to several feet below its original level". (Smith, 1855); "During the whole of the night and morning, the sea gently ebbed and flowed every quarter of an hour, flowing completely over our front garden, several times advancing as far as the sill of the front door and retreating to such a distance as to leave the piles of the five jetties near by, erected by Baron Alzdorf and Mr Charles Brown, so free of water that one could walk around the outermost of them dry shod, the water being some fifty feet away; while the vessels moored close to the shore lay on their sides high out of the water" (Taine, 1855); "Then came an immense tidal wave, rushing up to the then one sided street of Lambton Quay, and washing things out of the shops. A box of toilet soaps washed out of the only chemist (Mr Barraud), was picked up by my husband, then a lad. When it retreated the whole bay was left high and dry so to speak, as far as the Man of War anchorage for about 15 minutes - thousands of dead fish were piled up from Oriental Bay right round to Petone, but a lesser tidal wave swept them away and relieved the townspeople's fear of pestilence." (Withers, 1901)
obs_first_arrival_comments: The first surges came in during or immediately after the strong shaking, see Grapes & Downes for description of the three elements of tsunami generation: impulsive horizontal movement, differential uplift within the harbour, uplift external to the harbour.
obs_damage: houses and shops inundated, goods damaged, sea wall destroyed

source_material: "One most curious effect was the masses of fish thrown up on the beach between town and Terawhiti. They were carried up by the great wave, and left stranded there above the high water mark, and the late Mr. John McMenamin of Terawhiti station used to tell us of his ride along this bank of fish, his horse floundering and slipping among them as he galloped homeward after the 'quake'." (Keys, 1919)
discussion: The deposition of fish usually occurs when the inundation is fast and significant, i.e. at least 1-2 m. Although the location is within the area of uplift the largest waves probably didn't arrive for 10 minutes or so.

source_material: "The low neck of Watt's Peninsular was submerged about three feet, to the infinite alarm of many who were camped there that night on the occasion of the races." (Anon. 7); "the great earthquake ... sent the sea right across land from Lyall Bay to Evans Bay, and left all the flat land that then existed there covered in fish. The sand hills that are there now have sprung up since that great earthquake." (Brightwell, 1917); "Mr Drummond, living at Kilbirnie in the 1850’s, had seen fish cast ashore beyond where the Bitumen Plant stood, and that a large surf boat was carried by the tidal wave from Evans Bay and left half way across the isthmus where it was found three weeks later hidden amongst toe toe [toi toi] and flax." (Christie, 1953); "All around the harbour is a belt of mussel shells in some places a foot or more deep that were thrown up after the first grand shock - fish - crayfish and other creatures of the sea were thrown up along the coast in numbers and close to Wellington beds of oysters were exposed by being left by the low tide when previously they were well covered with water. At Lyall Bay the tidal wave flowed over the low ground for a considerable distance and left lots of fish dead on the racecourse." (Jolliffe, 1855); "a great wave, which swept across the sands as far as Burnham Water and rushed up into the gullies of the hills beyond." (Keys, 1919); "The dead fish were not seen or heard of by Mr. Roberts except where the wave came into the lake [Burnham Water] near Wellington." (Lyell, 1956a); Tidal wave flowed inland near to Wellington & left fish wh. died near Wellington - it came in over the race-source [sic] ... Burnham water a small lake in the centre of the course - not all the fish were washed -wave in the night (Lyell, 1856b); At the time of the shock, great sea waves rolled in upon the coast and for several weeks the tides were irregular. Dead fish were dumped by the waves on the race course at Wellington during the earthquake, and Mr Mantell relates that various vessels in Cook Strait reported numerous dead fish floating on the sea, some of them species never before seen. (Lyell, 1856d); [Based on reminiscences and family stories] Next day it was seen that the shake had been accompanied by an exceptionally high tide which left thousands of fish on the sandhills between Evans Bay and Lyall's Bay. During an earthquake in 1848 or 1855 (the latter year, I think) the waters of the two bays met….The morning after the earthquake, William, the eldest son, aged 12 years, was sent on horseback to ascertain how the Doughertys at the Pilot Station had fared. To avoid the dangerous tides, he took the route over the hills between Ludlams Gully and the little lagoon above the foothills. Riding around to Houghton Bay, William and Elizabeth found an enormous quantity of fish caught high and dry in a very simple manner. The phenomenal tide rose over a field of rushes which acted as a strainer to hold the fish as the waters receded…. (Sutherland, 1947)
discussion: Evans Bay was in 1855 larger than it is today, several hundred metres having been reclaimed since. The distance from Lyall Bay to Evans Bay, i.e. across the Rongotai isthmus, was about 1 km in 1855. The only residents of the Lyall Bay-Evans Bay area, lived on the surrounding hills, and the isthmus was in its natural state, a swampy area filled with flax and toi-toi. It is uncertain how extensive the sandhills were in 1855, one writer suggesting these may have come afterwards, perhaps the 2 m or so uplift in this area (Grapes & Downes, 1997) contributing to their formation. That the tsunami swept inland from the Evan's Bay side as the Lyall Bay side of the isthmus is indicated by the surf boat pulled up on the sand in Evans Bay being found "half way across the isthmus". Noting that the isthmus was said to have been inundated to about 1m and the tide was high at the time of the earthquake, but not necessarily at the time of the highest waves, the maximum height reached at the limit of inundation relative to sea level at time is estimated to have been about 3-4 m, the inland penetration at least 500 m. These are estimates, which need to be confirmed by numerical modelling or by comparison with a detailed topo map, as the situation is quite confusing with the uplift and the effect of tides.

source_material: "The low neck of Watt's Peninsular was submerged about three feet, to the infinite alarm of many who were camped there that night on the occasion of the races." (Anon. 7) "the great earthquake ... sent the sea right across land from Lyall Bay to Evans Bay, and left all the flat land that then existed there covered in fish. The sand hills that are there now have sprung up since that great earthquake." (Brightwell, 1917); "Mr Drummond, living at Kilbirnie in the 1850’s, had seen fish cast ashore beyond where the Bitumen Plant stood, and that a large surf boat was carried by the tidal wave from Evans Bay and left half way across the isthmus where it was found three weeks later hidden amongst toe toe [toi toi] and flax." (Christie, 1953); "All around the harbour is a belt of mussel shells in some places a foot or more deep that were thrown up after the first grand shock - fish - crayfish and other creatures of the sea were thrown up along the coast in numbers and close to Wellington beds of oysters were exposed by being left by the low tide when previously they were well covered with water. At Lyall Bay the tidal wave flowed over the low ground for a considerable distance and left lots of fish dead on the racecourse." (Jolliffe, 1855); "a great wave, which swept across the sands as far as Burnham Water and rushed up into the gullies of the hills beyond." (Keys, 1919); "The dead fish were not seen or heard of by Mr. Roberts except where the wave came into the lake [Burnham Water] near Wellington." (Lyell, 1956a); Tidal wave flowed inland near to Wellington & left fish wh. died near Wellington - it came in over the race-source [sic] ... Burnham water a small lake in the centre of the course - not all the fish were washed -wave in the night (Lyell, 1856b); At the time of the shock, great sea waves rolled in upon the coast and for several weeks the tides were irregular. Dead fish were dumped by the waves on the race course at Wellington during the earthquake, and Mr Mantell relates that various vessels in Cook Strait reported numerous dead fish floating on the sea, some of them species never before seen. (Lyell, 1856d); [Based on reminiscences and family stories] Next day it was seen that the shake had been accompanied by an exceptionally high tide which left thousands of fish on the sandhills between Evans Bay and Lyall's Bay. During an earthquake in 1848 or 1855 (the latter year, I think) the waters of the two bays met….The morning after the earthquake, William, the eldest son, aged 12 years, was sent on horseback to ascertain how the Doughertys at the Pilot Station had fared. To avoid the dangerous tides, he took the route over the hills between Ludlams Gully and the little lagoon above the foothills. Riding around to Houghton Bay, William and Elizabeth found an enormous quantity of fish caught high and dry in a very simple manner. The phenomenal tide rose over a field of rushes which acted as a strainer to hold the fish as the waters receded…. (Sutherland, 1947)
discussion: See entry for Evans Bay re the Lyall Bay- Evans Bay area, also refered to as the Rongotai isthmus. Parts of Lyall bay have been reclaimed and it is possible that the Lyall Bay Beach has prograded since the earthquake due to the approximate 2 m of uplift (see Grapes & Downes, 1997).Photos of the beach in the early 20th century show significant sandhills, which do not exist today. The estimated distance to the lake is about 2 km. Some accounts suggest the tsunami went further into surrounding hills. Noting that the isthmus was also said to have been inundated to about 1m depth and the tide was high at the time of the earthquake, but not necessarily at the time of the highest waves, the maximum height reached at the limit of inundation relative to sea level at time is estimated to have been about 4-5 m, the inland penetration at least 2-2.5 km. These are estimates, which need to be confirmed by numerical modelling or by comparison with a detailed topo map, as the situation is quite confusing with the uplift and the effect of tides.

source_material: "the great sea-wave which came in immediately after the first shock, about 5 feet higher than the highest tide inside the harbour, and 12 feet higher outside; the tide (i.e. water surface) continued ebbing and flowing every 20 minutes during the night" (Mallet, 1858); "The house collapsing around them [during the earthquake], Sally and Dan herded the children as far from the falling debris as possible. Huge waves began to crash on the beach only a few yards from the front garden, and were coming closer as they watched….The tide rose exceptionally high so it was impossible to go round the beach tracks to the Sutherlands [in Lyall Bay].... A tidal wave any bigger would have meant that they would probably all have been drowned before they could get to high ground, trapped as they were between the sea and the steep, and craggy hills…. The story was told also for generations in the two families about another curious occurrence that followed the first shocks of the quakes. The giant high tides which flowed across the isthmus between Lyall Bay and Evans Bay caused thousands of fish to be stranded an the sandhills there. The rushes, Alex Sutherland described in his book, acted like a sieve and retained the fish as the freak tide receded. (Manson, 1981)
discussion: As noted in Grapes & Downes (1997), the Manson accounts are based on family stories and not too much reliance can be placed on their accuracy as the author probably gathered a lot of information from newspapers of the day and other publications. Nevertheless, the family did live at the Pilot Station at Tarakena Bay and all survived the earthquake and tsunami. However, no height can be estimated from their account. The location of the height given by Mallet (1855) is unknown, and may be anywhere along the coast.

source_material: [On 14 February 1855] we walked for eight miles [from Wairau River mouth towards the west].... As we approached the hills, we noticed that in this spot the sea had risen at least twenty-five feet (Garin, 1855)
discussion: The evidence for tsunami impact, although observed three weeks after impact, appears to have been obvious. Taking into account the tide level at impact (high, ~0.6 m above mean sea-level) and subsidence and settlement that is known to have occurred in the lower Wairau Valley ( 0.9 m at the Wairau River Mouth, possibly less at Rarangi) (Garin, 1855; Grapes & Downes, 1997). the max height reached at the limit of inundation relative to sea level at time was at least 6 m, at most 7 m.

source_material: Mr J. P. Russell, of Wangaimoana, Palliser Bay, New Zealand, pointed out to me the spot where an anvil of his had been carried up by the tidal wave … some 30 ft above high water mark. (Phillips, 1899)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW was reached within a few minutes of the earthquake.

source_material: "In Cook's Strait in 1855 the highest elevation of the roller appears to have been about thirty feet, a shed at Te Kopi, in Palliser Bay, situated about twenty seven feet above the sea, having been swept away on that occasion." (Anon 7); "The earthquake waves were about 30 feet high, and showed a white crest although the night was cloudy; they succeeded the shocks. One family would certainly have been drowned had not some sailor, who had been on the South American coast, recognized the character of the approaching wave the moment it became visible " (Davie, 1870); "The tidal wave ... was ... thirty or 40 feet high in the straits, and Palliser bay" (Fox, 1855); "caused an immense wave, over thirty feet in height, which did much damage along the east coast of this province [Wellington].... both remembered the occurrence, and spoke of the wave being about the height represented, and as having done much injury along the east coast." (Hector, 1868); "[the waves] on the shores of the Wairarapa [were] 20 feet high, washing away the Boatman's Cottage and all in it, he scarcely having time with his Family on Seeing it approaching to escape to the hills, which he fortunately did, as it clear'd away a Ton of Iron, several Bales of wool and other things lying there on the Beach for Shipment to Wellington." (Hort, 1855); "The tidal wave on the night of the earthquake swept the wharves [at Te Kopi, Palliser Bay] completely away, and carried a number of bales of wool out to sea." (Iorns, 1913);" Immediately succeeding the first shock three large waves came up, the last higher than the first two, and at Tekopi about 45 mile [?] [from Wellington] four houses were washed away - but the inmates had retreated in time each succeeding wave being some minutes after the one preceding it." (Mason, 1855); "[At Palliser Bay] "The upheaval caused a considerable tidal wave.... The tidal wave on the night of the earthquake swept the whares [sheds; at Te Kopi] completely away, and took a lot of bales of wool to sea. Strange to say the return wave brought the wool ashore again, and none was lost." (Matthews, 1901); "My father's wool was stored at Te Kopi when the shake occurred, and the building in which it was stored was carried away by a tidal wave and then hurled back on the beach." (Matthews, ca. 1925b); "[At] Te Kopi, a small boat harbour at the Wairarapa, a very heavy wave swept the beach, washing away the sheds, buildings, the bales of wool that were lying there to be taken to Wellington, and all that was on the beach." (NZ Spectator and Cook’s Strait Guardian, January 31 1855); "... about 30? miles up the coast [Palliser Bay?] the sea suddenly rose and washed everything away, houses, boats and bales of wool waiting to be shipped but there again more miraculously no lives were lost. (Richardson, 1855)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW was reached within a few minutes of the earthquake.

source_material: "[On 13 Feb 1855, a resident at Wairau Bar during the earthquake] showed me how the sea had risen and come up to his house [at Wairau Bar] on three separate occasions. It rose fourteen feet above high tide mark, according to him, scouring, uprooting, leaving fish on dry land and causing extreme alarm. In several places you could see fissures in the ground. The tides were still three feet higher than usual. Those who saw the wave coming said that you would never see anything bigger or more terrifying (Garin, 1855); the earthquake was most severely felt in Wairau plains ... a tidal wave had washed over the banks from Cloudy Bay and done great damage. (Jolliffe, 1855); 2 large waves rolled in Jany 23 1855 over a spit of land a beach with a backwater over which it rolled covering it 2 or 3 ft with water & then retired again. (Lyell, 1856e); At the mouth of the Wairau river a gigantic wave swept the beach, similar to what is described to have occurred on the opposite side of the Straits, at Wairarapa, but fortunately without inflicting a similar damage; and the ebb and flow of the tide, at short intervals, occurred in the manner in which Captain Drury described it to have taken place in Wellington harbour. (Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle, 21 February 1855)
discussion: Taking into account the tide level at impact was about 1/2 hr to HW (which was ~0.6 m above mean sea-level), the water elevation at or close to the shore was about 4.2 m, assuming, not unreasonably, that it was measured at the time in relation to the known high tide mark and possibly known elevation of the homestead, not the new high tide mark. The new high tide mark, which was the result of subsidence and possibly settlement that occurred at the Wairau River Mouth, was 0.9 m higher, as identified by Garin (1855) and estimated by Grapes & Downes (1997) prior to the discovery of the Garin account. The horizontal inundation limit, and maximum height reached at the limit of inundation relative to sea level at time are unknown. As extensive lagoons and marshes existed behind the bar and river mouth, it may well be lower than the height reached at the Bar. It would also be expected that a bore travelled up the Wairau River.

source_material: "I have just learnt from Mr Weld, who was living south of the strait in the Middle Island [at Flaxbourne], that the first shock was felt around Cape Campbell at the same time as it was felt in Wellington at 9:30 p.m. on the 23rd. However, he also felt very strong tremors during the night. On the following morning at 3:00 he felt a shock, supposed to be local, which had the same strength as the first one. For several days there were other movements and waves rolled along the coast for a distance of 50 miles." (Lyell, 1856d); "A sea-wave washed in along the coast at & S of Pt Campbell more or less as far as Waipapa Point — the wave may have extended for 50 miles along the N.E. coast of the Middle IsI[an]d." (Lyell, 1856e); Mr. Weld, who resided south of the straits in the South Island, informed me that, besides experiencing there the shock of the 23rd, he felt another next morning of equal violence, and waves of the sea rolled in along the coast for a distance of 50 miles. (Lyell, 1868);
discussion: As noted in the discussion fo Kaikoura, the time of occurrence of the tsunami is uncertain due to the confusing accounts, and hence it is uncertain whether the tsunami was caused by the mainshock. Other large earthquakes, at least one possibly off the eastern Marlborough coast (Grapes & Downes, 1997), are known to have initiated small tsunami (see entries for XXXXX), but the timing of these is also confusing. It is unlikely, however, that any were large enough to cause a tsunami of the extent suggested in Lyell's papers, see entries for Cape Campbell, Flaxbourne, Clarence and Kaikoura and Grapes & Downes (1997). Hence, it is assumed the mainshock is the source. There is no indication of height at Flaxbourne.

source_material: "Tuesday, 30th.Jan. Morning fine. Wind from N.W…. Rode up to the Flags. The hills are very much shaken and split. My boat at the Flags was taken away 20 yards in land by the roll which came in from seaward and left high and dry on the green sward" (Trolove, 1855)
discussion: As the author of this account did not go to Wharanui until a week after the earthquake, it is uncertain when the tsunami moved his boat. Other large earthquakes, some possibly off the eastern Marlborough coast, are known to have initiated small tsunami (Grapes & Downes, 1997) (see entries for Kaikoura, and Clarence). However, it is unlikely that these caused a tsunami of the extent suggested by Weld (Lyell 1856d,e), see entries for Cape Campbell, Flaxbourne, Clarence and Kaikoura. Given that the coast is dynamic and subject to heavy seas, the boat was probably kept at least 2 m above HW, so a height near the shore for the tsunami of at least 2 m is indicated, noting that the location has not been visited by the writer, and may have changed since 1855. At present, the gravel beach above HW is 20-50 m wide in places.

source_material: A sea-wave washed in along the coast at & S of Pt Campbell more or less as far as Waipapa Point — the wave may have extended for 50 miles along the N.E. coast of the Middle IsI[an]d . (Lyell, 1856e); [On the way from Woodbank to Big River] it was observed that "the sea has been inland many feet above high water mark. Indeed in some places the sea occupies what used to be green bushes and grass. ….Friday [26 January] night - slept in the Big river hut - the chimney is down. The shakes have not been so constant tonight, but sharper than during the day. (Trolove, 1855)
discussion: Given that the author marks this comment at the time he had travelled from Wharanui ( i.e. Woodbank, which was near the stream now known as Woodbank Stream) and Clarence River mouth ( known as Big River or Waipapa Point in 1855), it is probable that the tsunami effects occurred along this stretch of coast. The coast is dominated by relatively steep gravel beaches in a dynamic environment subject to heavy seas. Given this, the occurrence of HW just before the earthquake, and the description that the sea reached many feet above HW, a water elevation at the shore no less than 2 m is indicated. See entry for Kaikoura re the uncertainty of the timing of the tsunami.

source_material: I have just learnt from Mr Weld, who was living south of the strait in the Middle Island [at Flaxbourne] , that the first shock was felt around Cape Campbell at the same time as it was felt in Wellington at 9:30 p.m. on the 23rd. However, he also felt very strong tremors during the night. On the following morning at 3:00 he felt a shock, supposed to be local, which had the same strength as the first one. For several days there were other movements and waves rolled along the coast for a distance of 50 miles. (Lyell, 1856d); "A sea-wave washed in along the coast at & S of Pt Campbell more or less as far as Waipapa Point — the wave may have extended for 50 miles along the N.E. coast of the Middle IsI[an]d." (Lyell, 1856e); Mr. Weld, who resided south of the straits in the South Island, informed me that, besides experiencing there the shock of the 23rd, he felt another next morning of equal violence, and waves of the sea rolled in along the coast for a distance of 50 miles. (Lyell, 1868);
discussion: Kaikoura is about 50 miles (80 km) from Cape Campbell, and hence, the southern limit of observations of the tsunami according to Lyell (1856 d,e; 1868). However, the accounts are unclear as to extent of the tsunami - to Waipapa Point, near the Clarence river mouth, which is only 50 km from Cape Campbell, or as far south as Kaikoura? Its time of occurrence is uncertain, and hence whether the tsunami was caused by the mainshock. Other large earthquakes, at least one possibly off the eastern Marlborough coast (Grapes & Downes, 1997), are known to have initiated small tsunami (see entries for January 24 or 25 and February 03), but the timing of these is confusing. It is unlikely, however, that any were large enough to cause a tsunami of the extent suggested in Lyell's papers, see entries for Cape Campbell, Flaxbourne, Clarence and Kaikoura and Grapes & Downes (1997). Hence, it is assumed the mainshock is the source and that the tsunami was at least of observable height in Kaikoura, i.e. no less than 0.5 m.

source_material: The Courtenay [now known as Waimakariri River] rose in our first shock "6 feet" [difficult to read, possibly 4) and fell again (Hamilton, 1855); The water in the Courtenay the south branch of the Waimakariri suddenly rose "six feet" - say, however, four. It fell again immediately. (NZ Spectator 24 February 1855); A man who lives at Kaiapoi, on the banks of the Waimakariri, says the river rose in a few minutes 6 feet. I think that must be a mistake; the oscillation of the water in the river bed, probably washed the Banks to an unusual height. (Sewell, 1855)
discussion: Disturbances in the Waimakiriri River at Kaiapoi occurred during the earthquake, and hence are seiches caused by passage of surface waves, not tsunami. Grapes & Downes (1997) also attributed the effects to seiche, which, given the magnitude of the earthquake (MW8.2-3), are not unexpected and were observed in many locations.

source_material: At the Heathcote ferry, a fresh wet mark was found up the sloping road, to about four or five feet from the water's edge. Now, in that case, the water would not have risen vertically above eight inches or twelve inches. (NZ Spectator 24 February 1855); at the Heathcote ferry the water washed up the sloping road only 4 to 6 feet wh. would give a vertical rise of certainly not more than one foot. (Hamilton, 1855); A wave, however, came up the Avon to within two miles of Christchurch. I was at the time living close to the river, and heard the rushing sound of the water; I did not however know what it was until the next morning when I noticed that the river weeds had been washed on to the grass, for about one foot in height. (Davie, 1870)
discussion: As the water level disturbances were within enclosed or semi-enclosed bodies of water, subject to seiches in association with the passage of seismic surface waves, they are highly unlikely to be tsunami and most likely to be seiches. The rise in the Avon River may have been caused by seiches in the Heathcote Estuary. Grapes & Downes (1997) also attributed the effects to seiche, which, given the magnitude of the earthquake (MW8.2-3), are not unexpected and were observed in many locations. No tsunami was observed on the sea-coast, but a small tsunami may have gone undetected.

source_material: "[during earthquake] We rushed out of the front door in time to see the sea, which all day had laid in molten stillness, arise in one almighty wave and break with a sudden roar against the wall not many yards from where we were standing" (Smith, 1855)
discussion: As the sea level disturbance was during the earthquake, a seiche, not tsunami, is indicated. Grapes & Downes (1997) also attributed the effects to seiche, which, given the magnitude of the earthquake (MW8.2-3), are not unexpected and were observed in many locations. Had significant tidal disturbances occurred later in the night, the port would almost certainly have reported them, despite the falling tide (LW was at 02:38 according to NIWA's Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)).

source_material: "The earthquake of 1855 was marked in this latter province [Otago] by a great sea wave." (Crawford, 1868)
discussion: This is the only account that mentions a possible tsunami in Otago. It is highly unlikely, given that a newspaper was published in Dunedin at this time and this recorded only that the earthquake was felt slightly. No sea level distrubances were mentioned. Although not mentioned, the occurrence of a seiche may account for Crawford's comment. Grapes & Downes (1997) note that seiches were observed in many locations.

placename: Cook Strait area [default location: south of Wellington]
source_material: see source event
discussion: Aftershocks of the January 23 event were numerous and protracted over several months. At least five aftershocks had magnitudes greater than 6.5, but probably less than 7.0. Hundreds with magnitudes 5.0 - 6.4 occurred and accounted for the frequent smaller shocks and vibrations felt over several weeks in Christchurch, Motueka, Wanganui, New Plymouth and Napier. Many hundreds, and probably thousands of aftershocks of magnitude 4 and above are indicated by the constant tremor and small shocks experienced at Wellington, Wanganui and Otaki. A report from Kekerengu on the Kaikoura coast suggests that at least one aftershock was more severe than the principal shock felt in the same area. This could have been local and initiated close to Kekerengu, outside the main rupture zone of the seaward extension of the Wairarapa Fault. (Grapes & Downes, 1997)

source_material: see source event

At about 07:00 August 15, although considerable rain had fallen, discolouration of harbour surprising; failure of boat to make headway was observed, cause not identified at time. At 08:30, strong current out to sea. LW expected at 10.00, but from 09:00-14:00 water advanced and receded 4 or 5 times, the height varying from the LWS to over half tide mark or from 4-5 feet. Violence and suddenness of recession remarkable, leaving fish on banks. Water level attained was not particularly high, as irregularities diminished towards HW. Disturbance did not cease until 17th. Commenced during night of 14-15th. (Anon 1. 1868)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW was at 03:33 (0.75 m) and 16:22 (0.80 m) NZMT, LW at 09:57 (-0.88 m) and 22:29 (-0.69 m). From LINZ Website tidal information relative to MSL (www.hydro.linz.govt.nz/tides), MHWS 1.0 m, MLWS -1.1 m, MHWN 0.7 m, MLWN -0.8 m

source_material: At Kemp's, at head of navigation in river, water rose and fell about 4 ft several times in succession at about 15:00 on 15 Aug. On 16 Aug tide was higher by 1½ ft than ever before known, and disturbance observed all the day as at Paroa. (Judd, A. 1868)

[Written by correspondent form Russell] Sudden rises and falls several times in succession in some creeks and rivers around the bay [Bay of Islands]. Water rushed in far above usual HWM, paused for a few moments and then rushed out as rapidly as it came in without breaching banks. This was repeated. (Daily Southern Cross 1 September 1868)
Not observed at Kororareka but the beach steep and there was a very heavy swell and heavy rain, keeping people indoors. (Judd, A. 1868)
Disturbance of water observed at the entrance to the Waitangi stream. (Judd, A. 1868)

On morning of 15 Aug, observed that during night tide had been higher than ever seen before, and some fencing was carried away by it or a fresh as it had been raining heavily all night. About 10:00 on May 24 water at about HWN in nearby creek, when tide had been ebbing for 5 hours. 10-15 minutes later it had ebbed to LWS, a fall of about 5 feet. Nothing further observed for some hours as weather too bad to be outside. At 15.00 water rushed forcefully up creek to higher than HWS, when it should have been half-flood, then stopped and receded and in 5-6 minutes fell 3 feet, then rose again to HWM, and continued rising and falling in same manner for an hour or more, before observation abandoned. (Judd, A. 1868) See also description for Paroa Bay.
discussion:
According to NIWA Tide forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW was at 03:19 (0.76 m) and 16:17 (0.81 m) NZMT, LW at 09:43 (-0.89 m) and 22:15 (-0.70 m).
From LINZ Website tidal information relative to MSL (www.hydro.linz.govt.nz/tides), MHWS 0.9 m, MLWS -1.1 m, MHWN 0.7 m, MLWN -0.8 m at Opua.

source_material: Similar phenomena as observed at Manawaora Bay. Some Maori canoes were washed away during the night of Aug 14-15 from a grass area considerably above HWS, higher than ever seen before. Rise and fall first noticed at about 10:00, “same degree as at Manawaora Bay but several times. Water disturbed all day 15 Aug, and to a less degree on 16 Aug. (Judd, A. 1868)

Water rose 7 ft vertically above the usual HWM [paper specifically notes that it is vertical not horizontal] (Daily Southern Cross 26 August 1868); On Great Barrier Island, at no specific location, on night of August 14/15 water rushed in and out sometimes going out 3 ft below LWM. On west side of island, water rose 5 ft higher than "usual" [no other detail]. (Daily Southern Cross 22 and 26 August 1868);
discussion: Assumption is made that maximum impact occurred near high tide, as occurred at nearby Port Charles (q.v.). According to NIWA Tide forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW was at 02:47 (0.81 m) and 15:32 (0.86 m) NZMT, LW at 09:09 (-0.93 m) and 21:41 (-0.76 m) at Tryphena.

source_material: Boat lifted 5 ft above HWM. Highest tide occurred on morning of August 15. (Daily Southern Cross 22 and 26 August 1868); On Great Barrier Island, at no specific location, on night of August 14/15 water rushed in and out sometimes going out 3 ft below LWM. On west side of island, water rose 5 ft higher than "usual" [no other detail]. (Daily Southern Cross 22 and 26 August 1868);
discussion: Assumption is made that maximum impact occurred near high tide, as occurred at nearby Port Charles (q.v.). According to NIWA Tide forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW was at 02:47 (0.81 m) and 15:32 (0.86 m) NZMT, LW at 09:09 (-0.93 m) and 21:41 (-0.76 m) at Tryphena.

source_material: At 02:00 on August 15, water rushed into houses on the flat near sawmill without warning. Flat about 3 ft vertically above spring tides, and mill buildings on flat built on blocks 2 ft high. Water was over two feet high in houses, and considerable difficulty experienced in removing people to safety. Some swam to high ground. ”During the same day”, water receded below LW mark at ebb tide, and then returned suddenly as a big wave of several feet in height. The flow and recession occurred several times during low water. It drove logs up creeks, carried away all stacked timber, and depositing it on the flat. Boats and a tramway were washed away. Some logs floated to Pakiri and also a boat. No damage to the sawmill machinery. One schooner at mouth of creek held fast and was not wrecked. (Daily Southern Cross 2 September 1868)
discussion:
According to NIWA Tide forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW was at 02:47 (0.81 m) and 15:32 (0.86 m) NZMT, LW at 09:09 (-1.03 m) and 21:41 (-0.85 m) at Port Jackson.
From LINZ Website tidal information relative to MSL (www.hydro.linz.govt.nz/tides), MHWS 1.1 m, MLWS -1.1 m, MHWN 0.8 m, MLWN -0.8 m at Port Jackson
obs_damage: Houses inundated, timber, boats, tramway washed away

source_material: Tide rose and fell about 6 ft several times. (Daily Southern Cross 22 Aug 1868 and Weekly Press 22 August 1868)

It was observed on morning of Aug 15 that during the night the tide had been 60 ft further than usual on flat in front of house. No noise heard during night. Shells, seaweed and fish scattered along beaches round the harbour. Ten ton barge set adrift from anchorage, later found ¼ mile up a saltwater creek jammed between the banks. (Buchanan 1977).
Within the Auckland harbour no difference in tides observed (Daily Southern Cross 22 and 26 August 1868); No disturbance observed. (Weekly Press 22 August 1868); See other Auckland locations
On afternoon of 16th August, tide in culvert near road observed to ebb rapidly carrying patches of marine grasses, then water rose quickly reaching almost to top of culvert. (Harope 1868)

At low water at 09:30 Aug 15, unusual noise like a whirlwind heard in a branch of the Tamaki River about 9 miles from Heads, then a crested wave rushed up at rate of 10-12 knots against wind and current. Then water rushed in and out 3 times at intervals of ½ hour, with diminishing violence. Then tide “ebbed and flowed repeatedly up to 12:30 sometimes to a depth of from 4-5 ft, but without the wave, when the tide flowed on to high water about 5 p.m ". (Daily Southern Cross 27 August 1868)

First wave came in at about 04:00, and swept all boats, canoes etc out to sea. When schooner topped first wave she “pitched so short” the foremast was carried away. No surf as wind was from off the land. (Mair 1868a); [From accounts gathered by writer] First wave broke at 04.00-05.00. Receding water swept boats, canoes, timber out to sea. Schooner, 3-4 miles off shore "fetched" heavily and broke foremast. Winf off the land, no surf anywhere along the coast at the time. (Mair 1868b)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW was at 02:11 (0.66 m) and 14:56 (0.71 m) NZMT, LW at 08:32 (-0.77 m) and 21:05 (-0.62 m) at Hicks Bay.
obs_first_arrival_comments: inconsistent data:  ie at 04:00 at time of high tide (02:00)
obs_damage: Boats, canoes, timber swept to sea; boat damaged

source_material: On afternoon of August 15, at time of high water, sea rapidly receded until water in river receded to below LWM, then suddenly rose again. Fluctuations observed till evening. Rock turned over near mouth of river. (NZ Herald 28 August 1868)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW was at 02:24 (0.69 m) and 15:09 (0.73 m) NZMT, LW at 08:46 (-0.8 m) and 21:17 (-0.64 m) at Port Jackson.

source_material: Maori at Opape and Torere alarmed shortly after sunrise by a great wave which rushed up the beach far above highest HWS, receded immediately, and was followed by smaller waves. Fishermen on the rocks were suddenly up to necks in water and had to swim to shore. They returned during recession, but fled when second wave approached. (Mair 1868a, b)
discussion:
Assumption is that "high above highest HWS" means at least 0.5 -1.0 m + another 0.1 m above MHWS. According to NIWA Tide forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW was at 02:21 (0.69 m) and 15:06 (0.74 m) NZMT, LW at 08:43 (-0.80 m) and 21:14 (-0.64 m) at Opotiki Entrance.
From LINZ Website tidal information relative to MSL (www.hydro.linz.govt.nz/tides), MHWS 0.9 m, MLWS -0.7 m, MHWN 0.7 m, MLWN -0.6 m at Port Ohope Wharf.

source_material: Maori at Opape and Torere alarmed shortly after sunrise by a great wave which rushed up the beach far above highest HWS, receded immediately, and was followed by smaller waves. Fishermen on the rocks were suddenly up to necks in water and had to swim to shore. They returned during recession, but fled when second wave approached. (Mair 1868a, b)
discussion:
Assumption is that "high above highest HWS" means at least 0.5 -1.0 m + another 0.1 m above MHWS. According to NIWA Tide forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW was at 02:21 (0.69 m) and 15:06 (0.74 m) NZMT, LW at 08:43 (-0.80 m) and 21:14 (-0.64 m) at Opotiki Entrance.
From LINZ Website tidal information relative to MSL (www.hydro.linz.govt.nz/tides), MHWS 0.9 m, MLWS -0.7 m, MHWN 0.7 m, MLWN -0.6 m at Port Ohope Wharf.

source_material: From indications on beach at the mouth of the river, the first wave must have been over 10 ft in height. (Mair 1868b) See Waioeka River, Opotiki entry
discussion: According to NIWA Tide forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW was at 02:21 (0.69 m) and 15:06 (0.74 m) NZMT, LW at 08:43 (-0.80 m) and 21:14 (-0.64 m) at Opotiki Entrance.

source_material: At 8:30 at about LW, a bore of no less than 6 ft high rushed up the river with great velocity swamping boats. In a few minutes river filled to HWM, remained high for several minutes, then receded and in 15 min was at LW again. Several small ebbs and flows followed. At 11:30 another bore of about 3 ft rushed up river at rate of 6-7 knots, reached nearly to HW, and receded in about 15 min. Several smaller bores followed and at about 14:00 the tide rose to its ordinary level and scarcely any perceptible change occurred until 16:15, when it commenced to ebb. On 16 August, sudden rise of about 1½ ft during flood tide at about 13:00. (Mair 1868a); First appeared at 08:30, at LW. Wave about 6 ft high rushed up the river at rate of 6 to 7 knots, filling the river to HWM. Water remained high for several minutes, then retreated and was low tide again ¼ hour later. Several smaller ebbs and flows continued until 13:00, only one at 11:00 being like the first. This was a wall of water 3 ft high, again bringing the level in the river nearly up to HWM, retreating again in 15 min. At 14.00 the tide was at its proper HW, remaining there for nearly 2 hours without any change. It then ebbed gradually. On 16th August, a sudden rise of 1ft 6 in at 13:00. From indications on beach at the mouth of the river, the first wave must have been over 10 ft in height. (Mair 1868b)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW was at 02:21 (0.69 m) and 15:06 (0.74 m) NZMT, LW at 08:43 (-0.80 m) and 21:14 (-0.64 m) at Opotiki Entrance.
obs_first_arrival_comments: Unlikely to be first arrival, see nearby Torere and Opape

source_material: At 10:00 it was low water with the current running out strong, soon after came in with unusual rapidity and at 12:00 was about the level of ½ tide and running out again very rapidly. About 15:00 the largest waves came in raising the level about 2 ft above normal spring tides. It was then nearly the time for high water; spring tides not due for several days. (Williams, 1868); Tidal disturbances observed. (Hawke's Bay Herald 22 August 1868, reprinted in Daily Southern Cross 26 August 1868)
discussion:
In this era there were few Europeans living in Gisborne, the writer (Williams) living away from the immediate coast. While there is no comment on any obvious inundation effects that might have occurred prior to 10:00, it is likely that some waves were higher earlier on the day when the tide was low. According to NIWA Tide forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW was at 01:32 (0.61 m) and 14:10 (0.69 m) NZMT, LW at 07:49 (-0.70 m) and 21:22 (-0.61 m) at 
From LINZ Website tidal information relative to MSL (www.hydro.linz.govt.nz/tides), MHWS 0.75m, MLWS -0.78 m, MHWN 0.52 m, MLWN -0.51 m at Gisborne.

source_material: A vessel anchored in Big River experienced strong “tidal wave” at 14:00, which carried away all lines. Frequent ebbing and flowing about every 15 min from 14:00 on 15 Aug until 12:00 on 16 Aug. Greatest rise 7 ft. (Hawke's Bay Herald 22 Aug 1868; quoted in other newspapers)
discussion:
According to NIWA Tide forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW was at 01:32 (0.61 m) and 14:10 (0.69 m) NZMT, LW at 07:49 (-0.70 m) and 21:22 (-0.61 m) at 
From LINZ Website tidal information relative to MSL (www.hydro.linz.govt.nz/tides), MHWS 0.75m, MLWS -0.78 m, MHWN 0.52 m, MLWN -0.51 m at Gisborne.

source_material: Tidal disturbances observed. (Hawke's Bay Herald 22 August 1868, reprinted in Daily Southern Cross 26 August 1868)
discussion: O.3 m assumed as a miimum for fluctuations to be observable.

source_material: No local effects noted in Taranaki Herald.

From "early hour" on 15 Aug until late in evening tide ebbed and flowed suddenly every half hour. At 07.30 and 16.30 the rise and fall were greatest being "probably not less than six feet". At one of these times, sea receded to wreck of Montmorency leaving it high and dry, while a boat being piloted into the Iron Pot was washed inside the breast work and was almost without water round it for a time. (Hawke's Bay Herald 18 August 1868); [At Napier] From about midnight of August 14, the tide observed to rise and fall in a remarkable manner about every hour. Waves increased in force until 9 or 10 o’clock on August 15, when the rise and fall was about 5 feet, or fully equal to the ordinary tides; only it being ebb tide at the time, the water sunk much lower than usually the case. During August 16 this continued in a lesser degree, and has at length gradually subsided. (Extract from Hawkes Bay Times, August 17 in NZ Herald 20 August 1868); First rush occurred at 04:30 on 15 Aug, when water rose 2½ ft over the ordinary HWM in harbour, but as water near HWM no particular notice taken At about 10:00 at LW, water rushed in filling up Iron Pot in about 8-10 minutes to about 3 ft above HWS then receded with tremendous force leaving the harbour almost dry. Another rush at about 11:00 which was more rapid in its flood and ebb, rose in about 6 minutes and fell in same time. Water also rose and fell inside the Spit, and sea in the Roadstead appeared as if boiling without any appearance of a wave. At about 13:30 water came in again covering the wharf and flooding all around. It was much slower in its flood and ebb taking 15 minutes each way. After this the sea became more serene, and rose and fell with decreasing force until evening of 16th when normal tidal movement began to resume. (Tabuteau, 1868); At 10:00 Aug 15, tide rose higher and fell lower in 10 minutes in the Iron Pot than ever known. (Evening Post 15 August 1868, and many other newspapers); Heavy showers from S.E. all day. On 15 Aug, tide was flowing, when suddenly began to ebb rapidly and in 10 minutes was lower than ever known. Wreck of the Montmorency was seen high and dry. Five minutes afterwards the tide turned and flowed into the harbour again, filling it up many feet above HW. For remainder of 15th tide ebbed and flowed at intervals of 2-3 hours. People on the Spit were rather alarmed and merchants got their sugar, flour, etc., raised above the floors of their stores. On 16th: Tide in harbour continues to flow in and out about every two hours, but not as violently as on 15th. On 17th: Tide has resumed its proper times and seasons. (Campbell, 1868)
discussion:
According to NIWA Tide forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW was at 01:14 (0.64 m) and 13:50 (0.75 m) NZMT, LW at 07:28 (-0.74 m) and 20:04 (-0.66 m) at Napier
From LINZ Website tidal information relative to MSL (www.hydro.linz.govt.nz/tides), MHWS 0.88 m, MLWS -0.86 m, MHWN 0.53 m, MLWN -0.52 m at Napier.
 Times and heights inTabuteau's account are at variance with newspapers, ie elsewhere greatest peak to trough heights recorded in most newspapers are at 07:30 (at low tide) and 16:30 and in some newspapers 10:00, whereas Tabuteau has greatest heights above expected sea levels at 04:30, 10 and 13:30. He also has the expected time for high tide as 04:30 when it was 01:14, and low tide at 10:00 when it should have been mid-tide, both too late by about 3 hours. However, it could just be that he observed the levels at this time and, for instance, at 10:00 sea level was at LWM when the surge occurred.Tabuteau's max zero to peak of 2.1 m at 10:00 implies are peak-to-trough of about twice this, whereas one newspaper suggest only 1.8 m. However, although not the usual interpretation, the account stating "the rise and fall were greatest being "probably not less than six feet"" may actually mean a rise of 1.8 m above mean sea level followed by a fall to 1.8 m below mean sea level, which would be consistent with observations of sea levels far below usual LWM and with Tabuteau.. Hence, Tabuteau's heights and times are not discounted.

source_material: At Whanganui: Sudden rise in river of about 2 ft, which receded after about 5 minutes {no date given]. (Daily Southern Cross 22 Aug 1868); No mention of local effects in Wanganui Chronicle (searched till 1 Sept)

During night of Aug 14-15, tide highest for last 10 years with one exception. HW not expected until 14:00, but tide at 11:00 as high as ordinarily is." (Evening Post 15 August 1868, and other newspapers)
At Motueka Wharf, tide observed to fall 2.5 feet in 2-3 minutes. On Aug 16 similar phenomena observed, but with less frequency [than on 15th] (Nelson Examiner 18 August 1868)

Particulars obtained from Mr Cross, harbourmaster, high water at 6.37 am, water ebbed as usual until 7.55, then ran in again rapidly, the water covering Boulder Bank in all directions until 08:00. Rise of water estimated to have been 5 ft. Water in harbour much disturbed. (Nelson Evening Mail 15 August 1868); On Aug 15, the tide flowed 4 times between sunrise and sunset, sometimes rising 2-3 ft in a few minutes. On August 15: High water at 06:30, tides ebbed until 07:54, then returned, flowing to 8:00 and in 6 minutes rose higher than at high water. At 12:00, in last quarter of ebb, the tide suddenly rose 2 ft, then fell again. At 14:10 the tide flowed again for a short time, and then receded. At 16:50 tide flowed, running in at a rate of 3.5-4 knots until 17:10, when it flowed very rapidly for a short time, and then at usual rate. Sunday, 16 Aug. High water, 07:40. Tide ebbed for 10 minutes, then stopped, and flowed for 5 minutes, and reached its full height. At 13:30 tide began flowing, but stopped shortly after, and did not resume flowing in until 14:10. Monday 17 August. Tide began to ebb 30 minutes before time. (Nelson Examiner 18 August 1868)
