According to NIWA Tide forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW was at 06:40 (1.19 m) and 19:17(1.33 m) NZMT, LW at00:25 (-1.11 m) and 12:58 (-1.29 m) at Port Nelson
From LINZ Website tidal information relative to MSL (www.hydro.linz.govt.nz/tides), MHWS 1.93m, MLWS -1.83 m, MHWN 0.88 m, MLWN -0.86 m at Port Nelson

placename: The Grove (end of Queen Charlotte Sound)
source_material: The tide throughout this day has been very irregular, in its rise and fall. (Extract from Evening Post in Hawke’s Bay Herald 22 August 1868)

Time first noticed not known, but sudden rises and falls at intervals from 15-20 min observed from "day break", “the average of the differential levels being 3 ft”. Movements not observed to be strictly regular, the rise being more sudden at times. Hector placed assistants at end of Brown's wharf all day to take measurements. (Evening Post. 15 August 1868); Changes in level first noticed at around 08.30. From then until noon, the tide kept "bumping" against the brickwork beside the watermen's gridiron, sometimes rising above HWM and then suddenly receding. The greatest observable difference in the levels was about 8 ft. The water almost reached the public street at Te Aro, and floated a quantity of timber that lay 20 yards from high water level. Bar of gravel thrown up at mouth of Ngauranga River. (Wellington Independent 18 and 22 August 1868); Disturbance noticed early on Aug 15. At nearly LW, sea rapidly rose to very high water level and then as rapidly fell again. Rises and falls continued most of the day. The highest rises were at about 09:00 and 12:30, when water level was several feet above the ordinary HW, although actual high water due at 15:20. Variations in level were very rapid. During the morning, the rise and fall of the water at the Gridiron was obvious. Fearing inundation, the lower stories of buildings were cleared out in some cases. Early in the day, Dr. Hector was engaged in making some observations from Brown’s Wharf. (Extract from New Zealand Advertiser, 17 August 1868, in Daily Southern Cross 22 August 1868)
discussion: NOTE: diagram of tidal variation available.

source_material: Report at 16.25 August 15: Tide throughout day very irregular in its rise and fall, which was rising higher and falling lower than ever before known. Tides running in for 20 min, then out in similar time. (Marlborough Express 22 Aug 1868; similar in telegrams in other newspapers)
discussion: From LINZ Website tidal information relative to MSL (www.hydro.linz.govt.nz/tides), MHWS 0.75 m, MLWS -0.72 m at Picton

source_material: Report at 10:00 August 15: Sudden flow of water 30 yds inland. Rose again suddenly to high water mark. First tide in morning 20 yds beyond high water. Still continues to rise and fall rapidly. From hills to west [follows Awatere information], sea appeared rough, with large breakers on the rocks at White's Bay and Port Underwood. Sea and especially at the bar [Wairau bar?]. Sea subsided during day. (Marlborough Express 22 Aug 1868); “10 to 10.20a.m. – Fall, 30 yards (not perpendicularly) and rising suddenly; heavy swell and surf; high storm tides altering all the morning. 11.30. – Reports water up to office.” [Presumed to refer to August 15] Daily Southern Cross 22 August 1868, and other newspapers)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW was at 01:40 (0.42 m) and 14:19 (0.54 m) NZMT, LW at 07:53 (-0.52 m) and 20:37 (-0.44 m) at Port Underwood. Assume office is at least 1-1.5 m above MHW

source_material: Nothing unusual near Blenheim or neighbourhood. “Unaccountable” rise in Wairau River of several feet at Mr Beatson's farm [location unknown], which receded in a few minutes carrying away quantity of fencing, etc [not stated]. (Marlborough Express 22 Aug 1868)

placename: Awatere River [Default location: Awatere River mouth]
source_material: A similar rise observed in Awatere River [location not stated] as in Wairau River [ie several feet], and a new ford created near Templeton's. [This location is about 15 km up the river]. (Marlborough Express 22 Aug 1868)

About the time of low water [on August 15], several bores or waves of unusual size were observed running rapidly in from the sea, and towards high water, the HWM was achieved very quickly. The largest bore, 4-5 ft in height, occurred at 17:00-18:00 in the evening, breaking of one vessel's moorings at the Stanley Wharf. Similar phenomena observed along the coast Those travelling by Cobb's coach saw the sea recede a considerable distance, then a wave break upon the shore and advance considerable distance up the beach [exact location not given]. (West Coast Times 21 August 1868; quoted in Grey River Argus 20 August 1868)

In the evening of August 15 a sudden rise of several feet was observed to take place in a few minutes, and as rapidly to subside. We have this on the authority of a number of persons whose veracity we can rely on, but whether or not their imaginations were excited by the news from Lyttleton, we cannot say. (Grey River Argus 18 August 1868)
No disturbance observed. (Weekly Press 22 August 1868)
discussion: <0.1 used to indicated tsunami was too small to be observable.

source_material: At 09:30 on August 15, a wave 7 ft in height was advanced towards the bar. It was nearly low water in the creek at the time and a strong current outwards. A tremendous rush of water came up, sweeping before it large quantities of timber used at the works at the bridge. Continued throughout August 15, also on August 16 to a less extent. (The Press 18 August 1868, reprinted in Weekly Press 22 August 1868); Lower layers of bales stored at new woolstore built on Donald & Duncan Cameron's property soaked with water. (Goff, Pers. Comm.)
discussion: The observed effects are long after the expected first arrivals and greatest wave heights further to the south at Banks Peninsula.However, greater effects, had they occurred, may have gone unnoticed at low tide. According to NIWA Tide forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW was at 12:55 (0.96 m) NZMT, LW at 06:34 (-0.95 m) and 19:09 (-0.85 m) offshore near Saltwater Creek.
obs_damage: timber washed away, water damage to wool bales

source_material: At about 03:00, 2 hours after ebb, a 4 ft high wave rushed up the Waimakariri. Vessels at several wharves broke away, some colliding, one lifted onto bank without damage other than snapped ropes. First wave at 03:00 followed by others at 15 min intervals. Between 03:00-04:00 seven bores, the first 2 or 3 being the largest; bore which came up at 8pm [?, should this be am?] was considerably above the banks near Harris' Island, but did not overflow them. It came up like a line of breakers, the greater part passing rapidly up the south branch of the river, receding just as quickly. Thought that the fact that it swept up the south branch saved the town. Fortunate that it also did not occur at high water. Waves continued to come up river at during the day, doing some damage to the sheet piling of the breakwater at Blind Creek, and tossing about shipping at wharves, one wave at about 11:00 smashing a dinghy. Waves were not as strong as tide rose higher. Bar shifted, the channel moving ¼ mile north. On night of August 15 and on August 16 more small waves reached the town. (Lyttelton Times 17 August 1868); Largest wave, 4-5 ft in height came up the river at 03:30. Some crews of vessels awakened by the noise, had time to cast anchor and prevent vessels from being washed against the bridge. Several others set adrift.Articles lying loose on the banks of the river were washed about. At most, water reached a few inches beyond HWM. Water rising and falling until 12:00 but no damage done. The land behind the rifle butts, and to seaward, was much flooded, water at the mouth of the river rising to about 10 ft in height. The river going up the river caused most wash along the south bank, but did not injure it. The ketch lying at the bar rode it out with difficulty. The signalman and pilot were compelled to clear out of their house. The bar recently opened is partially filled in, and it is hard to define where the best entrance really is. (The Press 18 August 1868, similar in Weekly Press 22 August 1868)
discussion: A key feature of the impact here is that some of the highest wave arrived at low tide, the height of the bore exceeded to height of the banks in some cases but did not flood over the banks, and thirdly that the effecst were quite differential in parts of the river system affecting the netrance and south banks to a greater extent. According to NIWA Tide forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW was at 12:55 (0.96 m) NZMT, LW at 06:34 (-0.95 m) and 19:09 (-0.85 m) offshore
obs_damage: a few boats damaged, articles washed from banks

source_material: The land behind the rifle butts, and to seaward, was much flooded, water at the mouth of the river rising to about 10 ft in height. The river going up the river caused most wash along the south bank, but did not injure it. The ketch lying at the bar rode it out with difficulty. The signalman and pilot were compelled to clear out of their house. The bar recently opened is partially filled in, and it is hard to define where the best entrance really is. (The Press 18 August 1868, similar in Weekly Press 22 August 1868); See entry for Kaiapoi for more infomation on behaviour in the river.
discussion: According to NIWA Tide forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW was at 12:55 (0.96 m) NZMT, LW at 06:34 (-0.95 m) and 19:09 (-0.85 m) offshore.
obs_damage: lands near mouth flooded, particularly on south bank; channel changed

source_material: Small wave of several inches noticed in Avon R [It is uncertain whether this effect of an earthquake on August 17, or tsunami]. (Daily Southern Cross 27 August 1868)

placename: Heathcote River [Default location: Estuary of the Heathcote & Avon Rivers]
source_material: All the beacon buoys moved out of place in the Heathcote River. (Lyttelton Times 18 August 1877; quoted in other newspapers)

At 03:30 at ½ ebb water suddenly receded from the harbour, rushing out at an estimated velocity of 12 knots in the stream and near the entrance of the harbour. The water continued falling until 04:30, when the end of the breakwater was dry, where average LW depth usually 15 feet [4.6 m]. At 04:30, with a loud roar, a wave of about 8 ft in height rushed up the harbour with great velocity. At 04:50 water was within 3 feet of the railway level and 3 feet [0.9 m] above the highest HWS, having risen 25 ft perpendicular in twenty minutes. At about 05:00 water rapidly receded and at 06:00 the bottom was visible beyond the end of the Government jetty; at 07:15 water again rushed up in the form of a heavy ground swell, and rose rapidly to 16 feet, and immediately began to fall again. At 09:30 the inner end of the screw pile jetty was dry, when the water returned to HWS with even more velocity than at 07:00. Off in the stream, the water was very thick and discoloured, boiling up as it were from the bottom. At 10:15 the water rushed out for about ½ hour, and rose again shortly after 11:00 to 18 ft; throughout the remainder of the day the water rose and fell without any regularity, sometimes at the rate of 3 ft per hour. During whole of 16th, no regularity of the tide, water ebbed and flowed three times in 6 hrs; at 14:16, time of HW, there was 17 ½ feet [at screw pile jetty?], and after ebbing an hour, it rose again to about 17 ½ feet at 16:15. Weather calm and clear; water very thick, and continuing to boil up in large eddies. On 17th and 18th, tides still very irregular, flowing one foot higher, and ebbing one foot and a half lower than the usual springs. Wednesday 19th, nothing perceptible. (Gibson 1868); Report by night watchman at the railway: At 04:00 John Knox barque seen to be lying on side; captain was aroused and when he came on board, he noticed that the harbour from the wharf to Officer's Point was quite dry and all vessels and boats high and dry. After a few minutes, a noise resembling thunder or a strong wind from off Officer's Point, then an immense wave seen coming up harbour towards head of bay. In a few minutes water surged around vessels, dashing them against jetties, tearing them from different wharves, causing collisions between them, stranding them on mud flats, and breaking mooring ropes, and considerably damaging them during rise and following recession. At least six vessels damaged. [Ed. Note; considerable detail omitted here]. Tide kept rising and falling rapidly for some hours. At 06:00 tide was below LWM, 15 min later was above HW, causing “fearful” current. At 09:00, another roller came into the harbour, again catching boats some now stranded on mud flats; again tide rose and fell rapidly, sometimes 3 ft in 5 min; At 10:30 a pilot boat came in from Heads, stating that they had noticed nothing except a very high tide. Keeper from Quarantine station also noticed little except the tide at 06:00 was lower by a hundred yards than it had ever been. The watch on board a vessel [location?] heard three distinct noises like rushing wind in the hour previous to the wave coming in. The officer on board another vessel stated water commenced rushing out of harbour at 12 knots, leaving vessel on mud. At 04:00 vessel lurched and commenced going round like a top, as if in a whirlpool and it continued until 08:00." The large buoy off Officer Point was carried into Dampier Bay. Report from Captain Jenkin's of John Knox, one of vessels damaged at Govt jetty: At 03:30 heard a great noise, ship went down on beam ends and lying with yard arms on wharf. Capt looked up harbour, and saw harbour dry as far as breakwater and a wave about 8 ft high. rolling in. Vessel thrown against wharf by wave, and its rebound and damaged. In 15-20 minutes, water was within 2 ft of top of wharf, and in less than half hour ship was dry again. Water ran in and out at intervals until 10:00, when another rush did further damage. Water continued disturbed in afternoonwith very strong current in and out of harbour. Jetty 300 ft long at head of bay swept away, and paddocks flooded. Details of tides etc: at 23.30 15 August, water half flood, remaining at this for some time; at 00:30, rose to usual HWM; at 01:00 fell back to half ebb; at 02:15, water was 18in higher than usual HWM; at 03:30, back to half-ebb; at 04:30 water was again at HWM; after this gradually water levels dropped; at 06:00, down to LWM, making three times high water in then next 6 hours; at 12:00, at HWM; at 13:00 water suddenly dropped 4 ft; at 14:15, water rose higher than HWM, covering the reef. Agitation still continuing at 18:00. [Lyttelton Times, 17 August 1868, reprinted in other newspapers); The current in the harbour is very strong; the water is rising and falling rapidly. Lyttelton Times 18 August 1868); At Government jetty where normally 6 ft of water at low tide dry at 04:00. At about 4:30, strange sound, like a steamer coming in, and a 20 ft wave seen coming up the harbour. It struck the vessels at the wharf, knocking them about violently and doing considerable damage. It broke over the breakwater and suddenly raised water inside 6 ft, damaging several vessels and setting them adrift. Water almost immediately receded leaving one vessel high and dry at the Govt jetty. At one time the sea bed was visible from the point of the breakwater to the buoy moored in a southerly direction off the Govt jetty. Water then rose and fell at intervals but still increasing at each influx until 11:00. About 10:00 a “roller" came up the harbour, the change in water depth [at Govt wharf?] was measured at 18 ft. Buoy with 4cwt anchor moved from near Officer's Point to Dampier Bay; vessels lying at anchor faced in all directions, indicating that the currents were not all flowing one way. Large quantity of fish floated on the water. Observations attempted but water levels too variable and there was a slight wash due to SW breeze. Fluctuations all day August 15. Flood tide higher than usual. At Lighthouse, sea still disturbed on August 16, rushing in whirlpools and very muddy. On August 17, fluctuation continued. At time of high water at 14.15 16 feet of water at Govt jetty, and two hours later it was 15.5 ft. At high water springs normally about 15 feet at the jetty. (The Press 18 August 1868, reprinted in Weekly Press 22 August 1868);
discussion: According to NIWA Tide forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW was at 0020 NZMT Aug 15 (0.86 m), 1256 Aug 15 NZMT (1.03 m), 01:14 Aug 16 (0.94 m); LW at 1815 NZMT Aug 14 (-0.83 m), 0634 NZMT Aug 15 (-1.01 m), 1909 NZM Aug 15 (-0.92 m). From LINZ Website tidal information relative to MSL (www.hydro.linz.govt.nz/tides), MHWS 1.03 m, MLWS -1.07 m, MHWN 0.63 m, MLWN -0.67 m at Lyttelton Port

source_material: Mr Mitchell heard unusual noise at about 03:00 and at the same time house shaken as if by earthquake. (Lyttelton Times 17 August 1868)
At 10:30 a pilot boat came in from Heads, stating that they had noticed nothing except a very high tide. [Lyttelton Times, reprinted in Evening Post 17 August 1868)
Keeper from Quarantine station noticed exceptional except the tide at 06:00 was lower by a hundred yards than it had ever been. [Lyttelton Times, reprinted in Evening Post 17 August 1868)
Vessel wrecked, and another damaged (Lyttelton Times 17 August 1868)

Letter from Okain Bay resident: In Akaroa harbour, Stony, McIntosh and Laverick Bays, and in the little recess to the N.W. of the Long Look-Out Point, all deep water inlets, the effects were only slightly observable. (Lyttelton Times 25 August 1868)

No extraordinary effects (Lyttelton Times 20 August 1868); Letter from Okain Bay resident: In Akaroa harbour, Stony, McIntosh and Laverick Bays, and in the little recess to the N.W. of the Long Look-Out Point, all deep water inlets, the effects were only slightly observable. (Lyttelton Times 25 August 1868)

Letter from Okains Bay resident: In Le Bon Bay, Okain and Raupo Bays, waves very destructive, sea rushed at least 2 miles, inundating whole of lands adjacent to river [location not stated, see rest of report for Okain Bay re inundation 2 miles inland]. (Lyttelton Times 25 August 1868)

From correspondent at McIntosh farm: At 06:00 on August 15, noticed noise from sea, saw sea come up to a paddock. By the time correspondent reached McIntosh’s house water came up to knee height. By this time his house also flooded, and family ready to flee. Sea then receded to a point where there was normally 16ft of water at LW. Another rush soon after; another at 13:00, when water was 3in higher than at 06:30. Reported that if water had risen a foot higher all houses on the flat would have been swept away, and that it was low water when first flood came, otherwise all would have drowned. Mud everywhere [presumed deposited?]; bridges floating about the bay, another deposited in a garden. A fence carried away. [Another report] All bridges washed away. (Lyttelton Times 20 August 1868, and in The Star 19 August 1868); Little Akaloa, which is also a deep water bay; although its violence was very great, yet the waters were more confined, and did not reach ten chains beyond the ordinary high water mark. (Lyttelton Times 25 August 1868); Report from Little Akaloa resident: Noise like wind blowing hard from about 02:00, but no notice taken until 05:30, when tide was rising gradually and had risen over a rill, over 200 yds from ordinary HWM. Water then rushed in and out the creek gradually increasing in height till highest level at about 11:45. Water then receded and left the harbour dry halfway across McIntosh's house lifted bodily by the water several inches, with damage done to furniture (estimated cost of damage to garden, fencing and timber: £100). Two bridges were washed away. Coast around bay strewn with timber. Another person heard the rumbling noise early in the morning, ran to warn next door family, and the two families barely had time to escape their houses. (The Press 20 August 1868)
discussion: Assume same tides as at Lyttelton

source_material: Overseer woken by rumbling at 04:00 on August 15, but no more notice taken. At 07.00, he found water had been 4 ft higher than highest HWM and things placed above HWM had been washed away. When he went to the beach, the water was considerably lower than LWM. Then a wave rushed in, and in ten minutes was a foot higher than ordinary HWM. Many things belonging to vessel under repair washed away; fish thrown up. Water rising and falling about 5 ft every half hour until 09:50, when it rushed in rapidly to 4 ft above highest HWM. At 10:20 it fell equally fast to its lowest point at 10:35; again at 11.15 water came in with a tremendous rush, carrying away a small jetty, some garden fencing, which was about 4 ft above HWM, and also destroying a great number of choice garden trees. At 11:50, it receded to its lowest point, then rushed in with greater force than previous waves, carrying away a boat house, more garden fencing, and 40,000 ft of timber stacked 5 ft above highest HWM. At 11:55 water receded again, to return at 12:40 reaching 7 ft above ordinary HWM, carrying away another jetty, and a ketch. Next rush at 13:05. After this water continued to rise and fall at intervals of about 45 min, each wave getting smaller .(Lyttelton Times 17 August 1868); Extraordinary sudden influx and reflux of water carried away a jetty and bridge over the main creek, and caused damage to breastwork. The beach strewn with firewood and fish. Sudden ebbs and flows occurred at intervals of 15 minutes, rising beyond its "ordinary" height and flooding paddocks. Wave washed around the rise on which the Holmes' residence stood, carrying away fencing and sawn timber. A ketch was beached and a mudbank created between the vessel and the sea. (The Press 18 August 1868); Wave carried away a bridge crossing a smaller creek, and entirely submerged the island on which stood a workshop, causing considerable loss. Ebbing and flowing at short intervals continued during August 16 and 17, but on August 18 became more regular, and by August 22, appearance of ordinary rise and fall. (The Press 22 August 1868); The lower parts of the flat inundated at irregular intervals by heavy rushes coming up the bay. The jetty entirely disappeared, not even a pile being left on the site. The bridge at the school was floated from its place, and the large bridge at the mouth of the main creek carried bodily up the flat. A schooner was carried ashore, and bumped for a time among the boulders, later washed off, and no damage done. (The Star 17 August 1868); Data for Pigeon Bay in Lyttelton Times 17 August 1868 [which Haast repeats and interprets] was corroborated by the District Surveyor, who happened to be in Pigeon Bay at the time, and who measured the vertical height of the water above spring tides. (Haast, 1868)

Very early am on August 15 residents woken by rising of sea rushing up bays with immense force, and inundating more or less the whole of the lower portion of the districts. Sea calm, receded further than ever known. At successive irregular intervals during the day and especially at high water, sea rushed in with immense force and "at 2 miles from the sea rose at least 10 ft above low water mark and covered the main road to a height of 5 feet". A bridge 2 miles from sea carried a great distance. A large amount of damage to private and public property (bridges & roads), plus many 1000's ft timber, posts, rails and firewood washed away. (Lyttelton Times 20 August 1868); Letter from Okains Bay resident (G. Bishop): In Le Bon Bay, Okain and Raupo Bays, waves very destructive, sea rushed at least 2 miles, inundating whole of lands adjacent to river [location not stated, see rest of report for Okain Bay re inundation 2 miles inland]. In Okain Bay, first wave rolled in at 02:10 [15 August], three others followed at 15 min intervals, and a fourth wave at about 03:00, being the largest and most violent. After 03:00 waves continued at longer intervals, varying from 30-60min, with diminishing force until next high tide near 14:00 when water rose to highest level. Several lesser waves continued up to time of high water on August 18. (Lyttelton Times 25 August 1868); [From information supplied by G. Bishop] The first wave came about 3 o'clock, but there is no certainty about the exact time. It was followed by three others, with intervals of about a quarter of an hour between them, and of which the last was the highest. A fifth wave came about 8 o'clock, but it was not so high, nor was the rush of water so violent, as of those which entered the bay afterwards. Between 10 and 12 o'clock in the forenoon, another succession of waves, at intervals of fifteen to thirty minutes, were experienced. They were irregular, but were quite as high as those in the early morning. A very high wave rushed in about 2 o'clock in the afternoon, which Mr. Bishop considers to be the most formidable and highest of all, and which rose 6 feet above the highest spring tides; the altitude of the Government bridges above high-water mark offering the necessary data for that assertion. My informant considers this wave 2 to 3 feet higher than any of the previous ones. (Haast, 1868) Water rose over the top of fences 2 miles from the sea, completely inundating the lower portions of the area. (The Press 20 August 1868);

Letter from Okain Bay resident: In Akaroa harbour, Stony, McIntosh and Laverick Bays, and in the little recess to the N.W. of the Long Look-Out Point, all deep water inlets, the effects were only slightly observable. (Lyttelton Times 25 August 1868)

Three Great Waves approached islands from NE on the morning of 15th Augt at 01:00 & were most severely felt as shown on the chart [q.v.] at Owenga, Okawa, Tupuangi & at Teraki. The greatest height reached by the 3rd & largest wave estimated at 20 feet perpendicular height above HWS. Roughly estimated that the sea receded from 10 to 15 feet in perpendicular height below HW. Second wave about 10 minutes after first, third and last wave 3-5 minutes later. Waves evidently came from NE direction. Most affected North & Eastern sides of the Islds. Where there were sandbanks, for example, at Okawa & at Owenga, the sea washed away “from 15 to 20 feet inland of the sand banks down to the level of the ordinary beach”. For about 24 hours after the first waves, the sea showed an unusual commotion and intermittent oscillation, especially during the afternoon of August 15. On Aug 16, between 16:00-17:00 sea retired twice to dead LW & “directly afterwards there seemed to be a general upheaval of the whole mass of ocean” until waters touched the beach, and rose to abt 3 feet higher up than MHW, within 15 minutes; remained static for about 10 minutes & afterward receded gradually. The day was fine & the breezes light. [A detailed inundation map accompanies the following account. It delineates affected areas with narrow and broad yellow bands with the following note:] “The broad yellow colouring shows where the three great waves were most severely felt, rising in perpendicular height above the mark of high water springs on average about 20 feet. The narrow yellow denotes a rise of about from 8 -15 feet as above.” [Text at top of Chatham island:] “Along this part of the coast the rise did not exceed over 6 feet above springs.” [ Ed. Note: Inundation map shows Kaingaroa as narrow yellow band.] (Ritchie, 1868); Kaingaroa better off than other settlements. Only one boat lost. (Lyttelton Times 31 August 1868); Written by correspondent from Tupuangi, Chatham Island: Little or no damage. (Hawke's Bay Herald 27 October 1868);
discussion: According to NIWA Tide forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW was at ~2018 Aug 14 estimated CIT (-0.32 m), 0223 Aug 15 estimated CIT (0.48 m) at Kaingaroa. At Waitangi West there is only a small difference between MHWS & MHWN. Note largest waves occurred almost at high tide.
obs_first_arrival_comments: Note: Chatham Island time ~45 min ahead onf NZMT
obs_photographs: Inundation map, see Ritchie, T. in Transcription database

source_material: New Govt pile driven bridge 1.5 miles from sea totally destroyed. (Lyttelton Times 20 August 1868); Letter from Okains Bay resident: In Le Bon Bay, Okain and Raupo Bays, waves very destructive, sea rushed at least 2 miles, inundating whole of lands adjacent to river [location not stated, see rest of report for Okain Bay re inundation 2 miles inland]. (Lyttelton Times 25 August 1868); From Le Bons Bay correspondent: A large wave, from 15-20 ft high, came up the river from the sea at about 03:00 on August 15, carrying away an unoccupied house. Water entered several other houses, residents escaping. Much damage was done; a tramway bridge was carried away. The current carried this bridge, with a whale boat, timber, scrub, &c., with great force against the Government bridge, carrying it twenty chains away and breaking it up. Sixteen chains of new road and two small newly-built bridges were damaged. The damage done to Government property was estimated at about £200. Inhabitants lost considerably – Mr John Smith, in stores and bridge; Mr W. J. Dalgleish, 18,000 feet of timber; and Bailey and Wright, in fences, boats, posts, and firewood. Many acres of grass land and garden are rendered useless, and numbers of pigs and poultry have been destroyed. (The Press 22 August 1868); About midnight on August 14/15 heavy wave or bore came up the river, doing considerable damage to everything on its banks. Waves continued to roll up at intervals of 15-30 minutes, gradually getting higher, until between 03:00-04:00 on August 15, a tremendous wave or wall of water, from 20 to 25 feet high, came up the river, carrying everything before it. About 32,000 feet of sawn timber in total (2 owners)was lost, fencing and firewood was swept away, stores damage, pieces of tramway was washed away and one house flooded with water 2 ft deep, another to 3-4 ft deep. The Government bridge and a private bridge were also washed away. The river, which was about 1½ chains wide before, and 3 feet deep, became 10 feet deep and 9 to 10 chains wide. A punt, 40 feet long, sunk for two years, was washed up and carried more than half-a-mile up the river, and left on a sand bank about twelve feet above high water mark. A house situated about ten chains up the river was washed away and left close to the bush. (The Star 19 August 1868)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW was at 2357 NZMT Aug 14 (0.79 m), 1233 Aug 15 NZMT (0.98 m); LW at 1843 NZMT Aug 14 (-0.77 m), 0610 NZMT Aug 15 (-0.94 m), 1847 NZMT. Aug 15 (-0.86 m). From LINZ Website tidal information relative to MSL (www.hydro.linz.govt.nz/tides), MHWS 1.03 m, MLWS -1.07 m, MHWN 0.63 m, MLWN -0.67 m at Lyttelton Port. Note that bore in river may have exceeded height of banks and surrounding land without inundating them.
obs_damage: Houses, bridges, roadway, timber, fences, boat and livestock damaged; inundation and erosion of land

placename: Wharekauri [default location for Wharekauri to Kaingaroa coast]
source_material: Three Great Waves approached islands from NE on the morning of 15th Augt at 01:00 & were most severely felt as shown on the chart [q.v.] at Owenga, Okawa, Tupuangi & at Teraki. The greatest height reached by the 3rd & largest wave estimated at 20 feet perpendicular height above HWS. Roughly estimated that the sea receded from 10 to 15 feet in perpendicular height below HW. Second wave about 10 minutes after first, third and last wave 3-5 minutes later. Waves evidently came from NE direction. Most affected North & Eastern sides of the Islds. Where there were sandbanks, for example, at Okawa & at Owenga, the sea washed away “from 15 to 20 feet inland of the sand banks down to the level of the ordinary beach”. For about 24 hours after the first waves, the sea showed an unusual commotion and intermittent oscillation, especially during the afternoon of August 15. On Aug 16, between 16:00-17:00 sea retired twice to dead LW & “directly afterwards there seemed to be a general upheaval of the whole mass of ocean” until waters touched the beach, and rose to abt 3 feet higher up than MHW, within 15 minutes; remained static for about 10 minutes & afterward receded gradually. The day was fine & the breezes light. [A detailed inundation map accompanies the following account. It delineates affected areas with narrow and broad yellow bands with the following note:] “The broad yellow colouring shows where the three great waves were most severely felt, rising in perpendicular height above the mark of high water springs on average about 20 feet. The narrow yellow denotes a rise of about from 8 -15 feet as above.” [Text at top of Chatham island:] “Along this part of the coast the rise did not exceed over 6 feet above springs.” [ Ed. Note: Inundation map shows Tupuangi as broad yellow band.] (Ritchie, 1868); Written by correspondent from Tupuangi, Chatham Island, on August 16: [The following may apply to Chatham Islands generally, however the correspondent is reportedly from Tupuangi] During the day of Friday, the 13th instant [sic; actually 14th], the tide was so low that rocks which had usually been submerged were high and dry. About 01:00 on August 15, the first great wave rushed in force and terrific noise. This fortunately served as a premonitory warning, and without doubt prevented the loss of many lives. 10 minutes after the first, another wave more terrible than the first, and after a like interval, the third and last wave. Houses, pahs, and bush in proximity with the shore, were engulfed and carried away by the drawback; but in many instances, human lives were preserved almost by a miracle…. At Tupuangi, two European houses were demolished, and the Maori pa completely washed away. The Maori is lost nearly all their clothing, and from two to three hundred pounds in cash. Unfortunately they had disposed of their cattle, and every other available commodity, in order to raise a fund to pay their expenses to New Zealand; but all is gone, and they are destitute…. Without doubt Tupuangi and the west point of the island was most severely visited. Indeed confident were the Maoris of a general deluge, that, when driven from their pa, the whole body encamped on Maunganui, the most elevated spot on the island, about 700 feet above the sea level. (Hawke's Bay Herald 12 September 1868); Whole Maori pah and 2-3 white settler's houses entirely destroyed and carried into the sea. Sand and kelp were the only remains of the pah, drays were smashed, and a 7-8 cwt grindstone erected at the pah was hurled a "considerable distance". Mr Enjst's house was carried away and deposited in the bush. The inhabitants, mostly Maoris, were left destitute. The first wave came into their houses, and they instantly fled for higher ground. First wave followed shortly after by a second, and a third wave, which was the largest. All they possessed was carried away as water receded, the loss of everything being aided by an offshore wind. Maoris had already sold many cattle and horses in preparation for returning to mainland NZ. (Lyttelton Times 31 Aug 1868); Most severely felt in the north, with low-lying areas all along the coast being inundated, though fortunately most buildings escaped damage. At Tupuangi, a Maori settlement of 60 or 70 people living mainly on the east side of the point, many whares were washed away. West of the point (where the Himitangi was later wrecked) a Moriori drowned while trying to salvage a boat. At Te Raki the wave struck a small house, carrying the contents, including a box of sovereigns, out to sea. Some household effects were later recovered but there was no trace of the sovereigns. The damage at Tupuangi included severe erosion east of the point. A cemetery was badly affected and, as a precaution against further tidal waves, the remains of an early chief were removed and re-interred at Ngatikitiki. The spot was marked by a sandstone headstone that is still visible today. (Holmes, 1993)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW was at ~2018 Aug 14 estimated CIT (-0.32 m), 0223 Aug 15 estimated CIT (0.48 m) at Kaingaroa. At Waitangi West there is only a small difference between MHWS & MHWN. Note largest waves occurred almost at high tide.
obs_first_arrival_comments: Note: Chatham Island time ~45 min ahead onf NZMT
obs_photographs: Inundation map, see Ritchie, T. in Transcription database

On Aug 16, between 16:00-17:00 sea retired twice to dead LW & “directly afterwards there seemed to be a general upheaval of the whole mass of ocean” until waters touched the beach, and rose to abt 3 feet higher up than MHW, within 15 minutes; remained static for about 10 minutes & afterward receded gradually. The day was fine & the breezes light. [A detailed inundation map accompanies the following account. It delineates affected areas with narrow and broad yellow bands with the following note:] “The broad yellow colouring shows where the three great waves were most severely felt, rising in perpendicular height above the mark of high water springs on average about 20 feet. The narrow yellow denotes a rise of about from 8 -15 feet as above.” [Text at top of Chatham island, ie from about Wharekauri to west of Kaingaroa] “Along this part of the coast the rise did not exceed over 6 feet above springs.” [[ Ed. Note: Inundation map shows Tupuanga as a very broad yellow band.] (Ritchie, 1868); "The sea went inland about four miles. "

placename: Waitangi West, Chatham Is (Historical: Anderson residence)
source_material: Three Great Waves approached islands from NE on the morning of 15th Augt at 01:00 & were most severely felt as shown on the chart [q.v.] at Owenga, Okawa, Tupuangi & at Teraki. The greatest height reached by the 3rd & largest wave estimated at 20 feet perpendicular height above HWS. Roughly estimated that the sea receded from 10 to 15 feet in perpendicular height below HW. Second wave about 10 minutes after first, third and last wave 3-5 minutes later. Waves evidently came from NE direction. Most affected North & Eastern sides of the Islds. Where there were sandbanks, for example, at Okawa & at Owenga, the sea washed away “from 15 to 20 feet inland of the sand banks down to the level of the ordinary beach”. For about 24 hours after the first waves, the sea showed an unusual commotion and intermittent oscillation, especially during the afternoon of August 15. On Aug 16, between 16:00-17:00 sea retired twice to dead LW & “directly afterwards there seemed to be a general upheaval of the whole mass of ocean” until waters touched the beach, and rose to abt 3 feet higher up than MHW, within 15 minutes; remained static for about 10 minutes & afterward receded gradually. The day was fine & the breezes light. [A detailed inundation map accompanies the following account. It delineates affected areas with narrow and broad yellow bands with the following note:] “The broad yellow colouring shows where the three great waves were most severely felt, rising in perpendicular height above the mark of high water springs on average about 20 feet. The narrow yellow denotes a rise of about from 8 -15 feet as above.” [Text at top of Chatham island:] “Along this part of the coast the rise did not exceed over 6 feet above springs.” [ Ed. Note: Inundation map shows Waitangi West as broad yellow band, broader to north and south.] (Ritchie, 1868); Written by correspondent from Tupuangi, Chatham Island, on August 16: Anderson family at Waitangi West aroused by first wave. The sea passed obliquely by, and was said to cause less damage because of this and because the house was more elevated than Hay's [at Te Raki] and surrounded by a stone wall. As a result, most household furniture was saved. A Maori named Makare was drowned at Teraikopakipa Point, trying to save Anderson's whaleboat, which had been washed away. “He was holding fast to the boat, when an unusual rush of water came in and carried him out. Being a good swimmer, the poor fellow contended fiercely with death, but, getting among the kelp, he sank at once. The body was found this morning about half a mile from the spot.” (Hawke's Bay Herald 12 September 1868) The Anderson family residing along the coast, 4 miles from Tupunga, had a narrow escape from their house. The manservant, hearing the wave around his hut, ran to tell the family to get out of the house. The next two waves took the house away. A Maori trying to save a boat was carried out to sea and drowned. (Lyttelton Times 31 August 1868)

obs_no_sig-waves: 3 very large waves, other smaller waves

source_material: At an early hour [not specified], roadway near French Hotel [Rue Lavaud] submerged, and damage done to two properties (Roberts, Marcel). Later rise and fall at jetty observed to be about 13 ft. The highest rise was at 12:00, when water crossed road on each side of Doctor's Bridge, doing no damage. No serious damage done in or about Akaroa. (Lyttelton Times 20 August 1868, similar in The Star 20 August 1868); Letter from Okain Bay resident: In Akaroa harbour, Stony, McIntosh and Laverick Bays, and in the little recess to the N.W. of the Long Look-Out Point, all deep water inlets, the effects were only slightly observable. (Lyttelton Times 25 August 1868); In the morning [of August 15], water receded further than known before, then rushed up the harbour at a rate of 6 knots, reaching 18 in higher than highest HWS. Rises and falls continued all day getting slower towards evening. No damage beyond the flooding of part of beach road. The greatest height change was 12 ft 9 in. (The Press 20 August 1868);
discussion: According to NIWA Tide forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW was at 23:44 NZMT Aug 14 (0.82 m), 1218 Aug 15 NZMT (1.0 m); LW 05:57 NZMT Aug 15 (-0.95 m), 18:32 NZMT Aug 15 (-0.91 m).

The narrow yellow denotes a rise of about from 8 -15 feet as above.” [Text at top of Chatham island:] “Along this part of the coast the rise did not exceed over 6 feet above springs.” [ Ed. Note: Inundation map shows no yellow band at Port Hutt ] (Ritchie, 1868); Large spars hurled up into flax. (Lyttelton Times 31 August 1868); Written by correspondent from Tupuangi, Chatham Island, on August 16: Beyond an extraordinary swell no serious inconvenience was experienced. (Hawke’s Bay Herald 12 September 1868); Captain and crew of the Rifleman [anchored in Port Hutt, Chatham Islands] were on board asleep at the time of tidal wave & knew nothing of it till the morning. Captain believed that: the first wave arrived at Tupuangi at 1 50 am, couldn't say when it arrived at Whangaroa or Waitangi, waves were 10 minutes apart, and there were no further waves after the three main waves. (Lubecki, 1868)
discussion: Although the high tide is later by 10-15 minutes than Tupuangi, the tsunami would take a similar time to travel, ire it would still have its greatest effect near high tide.

obs_photographs: Inundation map, see Ritchie, T. in Transcription database

placename: Te Raki Bay, Chatham Is (Hay residence)
source_material: Three Great Waves approached islands from NE on the morning of 15th Augt at 01:00 & were most severely felt as shown on the chart [q.v.] at Owenga, Okawa, Tupuangi & at Teraki. The greatest height reached by the 3rd & largest wave estimated at 20 feet perpendicular height above HWS. Roughly estimated that the sea receded from 10 to 15 feet in perpendicular height below HW. Second wave about 10 minutes after first, third and last wave 3-5 minutes later. Waves evidently came from NE direction. Most affected North & Eastern sides of the Islds. Where there were sandbanks, for example, at Okawa & at Owenga, the sea washed away “from 15 to 20 feet inland of the sand banks down to the level of the ordinary beach”. For about 24 hours after the first waves, the sea showed an unusual commotion and intermittent oscillation, especially during the afternoon of August 15. On Aug 16, between 16:00-17:00 sea retired twice to dead LW & “directly afterwards there seemed to be a general upheaval of the whole mass of ocean” until waters touched the beach, and rose to abt 3 feet higher up than MHW, within 15 minutes; remained static for about 10 minutes & afterward receded gradually. The day was fine & the breezes light. [A detailed inundation map accompanies the following account. It delineates affected areas with narrow and broad yellow bands with the following note:] “The broad yellow colouring shows where the three great waves were most severely felt, rising in perpendicular height above the mark of high water springs on average about 20 feet. The narrow yellow denotes a rise of about from 8 -15 feet as above.” [Text at top of Chatham island:] “Along this part of the coast the rise did not exceed over 6 feet above springs.” [ Ed. Note: Inundation map shows Te Raki as broad yellow band.] (Ritchie, 1868); Written by correspondent from Tupuangi, Chatham Island, on August 16: Two people, Hay and Amery, living at “substantial” dwelling of Mr Hay. Amery was awakened at the approach of the first wave [no detail on what awakened him]. They escaped the house with a few clothes and with little time to spare as the second wave approached. A "vast breaker" enveloped the "mansion", destroying the house, and breaking up the "massive stone chimney" so that no stonework remained intact. Hay and Amery rushed to higher ground, and watched the approach of the third wave, "which came rolling in with the most awful grandeur and thousand-fold power, bearing down out-buildings and stout old akeakes, which broke and cracked beneath its fury like matchwood, and sending its weeds and waters high up the grazing land and into the bush; carrying away young cattle, and scattering the debris of the ruins far away amongst the weeds and bushes of the adjoining swamp." [Ed. Note: see photographs of this location] No further large waves. Apart from house, cash, bales of wool, and all belongings except their scanty clothing lost. (Hawke's Bay Herald 12 September 1868); Hay residence house was washed entirely away, trees in front of house snapped in two. Hay and a visitor escaped with only an axe. (Lyttelton Times 31 August 1868);. At Te Raki the wave struck a small house, carrying the contents, including a box of sovereigns, out to sea. Some household effects were later recovered but there was no trace of the sovereigns. (Holmes, 1993)
discussion: Pictures of the location indicate that the swamps were at least 200 m inland.

obs_no_sig-waves: 3 very large waves, other smaller waves
obs_photographs: Inundation map, see Ritchie, T. in Transcription database

source_material: Residents of a Maori Kainga at the southern end of Lake Ellesmere informed Haast that they observed no unusual disturbances and the waves did not cross the shingle bank, which was 8 ft above HWM, and that they observed no unusual disturbances. (Haast, 1868)

It delineates affected areas with narrow and broad yellow bands with the following note:] “The broad yellow colouring shows where the three great waves were most severely felt, rising in perpendicular height above the mark of high water springs on average about 20 feet. The narrow yellow denotes a rise of about from 8 -15 feet as above.” [Text at top of Chatham island:] “Along this part of the coast the rise did not exceed over 6 feet above springs.” [ Ed. Note: Inundation map does not show Waitangi clearly but it lies between narrow yellow bands.] (Ritchie, 1868); Written by correspondent from Tupuangi, Chatham Island, on August 16: By a Maori just arrived from Waitangi we are informed that serious damage has been sustained there, and some houses destroyed, but no lives lost. Of this, however, we cannot give succinct detail. (Hawke's Bay Herald 12 September 1868); Written by correspondent from Tupuangi, Chatham Island: At Waitangi: Wave came in between 01:00-02:00. Most of the houses on the beach 'more or less damaged". At James Child's smithy, a boat washed up over fence to door, his house was flooded, and some contents destroyed, but he escaped to high ground. Customs boathouse washed away, with much damage to contents. George Selwood roused at the first wash; from beach watched whole of harbour and anchorage empty, then escaped with his family out a back window (by necessity) as second wave washed into the interior of his store destroying stock and counter. Waitangi accommodation house sustained serious damage, the massive stone chimney demolished, and the building lifted from its bearers. The Beamish house was also flooded and occupants fled. Auckland family house flooded and palings damaged. Mongute Hotel received no damage. The river between the two settlements became swollen to an inland sea, and a bridge across it washed away. Taylor's residence near river was flooded, and stock much damaged. A number of whaleboats were smashed and carried away. A wreck, previously deeply embedded in sand washed onto bank high and dry. (Hawke's Bay Herald 27 October 1868); Beamish's accommodation house (wood with iron roof) was lifted off its piles. Water entered several houses. One family escaped through a window, the water being knee deep in the house. Goods from stores and houses carried away in drawback and deposited on Waitangi beach. Water seen to rush up the Waitangi stream, inundating a large flat area. Vessels at anchor nearly dry. (Lyttelton Times 31 August 1868); Tidal wave reported to have done much damage, and in the following years the sea encroaching rapidly on the narrow strip of level land between the hills and high water mark. (Travers, 1871)
discussion: The extent of damage suggests that the max. observed height of inundation above sea level at the time is probably at the higher end of the range suggested by the inundation map, i.e. 3.5 m or more, despite the fact that many houses were very close to the beach. Note that Travers suggests that the beach eroded in the years after the tsunami, and hence today's beach may not be representative of the beach in 1868.
obs_first_arrival_comments: Note: Chatham Island time ~45 min ahead onf NZMT
obs_photographs: Inundation map, see Ritchie, T. in Transcription database

source_material: Three Great Waves approached islands from NE on the morning of 15th Augt at 01:00 & were most severely felt as shown on the chart [q.v.] at Owenga, Okawa, Tupuangi & at Teraki. The greatest height reached by the 3rd & largest wave estimated at 20 feet perpendicular height above HWS. Roughly estimated that the sea receded from 10 to 15 feet in perpendicular height below HW. Second wave about 10 minutes after first, third and last wave 3-5 minutes later. Waves evidently came from NE direction. Most affected North & Eastern sides of the Islds. Where there were sandbanks, for example, at Okawa & at Owenga, the sea washed away “from 15 to 20 feet inland of the sand banks down to the level of the ordinary beach”. For about 24 hours after the first waves, the sea showed an unusual commotion and intermittent oscillation, especially during the afternoon of August 15. On Aug 16, between 16:00-17:00 sea retired twice to dead LW & “directly afterwards there seemed to be a general upheaval of the whole mass of ocean” until waters touched the beach, and rose to abt 3 feet higher up than MHW, within 15 minutes; remained static for about 10 minutes & afterward receded gradually. The day was fine & the breezes light. [A detailed inundation map accompanies the following account. It delineates affected areas with narrow and broad yellow bands with the following note:] “The broad yellow colouring shows where the three great waves were most severely felt, rising in perpendicular height above the mark of high water springs on average about 20 feet. The narrow yellow denotes a rise of about from 8 -15 feet as above.” [Text at top of Chatham island:] “Along this part of the coast the rise did not exceed over 6 feet above springs.” [ Ed. Note: Inundation map shows Cape Point Durham as broad yellow band.] (Ritchie, 1868)
obs_first_arrival_comments: Note: Chatham Island time ~45 min ahead onf NZMT
obs_photographs: Inundation map, see Ritchie, T. in Transcription database

The narrow yellow denotes a rise of about from 8 -15 feet as above.” [Text at top of Chatham island:] “Along this part of the coast the rise did not exceed over 6 feet above springs.” [ Ed. Note: Inundation map shows Owenga and coast several kilometres to north as broad yellow band.] (Ritchie, 1868); Written by correspondent from Tupuangi, Chatham Island: [at Owenga] whares "elevated more than 30 ft above high water mark were prostrated", and 5 whale boats washed away. (Hawke's Bay Herald 27 October 1868); Some valuable boats were destroyed at Owenga, and a Maori hut or two washed away. (Lyttelton Times 31 August 1868)
obs_first_arrival_comments: Note: Chatham Island time ~45 min ahead onf NZMT
obs_photographs: Inundation map, see Ritchie, T. in Transcription database
