obs_photographs: Inundation map, see Ritchie, T. in Transcription database

source_material: Written by correspondent from Tupuangi, Chatham Island: A few fences carried away. (Hawke's Bay Herald 27 October 1868)
obs_first_arrival_comments: Note:  Chatham Island time ~45 min ahead onf NZMT

source_material: Rushing one instant up beyond HWS then dropping far below dead low water, sometimes in silence, sometimes with the noise of distant thunder. First noticed at 04:45, when sea at very low level. Buoy on edge of north reef, 50 yds from shore high & dry and rocks never before visible were well out of the water. A short while later, sea rushed violently in without warning, washing men and equipment high up onto landing stage. Strength of wave shown by submersion of the surf-line buoys at Govt and Co's landing places. Water remained at HWM for about 10 minutes, then retreated rapidly as low as previously, staying at low point for about 30 minutes, then rushed in again, but not as strongly as previously, remained at HWM for a few minutes then retreated to low water. Ebb and flow occurred 4-5 times in 2 hours. Sea rose and fell 9-10 ft, while ordinary tidal rise and fall was 6 ft. When sea at low water, all calm, rush was heralded by a few breakers. Between 05:00-07:00 a noise like distant thunder was heard at intervals. Sea disturbed to about 14.00 on August 15, sometimes rushing up to HWM, and a few minutes later falling about 20-30 ft, and then back again to HWM. After 14.00 sea became comparatively still, and the rise and fall became more regular. On August 17 some disturbance still visible in the morning. A steamer on her passage from Lyttelton to Timaru were struck suddenly by two or three heavy seas early on August 15, although the water at the time was calm, and the steamer was swept ten miles to the northward by a strong current, against which there was no making headway. (Timaru Herald 19 August 1868); Vessel (Stormbird) travelling south from Lyttelton found itself about 10 miles north of expected location during morning of August 15 - supposed to be caused by northward current. Strong currents noted by same vessel when anchored at Timaru just after noon. Tides strange and water observed to occasionally run up 20ft on beach and recede a "most unusual distance". Noticed steamer had rolled and laboured at sea between 04:00-05:00. Owner of a boat putting off from the beach reported that a rumble was heard from sea at 04:45 and wave of 12ft hit beach, washing up 20ft above level of high tide and receding to lower than lowest tides remembered, revealing rocks never seen before. Immediately after, a strong 6 knot northward current set in off beach, reversing some short time later. (Oamaru Times & Waitaki Reporter 18 August 1868, reprinted in Lyttelton Times 31 August 1868)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW was at 23:15 August 14 NZMT (0.78 m) and 11:48 August 15 NZMT (0.92 m) , LW at 05:29 August 15 NZMT(-0.90 m) and 18:01 August 15 NZMT (-0.85 m) at Timaru. Some inconsistencies in descriptive accounts. Stated fall of "20-30 ft" is inconsistent with a peak to trough measurement, as the water level does not appear to have greatly exceeded HWM at HW - hence assumed to represent a horizontal movement.

source_material: At 01:00 confused motion of sea noted. At 07:30, an enormous wave came in, then water receded to 8ft 6in below usual LWM leaving surf boat aground 400 ft from shore. Some people walked out and retrieved old anchor. About 1/2 hour later sea rose to unusual height carrying landing service boats up a creek. Sea rose and fell for some hours, the "jetty piles being sometimes covered and sometimes 12-15 ft out of the water -the total vertical rise of the sea being about 15 ft." At about 11:55 sea rose again higher than before, completely covering the shingle bank and washing over into the creek and flooding the Govt landing shed to depth of 2-2.5 ft. One person nearly drowned. About 6 minutes later wave receded, 10 minutes later rising again but not as high. This was last great wave [report made on 18 August) (Oamaru Times and Waitaki Reporter 18 August 1868); "Extraordinary changes in sea level since daylight; tide rising and falling about 15 ft perpendicularly, at intervals of 15 minutes, receding 8 ft below low water mark [Report at] 12.30 Rise and fall of tide remarkable since 9 this morning; last rise at 12, five feet higher than ordinary high water; in five minutes rise of 11 ft, and fell again almost as rapidly. Not entirely ceased yet. (Evening Post 15 August 1868, and other newspapers); During the forenoon, the water had risen many feet in a very short time, and the large boulders that line the shore, near the remains of the Oamaru jetty, were covered, a heavy surf at the time beating on the coast. The water rose within a few inches of flooding the narrow strip of land which separates the lagoon from the sea. The water fell as rapidly as it had risen, and in a very few minutes had gone down, as nearly as could be estimated, about 20 feet. Alternate risings and fallings succeeded each other so quickly, that in less than twenty minutes they were repeated five times. It is said that once, about day-break, the sea was lower than it ever been known before. A boat, to which the outer end of the line along which the surf-boats are drawn, was moored, and which at ordinary low water floats in 11 feet water, was left for a few minutes so completely dry that a man was able to walk out and pick up an anchor which had been dropped alongside some time ago. Not a breath of wind was blowing, yet the surf was heavier than usual, and broke upon the beach as furiously as if it had been blowing a strong gale. (Otago Daily Times 17 August 1868)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW was at 11:43 (0.87 m) NZMT, LW at 05:23 (-0.84 m) and 17:57 (-0.79 m) at Oamaru. Inconsistencies in data na difficult to interpret, maximum heights not being given early in the morning. They appear to have exceeded HWM, a 0.9 m has been assumed

source_material: On August 15, the sea, which had receded as at low tide, leaving the beach and rocks bare as usual, suddenly advanced to high water, and fluctuated irregularly all the forenoon." At 07:45, water at HWM; at 08:15 at LWM; at 08.30 high as HWS, then sometimes half tide, sometimes nearly HWM until 11:30 when it came in higher than any spring tide. There was little surf, no wind, "but the waves near the beach were much jumbled, not following each other with the regularity of breakers... The perpendicular height estimated between the rise and fall could not have been less than 10 feet; I should say rather 12." (Otago Witness 22 August 1868)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW was at 11:41 (0.86 m) NZMT, LW at 05:21 (-0.83 m) and 17:54 (-0.79 m) offshore near Kaitiki. The peak to trough estimate of 10-12 ft seems inconsistent with other descriptive data.
obs_first_arrival_comments: Almost certainly not the first arrival

source_material: At 09:00, an hour after flood tide, water suddenly rose 5 ft from a smooth sea, coming in without breaking, and reaching HWM. It remained stationary for 2 min then receded as quickly as it came in. Water in mid-channel smooth, strong current only noticeable near rocks and banks. Current at lower Red buoy was 7 knots. Upper Red and Black buoys set adrift. (Otago Daily Times 17 August 1868)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW was at 11:38 (0.87 m) NZMT, LW at 05:18 (-0.85 m) and 17:52 (-0.80 m) at Otago Harbour entrance.
obs_first_arrival_comments: Almost certainly not the first arrival

source_material: Water rose and fell at short intervals throughout the day. Harbour Master appointed to record changes every 5 minutes on one occasion water fell 17in in two minutes. (Otago Daily Times 17 August 1868)"Report at 10:00: Water rose 1 ft and fell in a few minutes; three buoys drifted; large ships swung round three times in one tide; water falling." (Evening Post 15 August 1868, and other newspapers); Report telegraphed at 15.30 Aug 15: "waters rising and falling. Two ships anchored off Maori Kaik swung completely round twice. (Evening Post 17 August 1868 ) Buoys in channel drifted from position. Two large ships off Maori village swung round 3 times in eddy. At high water at 13:00 tide continued to rise and fall about 7 inches, and at the rate of two in a minute. (Marlborough Express 22 August 1868)
obs_first_arrival_comments: Almost certainly not the first arrival

source_material: Disturbance was seen, but was not as great as at Harbour entrance. (Otago Daily Times 17 August 1868)

"Great rise and reflux of the water", punt moored near east Taieri Bridge washed away from moorings, and carried down river. It was retrieved before it reached broken water at the bar. (Otago Daily Times 17 August 1868)
obs_damage: punt broke away, but no damage

placename: Port Molyneux [mouth of Clutha River; port destroyed by change in river channel due to floods in 1878)] and along coast to Catlin's River
source_material: From Port Molyneux: At the river mouth and along the coast towards Catlin’s River, “storm wave” observed on August 15. At 18:00 [ed. note: definitely 6 pm in this paper and Bruce Herald] a wave 6 feet high rolled into river mouth. One boat, lying alongside the jetty, was lifted a considerable height by the waves, and then dropped, breaking mooring lines. Another boat grounded by one wave in Puerua River, but got off with some minor damage. (Extract from Bruce Herald in Southland News 5 September 1868)

Waves passed over bar and raised the water in the Aparima estuary to a height of 3 ft above MHWS [implication is that this occurred at the same time as at New River estuary/Invercargill (q.v.)? i.e. at 08:00]. Inhabitants of buildings in lower part of the town were seriously alarmed, but no damage was done apart from the removal of a mooring dolphin. Some cattle on the low ground on the opposite shore of the estuary nearly overtaken by water, some had to swim. (Southland News 18 August 1868); Tidal disturbances also observed at Bluff and Riverton. (Southland Times 17 August 1868) Travellers in buggy on beach between Invercargill and Riverton were compelled to move to higher ground. Sudden rise of 2.5-3 ft in the Waimatuku River. Between Riverton beach and Invercargill, water rose to cover road to a depth of a few inches, but this often happens in a strong west wind. (Southland News 18 August 1868); Water rose in the form of a large wave. Some residents took to the hills. (Otago Witness 12 September 1868)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW was at 09:28 (1.04 m) August 15 NZMT, LW at 03:09 (-1.02m) and 15:41 (-0.99 m) at New River Entrance. These tides are close to MHWS.

source_material: Travellers in buggy on beach between Invercargill and Riverton were compelled to move to higher ground. Sudden rise of 2.5-3 ft in the Waimatuku River. Between Riverton beach and Invercargill, water rose to cover road to a depth of a few inches, but this often happens in a strong west wind. (Southland News 18 August 1868);

At 08:00 when tide a bit more than half flood, a wave or "bore" variously estimated from 3-5 ft, entered the Heads and ran up as far as the Jetty, to HWM. Water started to recede 30 min later and ebbed rapidly for about 30 min, followed by another wave which flowed and ebbed with less velocity. This was repeated at intervals until noon. There were no vessels at anchor in harbour, but one lighter moored in a creek was grounded 3-4 times. (Southland News 18 August 1868); Before 12:00 water in New River estuary rose and fell 3 times, sometimes with imperceptible ebb and flow of ordinary tide and sometimes " "with alarming and startling rapidity". Ebbing tide suddenly changed and rose quickly for several feet and then as suddenly receded sometimes 10 chains. Boatman coming up harbour was almost capsized by wave 2-3 feet high that rose nearby and advanced very quickly. Some boats unloading at various points round margins of New River were suddenly turned as if in a whirlpool, and left high and dry. (Southland Times 17 August 1868)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW was at 09:28 (1.04 m) August 15 NZMT, LW at 03:09 (-1.02m) and 15:41 (-0.99 m) at New River Entrance. These tides are close to Mean Spring tides at bluss, indicating tides were at MHWS level on August 15.

source_material: Early on morning of August 15 sea suddenly receded 200 yds on a ~1:200 slope, then returned for 180 yds, at a pace that allowed a settler to flee safely (Southland News 18 August 1868)

On morning of August 15, tide rose very rapidly, and reached HWM at about 07:00, 3 hrs before proper HW. From then till 12:00 it repeatedly rose and fell about 2 ft. “It then set out with great violence for about 30 min, then resumed its ordinary rate until low water, which took place at about the usual time”. No further disturbances noticed. Also observed at Pilot station (outside the narrows) that water reached higher than ever known, while in the harbour it reached only to ordinary spring tide mark. It was also observed that the first surge was highest. [It is uncertain whether the following refers to the effects of the tsunami or a very high spring tide the previous month] The first strong rush of tide brought in an immense field of kelp which almost covered the harbour entrance and carried away nearly all of the channel buoys. It later broke up into small patches and spread over the bay. (Southland News 18 August 1868); on August 15, morning tide came in at about 10 knots, bringing in a great quantity of kelp, which entangled moorings, with the result that many were moved. (Southland Times 17 August 1868);
discussion: According to NIWA Tide forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW was at 09:57 August 15 NZMT (1.06 m) , LW at 03:38 August 15 NZMT (-1.03 m) and 16:11 August 15 NZMT (-1.01 m) at Bluff entrance. From LINZ Website tidal information relative to MSL (www.hydro.linz.govt.nz/tides), MHWS 1.06 m, MLWS -1.14 m, MHWN 0.66 m, MLWN -0.64 m

source_material: Sea sounded disturbed at the same time and after the earthquake was felt; tide flowed several feet beyond high water mark prior to expected high tide. Timber and merchandise placed beyond at high tide level was washed away. Several places near the beach were flooded and one or two boats washed from their moorings. (Thames Advertiser 19 October 1868, quoted in Daily Southern Cross, 20 October 1868) . Sea sounded disturbed for some time after the quake (Auckland Herald, 17 October 1868); Tide said to have flowed several feet beyond high water mark prior to expected time, washing away timber and mechandise placed beyond HWM. Several places near beach flooded, and one or two boats washed from their moorings. (Nelson Examiner 29 October 1868)

At Waitara … the water was affected the tide receding and then suddenly coming in again. In the roadstead [New Plymouth?], no alteration was observeable, and although it was high tide it was not higher than those usually at the spring of the year. (Taranaki Herald 24 October 1868; also quoted in Nelson Colonist, 6 November 1868)

"The inhabitants living in the lower portion of the town were apprehensive of a tidal wave, and removed themselves to more elevated situations". (Nelson Examiner 29 October 1868); No local sea level fluctuations noted in Taranaki Herald.

"The river was agitated, but being in high flood, the commotion was not very marked, although the steamers strained at their cables alongside the wharf." ((Wanganui Chronicle, 20 October 1868); people remained in streets all night in fear of a "tidal wave". No mention of any such occurrence. (Auckland Herald, XX October 1868);

"The only place I have observed of a report being made in the newspapers of a tidal wave on that occasion was at Auckland. Yet upon the sandspit there appears to have been one of at least seven or eight feet. The masts of the Juno, which was wrecked there some two years ago, being at high water mark on the 18th [October], but when seen again in about ten days, some of some of them were lying on the side of some low sand hills, and others away inside the spit, where no tide has been now for a number of years. An old canoe, which has lain for years near the same place, is now further in and fully ten feet higher than where it previously lay" (Nelson Examiner 3 February 1869)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW was at 23:13 (1.76 m) October 18 NZMT near Cape Farewell, i.e. the earthquake occurred within 1 hr after HW and hence inundation heights can be calculated reasonably accurately.

source_material: "A disturbance in the regularity of the tide was noticed yesterday [19 October], the ebb not commencing at its proper time." ( Nelson Examiner 20 October 1868); The shocks were felt sensibly and sharply on board some of the vessels in the harbour, and some of the officials on watch on wharf noticed that the tide, then about an hour after high water, came back with a rush under the wharf; and this afternoon [19 Oct] there was some slight tidal disturbance.(12 hours + after earthquake) (Nelson Examiner 20 October 1868)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW was at 22:54 (1.94 m) October 18 NZMT, LW at 05:05 October 19 (-1.93 m) at Nelson. From LINZ Website tidal information relative to MSL (www.hydro.linz.govt.nz/tides), MHWS 1.93m, MLWS -1.83 m, MHWN 0.88 m, MLWN -0.86 m at Port Nelson. Hence, earthquake occurred at time of spring tides.

source_material: "The tides for the last few days have been very high, and yesterday [October 20?] it was noticed to be far above its proper height." [Note that the earthquake was preceded by stormy weather for several days.] (Marlborough Press 21 October 1868)
discussion: The earthquake occurred at the time of spring tides nearby at Nelson (q.v.), hence high water levels at Picton probably represent this.

source_material: Immediately after the earthquake occurred, the ocean at the sea beach receded about eighty yards.(Westport Times, 24 October 1868, quoted in Daily Southern Cross 29 October 1868); "The sea receded some distance [at Westport] but there was no wave." (Telegrams in Evening Post 22 October 1868); No wave of any great size arose. It is stated, however, by those who were near the river at the time, that there was a sudden fall of two or three feet in the level of the stream and a rise as sudden. It was about the time of high water when the earthquake occurred, and there was a considerable surf on, with a strong breeze blowing, accompanied by occasional showers. (Westport Star 20 October 1868, quoted in Grey River Argus, 24 October 1868)

Some people, apprehensive of a tidal wave moved to top of hill on Peninsula for safety, remaining there until morning. No distrubance of the sea noted. (Herald 22 October 1868, quoted in Marlborough Press 28 October 1868)
Some people moved to higher ground for the rest of the night for safety. No mention of tidal disturbance. (Grey River Argus 20 October 1868);

No tidal or ocean disturbances accompanied or succeeded the shock. (Westport Times 19 October 1868, quoted in Marlborough Press 28 October 1868); Earthquake caused people to rush to the terraces to avoid any tidal disturbance. It is not noted that a tidal disturbance occurred. (Daily Southern Cross, 20 October 1868); No disturbance of sea occurred at Hokitika during the night ie in the 8 hours following the earthquake. (Westport Times 24 October 1868, quoted in Daily Southern Cross, 29 October 1868); "No visible commotion in the sea was visible when we went to press." (West Coast Times 19 October 1868); " during the disturbance [earthquake] so perceptible on land the sea was calm and placid" (West Coast Times 20 October 1868)
see source event

Some unusual tidal phenomena occurred yesterday, similar to what occurred here on the occasion of the great earthquake in Peru. About the time of half-flood, a large wave broke along the shore, and there was a strong tidal current up the Buller [River] to a distance beyond the usual tidal influence. According to marks on the banks, the water suddenly rose and fell a distance of two feet. (Westport Times 4th March 1869)
The same phenomena [as occurred at Westport] presented themselves at other places along the coast. At Charleston, it is said, a vessel was driven up on the beach ...(Westport Times 4th March 1869)
The same phenomena [as occurred at Westport] presented themselves at other places along the coast... at Hokitika the Harbour Master's boat was washed away. (Westport Times 4th March 1869)
see source event
see source event
discussion: Although it is not stated it is assumed that the observations were made at one of the most populated locations in Wellington at the time, namely, Lambton Harbour.

source_material: see source event
discussion: According to NIWA Tide forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), tides at Westport on 29 April 1870 were LW at 03:16 (-1.15) and 15:35 (-1.22), HW at 09:25 (1.21) and 21:44 (1.20) (all times are NZMT, which is equiv to standard time in 1870). On April 30, LW was at 03:50 (-1.23) and 16:09 (-1.28), and HW at 09:59 (1.27) and 22:17 (1.26). From LINZ Website (November 2008) tidal information relative to MSL (www.hydro.linz.govt.nz/tides), MHWS 1.47 m, MLWS -1.50 m, MHWN 0.78 m, MLWN -0.79 m and highest astronomical tide 1.86 m.

source_material: see source event
see source event
see source event

Very large tidal waves ran into harbour between 06:00-07:00 May 11. First wave carried away buoy with 60lb weight, vessel dragged anchor. Extraordinary rise and fall noted. At 12:30 tide was lower by 3ft than ever known before. At 2 pm tide was observed running strongly and rapidly in one side of harbour and out other. Water very turbid. Disturbance continued all day until after dark. (Evening Star 21 May 1877; The rise and fall in the tide was three feet. (Evening Post 22 May 1877, and many other newspapers)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW (0.7 m) was at ~05:30 in 1877; LW (-0.8) at 11:45 (all times are NZMT, the standard time in use in 1877).

source_material: Report at 15:30 May 11: Wave rushed into harbour in morning. Water rose 8 ft in as many minutes, but did not reach township. At 12:00 tide fell suddenly to about 4ft below ordinary LW & rose again very fast. (Evening Post 12 May 1877); Tide ebbed & flowed at least 7 times during day at irregular intervals (Macfarlane 1877); [The following is Bay of Islands in general] A large tidal wave into the Bay and surrounding harbours, rising 6ft in as many minutes. (Evening Star 11 May 1877); Maoris from some of the islands in the bay reported that at about 17:00 May 11 water rose over 8 ft in as many minutes. Rushed in & out at intervals of about 20 min until late in evening. (Martin & Edwin 1877)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides) high tide (0.73 m at Waitangi, Russell, etc) was at about 05:10 and again at just before 18:00 (0.72)on May 11(all times are NZMT, the standard time in use in 1877) .

source_material: At 16:00 May 11 wave rushed in, covering at least 10 yds of beach above HWM. Whale boat washed ashore. Wave receded immediately, came in again a short while later, staying at a high level for over 10 minutes. Tide ebbed & flowed repeatedly after this but did not reach former heights. (Macfarlane 1877); A huge wave suddenly swept two boats into a paddock at about 17:00 May 11. The water then rose & fell rapidly several times but not as high as previously (Martin & Edwin 1877); ; [The following is Bay of Islands in general] A large tidal wave into the Bay and surrounding harbours, rising 6ft in as many minutes. (Evening Star 11 May 1877); Maoris from some of the islands in the bay reported that at about 17:00 May 11 water rose over 8 ft in as many minutes. Rushed in & out at intervals of about 20 min until late in evening. (Martin & Edwin 1877)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides) high tide (0.73 m at Waitangi, Russell, etc) was at about 05:10 NZMT and again at just before 18:00 NZMT (0.72 m)on May 11 (all times are NZMT, the standard time in use in 1877). Assumption paddock is 1-1.2 m above HWM. The wave at 16:00-17:00 seems inconsistent with strong effects at other locations in the morning, ie 04:00-05:00

source_material: Felt very strongly up the Waitangi River at about 05:00 May 11. (Macfarlane 1877); Tide falling when captain of ship Iona went ashore in morning. Soon after a wave rushed in and drove boat and passenger onto shore above HWM. (Martin & Edwin 1877); ; [The following is Bay of Islands in general] A large tidal wave into the Bay and surrounding harbours, rising 6ft in as many minutes. (Evening Star 11 May 1877); Maoris from some of the islands in the bay reported that at about 17:00 May 11 water rose over 8 ft in as many minutes. Rushed in & out at intervals of about 20 min until late in evening. (Martin & Edwin 1877)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides) high tide (0.73 m at Waitangi, Russell, etc) was at about 05:10 and again at just before 18:00 on May 11 (all times are NZMT, the standard time in use in 1877) .

source_material: At 05:00 May 11, sea rose 6ft above highest HWS, covering several stretches of low-lying land at head of bay (Macfarlane 1877); (Manowara, presumed same location?) Creek bed and mud flats dry at 05:00 May 11, despite being time of high tide. Then noise of thunder as a large wave approached. People ran towards house, reaching it as the wave did. House inundated to about a foot deep. Water then quickly receded. (Martin & Edwin 1877); [The following is Bay of Islands in general] A large tidal wave into the Bay and surrounding harbours, rising 6ft in as many minutes. (Evening Star 11 May 1877); Maoris from some of the islands in the bay reported that at about 17:00 May 11 water rose over 8 ft in as many minutes. Rushed in & out at intervals of about 20 min until late in evening. (Martin & Edwin 1877)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides) high tide (0.73 m at Waitangi, Russell, etc) was at about 05:10 and again at just before 18:00 on May 11. According to LINZ website, MHWS is about 0.9 -1.0 m about MSL, highest astronomical tide at Marsden Point and Whangarei, about 0 .3 above MHWS; highest HWS was about 0.6 m more than HWM on May 11.

source_material: At about 12:00 May 11 water at wharf fell more than 4ft in 10 minutes, then rose 6ft in about 15 minutes. Boat at anchor in twenty feet of water grounded and found to be in 12 ft water. Several vessels at anchor were swinging with their bows in opposite directions, while others were revolving in a circle. Nothing of particular note at high water at 16:00, but at 20:00 tide high again. (Martin & Edwin 1877); [The following are Bay of Islands in general] A large tidal wave into the Bay and surrounding harbours, rising 6ft in as many minutes. (Evening Star 11 May 1877); Maoris from some of the islands in the bay reported that at about 17:00 May 11 water rose over 8 ft in as many minutes. Rushed in & out at intervals of about 20 min until late in evening. (Martin & Edwin 1877)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides) high tide (0.73 m at Waitangi, Russell, etc) was at about 05:10 and again at just before 18:00 on May 11 (all times are NZMT, the standard time in use in 1877).

source_material: Wave broke over beach at daybreak with tremendous roar, then rolled up river rapidly, receded swiftly, sweeping away timber stored above HWS. Vessel at anchor driven with force onto bank and left high & dry. Half of Tutukaka Harbour was left dry, and large quantities of fish left on beach. Each succeeding wave decreased in size and force. (Evening Star 18 May 1877).
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides) high tide (0.7 m) was at about 04:55 NZMT, low at 11.15 NZMT (-0.78) and high at 17:30 NZMT (0.71 m)on May 11 (all times are NZMT, the standard time in use in 1877)

source_material: First noticed at about 09:00 May 11, tide ebbed and flowed rapidly all day until at least 22:00. Ebb and flow each 15 min, i.e. period 30 min. 30min. No surf, but water came in rapidly to ordinary neap and ebbed to low water mark. Continued all day May 12 to lesser degree. (Evening Star 18 May 1877)

Four distinct waves, each 4-6 ft in height, separated by about two hours. Second Report: At 07:00, the Kina, moored at Warkworth wharf, grounded when being swung round when tide was ebbing. Suddenly water rose 6 ft and then quickly receded to normal river level. Vessel was able to be righted in the interval. A similar wave of 5 ft at 09:00 carried a grounded cutter up river for a mile. The Kina again grounded at about 13:00. At 14:00 another wave about 4 ft high. Waves were also observed at Mahurangi Heads. Later report: Four immense waves at 07:00, 6 ft in a few minutes, at 09:00, 5 ft, at 10:00, 4 ft, and at 12:45 4 ft in 5 minutes. (NZ Herald 12 May 1877)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides) high tide (0.89 m) was at about 04:50, low at 11.10 (-0.96) and high at 17:30 (0.89 m) on May 11. The accounts here exemplify difficulty in determining whether they are peak-trough or zero-peak. From Port Charles entry for 1868 August tsunami (q.v.), the following description "Flat about 3 ft vertically above spring tides, and mill buildings on flat built on blocks 2 ft high", ie if water surrounded but did not enter houses, inundation was about 1.2 m above HWS, hence about 1.6-1.8 m above

source_material: On May 11, many logs stored near the harbour washed up a creek. A few logs washed over bank. Observer awakened about an hour before daylight by sound of water round house and saw logs racing upstream and whole flat area under water. Effect at high water in evening less than in morning. Water rose and fell an average of 8 ft every 20 min all day. Sometimes the rise and fall were as much as 10-12 ft. At 14:00 water possibly rose and fell more. At near LW it came up to level of wharf and went back nearly to reef. Punt broke away, and went ashore, but no damage was done. (Evening Star 16 May 1877, and other papers)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides) high tide (0.68 m) was at about 04:25, low at 10:45 (-0.74) and high at 17:00 (0.67 m)on May 11. From LINZ Website tidal information relative to MSL (www.hydro.linz.govt.nz/tides), MHWS 1.1 m, MLWS -1.1 m, MHWN 0.8 m, MLWN -0.8 m at Port Jackson

source_material: First noticed at about 04:00 May 11.Two vessels in the harbour dragged anchor and were driven ashore, but got off at next tide with no damage. The tide rose to an alarming height, and current was estimated to be at least from 8 to 10 knots. The only damage was a fence carried away. (Evening Star 16 May 1877)
discussion: From LINZ Website tidal information relative to MSL (www.hydro.linz.govt.nz/tides), MHWS 0.9 m, MLWS -0.9 m, MHWN 0.7 m, MLWN -0.7 m at Huruhi (all times are NZMT, the standard time in use in 1877)

source_material: Between 09:00-10:00, workmen on the Gridiron noticed tide suddenly recede and in a minute come back with a rush. Perceptible rise of 9in. (Evening Star 11 May 1877); At 10:00, men working on Gridiron at Gore Street jetty noticed tide suddenly flow at ebb tide. It receded 15 minutes later. At 11:00 another wave rolled in and again receded in 15min. At 12:30 tide again suddenly flowed and receded in quick succession. Wave never more than 12” in perpendicular height. Other fluctuations later in day were noticed by fishermen. High tide on North Shore noted to be at 17:38, but no disturbances were seen. (NZ Herald 12 May 1877); Report at 15:30 May 11: At ¾ ebb at 10:30 water rose rapidly about nine inches, and then receded. The flood tide came in very fast. (Evening Post 12 May 1877)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides) high tide (1.01 m) was at about 05:07, low at 11.26 (-1.09) and high at 17:42 (1.01 m) on May 11 at Auckland (all times are NZMT, the standard time in use in 1877) .

source_material: Report to 09:55 May 12: No tidal phenomena observed on May 11. (Evening Post 12 May 1877)
[hard to interpret what is meant in this extract] At 06:00 remarkably high flood tide. 2 hrs later it was low tide at the bar of the river. (NZ Herald 12 May 1877)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides) high tide (1.01 m) was at about 05:07, low at 11.26 (-1.09) and high at 17:42 (1.01 m) on May 11 at Auckland (all times are NZMT, the standard time in use in 1877) .

source_material: At 16:00-17:00 pm boat at wharf moved by "immense" wave passing round boat, resulting in damaged rail and broken rope. (Thames Advertiser 14 May 1877); Report at 09:00 May 12: 2 ft tide rushed in and out again at 16:00 on May 11 at ¾ flood. On May 12, 2 hrs after HW water rushed in to nearly HW and stayed there a short time. (Evening Post 12 May 1877)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides) high tide (1.13 m) was at about 04:56, low at 11.14 (-1.22) and high at 17:30 (1.14 m) on May 11 near Thames (all times are NZMT, the standard time in use in 1877).

source_material: Bore of about 2 ft, creating strong current. Fell in a few minutes same extent. (Thames Advertiser 14 May 1877)

placename: Motuahi Island, Waihou River [Historical: 10 miles up Thames River]
source_material: Noticed as bore 3-4 ft high 10 miles (16km) up Thames River at Hauraki Sawmill, where it suddenly covered sand banks. Subsequent waves became less and less. (Thames Advertiser 14 May 1877); A tidal wave felt up Thames River. It rose suddenly about 3 ft at 4 o’clock [am or pm not specified] on May 11 and receded just as quickly. Another rise at 07:00 May 12. (Westport Times 15 May 1877); Wave was seen in River on Friday [May 11], the rise being about three feet at 4 o’clock [am or pm not specified]. At about 7 a.m.[date not specified] it came in suddenly, but not very high, returning as quickly, and rose again. (Taranaki Herald 12 May 1877); Wave was seen in the Thames River on May 11, rise about 3ft. At four o’clock [am or pm not specified] on May 11 it came in suddenly, but not very high, returning as quickly, rose again about seven on May 12. (Evening Post 12 May 1877)
discussion: Assume 4 o'clock refers to 16:00 given observation at nearby Thames (q.v.)

source_material: First observed at about 08:00 on May 11, when water rose suddenly 5-6 feet up the beach, and from 2-3 ft “higher than usual”, and receded with equal rapidity. A sudden rise and fall of about 1 ft was noticed several times during May 11. (Bay of Plenty Times 12 May 1877); At about 21:00 on May 12, sudden rising of water levels caused breakage of the end-hawser of the s.s. Wanaka at the wharf. The vessel heeled over at a considerable angle but was righted. The two persons who were coming down a gangway had a very narrow escape as it moved into a perpendicular position on the side of the steamer. The line of the s.s. Rowena lying outside the Wanaka parted at the same time, but no damage was done. (Bay of Plenty Times 16 May 1877); The tide rose suddenly several feet higher than spring tides and kept rising and falling a foot at short intervals all day on May 11. (Thames Advertiser 12 May 1877); Tide rose from 2-5ft higher than spring tides and receded rapidly. Several other rises during the day of May 11. A number of houses on the beach flooded. (Thames Advertiser 14 May 1877)
discussion: According to NIWA tide Forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW at about 04:15 NZMT (0.63 m) and at 17:00 (0.61), LW at 10:45 (-0.68) at Tauranga (all times are NZMT, the standard time in use in 1877). It is uncertain of measurements are vertical or horizontal. Given that it should have been mid-tide at the time, a rise of about 0.5 m above HWM is reasonably consistent with the description of 2-3 ft "more than usual" and the occurrence later of many waves of peak to trough of 1 ft only. The rise up the beach of 5-6 ft may not have been from the predicted tide level, but from previous tsunami waves. The flooding of house is mentioned in only one newspaper, this not being the local paper and hence it is somewhat doubtful.

source_material: "A cargo that had been landed at Port Awanui for Tuta Nihoniho was swept away." (McKay 1966)
discussion: From LINZ Website tidal information relative to MSL (www.hydro.linz.govt.nz/tides), MHWS 0.7 m, MLWS 0.7 m, MHWN 0.6 m, MLWN -0.6 m at Tolaga Bay. It is likely that goods were stored above HWS

source_material: First wave hit between 00:01-02:00 on May 11. This was slight. Another wave at 04:00 rose 2ft, appearing like a slight increase of high tide. At 07:00 a heavy wave, rushing in with terrific force, rising 7 or 8 ft vertically in as many minutes and then receding as quickly, washing away about 50 yds of a sandy point in the harbour. No noise was given of its approach. Similar waves occurred at 09:00, 11:00, 12:40 and 14:30, each rising from 2-3 ft. Disturbances thought to have ceased morning of May 12, but resumed later in the day and continued irregularly to morning of May 14. Waves were somewhat regular at first but not later. (Crisp 1877); Report at 09:10, May 11: At ¾ ebb, water rushed in past usual HWM, receded and second smaller rush occurred. Later report at 12:30 May 11: Tidal disturbances throughout night May 10-11. At 03:00 [sic] at 3/4 ebb tide, wave rushed in at 8 ft above top of the hull of ss Go-Ahead, then wave struck the bar that partially broke it, causing only a 3-4 ft rise in the river, overflowing the banks in low-lying places. At 09:30 another wave ran up the river, at 09:45 another, and almost immediately a fourth. Water in the bay was agitated. (Evening Post 11 May 1877); Report to May 12 09:00: Disturbances ceased. Press Agency Report to 14:45 May 11 [sic, probably should be 12]: The tidal disturbances continue. At 7:00 tide rose 8 ft in 10 min; at 09:00. it rose about 4 ft; and at 11:00. about 3 ft. At 12.40, and again at 15:30, tide rushed in for about 10-15 minutes, rising 3-4 ft. (Evening Post 12 May 1877); From Gisborne eyewitness: Tide was about ½ ebb, slowly receding for several hours, when immense roller fully 5ft vertically surged inshore washing high above where men had been at work on the boat Go-ahead. Almost immediately water receded and was followed by minor surges. First big wave occurred at a few minutes after 07:00. (NZ Herald 15 May 1877); Eight waves over the bar. [Extract as in other newspapers plus following additional information] eighth wave up river at 12:30 at ¼ flood tide. River much higher than ordinary high tides. Current up river estimated at 10mph. Many boats in river adrift. (NZ Herald 12 May 1877); [As in other newspapers, plus following.] At ¼ flood Turanganui river was higher than ordinary high water mark. Boats went adrift, punt was carried away, and all operations suspended between the river and the bar. (Bay of Plenty Times 12 May 1877)
discussion: Note that arrival time at 00:01 - 02:00 (travel time 11.5-13.5 hrs) is too early and not used. Note also that there are no local newspapers in this era. According to NIWA tide Forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW occurred at about 03:18 NZMT (0.52 m) and at 15:54 NZMT (0.50), LW at 09:38 NZMT (-0.55). Hence 3/4 ebb would have occurred at about 08:00 not 03:00 as in some extracts. According LINZ website, MHWS is 0.75 m above MSL, highest Astronomical Tide 0.95 m above MSL.
obs_first_arrival_comments: Note that the first observed arrival of 00:00-02:00 is ignored as it is too early.
obs_predominant_period_comment: (ie 8 larger surges in 5.5 hrs, with period of 15 min.; or surges in between large surges)
obs_damage: small punt and sevaral boats set adrift; coastal erosion

At 07:00 a heavy wave, rushing in with terrific force, rising 7 or 8 ft vertically in as many minutes and then receding as quickly, washing away about 50 yds of a sandy point in the harbour. No noise was given of its approach. Similar waves occurred at 09:00, 11:00, 12:40 and 14:30, each rising from 2-3 ft. According to NIWA tide Forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW occurred at about 03:18 NZMT (0.52 m) and at 15:54 NZMT (0.50), LW at 09:38 NZMT (-0.55). Hence 3/4 ebb would have occurred at about 08:00 not 03:00 as in some extracts. According LINZ website, MHWS is 0.75 m above MSL, highest Astronomical Tide 0.95 m above MSL.
obs_first_arrival_comments: Note that the first observed arrival of 00:00-02:00 is ignored as it is too early.
obs_predominant_period_comment: (ie 8 larger surges in 5.5 hrs, but some rose and receded in 15 min)
obs_damage: small punt and sevaral boats set adrift

source_material: Report to 09:00 May 11. No tidal disturbances observed yesterday [May 10? Misprint?]. (Evening Post May 12)

Between 12:30 and 14:00 boat carried onto Boulder Bank during docking, but floated off a quarter hour later. Wave, "not of very gigantic proportions" arrived about 07:00, broke over mole on the western side of Spit, but no damage was done to its pile apparatus. Tide ebbing and flowing every alternate hour throughout day, rising and falling 2ft. At 17:00 when water had fallen several feet in Iron Pot, strong current flowed between moles and works on eastern side of Spit. At 17:30 it slackened and by 18:00 current had stopped. At times water receded nearly out to wreck of Monmorency. Disturbances intenser and more protracted than those of 1868. Fluctuations continued for more than 24 hours. Less than half hour from high to high tide. (Hawke's Bay Herald 12 May 1877); Extremely high tide at HW at 04:00 May 11. At 07:00 tide rose rapidly and at 07:15 was as high as "good spring tides". Fell rapidly and then rose again at 08:00 as high as ordinary neap tide. Fell again rapidly, and at time of report (09:00) was rising again Later report: Tidal fluctuation since 23:00 May 10. Tide ebbed and flowed twice each hour. At high tide in morning, water flowed over Watt's Wharf. (Evening Post 11 May 1877);
discussion: According to NIWA tide forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW occurred at 02:57 NZMT (0.55), and 15:31 NZMT (0.53), LW at 09:16 (-0.57). Note arrival at 23:00 may 10 ignored as it is too early ( the origin time selected is the earliest seen in the scientific literature), but tsunami may have arrived before first observation at 04:00.

source_material: At 09:30 rose 4ft, came in again at 21:30 to much above HWM. (Evening Post 12 May 1877)
discussion: According to NIWA tide forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW occurred at 02:36 NZMT (0.52), and 15:08 NZMT (0.51), LW at 08:53 (-0.54) and 21:38 (-0.49)

source_material: Ship rounded Jackson's Head at 07.15, sea smooth. At 07:00 3 miles from inner rock ship rose on end, nearly dipped stern under, and receded half mile. (Evening Post 12 May 1877, and other newspapers); Captain Dalton, of the schooner Ruby, states that as he came up from Kaikoura on May 11 the sea was perfectly smooth in Cooks Strait, but every 15 or 20 minutes an enormous blind wave came up as big as a dozen waves rolled into one, but without any ‘”face” or break. (Hawke's Bay Herald 14 May 1877)

Shortly before 07:00 at ¾ ebb, tide rose to above usual HWM in about 15 min, receded in 15 minutes to LWM. Continued to ebb and flow at intervals decreasing from 15 min at 08:00 to 10 min at 10:00, the rise and fall diminishing also. At 08:00, difference was nearly 5 ft; at 10:00, 2 ft. At 12:00 intervals of ebb and flow were reduced to 7 min and the rise to about 1 ft. At corner of old reclaimed land near back of Lion Foundry, water raced in and out of a gap in the sea wall under construction as a bore running at an estimated rate of 7-8 knots, due to rise of 4-5ft and then recession of same amount. The current from the outflow was noticeable far beyond Queen's Wharf. The surface of the harbour was a series of whirlpools and eddies. Disturbances continued all day, high and low water occurring about 20 times between 07:00 and 15:00. Boats caught up in currents but no accidents occurred. Later report at 20:30: Tidal disturbances continuing with ebbs & flows every 20 min; rise and fall at wharf nearly 4 ft. Outer signalman at Heads reported moderate sea with a "long run on the beach". (Evening Post 11 May 1877); Disturbances continued in evening of May 11 as long as observations were maintained. Tide ebbed & flowed generally once in 20 min, and the rise & fall varied from 2-4ft, sometimes more, sometimes less. Still disturbed on morning of May 12, but much less, the rise & fall being a few inches. Ordinary tides dominant on afternoon of May 12. At Wellington Heads: high tide apparent at 15:10, heavy sea on beach but not much more than after a SE gale when there has been a heavy sea at Heads. (Evening Post 12 May 1877)
discussion: According to NIWA tide forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW occurred at 01:58 NZMT (0.39), and 14:29 NZMT (0.51), LW at 08:15 (-0.39) and 20:38 (-0.36)
obs_predominant_period_comment: 30 m decreasing to 20 min decreasing to 14 min

source_material: Very strong. Reached at least up to a fence. (Crawford 1877)

Outer signalman at Heads reported moderate sea with a "long run on the beach". (Evening Post 11 May 1877); Report at 09:00 May 12: Heavy sea on the beach on May 11, but not more than frequently seen after a S.E. gale. At 13:00 vessels anchored in the bay were swinging stern onto the S.E wind, although it was flood tide. (Evening Post 12 May 1877)

Report on May 11: “The tide has been running in and out three or four times per hour; when it was low water the tide would rush in above high water mark, and it would do the same at high water, it would rush out to low water mark and back again and so on all the day.” (Marlborough Express 16 May 1877)
discussion: According to NIWA tide forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW occurred at 03:33 NZMT (10.37) and 16:13 NZMT (0.38), LW at 09:54 NZMT (-0.40), NZMT being equivalent the standard time in use in the era.

source_material: Report on May 12: On May 11, waves at 14:30 and at 18:00, when it rose 6 ft in 3 minutes. No damage except washing away of some loose material at wharf. Slight fluctuations until May 12. (Thames Advertiser 14 May 1877 and other newspapers); Report at 17:00 May 11: 3 ft high bore up river at 16:30. Later Report at 10:10 May 12: Another bore 6 ft high at 18:00 May 11 seen by workmen on new wharf. Bores continuing in milder form. (Evening Post 12 May 1877)
discussion: According to NIWA tide forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW occurred at 08:38 NZMT (1.20), and 21.01 NZMT (1.20), LW at 02:28 (-1.11) and 14:51 (-1.23), NZMT being equivalent the standard time in use in the era.
obs_damage: Loose objects on wharf washed away

source_material: "The s.s. Tui, while at Kaikoura, experienced the force of the waves and it carried away all three of her warps." (Hawke's Bay Herald 14 May 1877)
Report to May 11 at 16:30: no disturbances observed. (Evening Post 11 May 1877); Nothing local reported in West Coast Times (Hokitika)

On May 11, although the Waimakariri river was quite smooth, a number of waves rushed up like a “bore” to the town. The highest wave rose from 2-3ft at the Swing bridge, coming in with great force. The first wave reportedly at 06:00; at 08:00 three waves in succession, and others at longer intervals up to 12:00. (The Press 12 May 1877); At 1200 on May 12, two additional waves and further fluctuations during the afternoon. (The Press May 14); Waves in the river were nearly as large as those observed in 1868. Largest was about three feet high at the Swing Bridge in the centre of Kaiapoi. Waves rushed up the river at the rate of about 6 mph. Smaller waves continued till evening of May 11, the time between each succeeding wave increasing. (The Star 12 May 1877)
discussion: According to NIWA tide forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW occurred at 01:52 NZMT (0.73), and 14:23 NZMT (0.75), LW at 08:07 (-0.78) and 20:31 (-0.70)

source_material: Several bores, see Kaiapoi entry. (The Press May 12); No damage was done, but the rollers coming in on the beach were unusually heavy, and the sea was in a violent state of commotion early in the day. (The Star 12 May 1877)

discussion: According to Fraser (1998) a 0.9m rise occurred in the Avon River. No descriptive account of this has been found in preparing this database.

source_material: Early in morning of May 11, tide was higher than ½ flood at time of LW. Once noticed, Harbourmaster organised to have the phenomena observed. At 07:00 water was "disturbed and muddy and rushing up harbour at unusual speed”, rising at a rate of 18in in 7 minutes. At 09:00 water rising & falling 3ft every 9 minutes. At 12:00 disturbance decreased, harbour muddy. At 14:00 at high tide water level was highest since 1868, the water rising from 6ft 2in, based on the marks by the Screw Pile Jetty, to over 17ft, showing a range of more than 10ft 10in. The water at high flood rose and fell at rate of 1 ft per 5-6 minutes. Currents round point of eastern breakwater were at least 8 knots. Boat swept by current from inside to outside breakwater. Other boats & barges difficult to manage, and a buoy shifted half mile. No damage to harbour works or vessels. Fluctuations continued till at least late in night of May 11, but abated. (The Press 12 May 1877); At about 07:30 May 11 disturbance of the water first noticed, rising and falling rapidly. At 09:00, water rose from 6.5 ft to 9.5 ft in 9 minutes and then fell as suddenly. At about time of ½ flood at 10:00, it rose quickly from 6ft.9in to 11ft.9in. At 10:40 water level fell from 14ft. 6in to 13ft in 5 minutes .At 14:00 the tide was at its highest, a little over 17 feet was registered at the base of the screw-pile jetty - 2 ft more than usual at HW. Tide then fell fast .During whole morning swirling in and out with great force between the breakwaters. No damage to shipping, but operations suspended or very difficult. Harbour thick with stirred-up mud. At 16:00, two hours after high water, the tide showed 16 feet at the Screw Pile Jetty, after which it fell again rapidly. Disturbance still continuing at dusk. Buoy moved from breakwater to Sandy Bay. Sea at the heads in great confusion, "the water being thick with mud for some distance to seaward, and breaking on the shore with great violence". (The Star 12 May 1877)
discussion: According to NIWA tide forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW occurred at 01:56 NZMT (0.77), and 14:27 NZMT (0.78), LW at 08:11 (-0.81) and 20:35 (-0.74) at Lyttelton.

source_material: At dead low water at 08:00 May 11, water suddenly rose about 12 ft, causing people to leave houses and move to higher ground. This was first of a series of waves that climaxed between 12:00 and 13:00, "when an immense wave smashed rushed in on the land smashing down fences and destroying other property, the debris of which was carried out to sea by the reflux." Timber was also carried out, & not recovered. Wave height at this time estimated by the submergence of jetty mooring piles, indicating about 6 ft above HWM. . Range estimated at 18 ft, as water receded to 6ft below LWM. At high water on morning of May 12, the range was much less than at previous tide, but continued all afternoon although decreasing. (Akaroa Mail 18 May 1877)
discussion: According to NIWA tide forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW occurred at 01:56 NZMT (0.77), and 14:27 NZMT (0.78), LW at 08:11 (-0.81) and 20:35 (-0.74) at Lyttelton. Little Akaloa Bay tides would be within a few minutes of tides at Lyttelton, i.e. first recession occurred at about LW, and maximum effect occurred 1-2 hours before HW.

source_material: The effects of the wave were reportedly greater than at Lyttelton Port. The first disturbance noted at about 06:00, when the tide receded for an immense distance. It subsequently rose to about 7 ft above ordinary high water mark, being over the hand-rail of the wharf. The jetty at Holmes’ Bay was washed away, and a yacht carried up into the bush. The boat Akoroa was unable to proceed higher up than Holmes’ Bay, and considerable difficulty was experienced in landing and embarking passengers &c. (The Star 12 May 1877)
discussion: According to NIWA tide forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW occurred at 01:56 NZMT (0.77), and 14:27 NZMT (0.78), LW at 08:11 (-0.81) and 20:35 (-0.74) at Lyttelton. Pigeon Bay tides would be within a few minutes of tides at Lyttelton, i.e. first large recession occurred 2 hours before low tide. It is unknown when the maximum occurred, but at least 2.1 m to possibly as much as 3.5 m.
obs_damage: jetty washed away, yacht thrown into bush

source_material: "The wave passed over without causing damage" (Akaroa Mail May 15)
Two small bridges displaced. (Akaroa Mail 15 May 1877)
7 chains of jetty lost at Barry's Bay shortly after 2pm. (Akaroa Mail 15 May 1877)

Harbour muddy. Disturbance possibly noticed by fisherman during night. First observed at Akaroa at about 07:00, when water receded suddenly, then flowed back to HWM in 10min. Ebb and flow continued until 14:00, at intervals of 15-20 m, "rise & fall varying at from 3 to 5 ft". The rise and fall increased at 14:00 and inundated lower part of township. Wave of 1868 considered to be worse, but 1877 wave rose & fell with greater rapidity. People removed goods at risk before high tide at 14.30. Water encroached on the lower portions of town early in forenoon and had entered several houses After 14:00 the risk of damage became greater. The fast current caused damage to several houses. In one house (Mlle de Malmanche) books, linen, crockery groceries were washed away, one door was wrenched off hinges and several fireplace bricks were displaced. People and articles were rescued from encroaching waters. Other houses were abandoned. Heavy deposits of thick sediment left in one house. In Lower Jollie st, cooperage material washed away, and house was slightly moved from its foundation, and the brick chimney "rent". Estimated Loss: £30-40. No damage to another house but water entered water well, and wood, bags of coal were shifted. Five other houses flooded with water damage only. Only one house at upper end of town just reached by water, others unaffected. (Akaroa Mail 15 May 1877); First wave at nearly dead low water, at 07:00, May 11. Sea came in with great force, and receded in 5 min, the rise and fall being 8ft. Waves coming at intervals of 20 min. No damage reported. (Thames Advertiser 12 May 1877, and other newspapers); As much as 10 ft [above average HWM? carries on from Pigeon Bay report where this is stated]. Later report from own correspondents: Akaroa partially under water. Later report still: Tidal waves began about 01:00 May 11. Succession of waves until 15:00, when waves reached greatest height, fully 10ft above HWM, flooding houses along the beach. At 17:00 tides subsiding. (The Press 12 May 1877)
discussion: According to NIWA tide forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW occurred at 01:17 NZMT (0.75), and 13:44 NZMT (0.79), LW at 07:30 (-0.79) and 19:55 (-0.76)
obs_first_arrival_comments: Note: 01:00 arrival in one newspaper discounted, as too early
obs_damage: 8 houses flooded, 1 houses shifted from foundation, contents damage

source_material: "On the night of the 11th, there came a tremendous sea like a small tidal wave ... Old Jamie's place is partly washed away. Beamish's house was inundated, and the Waitangi Bridge washed away." (Evening Post 22 May 1877)
discussion: Comparison with effects at Waitangi in 1868 (estimated 3.5-4.6 m water height above sea level at the time, encroaching at near HW) suggest that the inundation height in this event is less - perhaps 3.0 -3.5 m, assuming a similar state of the tides as in 1868.
obs_damage: one house partially washed away, another inundated, bridge washed away

source_material: First noticed just after 07:00, then rapid rises and falls all day. Rush at times heavy. At forenoon, sea kept breaking over breastwork in front of railway station. Boats swinging round, never pointing in same direction for 20 min. Exact rise and fall not discernible, but about 3-4ft. (Timaru Herald 12 May 1877); The tidal wave did not attract much attention here. It rose about four feet and swung the ships about in all directions. (Evening Post 22 May 1877)

May 11 am, sea in the Bay receded and flowed at intervals of about ¼ hour in an extraordinary manner. At about morning LW, the sea rose suddenly, and in about 10 minutes it was within 1 ft of HWM. Disturbance continued all morning. At about 12:00 the sea rushed into the Bay with tremendous force, rollers pouring over the Breakwater with great violence, causing a barque at the wharf to snap the mooring warps, be carried away from the mooring posts and past the Breakwater where it glanced off a large concrete block. Soon after the water in the Bay began to rush out to sea again with something like the force and rapidity of the River Waitaki, boiling, eddying, and whirling: For some minutes the sea from about the new wharf to some considerable distance outside the wharf resembled one continuous whirlpool. Vessels inside the breakwater dragged their moorings, and some collided. The barque washed from the wharf was driven into the Breakwater, and during one big wave grounded. It was then caught in the current, and for the next five minutes the vessel was whirled round and round in the whirlpool at the end of the Breakwater. At 12:30 the current had ceased and the whirlpool disappeared. When the worst of the current had subsided, vessels attempted to move, but some collided causing damage to superstructure. Toward evening the sea subsided. (North Otago Times 12 May 1877); Report at 11:00 May 11: "Extraordinary commotion" since midnight May 10; waves ebbing and flowing 8-10ft. No damage to shipping as yet. (Evening Post 11 May 1877, & other newspapers);
discussion: According to NIWA tide forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW occurred at 00:41 NZMT (0.68), and 13:06 NZMT (0.70), LW at 06:54 (-0.70) and 19:16 (-0.68)
obs_first_arrival_comments: Note: 00:00 arrival in one newspaper discounted, as too early

source_material: On May 11 a particularly high tide was noticed but it was attributed to gales. Masses of seaweed and debris were left far above any previously existing high water mark on low-lying parts of the beach. Few people noticed any higher than usual water levels. (North Otago Times 15 May 1877)

"Tidal wave rose fully 3 ft." (The Press May 12, and other newspapers); At daybreak, fishermen observed tide receding and flowing several feet on the beach. Early in forenoon tide seen suddenly to rise and fall at the piers, rough meaurement of from 7-20 in, continuing for several hours. Harbour turbid, and moored vessels swung at anchor. (The Press May 14); Fisherman along "banks" noticed the tide first recede rapidly and then return as suddenly rise several feet up the banks. An hour or two later, the water was observed to ebb far below spring tide low, exposing the lower part of Mansford Bay [now Carey's Bay, just north of Port Chalmers)], not seen since 1868. Tidal disturbance noticed at the pier at Quarantine Island at 09:00. First tide ebbed, being then at low water, then flowed and continued rising & falling 7-18 in. At 9.30 the Harbourmaster became aware of the tidal fluctuations at the piers. Rises and falls were noticed until long past noon, the rise being as much as 15-20 in in half as many minutes, while the ebb was nearly as great. Tidal disturbance also noticed at the Heads, but not closely observed as the Pilot thought it was due to a heavy sea at the bar. (Otago Daily Times May 12); Report to 11:35 May 11: At 10:30 flood tide rose 5 inches in 7 minutes, then fell 2 inches in 3 minutes. (Evening Post 11 May 1877); Report at 15:30 May 11: Wave rose 3 ft. Report at 16:00 May 11: - "Subsequent observations show an alternate rise and fall of the tide from 11 a.m. to 1.45 p.m. The greatest rise was eight inches in one minute, and the greatest fall four inches in three minutes. The tide is now ebbing in the ordinary way." (Evening Post 12 May 1877);
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)) , HW (0.7 m) was at ~00:30 and 13:00 NZT in 1877; LW (-0.7) at 06:50 at Otago Harbour entrance. According to LINZ website, Port Chalmers, MHWS 1.12 m , MLWS -0.95, HAT 1.34 m (all relative to MSL); Note: first rise observed almost at the time of LW and the largest fall and presumably rise is within an hour or two of LW, resulting in these waves probably not excceding MHWS. Although the term " rise and fall" in historical documents tend to suggest peak-to-trough rather than zero to peak, the fact that the water levels went far below low water springs and the way the articles are written tends to suggest in this case that rise means rise above mean sea level and fall below it, as the range is too small otherwise.

source_material: At 10:00 wave of about 1.5 ft seen coming up river loaded with small pieces of driftwood. River rose to 4 ft above its former height but receded within 20 minutes. Continued disturbances hourly until at least 14:00. (Otago Daily Times May 12)

A succession of seven waves rolled into Riverton Harbor between 7 and 12 o’clock yesterday. About 9 o’clock a wave, between three and four feet high, rolled up the river and swung the Express away from her moorings, carrying away her funnel and mainmast, and bringing the vessel nearer the north bank. ( Western Star 12 May 1877); Report at 19:00 May 11: A tidal wave was experienced here at 1 o’clock [sic, note previous extract] this morning, and advanced and receded seven times between that hour and 12 noon. The first wave lifted the Express from her moorings and brought her closer in shore, and carried away her funnel and mainmast. Before the wave rolled in, the steamer’s decks were dry and the men were about to commence pumping out. No other damage is yet reported. (Evening Post 12 May 1877);
discussion: It is assumed the time of arrival of 01:00 is incorrectly reported in the Evening Post, and should be 07:00 as reported in local paper.According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)) , HW (0.7 m) was at 10:26 NZMT (0.92); LW at 04:15 NZMT (-0.89) near Riverton.

source_material: Report at 12:15 May 11: Waves rushing every hour since 09:00; rise and fall, 4-5ft. (Evening Post 11 May 1877); Tide rushing in and out on morning of May 11 in a most unusual manner, and at a great rate. The vessels at the wharf were up at least four feet, and down as much in a quarter of an hour. (Southland Daily TImes 12 May 1877)

3 or 4 m above normal high water; casks and boat gear washed away, but recovered. (Kerr 1877); Waves washed away a number of casks which were stowed away on a bank ten feet high [almost certainly at Perseverance Harbour]; the whole of them were subsequently recovered. (West Coast Times 7 July 1877, extracted from Otago Guardian)
see source event
see source event
see source event
discussion: According to NIWA Tide forecaster (www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW was at 20:02 (0.68 m) September 8, LW at 02:16 NZMT on September 9 ( the standard time relevant for this era) at Gisborne.

source_material: On afternoon of 28 June 1881 a heavy sea commenced breaking on all the beaches round the harbour and wharves. Opinion differed as to the cause of the heavy swell in the harbour; some attributed it to a heavy gale to the south, which was not seen locally ie no wind; some to an earthquake far away as in 1877.TThe heavy sea prevented the landing of passengers at one jetty; On the evening of 28 June, the conditions were so bad near the Wainui jetty that a party in a boat attempted a landing instead on a nearby island. The boat was capsized 40 m from shore and smashed up, and the occupants both badly injured The unusual wave motion continued to some extent but was abating on June 30. (Akaroa Mail 1 Jul 1881 )
discussion: See event on 29 June 1881 (i.e. next day)

source_material: A heavy sea was running on afternoon of 28 June, heavier than had been seen for 15 years. The tide was unusually high, and the breakers on the beach along by the gasworks encroached considerably on the esplanade, and completely routed the inhabitants of the tents and huts in that locality. These have been broken up and washed away by the waves; the occupants were able to save the contents. Seas broke constantly over the breakwater during the whole afternoon. (North Otago Times (Oamaru) 29 Jun 1881)
discussion: See event on 29 June 1881 (i.e. next day)

source_material: When tide supposed to be at low ebb at 11.30 am [June 29] with barely enough water for coming into the wharf, the captain of a steamer found the water at wharf considerably deeper than expected for the tide. Then a large wave 10 ft high was seen coming up the harbour taking a minute before it reached the wharf. Despite strengthening of the moorings, these broke and the boat was carried onto the decking of the wharf and then onto the beach. The boat floated off on the next wave and there was no serious damage. [Reported in the same article implying association] At Wainui, Akaroa, a boast was capsized a short distance from the beach. (The Press Jun 30 1881); Captain Cameron, of the p.s. Titan, reports that at 11.35 am yesterday, while lying moored alongside the Pigeon Bay wharf, a wave came up the bay, tore the steamer away from her moorings, and landed her on the beach, the wave having a rise and fall of about 10 or 11 feet. The tide was just beginning to flow at the time, and the waves kept rolling up the bay, though not so high as the first one, until 20 minutes past 12, when a higher wave came up, and the tide having risen a little the Titan floated off, without having sustained any damage. The phenomenon created considerable excitement in the bay. It is reported that on Tuesday an unusually high wave swept into Wainui, Akaroa, and drove a boat with three men in it ashore; the men escaped uninjured. Nothing unusual was noticed in the harbour at Lyttelton yesterday.(Lyttelton Times 30 June 1881);
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), LW (-0.78 m) occurred at 11:28 NZMT (the standard time relevant for this era) at Pigeon Bay.

source_material: Nothing unusual was noticed in Lyttelton harbour on June 29, i.e. on the day of unusual waves in Pigeon Bay. (Lyttelton Times 30 June 1881 )
see source event

The tide rushed in and out of the harbour on 29 August with tremendous force. Two barques dragged their anchors. The upper part of the harbour was left bare by the receding tide, stranding an immense quantity of fish on the banks. The barque Grasmere, loading timber, lost several logs from alongside. A raft of timber dragged two anchors down the harbour. (NZ Herald 30 August 1883); "... on Wednesday [29 August] we were visited with another tidal wave, such as the one that occurred here about seven years ago. The tidal disturbance commenced about 5 in the morning. A raft of timber moored with two anchors was carried away down the harbour. The timber ships were twisted around on their anchors, and the barque Grasmere lost a quantity of baulk timber that was alongside here. The steamer Glenelg had difficulty in getting alongside the wharf, owing to the sudden changes in the tide. The greatest rush of water was about 6 o’clock and ten o’clock in the morning. The tide kept rushing in and out the whole day at short intervals. We expect to hear of some volcanic agency having been at work. – (Own Correspondent, August 29)" NZ Herald 3 September 1883); Captain Edwin [in Wellington] received the following telegram this morning [Wednesday August 29] re tidal wave at Mongonui: “Sea has been rushing in and receding with much rapidity for several hours”. LATER A further message from Mongonui states that the first rush of water took place at 10 pm last night [August 28], but nothing of any consequence until 4 o’clock this morning [August 29], which lasted until 10 o’clock.... Mongonui, 2 am [August 30?] The tide is still coming and receding rapidly, but at long intervals. (Waikato Times 30 August 1883; similar in other newspapers); Telegrams were received by Captain Edwin today that a marine phenomena resembling a tidal wave, was experienced this morning in the extreme north of this island, and on both sides of the island – at Russell on the east, and Mongonui on the west side. The tide rose and fell several times in rapid succession at each place, and no doubt the same thing would have been noticed all around the North Cape had there been any stations of observation in that locality. Captain Edwin is disposed to regard this disturbance as the effect of a storm wave produced by a distant cyclone, and not attributable to any volcanic outbreak or submarine earthquake. (Evening Post 29 August 1883); Captain Edwin’s telegrams today report that the sea disturbance still continues at Mongonui, where also considerable discolouration of the water is noticeable. (Evening Post 30 August 1883)
obs_first_arrival_comments: Direct wave not expected; source of tsunami is meteo-tsunami
obs_damage: Timber washed away, boats dragged anchor, fish deposited

source_material: Captain Edwin [in Wellington] received the following telegram this morning [Wednesday August 29] re tidal wave at Mongonui: “Sea has been rushing in and receding with much rapidity for several hours”. LATER Captain Edwin received a telegram timed 9. a.m. from Russell, stating that a tidal wave had been experienced there also.... Russell, 2 am [August 30] The tidal disturbance continues. (Waikato Times 30 August 1883); A slight tidal wave was noticed am on 29 August. (NZ Herald 30 August 1883)
obs_first_arrival_comments: Direct wave not expected; source of tsunami is meteo-tsunami

source_material: From Warkworth correspondent: "A heavy tidal wave took place [at Warkworth] on Wednesday [29 August] at 11:55 a.m. It came against the ebb tide, causing a fearful roar as it proceeded along the mud flats, but on reaching Duck Creek, where the banks are steep, it ran up almost noiselessly. Below the Red Bluff its roars were heard fully a mile off. The tide at Craigieburn rose over four feet." (NZ Herald 1 September 1883)
obs_first_arrival_comments: Direct wave not expected; source of tsunami is meteo-tsunami

source_material: " The tidal wave was experienced here yesterday [30 August, more probably 29 August]. At low water, the tide suddenly rose about three feet, receding and coming up again more slowly, and again receded and coming back in the usual manner at the proper time in the afternoon. " (NZ Herald 31 August 1883); "At Tauranga, Thames, Coromandel and Castlepoint, no disturbance has been observed." (Evening Post 30 August 1883)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), LW (-1.16 m) occurred at 09:28 NZMT (the standard time relevant for this era) at Coromandel harbour. As with Whitianga and Tairua, it is possible that the tide had receded before rising and the 0.9 m is in reality a peak to trough. In this case, the time of the first observation supposedly "at low tide" may be incorrect.
obs_first_arrival_comments: Direct wave not expected; source of tsunami is meteo-tsunami

placename: Riverhead (Default location for Upper reaches of Waitemata Harbour)
source_material: At about 8 o’clock, reportedly an hour or so before ebb tide, on 29 August the tide in the river seaward from Riverhead suddenly changed from an ebb tide to flood, and in about half an hour, rose "six feet high".Then just as suddenly it returned to ebb tide again, and in about another half hour it had resumed it original state of ebb. About an hour afterwards the true flood tide came in. The rise at the time of ebb were also was also noticed at the dock, where the water rose three or four feet. Several other persons upon the water at the time named also reported the occurrence. No damage is reported as done to the shipping or property abutting upon the harbour, but this may be accounted for by the fact that the wave occurred at almost low water. Had it come in with the top of high water serious damage might have been done to the shipping in the harbour (NZ Herald 30 August 1883); A tidal wave occurred in Auckland harbour just before the last of the ebb tide this morning [August 29]. The rise was about six feet, after which there was a reflux. The wave was most felt in the upper reaches of the harbour. (Hawke's Bay Herald, 30 August 1883; and other newspapers)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), LW was at 09:51 NZMT (-1.19 m) on 29 August. As with other accounts, it is uncertain whether the tide had receded before the flood and the first observed rise is trough to peak or zero to peak. The former is assumed.
obs_first_arrival_comments: Direct wave not expected; source of tsunami is meteo-tsunami

source_material: "The [tidal] wave was first experienced at Mercury Bay at about 4 am, and that in a few minutes the tide rose (it was ebb time at the time) fully six feet, and as suddenly receded again, leaving the vessels in port high and dry. Throughout the day the waves was felt each time with equal strength. On the appearance of the second wave the vessels broke away from the wharf, and the Linda Weber got caught by her rail on the piles of the wharf, and as the tide rose it was feared she would capsize, but fortunately the vessel slipped off the piles, and a serious disaster was averted. (NZ Herald 31 August 1883)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), HW was at 02:51 NZMT (0.71 m), LW at 09:10 NZMT (-0.80) on 29 August. It is unclear whether the rise is from trough to peak or zero to peak - if the latter, HW would have been exceeded by about 1.6 m and a comment would be expected. See also the Tairua extract where peak to trough is more clearly indicated.
obs_first_arrival_comments: Direct wave not expected; source of tsunami is meteo-tsunami

source_material: At about 8 o’clock, reportedly an hour or so before ebb tide, on 29 August the tide in the river seaward from Riverhead suddenly changed from an ebb tide to flood, and in about half an hour, rose "six feet high".Then just as suddenly it returned to an ebbing tide again, and in about another half hour it had resumed its original state of ebb. About an hour afterwards the true flood tide came in. The rise at the time of ebb were also was also noticed at the dock, where the water rose three or four feet. Several other persons upon the water at the time named also reported the occurrence. No damage is reported as done to the shipping or property abutting upon the harbour, but this may be accounted for by the fact that the wave occurred at almost low water. Had it come in with the top of high water serious damage might have been done to the shipping in the harbour (NZ Herald 30 August 1883); .A tidal wave occurred in Auckland harbour just before the last of the ebb tide this morning [August 29]. The rise was about six feet, after which there was a reflux. The wave was most felt in the upper reaches of the harbour. (Hawke's Bay Herald, 30 August 1883; and other newspapers)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), LW was at 09:51 NZMT (-1.19 m) on 29 August. As with other accounts, it is uncertain whether the tide had receded before the flood and the first observed rise is trough to peak or zero to peak. The former is assumed.
obs_first_arrival_comments: Direct wave not expected; source of tsunami is meteo-tsunami

source_material: "… the [tidal] wave was felt in a similar manner as at Mercury Bay, but no damage was done. The sudden rise and fall was fully six feet." (NZ Herald 31 August 1883)
discussion: See comments for Whitianga.
obs_first_arrival_comments: Direct wave not expected; source of tsunami is meteo-tsunami

source_material: Notwithstanding the general belief that the tidal wave did not affect the Thames, we learn that a very considerable rise in the height of the water at the Goods Wharf actually did take place before noon on Wednesday last [29 August]. Mr Gibson, engineer to the Rotomahana, states that at about 11 o’clock in the morning of that day he was engaged in effecting some alterations or repairs to the propeller of the steamer, and that going on board for a few minutes in order to obtain something he required in the work, he, after returning to the stern of the boat, was astonished to find the water has risen considerably during the few minutes of his absence. He estimates the height gained at two feet, which was retained for the space of a couple of hours. There has also been a rumour that the height of the Kanaeranga [Kauwaeranga?] Creek at its mouth was much greater than the ordinary level reached. (Thames Advertiser 31 August 1883); "When the tide had been going out some time it was noticed to suddenly rush back again in the Kauwaeranga River as high as full high tide." (NZ Herald 31 August 1883); " Nothing was seen of the wave at the Thames" (Waikato Times 30 August 1883); "At Tauranga, Thames, Coromandel and Castlepoint, no disturbance has been observed." (Evening Post 30 August 1883); "Captain Edwin has received a telegram from the Thames today [August 31] stating that the tidal disturbances are now occurring in that harbour." (Evening Post 31 August 1883);

source_material: The tidal wave came in at Maketu on Friday last [August 31] at 3 p.m. The wave was 3 feet high, and went 3 miles up the Kaituna River. (Bay of Plenty Times 4 September 1883)

source_material: The effect of the tidal wave on Wednesday [29 August] was very marked along the coast. Two gentlemen riding along about W[h]angara were bailed up by the tide for about two hours. After passing one of the points, with a falling tide, the water suddenly rose and hemmed them in for the time, it being quite impossible to proceed until the water had receded. (Poverty Bay Herald (also known as Evening Herald) 31 August 1883.)

At 2 o’clock the tidal wave again made its appearance, rising three feet, and had not receded at the time we go to press." (Poverty Bay Herald (also known as Evening Herald) 29 August 1883.); “Gisborne, 2 a.m. [sic; August 29]] Tide rose 3ft, and then receded again. At 2.p.m. it rose suddenly 3 ft, but did not go back.” (Hawke’s Bay Herald, 30 August 1883)

source_material: "The steamer Macgregor returned to the Waitara last evening [August 30], and entered, there being then ten feet of water on the bar. She left again this morning- The vagaries of this river are difficult to account for, but it has been suggested to us that yesterday it was probably the tidal wave which was the cause." (Taranaki Herald, 31 August 1883)
