source_material: "There has been no unusual rise and fall here [at Nelson], but the signalman reports an unusual circumstance. Yesterday afternoon [August 29] it should have been low water at 1 o’clock, but at 11 o’clock, two hours earlier, flood tide commenced and flowed until 1 o’clock, when it receded for a time, and then the inflow commenced and continued as usual. (Nelson Evening Mail 30 August 1883); Last night [August 31] about 8 o’clock the tide suddenly rose to considerably above high water mark, the time for high water not being until after 9 o’clock. The tide fell again about ten inches, after which it commenced to flow in again as usual. (Hawke's Bay Herald 1 September 1883); "Last night [August 31], about 8 o’clock, the tide suddenly rose to considerably above high water mark, the time for high water not being until 9 o’clock. It fell again about ten inches, after which it commenced to flow in again as usual." (Evening Post Saturday 1 Sep 1883 );

obs_first_arrival_comments: Direct wave not expected; source of tsunami is meteo-tsunami

source_material: "A small tidal wave was noticed in the Waimakariri at Kaiapoi yesterday afternoon [29 August]. A boat was swamped at the bar, and the yacht Ariel, lying in the river undergoing repairs by her owner, was swerved completely round by the force of the current." (Lyttelton Times 30 August 1883)
obs_first_arrival_comments: Direct wave not expected; source of tsunami is meteo-tsunami

source_material: Last night [28 August] and this morning [29 August] the waters of Lyttelton harbour have been ebbing and flowing without due regard for the tidal almanac. About half past ten this morning some men at work in the Lyttelton dock noticed the water in the dock to fall suddenly about 2 ½ ft, it then being flood tide. At 7.30 [am] the water at the waterman’s wharf was 6 ft below the usual low water mark, and one of the launches lying alongside the wharf took the ground. The wharf at Purau was also reported to be high and dry. Pilot Reed, when taking the barque Thurso out of harbour this morning, noticed the water off Pigeon Bay to be in a very muddy condition. (The Star 29 August 1883); "Lyttelton, 4 pm [August 29] The tidal movement here was from 7 to 9 this morning; rising and falling from 3 to 4 ft; going down 3 ft below low water line.... Christchurch, last night. At flood tide this morning [29 August] at half-past ten, the water in the dock suddenly fell two feet and a half; at half past seven at the waterman’s wharf it was six [ft] below the usual low water mark ... (Waikato Times 30 August 1883; and other newspapers); The movement of yesterday’s [August 30] tides at Lyttelton was still irregular. At 3 p.m. the tide rose 7 feet 11 inches, which would be quite 2 feet more than ordinary high water. Then it fell four feet within an hour and again rose six inches, showing that the submarine disturbance had not spent itself on Tuesday night and Wednesday. The water in the harbour was also thick and muddy. (Hawke's Bay Herald 1 September 1883; and other newspapers)

obs_first_arrival_comments: Direct wave not expected; source of tsunami is meteo-tsunami

source_material: On Wednesday morning [29 August], about 9 a.m. the water suddenly receded, till the Government steps [at Akaroa] were left quite dry, and a minute later the tide came rolling back to normal high water level. At the head of the Bay and Barry’s Bay, we understand the effect was still more apparent. The steam launch Pioneer was at the latter place in the morning, and Messrs Wight and Bruce were going to moor the firewood punt to the Government jetty, the water being unusually high, nearly level with the flooring. However, in a few seconds, the water receded leaving the jetty bare, and rendering it impossible to moor the punt there. (Akaroa Mail 31 August 1883)
obs_first_arrival_comments: Direct wave not expected; source of tsunami is meteo-tsunami

source_material: At Timaru the effects were most marked about half-past seven yesterday morning, [August 29] and about two o’clock in the afternoon [of the same day]. At the former hour, the water was nearly 3 feet lower than ordinary low water springs, there being only a foot or two in the channel in front of the Landing Service. The sea was more or less disturbed during the forenoon, and at two o’clock the ebb and flow of the wave was very marked, the rush of the water round the end of the breakwater being so violent as to almost resemble a “rip”. (Timaru Herald 30 August 1883 ); The tidal disturbances along the coast manifested themselves slightly at Timaru. A “rip” formed yesterday at the end of the breakwater, and at intervals the tide swept into the harbour with great force, rising to quite an unusual height. (Lyttelton Times 30 August 1883); "A tidal wave has been experienced here several times during the past twenty-four hours[ 28-29 August]. The most marked disturbances of water occurred this morning." (Hawke's Bay Herald 30 August 1883; similar in other newspapers);
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), LW was at 05:51 NZMT (-0.93) and 18:22 NZMT (-0.85), HW at 12:09 NZMT (0.93) at Timaru on 29 August (NZMT being equivalent to standard time of the era). According to LINZ website, MHWS 0.99 m , MLWS -0.95 m, MHWN 0.6 m MLWN -0.63 m (all relative to MSL);

source_material: The tidal wave ... affected the tide at Oamaru.... There was nothing felt among the shipping, but the tide gauge registered a sudden rise in the tide on Tuesday night [August 28] of from two to three feet. (North Otago Times (Oamaru) 31 Aug 1883)

The fishermen at the port reported the occurrence at 12 o’clock last night of a tidal wave [August 28], which rose fully two feet, and receded almost immediately. (Bay of Plenty Times 28 August 1883); Port Chalmers, 5 pm [August 29] There was an unusual tidal movement here from 11.30 am to 3 pm [August 29]. At 1 pm the tide rose suddenly 15 inches, and receded the same in five minutes and continued receding irregularly until 3 pm. (Waikato Times 30 August 1883) NEED LOCAL PAPERS
Reports from Auckland, Gisborne, Christchurch, and Timaru and Indonesia as elsewhere, but no local effects noted. (Southland Times 30-31 Aug 1883)

"One of Hill's correspondents, at Mohaka, reported a large wave that he associated with the earthquake. No time was given. A tsunami could have been generated if the earthquake had been shallow enough to cause significant vertical seafloor deformation, or by a submarine landslide triggered by strong shaking. A tsunami from sources near Cape Turnagain would arrive at Mohaka about an hour after the earthquake. However, it is unlikely a landslide source near Cape Turnagain would cause a significant wave at Mohaka without causing a large tsunami locally, which was not reported. A more probable source of a tsunami at Mohaka, would be the large earthquake-induced coastal landslides from the cliffs at Cape Kidnappers. 
A report of a second possible tsunami appeared in the Wairoa Guardian two weeks after the mainshock. A heavy shock was reportedly felt at Mohaka on August 25 at 10.30 UT (2200 NZT) was "followed immediately by the uprising of the sea". This earthquake was not felt a short distance away in Wairoa nor reported elsewhere and hence its occurrence and that of an associated tsunami is doubtful. Some confusion with the August 8 shock, which occurred at almost the same time of day, cannot be discounted. 
A search for tidal records from Napier and Gisborne, which might confirm either tsunami, was not successful and the validity of the tsunamis remains in doubt." (Downes, 2006)

Seiches seem to have been generated by the earthquake in the Waipawa, Porangahau, Manawatu and Wanganui rivers, and in Lake Rotomahana. At the latter place, “the guide in charge of the boats had his hand badly injured endeavouring to hold the boat against the jetty” (Poverty Bay Herald August 17 1904), when water in the lake became agitated and rose 60 cm. (Downes, 2006)

On inquiries being made ... it was found that nothing unusual was observed in Auckland. (New Zealand Herald 3 February 1906)

Fluctuations noted at 06:00. When tide should have been approaching low water, tide suddenly changed and in a short time rose 2 ft [0.6 m]. By 07:00 water had receded to low water mark. At 08:00 water appeared to be rising in normal way. At 10:00 water began to ebb and fell at least 18 in [0.45 m], the water rushing out of the river with considerable velocity. A short time later water began to rush in again. A similar pattern occurred at 11:00, with another fall of 28 in [0.7 m]. The tide began to run in again until about noon, when it then dropped nearly 12 in [0.3 m] in 10 minutes. At 13:00, at time of HW, a fall of 1 ft [0.3 m] occurred. The water in the harbour was noted to be tranquil. At 06:00, the sea was smooth and there was no break in the waves. When the abnormal rise began, the seas broke continuously and with much violence. (Poverty Bay Herald 2 Feb 1906); The tidal disturbances continued at intervals during the afternoon [of Feb 2] and this morning [Feb 3] at 9 o’clock after about an hour’s flood the water commenced to ebb for a short period. (Poverty Bay Herald 3 Feb 1906)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), LW occurred at 05:34 NZMT (-0.51 m) and 18:04 NZMT (-0.58), HW at 11:45 NZMT (0.57 m) (NZMT is standard time for this era).

placename: Motutere [default location for Lake Taupo shore opposite Hipaua Cliffs]
source_material: see source event

"At Karamea, about 50 miles to the north-east of Westport, the tide was the highest known for several years (Newspapers). An earthquake wave is thus indicated." (Morgan 1913); "On Saturday and yesterday there were exceptionally high tides along the coast. At Karamea the water was the highest on record. Whether this condition is or is not due to the seismic activity cannot be declared." (Westport Times 24 February 1913); "At Karamea the tide was the highest for some years..." (Westport News 24 February 1913 )

"at Ngakawau, 20 miles to the north-east, the tide was over 3 ft above ordinary springs, and perhaps 5 ft (personal communication from Mr Dind)…. An earthquake wave is thus indicated. " (Morgan 1913).

"At Cape Foulwind six miles west of Westport, cracks opened in the ground and mud issued from one. A small stream was reported as having temporarily dried up. It was also stated that after the earthquake the sea receded…. An earthquake wave is thus indicated. " (Morgan 1913); Falls of rock reported from Cape Foulwind. (Hogben 2, 1913); [After the earthquake] On going down to the beach, parts of the cliff had fallen on the track going down – a few tons of solid sandstone – and on the beach itself a couple of 100 tons of softer material…. (Hogben 3, 1913);" South of Cape Foulwind a tidal wave was quite marked following the first shock. In my opinion the disturbance was seaward of Tauranga Bay [3 km south of Cape Foulwind.] that point being its centre." (Hogben 4, 1913)

"At Westport the tide was reported as extraordinarily high, the tents of the campers being all but invaded by the sea shortly after the earthquake ([information from] newspapers)…. An earthquake wave is thus indicated." (Morgan 1913); After the earthquake the sand on the beaches was found to be unusually soft and today [date not given] it was noticed that there has been considerable erosion from the sand on the east side of the Buller River, the West side, to my knowledge has not been inspected. (Hogben 1913); Boatmen outside the bar could see the undulations along the surface of the water. Steamers report no sign of the disturbance at sea. Those aboard steamers in the port had a lively time. The vessels were thrown about by the agitated water. Every soul below on board the Karori rushed on deck. Quite a “sea” surged in the river. The water became muddy – a condition probably due to landslips in upper reaches. (Westport Times 24 February 1913);The highest tides for some years are reported at Karamea and a party of campers on the North beach at Westport were compelled to shift from quarters hitherto considered safe from the encroachment of the sea.. Quite a "sea" raged in the [[Buller] river. All hands were below on the steamer Karori and rushed to the deck when the big shake was felt. Arriving steamers report no disturbance at sea. (Evening Post 24 February 1913); While the steamer Katoa was off Westport at 12.38 o’clock on Saturday, she was lifted by a submarine disturbance and shaken from stem to stern. The sensation was as though the steamer had been raised from under, and was scraping her way over a derelict. The shock lasted four seconds, but had no appreciable effect on the sea. Captain Norten is of the opinion that the centre of the seismic disturbance was out to sea. (Evening Post 25 February 1913)
see source event
discussion: Note that <0.1 m is used to indicate that the tsunami was too small to be distinguishable.

source_material: In the early morning of November 12 soon after the tide turned to rise a tidal wave arrived and rose to the ordinary high water mark. This was followed for some hours by a succession of rises and falls at intervals of about 20 minutes, the tide rising about 3 ft in about five minutes. This continued through the day, and diminished toward evening. Similar movements on a lesser scale were still to be observed on November 13. (NZ Herald 17 November 1922)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), LW occurred at 05:15 NZMT (-0.79 m), HW at 11:37 NZMT (0.81 m) (NZMT is standard time for this era).

source_material: From Hamer, W H, Engineer to the Board, Auckland Harbour Board, Engineer’s Office, dated 17 November 1922: We noticed considerable irregularities in the tides [on the tide gauge records] from about 2.30 pm (New Zealand time) on the 11th instant to about 9 pm on the 13th. The ranges were about normal, but on the morning and afternoon of the 12th, and the morning of the 13th, about the time of low water, the tide was particularly erratic. On those three low tides, there were two marked periods of low water in each case i.e. the tide fell, rose, and fell again. Before and subsequent to the above tides, the curves were quite normal. (Government Astronomer papers, 1922): Erratic tidal movements recorded on tide charts at Waitemata; apparently some small irregularities starting at 14:30 on Nov 11 [ie 2 hours before the earthquake!]." The low tide and the rising tide were both very “groggy” on the chart following this first sign of disturbance. At the next low water, the tide rose and then fell again, erratic curves being shown on the chart." Worst period at between 06:15 am to 07:15am on Nov 13. Tide rose 4.5 inches at low water at 06:15, then fell 3.5 in by 07:15. Tide very erratic until 09:15 then more regular. Slight irregularities recorded at 20:00 on Nov 14, at high water at 02:30 on Nov 15, and at 08:30 on Nov 15. The range of the tides "not materially affected". (NZ Herald, 18 Nov 1922);
discussion: The first observed irregularities are clearly not related to the tsunami as they occur before the source earthquake.

source_material: Surges noted in the river [Uawa] some distance [not specified] from the mouth. The disturbance was noticed by many at Tolaga Bay. (Poverty Bay Herald 13 November 1922)
Fluctuations in water levels were noted by people on Waikanae Beach. (Poverty Bay Herald 13 November 1922)

Curious departures from the normal were noted in the behaviour of yesterday’s [Nov 12] tides in the local rivers. At seven o’clock the incoming tide had the speed of a millrace and continued to run strongly until near ten o’clock. At that hour a racing boat was left floating at the staging of one of the rowing clubs, and the crew were surprised to find that the water had suddenly receded, and left the skiff high and dry. Almost immediately the water again commenced to flow, and covered the level mud-flat between the rowing sheds within a very short space. Those who remarked on the peculiar action of the tide calculated that the level of the water must have dropped a foot in a short interval. A party at the Hole-in-the-wall also noticed that the tide fell and rose again very sharply at about twelve o’clock. The peculiarity of the action of the incoming tide was noticed from the signal station at Gisborne yesterday. It appears that a small tidal wave must have visited these shores. Yesterday morning [Nov 12] from observations made of the Harbour Board’s tide gauge in the Turanganui River it was noted that about 10.30 o’clock the water came up to the 7 ft mark. The rise in level of the water appears to have been a fairly gradual one. After a short time the water receded and at full tide time, 11.9 am, only 6 foot 6 inches was showing on the gauge. No peculiarity in the tidal conditions was noticed in the afternoon. (Poverty Bay Herald 13 November 1922)
discussion: Note:HWM seems to be about 6 ft 6in (2 m) on the gauge in 1947 see 1947 March 25 entry for Gisborne. According LINZ website, MHWS is 0.75 m above MSL, highest Astronomical Tide 0.95 m above MSL. According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)).

source_material: From Kenny, Napier Harbour Board: In reply to the letter from the Marine Department of given date re tides at Napier on the 11th, 12th and 13th inst. I reply as follows: 11th High water - Gauge 5’3”, 12th; High water - Gauge 5’3; 13th High water - Gauge 5’3. Some line fishermen, fishing off the Breakwater PM on the12th instant reported an unusual current setting due west about 5 miles per hour. Our tides were however unaffected. (Government Astronomer Papers, 1922)

According to de Lange (1986) and subsequently Fraser (1998), citing the source of the information as the Evening Post, 1922 November 21: "the tide changed direction several times during a 15 min period with fluctuations of up to 0.1 m."

From Fryer, Lyttelton Harbour Board: In response to your request I am forwarding herewith a tide-gauge chart covering the period you mention. It shows clearly the effects of the tidal wave on the morning of the 12th inst. at 9 am and noon, but unfortunately the record on the evening of that day is marred by oscillations of the drum caused by local disturbances, due to a heavy SW gale. There also appear to be minor irregularities in the curve at midnight on the 12th and 11 am on the 13th. Apparently the abnormal rise and fall was not rapid enough to excite particular notice, as the Harbourmaster informs me that the matter was not reported to him by anyone. (Government Astronomer Papers, 1922)

From Pellow, A., Chatham Islands: 1922 November 12 On Sunday morning [at] ten o’clock an Owenga resident noticed 5 waves in succession which rose to a height of about 3 feet above ordinary high water mark. At that time it would be about ¾ tide. At about the same hour at Waitangi it was noticed that the tide was abnormally low and then a wave came in which went well up above high water mark. No further abnormalities were reported to me. (Government Astronomer papers, 1922)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), LW occurred at 04:29 Chatham Island Time (CIT) (-0.33 m), HW at 10:34 CIT (0.29 m) at Waitangi

At that time it would be about ¾ tide. At about the same hour at Waitangi it was noticed that the tide was abnormally low and then a wave came in which went well up above high water mark. No further abnormalities were reported to me. (Government Astronomer papers, 1922)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), LW occurred at 05:15 NZMT (-0.79 m), HW at 11:37 NZMT (0.81 m) (NZMT is standard time for this era).

source_material: From Wightman, G C. Secretary, Timaru Harbour Board, dated 28 November 1922: In reply I have to state that the Board has no Automatic Tide gauge in operation, consequently it has no readings. The Harbour Master was advised by men fishing on the wharves on the 12th instant that the tide suddenly fell about 3 feet and then returned to its former level within about a quarter of an hour. (Government Astronomer papers, 1922); According to de Lange (1986) and subsequently Fraser (1998), citing the source of the information as the Evening Post, 1922 November 21: "minor oscillations were observed on the 12th and 13th".

According to de Lange (1986) and subsequently Fraser (1998), citing the source of the information as the Evening Post, 1922 November 21: Tidal fluctuations of up to 0.2 m were detected on the 12th and 13th [November]"

An unusual sea, with several large rolling waves and strong backwash, was observed on Castlecliff Beach on the afternoon of December 25. Several people had to be rescued The waves were likened to a minature tidal wave and tentatively connected to the earthquake in the South Island on the same afternoon. (Waikato Times 27 December 1922)
discussion: As no tsunami was observed near the source of the earthquake, and seiching in the open sea, is higly unlikely, the waves cannot be related to tsunami.

source_material: At Gore Bay, some distance out from Cheviot, the shake was very severe. Summer campers there had the unique experience of watching great slices of the earth become detached from the cliffs and sweep down to the sea. Campers say that it appeared as if the whole front would fall into the sea, which at the time of the quake, was exceedingly rough. (Lyttelton Times 28 December 1922)
discussion: Gore Bay is on the coast about 30 km northeast of the epicentre of the earthquake and within the MM8 isosiesmal (NZ National Earthquake Information Database). The collapse of the cliffs into the sea, as described, have the potential to cause tsunami waves locally, but nothing appears to have been noticed or caused alarm.

source_material: A party who were on the beach at Leithfield found the sand sinking beneath them much to their alarm. They went down some feet before solidity was reached, and then it was to find water bubbling at their feet. They ran to safety as soon as they got clear, while the water rose some fifteen inches in the vicinity most affected. (Press 27 December 1922)
discussion: This extract clearly describes liquefaction, not tsunami.

source_material: Great alarm during the earthquake was caused at Waikuku Beach by the opening of fissures in the sand through which the seawater forced it way up to the surface. (Press 26 December 1922); Immediately after the main disturbance, water commenced to make its way to the surface [at the end of the road near the sandhills] over a radius of about a chain. One of the scores of motorcars belonging to the holiday-makers became stuck fast in the soft mud that was made by the springs of water. (Press 27 December 1922)
discussion: These extracts clearly describe liquefaction, not tsunami.

source_material: "There was no noticeable effect on the tide during and after the ‘quake." (The Press 26 December 1922)

The wharves rocked, the vessels in the harbour swayed at their moorings and the harbour Board’s dredge crashed against the spring-pile wharf at which she was moored. Persons on the wharves at the time were scarcely able to keep their feet. A steamer 10 km off Lyttelton heads felt the earthquake as a bumpng, giving the impression that the stern had touched an sandbank. (The Press 26 December 1922)
discussion: de Lange & Healy (1986) report that seiches occurred in Lyttelton harbour. However, the effects described are explained by strong shaking effects, similar to those experienced by the steamer off Lyttelton Heads. Further, the effects described occured during the earthquake, not some time after it as would be expected if a tsunami had been generated.

source_material: see source event

The Moriori at Manakau [a boat?] was partly washed away, and the Wharekauri bridge was badly damaged. (The Sun (Christchurch) 2 August 1924); on my return to Wharekauri on the Sunday I met Tom Rapu at Matanginui and he said a big sea on the north coast the previous night [July 19] had washed away the new bridge at Okahu, swept over Te Awanui Island and carried away many fences along the coast. The road used at this time was along the coast and I found that indeed much damage had been done. (Holmes, 1993)
obs_damage: Bridge, roadway damaged, fences swept away
impact_summary: de Lange, W P, Healy, T H 1986. New Zealand tsunamis 1840-1982. New Zealand of Geology and Geophysics 29: 115-134.

source_material: “Tidal wave experienced at Kaingaroa, Owenga, and Pitt Island, between 7-15 p.m. and 10-25 p.m. (N.Z. time [correct? CIT possibly]) on Saturday, 19th July. Not noticed at Waitangi. Reports conflicting; but there appears to have been a succession of waves from 10 to 20 feet high between the times stated.” (Acting Secretary Telegram, 5 August 1924); A wave swept inland for about five chains on the eastern side of the island. A trawler belonging to the Kaingaroa Fishing Co. was lost, and another was smashed, while the dam which supplies the company with fresh water was washed out…. Kaingaroa Lake, which gives a supply of fresh water to the Kaingaroa Co., had been washed out through the carrying away of the dam. The lake had been drained, and it would cost a considerable sum to rebuild the dam…. at Kaingaroa some fishermen who were playing cards went out to see what was amiss. On seeing the wave they made a rush inland to the bush on the west side of the island, which was not affected. Only the east side suffered, the places being Kaingaroa, Pitt Island, and Mangere Island. (Dominion 5 August 1924); the force of the water was such as to completely sweep away a spot about a hundred yards in length separating from the sea a small lake from which the water supply for the freezer was procured. The water pipes are said to be twisted and turned beyond repair. Mr Tom Suvip’s launch and four dinghys were washed away …(Star 2 August 1924); The dam at the Kaingaroa Lake, which supplies fresh water to the Kaingaroa Company, was washed away, and the company will not be able to carry on its fishing industry until the dam has been rebuilt. This will cost a considerable sum. The company also lost a fishing trawler, and another fishing trawler was broken up…. The wave washed a distance of about five chains inland at Kaingaroa…. at Kaingaroa some fishermen who were playing cards in a hut went outside to investigate the noise. Seeing the wave, they ran inland. The huts were smashed up. Damage was done to the freezing works, and four fishing launches lying at their moorings were wrecked …. A resident of Kaingaroa, Mr S. Clough was washed off horseback when he was riding along the beach at 8 p.m.[CIT], but he managed to cling to tussocks, and saved himself from being carried out to sea. Nobody was injured by the wave. (The Sun 2 August 1924); launch Wahine, owned by Tom Soowich, had disappeared from her moorings and was not seen again, except that her rudder was found some time later in the lake. The wave also wrecked a dam at the lake outlet... The high sea [at Waitangi] seemed odd as the weather was fine. (Holmes, 1993)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), HW at 2004 CIT 1919 NZMT (0.71m) at Kaingaroa. The tide appears to be the highest for the month, i.e. a spring tide.
obs_damage: huts washed away, one trawler damaged, another lost, dinghies lost, dam destroyed, freezing plant damaged

source_material: “Tidal wave experienced at Kaingaroa, Owenga, and Pitt Island, between 7-15 p.m. and 10-25 p.m. (N.Z. time) on Saturday, 19th July. Not noticed at Waitangi. Reports conflicting; but there appears to have been a succession of waves from 10 to 20 feet high between the times stated.” (Acting Secretary Telegram, 5 August 1924); West side of the Islands not affected at all (The Sun 2 August 1924); At about 9pm the Waitangi River was very high. I then crossed the old Waitangi bridge on foot. At Waitangi beach the water was high and coming in fast, forcing me to walk through paddocks along the foreshore to the steps up the cliff. The high sea seemed odd as the weather was fine. (Holmes, 1993)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), HW at 1919 CIT 1834 NZMT (0.36m) at Waitangi. The tide appears to be the highest for the month, i.e. a spring tide.

source_material: The Moriori at Manakau was partly washed away, and the Wharekauri bridge was badly damaged. (The Sun 2 August 1924); George Clough, who was riding along the beach towards Manukau, was washed off his horse but managed to hold on to a fence along the foreshore and later walk inland. He found his horse the next day but the fence he had clung to had completely disappeared. (Holmes, 1993)

“Tidal wave experienced at Kaingaroa, Owenga, and Pitt Island, between 7-15 p.m. and 10-25 p.m. (N.Z. time) on Saturday, 19th July. Not noticed at Waitangi. Reports conflicting; but there appears to have been a succession of waves from 10 to 20 feet high between the times stated.” (Acting Secretary Telegram, 5 August 1924); at Owenga two launches and five dinghys were lost. … The proprietors of the new shell-crushing works at Owenga had their whare smashed to matchwood and their machinery damaged. (Star 2 August 1924); a trawler which was on the cradle, and was awaiting relaunching after undergoing an overhaul, was completely broken up, and a launch was badly damaged…. The roar of the approaching wave was heard at Owenga.... A shell-crushing plant belonging to R. Whitelaw and J. Wells, which had been taken to the Islands by the Tees on her previous trip, was washed out to sea and washed in again. A hut used in connection with the plant was washed out to sea and lost. Beaches were completely stripped of shells. (The Sun 2 August 1924); At Owenga there was a large building near Ascot’s freezer (where the chimney is now). This had been built by Jack McGregor and another, who were interested in crushing pipi shells for fowl and path grit for export to New Zealand, but the venture was unsuccessful. At the time of the tidal wave two men were living in the building and when they opened the door to investigate the noise the sea washed through, though not to any great depth. The fishing vessels Sisters and Tangaroa had been drawn up the beach at Owenga for painting and repairs and the wave wrecked them. (Holmes, 1993)
obs_damage: trawler, launch and dinghies lost, hut smashed, shell-crushing machinery damaged

source_material: “Tidal wave experienced at Kaingaroa, Owenga, and Pitt Island, between 7-15 p.m. and 10-25 p.m. (N.Z. time) on Saturday, 19th July. Not noticed at Waitangi. Reports conflicting; but there appears to have been a succession of waves from 10 to 20 feet high between the times stated.” (Acting Secretary Telegram, 5 August 1924); Pitt Island Wharf was swept away and some beaches were cleared of shell…. The Pitt Island Wharf was completely washed away, not a sign of it remaining. A dinghy and a surf boat were washed up a creek a distance of eighty yards … Only the east side suffered, the places being Kaingaroa, Pitt Island, and Mangere Island. (Dominion 5 August 1924; similar in The Sun 2 August 1924); Considerable damage was done on Pitt Island. The water went quite a distance inland up the creek and, among other things, a dray-wheel wharf at Flower Pot was wrecked. (Holmes, 1993)
obs_damage: wharf washed away, several boats damaged

source_material: Only the east side suffered, the places being Kaingaroa, Pitt Island, and Mangere Island. At the last-named place a big landslide occurred. (Dominion 5 August 1924; similar in The Sun 2 August 1924)
see source event
see source event

"This earthquake was accompanied by a large rotational slump at Whitecliffs [i.e. near Little Wanganui Head] about 20 km south of Karamea. An area of sea floor was uplift as a result involving a region of 196 000 m2 and a vertical motion of about 16 m. Prior to the earthquake this area was an average of 3 m below sea level (Henderson, 1937). It is possible that this event is responsible for the 2.5 m tsunami reported at Karamea. The weather conditions at the time were bad and a cyclone was centred over the Tasman Sea to the west of the South Island. Newspapers report heavy seas at Greymouth, New Plymouth and Auckland on 19 June. This would make the observation of a tsunami difficult, especially since the waves reported due to the storm were in excess of 6 m." (de Lange & Healy , 1986)

"the lighthouse keepers at Cape Farewell Spit noted that, in addition to the damage caused directly by the earthquake, materials including tools were swept away by a high tide which followed the earthquake. The following day it was found that a big tide had breached part of the Spit exposing a large Maori burial ground (Chapple, 1984)."(de Lange & Healy , 1986)
"WAIROA: a 3 m surge or wave is reported from the Wairoa River following the earthquake." (de Lange & Healy, 1986)

"WAIKOKOPU: Three “tidal waves” are reported as having rushed to sea in succession. This probably means recession, since the report also states the local Maoris took advantage of the waves to trap large quantities of fish and shellfish." (de Lange & Healy, 1986); "At Waikokopu the tides were irregular [after the earthquake] and showed a small rise and fall five times within the ordinary period. (Marshall, 1933)

"WAIKARE RIVER: A large wave destroyed a woolshed and left fish strewn 15.2 m vertically above high tide level. This suggests that the wave was at least 15 m high. It seems that this was a locally generated wave produced by a large rotational slump on the opposite side of the Waikare estuary." (de Lange & Healy, 1986)

"At Port Ahuriri the tide [at the time of the earthquake] had just begun to ebb. It has been stated by the Harbourmaster (Captain White-Parsons) that for some minutes the ebb maintained its ordinary flow, but it soon gathered force, and within a few minutes flowed with an estimated velocity of fifteen miles per hour, and this was maintained until well past the proper time of low water, and even past the next period of high water. It is, of course, clear that this was due to the outflow of water from the Ahuriri lagoon as a result of the rise in the land.... Though the outward flow of the ebb at Port Ahuriri which had begun just before the earthquake was maintained for two tidal periods, it was found that after the first outflow, which amounted to an emptying-out of the Ahuriri Lagoon, the tides soon became regular again, though it was noticed high tide occurred a little earlier than before. This result, again, was probably due to the now smaller area of Ahuriri lagoon.... No tidal wave was noticed on the ocean coast [near Napier and Port Ahuriri]. On the shore of the Ahuriri Lagoon the water rose in a wave 2 ft. or 3 ft. above tide level…. [No further mention of anything that relates to tsunami.]" (Marshall, 1933); "After the first shock of the Napier earthquake. The water withdrew from the inner harbour, and surged in again, partially filling it. Local residents have told the writer that a big wave came up on to Marine Parade after one of the shocks, but this has not been verified." (Laing, 1954)

Oral history People were pulled out to sea in 1-2 m waves. (second hand inf. obtained through P. Parsons, Hawke's Bay. No written acct); "At Clifton, which is situated ten miles south of Napier, no indication of any change in the position of the shore-line could be detected. There was no visible disturbance of the materials on the beach." (Marshall, 1933)
see source event
see source event
see source event
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), HW was at 00:29 NZMT (0.77 m) on February 3 at Kaikoura (NZMT is standard time for this era). From LINZ Website tidal information relative to MSL (www.hydro.linz.govt.nz/tides), MHWS 0.7 m.

source_material: see source event
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), LW was at 01:55 NZMT (-1.31 m), HW at 08:09 NZMT (1.41)

source_material: At 8.30 pm on 2 April, water suddenly rose 2 1/2 ft above its ordinary level. Movement continued at intervals of from 15 to 20 minutes, and gradually increased until 24:00, when the rise and fall was almost 4 ft. On the morning of 3 April, a very large wave, like a breaker on the coast, came in the heads and swept up Mill Bay. It increased in "intensity" as it moved into shallow water. One boat torn from moorings, but no damage done. The water came in surges, and total rise was 4 ft. Water then receded rapidly, and stones & debris could be heard rolling along the bottom. The lowest point was well below low water. Fluctuations continued on morning of 3 April, but each successive wave was lower, and disturbance ceased in the afternoon. (Northland Age 11 April 1946)

At about 19:45 on 2 April, people heard sounds as if storm approaching, but there was no wind and a calm sea. On investigation, waves nearly three feet high, unlike any seen before, were seen pounding the beach. "There was a solid wall of water advancing, with no trough behind it, just a flat plain of raised water. The waves came in regularly about every four minutes ... but it was not until nearly 3 o'clock that the water receded before the advance of each wave." Waves were continuing on morning of 3 April although diminishing. (Northern Advocate 3 April 1946); Waves continuing but diminishing on April 3/4. (Northern Advocate 4 April 1946); Waves continuing but diminishing on April 3/4. (Northern Advocate 4 April 1946)
discussion: See tide at Tutukaka

source_material: "As the tide came in last night [2 April] … waves estimated at up to 8ft high experienced in the river, the effect being as if the tide was making and ebbing rapidly as wave succeeded wave." (Northern Advocate 3 April 1946); Waves continuing but diminishing on April 3/4. (Northern Advocate 4 April 1946)

Disturbances like those at Matapouri noted in the creek on night of 2 April. "Waves several feet high followed one another in rapid succession, creating a swift current where normally there is none, and roaring under the bridge." Similar conditions continued to next day, although the sea was "flatly calm, the wind being offshore". Water muddy, when usually clear. On the ebb, the tide did not reach the usual low water mark, and people watched "a succession of small tidal waves rising from the calm sea and sweeping up the beach". No damage reported. (Northern Advocate 3 April 1946); Waves continung on morning of 4 April although diminishing. Where the waves swept up the creek and back again with a rise of about 4ft, the stone facings of the bridge were damaged, one corner of the facing holding the spoil washed out completely. Tides at their peak were highest ever known, while normal low water was not reached. Other Northland coastal centres also affected (no detail.) (Northern Advocate 4 April 1946); also in Waikato Times 4 April 1946);
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW was at 19:33 NZST (0.97) at Tutukaka Harbour.
obs_damage: minor damage to stone facings on bridge

source_material: "High" waves thought to be connected with Aleutian tsunami experienced from Whangarei harbour northwards. Waves swept up tidal rivers, creating swift current with rapid ebb and flow. (NZ Herald 4 April 1946)

Abnormally high tide experienced at Nagle Cove, Port Fitzroy. Surge also experienced on beaches and tide rushed up creek overtopping banks, and flooding grassy areas high above normal high tide mark. After receding a considerable way, it contiued to rush up at intervals to normal high tide level. (W. McLean, 4 Apil 1946, personal report to Dominion Observatory)
Slight irregularities in 24 hrs up to 4 April, but no effects of consequence. "Variations .. were not much more than one inch". (NZ Herald 4 April 1946, similar in Waikato Times 4 April 1946)

On the evening of 2 April, at twilight, a wave 5-6ft in height was observed to rush up Uawa River. No damage reported. Almost exactly 12 hours later, when tide was low, a similar wave of similar height was seen. At a point 3 miles up the river, water rushed in where the creek had been dry for several months. Driftwood found along banks of Uawa River several feet above highest recorded tide mark. On 3 Apr, three waves 2 1/2 ft high were noticed by swimmers and others at Tolaga Bay Dairy Factory. (Report from Post Office, Tolaga Bay, dated Apr 8; also submitted to Gisborne Herald)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), HW at 18:04 April 2 NZST (0.68), LW at 00:14 NZST( -0.73), HW at 06:30 NZST (0.78) April 3. Tide would have been high at the arrival of the first waves and those twelve hours later, suggesting that for at least the second set of waves and probably the first also, water had receded first, i.e.a peak to trough of 5-6 ft was observed rather than zero-to-peak, suggesting that the zero to peak was about 0.8 -0.9 m [at high tide], which is consistent withthe "several feet" height above HWM of driftwood. MHWS at Tolaga Bay is 0.7 m above MSL (LINZ Website) suggesting also that the tsunami ariived at the time of Spring Tides.

source_material: Nothing observed on tidal records or by fishermen. (Report to Marine Department from Nelson Harbour Board, dated 16 May 1946)
Unusual variations noted on tdal records. No details. (Report to Marine Department from Wellington Harbour Board, dated 23 April 1946)
Nothing unusual noted on tidal records. (Greymouth harbour Board Report on Tide gauge records, dated 24 April 1946)

Foamy waves, associated with a strong current causing the banging of wood into a boatshed, was noticed going up the Cam river near the swing bridge at Kaiapoi at about 15:00 on 2 April. Waves not caused by wind. No damage. (The Press (Christchurch) 12 April 1946)

According to a personal recollection of an incident as a child of 10, a tsunami first receded then inundated and significantly damaged a house at Tuapeka, on the northern coast of Chatham Island in 1947 [which is likely to have been in realtity 1946, see next column]. (Collins, 2005)
discussion: Although this article refers to the tsunami as being in 1947, the 1947 tsunami from near Gisborne isn’t known to have caused large waves on Chatham Island. Given the strong effects at Perseverance Harbour, Campbell Island, it is more likely that the event described occurred in 1946.

source_material: Harbour Master at Oamaru reported a "strong confused run at entrance" on Apr 3. (Report to Marine Department from Dunedin, 14 May1946)
Not noticed at Taiaroa Heads nor recorded (Apr 1-8) at Birch Street Wharf. (Report to Marine Department from Dunedin, 10 May 1946)
obs_first_arrival_comments: See tide gauge data columns also

source_material: "A peculiar pulsating effect", quite different in appearance from that observed in a storm, was observed on tidal records at main wharf from 20:00 April 2 and throughout Apr 3 and Apr 4. (Report to Marine Department from Dunedin, 6 May 1946)
obs_first_arrival_comments: See tide gauge data columns also

placename: Stewart Island [default: Half Moon Bay, Oban]
source_material: Tide rose and fell in surges, "about 4ft higher at their peak than when they receded". Uncertain date and hence association with tsunami. Report refers to "last week". (Evening Post 9 April 1946)

Another [tsunami] early in April 1946 washed away one of the boats, and drums of petrol, timber, and sheets of iron stacked several feet above the highest known spring tide level, and wrecked the boatshed. (Kerr, 1976)
obs_damage: boat, drums, housing material washed away, boatshed damaged

source_material: Nothing unusual noted but light[house] on high ground and houses not within sight of sea. (DSIR Seismological Observatory files, now held at GNS Science)
Reported to be furthest extent of wave. Effects diminished rapidly north of Tolaga Bay. (Gisborne Herald 26 March 1947)
Effects extended to here (first report). Later eyewitness report: beaches waterlogged to well above HWM. Speed and height of surges rapidly diminished northwards. (Gisborne Herald 26 March 1947)
discussion: Tsunami would have arrived at high tide, which was also a spring tide at about MHWS level. See Tolaga Bay

source_material: (Location noted to be just north of Tolaga Bay. Newspaper refers to Kaihu Beach, which we assume to be Kaiaua Beach) A huge swell rose up from southward and covered beach to depth of probably 6 ft. (Gisborne Herald 26 March 1947)

A huge swell that reached high up beaches and wharves, No damage. A series of high bores travelled up Uawa River for 2 miles (3.2km) and overflowed banks at low points without serious effects. No damage caused north of Tolaga Bay. (Gisborne Herald 26 March 1947) Earthquake "followed by tidal wave varying from 6-15 ft, according to locality from 14miles north of Tolaga Bay to 10 miles south, where two bridges at Waihau bay 10 ft above sea level were swept away. Secondary wave of smaller proportions followed an hour after shock experienced. Both waves were observed in the Uawa River as far as 3 miles inland. (DSIR Seismological Observatory Felt Report)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), HW was at 08:37 March 26 NZST (0.71) at Tolaga bay. MHWS at Tolaga Bay is 0.7 m above MSL (LINZ Website) suggesting also that the tsunami ariived at the time of Spring Tides.

source_material: Two old bridges on old coastal road (now acess to Waihau Station) "destroyed at a level 10-12ft above the previous highest point reached by sea". (Gisborne Herald 26 March 1947); Earthquake "followed by tidal wave varying from 6-15 ft, according to locality from 14miles north of Tolaga Bay to 10 miles south, where two bridges at Waihau bay 10 ft above sea level were swept away. Secondary wave of smaller proportions followed an hour after shock experienced. Both waves were observed in the Uawa River as far as 3 miles inland. (DSIR Seismological Observatory Felt Report)

[Note: The bridge over the Pouawa River, referred to in the following accounts, was at the northern end of Pouawa Beach, whereas the cottage occupied by the Mr & Mrs Hall, a nephew, and two visitors who had not long arrived, was the only house along the stretch of beach and it was located near the south end of Pouawa Beach, just north of Turihaua Point. There is a separate wave height entry for the latter, but the descriptive data are not separated as some comments apply to both locations.] Decking & superstructure of 36 yr old wooden truss bridge (54ft truss span and two 25ft stringer spans) was lifted bodily and deposited half mile up Pouawa River. The cottage occupied by the Halls at the southern end of Pouawa Beach, in which there were three people, was overwhelmed by first wave. Only one section of house was not demolished. It was moved 10 ft and twisted. The rest of the house was smashed and swept out to sea. Another two people escaped to the road above the cottage before the wave hit. At another location nearby, a man’s attention to the wave was drawn by noise and a child's comment. The level of water remained high for some time after the [first?] wave. (Gisborne Herald 26 March 1947); Telegraph poles in area well inland from the beach [which end of beach not stated] carried strands of debris in cross-arms and wires, taken as indications that waves reached at least 35 ft. Very little development or settlement in the area . Two men travelling by car from Gisborne were approaching Pouawa Bridge just before 9 am, noticed a huge swell developing in the bay and saw it break on the first shelf of rocks. They estimated the height as at least 40 ft above sea level, foam and spray being thrown higher as wave broke. They drove rapidly to higher ground beyond the bridge. The destruction of the bridge was also observed by shepherd on high ground. Earthquake felt severely by the people in the cottage (clock swinging only effect noted). Clock registered 8.40 am when wave was noticed as Mr Hall looked towards Tapuwai [note that many details here are inconsistent with Tunnicliffe account (q.v. below)]. The second wave arrived when water had receded enough for people still in the cottage to consider getting out. It was not as high as the first wave. The first wave washed the two people outside up onto the road. (Gisborne Herald 27 March 1947); Mr Hall saw a wave coming in when he looked out the door toward Tapuwai. Another person at the cottage estimated wave to be 15-20 ft. [Other details same as Gisborne Herald.] (Dominion 27 March 1947); A report from two people from Rotorua travelling by car from Gisborne stated that they reached the hill south of Pouawa at about 9 am, saw a huge swell, realised the danger when the wave hit the first rocks, where it appeared to be about 40 ft high. Foam and spray went higher. On the way back [from their destination] they found fish which had been thrown 30 ft above high tide level. At the Hall cottage, the water reached the eaves and the room the three people were in was turned completely round. The other four rooms and three sheds were demolished. (Daily Telegraph 27 March 1947); [The following recollections from one of the two people, the nephew, who were outside the Hall cottage when the first wave arrived were published in 1990. Details of who saw what differ from Hall statements in newspapers at the time.] The house was 6ft below road. The view from the door was north along beach, where "approaching the shore and us, at breakneck speed and roaring like an express train was a wall of dirty coloured water towering a good 30 ft, boiling and curling as it picked up acres of beach sand on its way to engulf us within seconds." Before they could do anything the wave washed over them sending the other person (Winkfield) who had been outside slightly closer to the sea, hurtling past. They were swept up onto the road, one thrown up against a 6 ft bank, while the other (the author) was caught on a fence under water, and then thrown up onto the road also where the water was a foot deep. A smaller wave hit him there. He saw the wave careering "up the hills for many hundreds of yards. Smaller waves were still coming in from the sea. As the waves came in they met receding surges with much debris. At this stage the sheds were picked up in the swirl, the roof peak of the house bobbed out of the water. The boathouse was detached and shattered. By the time they pushed towards the house the water was 4 ft deep. People in house escaped to bank above road. The author’s estimation of height of the wave about 25ft. (Tunnicliffe 1990); Observations by Mr Bennett from EQC state that debris was thrown 40ft above MSL at Pouawa, but wave estimated to be only about 15 ft. Estimated greatest at Tatapouri, wave reported to have arrived at 9.07 am. (DSIR Seismological Observatory files)

placename: Pouawa Beach south  (location of Hall cottage)
source_material: See entry above for Pouawa Beach North.

From near Turihaua homestead [south of Turihaua Point on <20m contour], a huge sea was seen to break about a mile offshore by Mr M Newman, travelling south; he then saw huge swell rising off-shore at Tatapouri [i.e. to south of Turihaua]. Mr Newman knew of no foul ground where the wave broke. He drove on and stopped jeep 50 yds up the road above theTatapouri Hotel (about 2.5-3km south from Turihaua) and saw crest of first big surge sweep in, rolling over sand dunes in front of hotel and enveloping lower part of building. Outhouses were lifted off foundations and disintegrated in swirl, and sucked out to sea. Fences and other moveable objects swept away. Hotel immersed up to windowsills. Looking towards Turihaua, Newman also saw the water sweep across the road to Turihaua, almost up to the level of the house, tearing out fences and washing over the gardens, the wave bringing back debris when it receded. Newman watched as a second wave 30-35ft high above normal HWM surged across the bay towards Turihaua Point (with Hall family and Pouawa Beach on the north side). First wave was "a huge swell the crest of which broke upon the land. The second wave formed itself well out in the bay. Broken water showed the line of its approach to Turihaua Point". The second wave swept high up the beaches and across the highway, which Mr N estimated was 20ft under water in some places at height of surge. Debris was left on the road. (Gisborne Herald 26 March 1947)
(See also Waimata River, both rivers join Turanganui) A small wave travelled up river bringing driftwood. No damage to properties backing onto river. (Gisborne Herald 26 March 1947)
discussion: Tide was high at the time; see tides at Gisborne or Tolaga Bay.

source_material: See also Turihaua Point South. Mr L Robinson's holiday cottage and motor shed on seaward side of Tatapouri Hotel (which is on ground <20m contour) was smashed. He saw approach of wave and escaped. Note that the earthquake was not felt. Warning of wave given by daughter at Hotel at about 9.20am. (Gisborne Herald 26 March 1947); Proprietors of Tatapouri Hotel (McLauchlan or McLaughlan) were warned by daughter, they managed to run up a bank at the back of the hotel, saw the second wave coming from the back gate. A short time after running away they looked back to see water around the front and two sides of hotel. The cowshed was destroyed and a two room cottage and its contents were carried out by the water as it receded. Mr McL estimated "the height of the wave at that point [which point is unclear, when it hit the hotel or bach?] at 12ft above high water". The water was 3 feet deep when it hit the hotel verandah and stoved it in, and left seaweed and sand in the hotel. (Dominion 27 March 1947); After the second wave the water remained at a high level for ten minutes before it receded. (Grayland 1978) Wave arrived "shortly after 8.40" (NZ Herald 27 March 1947). The first wave was at approximately 9.5am and the second 3-4 minutes afterwards. They were both 12-15ft in height." (Harbour Board report in DSIR Seismological Observatory files)
discussion: Tide was high at the time; see tides at Gisborne or Tolaga Bay.
obs_damage: Hotel damaged, cottage and shed destroyed.

source_material: Early report states that there was no damage to buildings at the base of the hill despite being on flat ground near the shore. This report appears to be superseded by the later report : A house (owners Mr & Mrs H Olsen) on low ground on Makorori side of Tatapouri Headland was immersed with only three feet of roof showing [no detail on the source of this report, or whether anyone was inside the house]. (Gisborne Herald 27 March 1947); Two drovers with cattle and dogs were nearly caught on the beach, some dogs at the rear having to swim. (Dominon 27 March 1947)
discussion: Tide was high at the time; see tides at Gisborne or Tolaga Bay.

source_material: As seen from Wainui, waves appeared to crash about half-way up the cliffs at Tatapouri Point [From Topo map approx 60m cliff at Point, then lesser gradient to 100m. Max height further inland 186m]. (Gisborne Herald 27 March 1947) ; From top of Tatapouri Hill Mr F Whitehead saw the first wave come in and go out. As it receded the second wave, which appeared to be higher than the first, started to come in but the receding waters broke its effect. (Dominion 27 March 1947); From Secretary of Gisborne Harbour Board, who investigated reports for Seismologocal Observatory, attention to wave drawn by foam well out to sea off Tatapouri; great surge grew larger to 30-40ft as it approached Tatapouri. Appeared to come from a little south of east, breaking at Tatapouri first the progressively breaking on other beaches along the coast to a little south of Young Nick's head. Not noticed north of Gable End [clearly inconsistent with other reports]. One observer saw wave cross bay from Tuahine to Young Nicks Head, speed 40 mph and reaching 30ft off Muriwai. Another observer saw wave break at Wainui estimated height 30-40ft. (Seismological Observatory files)
discussion: Tide was high at the time; see tides at Gisborne or Tolaga Bay.

source_material: Bores several feet high entered river and harbour basin, causing anxiety. (Gisborne Herald 26 March 1947)
discussion: Tide was high at the time; see tides at Gisborne or Tolaga Bay.

source_material: (See also Taruheru River, both rivers join Turanganui) A small wave travelled up river bringing driftwood. No damage to properties backing onto river. (Gisborne Herald 26 March 1947)
discussion: Tide was high at the time; see tides at Gisborne or Tolaga Bay.

source_material: See Gisborne: Kaiti Beach
discussion: Tide was high at the time; see tides at Gisborne or Tolaga Bay.

source_material: Three large surges of approx 12 ft in variation (ie peak-to-trough) in Gisborne Harbour. No damage. Wave could be seen coming across bay from direction of Muriwai. A bore formed in Turanganui River and in harbour. All lines to boats at wharves held. After first rise water dropped 12 ft to well below LWM. Dredge dragged mooring until retied with help of launch. Two other large bores came up harbour channel, but no damage. Other smaller fluctuations later in the morning. (Gisborne Herald 26 March 1947); In Kaiti Basin tide ran well out below LWM and came in to approx 5ft above spring tide level and continued to ebb and flow, "the ebbs and flows alternating at periods of 8 to 10 minutes and running up to 7 or 8 knots". The tides returned to normal after about 2 hours. No structural damage was done to the port. (Gisborne Herald 2 April 1947); Officer of Pukeko did not see wave until it entered the harbour. It struck the concrete harbour entrance with great force and swept up the channel causing a 12ft lift. The wave did not top the wharf. Another officer saw approach of the second wave - "it was not broken - just a huge wall". It struck the harbour entrance with force and caused a heavy surge and rip. Later there were further minor bores, and tidal fluctuations throughout the morning. (Daily Telegraph 28 March 1947); "On Wednesday 26 March at 8:30am a prolonged earthquake shock was experienced throughout the district. This was followed at 9.5am by a tidal wave which caused a high bore in the river and inner harbour. The tide ran out to well below low-water mark and came in to approximately 5 feet above spring tide level and continued to ebb and flow, gradually subsiding back to normal about 11am. The dredge "A.C." dragged her working moorings but the launch Takitimu took her in tow and she was berthed at No.6 wharf. On examination there seems to be no structural damage done to the harbour. The tide ebbed and flowed at intervals of approx. 8-10 minutes and ran about 7 to 8 knots, gradually taking [tailing?] off. (G. McKenzie Smart, Harbourmaster report.) "The tide was high and showing 6ft 6in on the automatic tide gauge. The wave caused a bore in the harbour channel and the river of a height of from 5 to 6 ft above high water mark and above the 6ft 6in on the tide gauge. The water then receded to low water mark or zero on the gauge followed by another run in to 7ft 6in on the gauge. The tide continued to run in and out at approximately 10 min. intervals, gradually subsiding to normal at 11 am, when the gauge was fairly steady at 6ft." (Observatory files) Postmaster at Gisborne reported the waves of 12-15ft (where?) arrived at 9.02 am. (Source?? ) 5 to 6 ft above high water mark and above the 6ft 6in on the tide gauge. The water then receded to low water mark or zero on the gauge followed by another run in to 7ft 6in on the gauge. The tide continued to run in and out at approximately 10 min. intervals, gradually subsiding to normal at 11 am, when the gauge was fairly steady at 6ft." (Observatory files) Postmaster at Gisborne reported the waves of 12-15ft (where?) arrived at 9.02 am. (Source??)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), HW was at 08:32 March 26 NZST (0.70) at Gisborne. MHWS at Gisborne is 0.76 m above MSL (LINZ Website).
obs_no_sig-waves: 3 large waves, followed by smaller waves

source_material: Water swirled round base of Cook Monument and over the road. Water entered cottages built at road level at eastern end of beach. Some structural damage possibly done (no detail). (Gisborne Herald 26 March 1947) Large waves broke at Kaiti and Waikanae beaches. Water damaged the contents of some cottages at Kaiti. (Dominion 27 march 1947)
discussion: Tide was high at the time; see tides at Gisborne or Tolaga Bay.

source_material: Residential area suffered some damage, including washing out of foundations of one cottage and severe structural damage to surf club premises. Caravan floated before being grounded (no detail). "One report from Wainui referred to huge patch of sea lashed to white froth some miles out from Tuahine Point, where the water remained disturbed and frothy for some time after the last tremors of the morning quake had subsided". (Gisborne Herald 26 March 1947); Houses along Wainui Beach threatened and if wave had been another 2 ft higher a disaster could have occurred. Considerable amount of damage caused. Both ends of beach where road slopes down were worst hit. At southern end: creek said to have taken the main force of wave. Bank in front of house nearest creek washed away, water swept away fence and entered house. Other houses (or at least gardens) said to be damaged. Eyewitness told of wall of jet-black water advancing up beach, breaking as it hit bank in front of house and washing into house itself. A caravan on the lawn was lifted, turned and deposited on a fence. A wireless pole and fence demolished. As wave receded about 50 yds in front of house it met an incoming wave and water rose high in air. A series of smaller waves broke over the bank. At northern end of beach: Wave judged to have come up to edge of road at the carpark near Okitu Stream. Surf Club premises badly damaged nearby. Doors forced open, floor subsided, strewn with sand and silt, A shed nearby (or the Surf club shed?) on its side. Eyewitness reported water travelling 50 yds up bank behind clubhouse, before rushing back through it. Parts of bank all along beach washed away (see Weekly News photo). (Gisborne Herald 27 March 1947); Although high above sea level houses at Wainui were threatened. Windows 30-49 ft above sea level were splashed when wave hit bank in front. All along the beach, banks were seriously eroded. (Dominion 27 March 1947); Officer from Pukeko reported that a trail of debris was left by waves along beach. Water had entered several cottages, causing some structural damage (no detail). At the point where the road met the beach, there were signs the waves had nearly reached the highway. On the northern part of the beach the waves had crossed the road. (Daily Telegraph Mar 28); Photograph "Damage to the foreshore at Wainui Beach. Most of the force of the water was taken by the bank. [Erosion evident] (Weekly News Apr 2)
discussion: Tide was high at the time; see tides at Gisborne or Tolaga Bay.
obs_damage: Surf club damaged, houses inundated, fences damaged, caravan floated, beach and stream banks eroded

source_material: On northern side of Young Nick's Head, surge not as severe as on southern side and water reached no further inland than lower levels close to beach and the flat land on the sides of the Waipaoa River. Only minor damage in the area (no detail). (Gisborne Herald 27 March 1947)
discussion: Tide was high at the time; see tides at Gisborne or Tolaga Bay.

source_material: Huge swell came up and "swept inland a considerable distance, and wrecked fences and imperilled stock and crops". Full extent of damage not ascertained. (Gisborne Herald 26 March 1947) See also Waipaoa River entry.
discussion: Tide was high at the time; see tides at Gisborne or Tolaga Bay.

source_material: Water surged up beach and flooded low-lying land near sea to a depth of approx. 12ft. Pumpkins in 15 acre paddock were swept out to sea. Half a mile of fencing was demolished. (Gisborne Herald 27 March 1947); RS Murphy (now of Gisborne, contacted 28/11/99) stated that Murphy's Beach is probably at Maraetaha River mouth. He didn't remember the tsunami.
discussion: Tide was high at the time; see tides at Gisborne or Tolaga Bay.

source_material: Between Kaiwitau Block and Te Mahanaga [Mahanga?] many fish were stranded by the waves. A feature was the large size of the fish (schnapper, turbot, flounder, dogfish, stingray and groper). Mr Omana saw wave coming in (exactly where on his way to Mahia Peninsula not stated) and went for shelter . When the wave receded "swarms of fish" were observed splashing in a 16 acre maize field. Many people came to collect the fish. At the top end of the Peninsula a road contractors caravan was hit by the wave with no damage caused. "Today right across the peninsula to well up the coast towards Gisborne there is sea water covering crops of maize, the emergency landing ground and a considerable portion of Mr Justice Johnston's property. (SOURCE?); " At Te Mahanga on Gisborne side of Opoutama, wave swept into a house (Miss S Bowen's) and swept it off its foundations. One section of the building was torn apart and left as a tangled wreck. Long sections of fencing fronting Te Mahanga beach were torn up. Eyewitnesses estimated the wave height as 15-20ft. It swept more than 200 yds inland. (Gisborne Herald 31 March 1947) ; Eyewitnesses estimated that the wave, which was of "no great height" commenced from 2 miles out to sea and brought in hundreds of schnapper and stingrays stranding them on the beach between Kaiwaitau Block and Te Mahanga, over a distance of 10-12 miles. The majority of schnapper were 15-20lb, several 28-31lb. (Dominion 28 March 1947); Wave arrived at about 9am. Waves between 10 -15ft above spring tide level. Two waves swept across swamp lands, waters did not recede for half an hour. Fish deposited along miles of beach and cliffs. (NZ Herald 27 March 1947)
discussion: Tide was high at the time; see tides at Gisborne or Tolaga Bay.
obs_damage: House damaged, fencing washed away, fish stranded

source_material: No sign of tsunami (Gisborne Herald 26 March 1947)

See also Te Mahanga entry. Wave on a small scale experienced on Mahia peninsula. (Dominion 28 March 1947) Observations from Mr Bennett of EQC, "damaging effects also reported at a place on WEST side of Mahia Peninsula". (DSIR Seismological Observatory files, 1947)

Vessel Koau, which was sheltering at Portland Island, did not notice any disturbance. (Daily Telegraph 28 March 1947); Marine Dept memorandum reports wave not seen at Portland Island [lighthouse] (DSIR Seismological Observatory files 1947)
Marine Dept memorandum reports wave did not affect the port nor were unusual movements recorded on the tide gauge (DSIR Seismological Observatory files)
Marine Dept memorandum reports wave not seen at Castlepoint (DSIR Seismological Observatory files, 1947)

Observatory files contain record of 1947 conversation with person in receipt of letter from Chatham Islands stating that at 11.30am (prob Chatham Islands time) on March 26 an unusually large wave carried a boat that had been beached at high tide mark farther up the beach than the sea had ever reached before. (DSIR Seismological Observatory files, 1947) Eiby (1982a) concludes "that it is impossible to to be certain that no wave reached the Chathams, but the balance of probability seems against it".
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), HW was at 07:28 March 26 NZST (0.34) at Waitangi, Chatham Island. Tsunami arrived at mid-tide, or about MSL. MHWS is 0.4 m above MSL (LINZ website).
obs_first_arrival_comments: Note: Chatham island time CIT) 45 minutes ahead of NZST

source_material: According to a personal recollection of an incident as a child of 10, a tsunami first receded then inundated and significantly damaged a house at Tuapeka, on the northern coast of Chatham Island in 1947 [which is likely to have been in realtity 1946, see next column]. (Collins, 2005)
discussion: Although this article refers to the tsunami as being in 1947, the 1947 tsunami from near Gisborne isn’t known to have caused large waves on Chatham Island. Given the strong effects at Perseverance Harbour, Campbell Island, it is more likely that the event described occurred in 1946.
obs_first_arrival_comments: Note: Chatham island time CIT) 45 minutes ahead of NZST

source_material: Believed to have escaped damage (Daily Telegraph 19 May 1947)

placename: Kaihu Beach [unknown; default location: Kaiaua Beach]
source_material: "on more northerly beaches [from Tolaga Bay] there were further signs which indicated the rapid dissipation of the force of the wave." (Gisborne Herald 19 May 1947)

Along some of the beaches between Tatapouri and Tolaga Bay driftwood was deposited well above high tide level. (Gisborne Herald 19 May 1947); Along beach near Tolaga Bay township driftwood lines were "high enough to indicate the passing of a substantial wave" (Gisborne Herald 19 may 1947); 6-8ft higher than previous tsunami. Two police officers driving to Tolaga Bay noticed logs and debris on low-lying sections of road before reaching Tatapouri [probably at Makorori]. No further evidence of inundation as far as Tolaga Bay. (Daily Telegraph 19 may 1947); Postmaster reported driftwood 50 yds from HWM, well beyond limit of previous wave. (DSIR Seismological Observatory Files, 1947)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), LW occurred at 2108 NZST (-0.51 m) on May 17 at Tolaga Bay, i.e the earthquake occrred two hrs before LW, the tsunami probably occurring about 1.5 hrs before LW

source_material: Earthquake stopped clocks at Mr N Loisel's, worst shake since Masterton quake. "Water surged up creek at height greater than in March, covering footbridge not reached in previous tsunami. Mr Loisel estimated "water penetrated 400yds inland and two chains above high water level". A pile of logs were swept across road and deposited in a plantation. (Daily Telegraph 19 May 1947); Higher than wave in March, lifting heavy timber which lay adjacent to bridge previously damaged. Mr Loisel considered the wave was substantially higher at Waihau than previous wave. The bridge site was 2.5 chains from normal HWM. The furthest point inland reached by the wave was about 400yds from HWM. (Gisborne Herald 19 May 1947)

At Tatapouri Hotel wave reached within a chain and a half [30m] of the building. Comment by Hotel owner, W D McLaughlan, "But for the fact that the tide was almost right out I think the wave would have come nearly as high as the last one". He estimated wave height must have been 12ft. Mr Robinson, who lost bach and furniture in March, had his boat stoved in where it was moored on the sand above high tide level. (Daily Telegraph 19 May 1947); Wave left its mark level with top of sand bank in front of hotel. Mr Robinson's flat-bottomed boat was found against the bank with its side stoved in. Wave height estimated to have reached 12 ft above normal HWM and "taking account of average rise and fall of the tide there it probably ranged to 18 or 20 ft [5.5-6m] above sea level when it struck the reefs in that locality". (Gisborne Herald 19 May 1947); Hotel owner heard a rush of water about half an hour after the quake, and went out to find that the sea had reached to the top of the bank in front of the hotel. He estimated the wave to be 12 ft high, taking into account the tide and height of the bank. (Dominion 19 May 1947)
discussion: The observation of the hotel owner at Tatapouri is probably more reliable than that published by the Gisborne Herald, and for this reason is assigned here

source_material: Along the Makorori Beach road driftwood was deposited on road at several places, without doing damage to the road. (Gisborne Herald 19 May 1947);Two police officers driving to Tolaga Bay noticed logs and debris on low-lying sections of road before reaching Tatapouri [probably Makorori]. No further evidence of inundation as far as Tolaga Bay. (Daily Telegraph 19 May 1947)

No earthquake damage reported, other than fracture of water supply pipeline at Te Arai bridge at Manutuke [less than 10km SW of Gisborne]. (Daily Telegraph 19 May 1947) "Followed shortly before 8pm by tidal wave. No damage although main road covered beyond Tatapouri." (DSIR Sesismological Observatory Felt report); Secretary to Gisborne Harbour Board reported that there were no signs of the wave in Gisborne Harbour. (DSIR Seismological Observatory files)

Severe shake, more severe than earthquake in March. ( Daily Telegraph 19 May 1947); Residents found that "sea-water had washed the lower portions of some sections, but that no damage had occurred". (Gisborne Herald 19 May 1947)
No "extra large wave" seen at Wairoa. (Daily Telegraph 19 May 1947)
see source event
discussion: Note that ≤ 0.1 m is used to indicate that tide-gauge records were searched at the time and that the tsunami was too small to be distinguishable.

source_material: see source event

source_material: see source event

(per PA) "At 9.30 last night [5 November] Mr Ted Clements and his sons, Maurice, were coming Matapouri on the launch Dorothy after a fishing trip to the Poor Knights Island. Suddenly a 3 ft wave swept the boat under the bridge damaging the vessel’s ventilators and injuring Maurice Clement’s arm." (Gisborne Herald 7 November 1952); Time uncertain A fishing launch damaged when swept under bridge by 3ft wall of water. Person on board launch had arm injured. (NZ Herald 7 November 1952)
discussion: De Lange & Healy (1986) note that the event "seems to have been a bore formed inside the estuary at Matapouri Bay."

source_material: (per PA) Two hours previous to the observed wave at 9.30 p.m at Matapouri., a person at Tutukaka heard a roaring noise and saw a wave about 1 ft high coming swiftly up the Tutukaka river. The wave was observed to take 15 minutes to run in from the bay entrance and the same time to run out. The tide rose 30 in with each wave and dropped again as the wave receded. Waves were still coming in when the observer retired at 11 p.m. . The water was still surging the next morning [6 November]. Another Tutukaka resident said he heard a roaring at 9 p.m. and saw a 3 ft wave coming in. Every 10 minutes the water would settle down and then the wave would run back. This went on until he retired. (Gisborne Herald 7 November 1952; similar in many other papers)

(per PA) At about 10 p.m. a tidal wave washed a launch from its cradle and carried it up the bank. The wave also shifted a big log from where it had been half buried in the sand and carried it about six chains. The water was still disturbed on the morning of the 6th. (Gisborne Herald 7 November 1952; similar in many other papers)
No local effects were noted in the Bay of Plenty Times, published in Tauranga.
discussion: Assume <0.2

source_material: Disturbance in water level in inner harbur from about 08:00 6 November, evident on tide gauge from mid-morning. At 10:05 gauge read 8 ft 3 in, level fell 12 inches in next 20 minutes. At 10:34 a further and much sharper drop recorded, falling to 3 ft 6in on the gauge. Gauge steady for the next hour, and at 11:32 reading was still 3 ft 6 in. Within next 10 minutes, level rose by 2 ft 6 in, and then minor surges and recessions until 12:00. Disturbance was likened to that in 1947 but range was noted to be not as wide, and no bore or crest was observed. Changes in level likened to huge swell banking up and filling tideways, with no surface break. Late on afternoon of 6 November tide still showing marked fluctuations. In vicinity of No 3 shed rise was 2 ft every 5 minutes. Each maximum was followed by a recession. Fluctuations continuous since about 10:00 on 6 November. (Gisborne Herald 7 November 1952; similar in NZ Herald & Evening Post 7 November 1952)
The Daily telegraph records effects elsewhere but has no information on effects in the local area

The water in Wellington harbour rose and fell six to eight inches all day on 6 November. The Wellington Harbour Board’s tide gauge, which usually shows a straight line, recorded a regular series of undulations. The greatest rise above normal was just over eight inches at the peak point about 8 a.m. At no stage was it ever very noticeable to the casual observed and had no effect on shipping. The rise and fall was still continuing later yesterday afternoon, and was expected to ease off gradually (Dominion (a morning paper) 7 November 1952); On night of 6 November [probably evening] tide gauge registered a peak amplitude of 18 inches. When inspected at about 12:00 on 7 November, the wave amplitude had decreased to one foot. The beginning of the disturbance was recorded early on the tide gauge chart on 6 November, and considerable disturbances, compared with the normal smooth curves on most days, were recorded on 6 November and the first 2 ½ hours of 7 November. (Evening Post 7 November 1952)

"The marine disturbance caused by an earthquake off Siberia on Tuesday had no effect on the tide level in Nelson harbour. On Wednesday evening [Nov 5] the tide gauge rose a little and then returned to low water mark again. The relieving Harbourmaster, Captain A.H. Howie, said this morning that the tidal waves approaching New Zealand from the east, although affecting Wellington and other eastern coast ports, would be unlikely Mail 7 November 1952)

The small collier Rata “touched” the bar when sailing from Greymouth shortly before midday on 6 November. It ws believed that she was “dumped” following a lift created by tidal waves. The waves were first recorded on the Greymouth Harbour Board’s electrically operated water level gauge at 10 pm on 5 November. They were still affecting the readings at 11 o’clock on 7 November. The subsequent variations on the chart were so large that the Harbourmaster Captain H Moore ordered an inspection of the gauge, which was found to be operating normally. Since the night of 5 November, "a variation of up to 14 in has been shown on the gauge ... In the opinion of Captain Moore [harbourmaster] this would represent a wave of between seven and nine feet at the Harbour entrance half a mile distant from the gauge." It was noted that this was the first time that such a meandering reading has been recorded on the instrument since its installation in about 1940. A fisherman, who was using a hand net in the Grey River between 10 and 11 o’clock am on 6 November shortly before the Rata sailed, reported that a three-foot wave in the river had lifted his rowing boat on to the rocks. It was followed by an 18-in wave. The Rata was ‘dumped” onto the bar by an extraordinary lift just as she sailed, but with her 14 ft draught did not hit heavily. The high water reading yesterday was 19 ft 5 in. (Evening Post 7 November 1952)
obs_first_arrival_comments: See tide gauge data columns also

source_material: No visible wave but strong current at mouth of Ashley River tore nets between 06.10 and 06.45. At about the same time, at a distance 1.2 km upstream water rose rapidly 18-25 cm reaching HWM more than 2 hrs before high tide. (Christchurch Star Sun 6 Nov 1952)
No effect noticed except high tide reached early. (Christchurch Star Sun 6 Nov 1952)
"Tide gauge showed considerable disturbance from 11.10pm [Nov 5] to 0600 [Nov 6]". (Christchurch Star Sun 6 Nov 1952)
