The Otago Daily Times records effects elsewhere but has no information on effects in the Otago harbour area.
discussion: The Otago Daily Times records effects elsewhere but has no information on effects in the Otago harbour area.

source_material: The Southland Times records effects elsewhere but has no information on effects in the local area
see source event

Residents of Leigh described the harbour waters as “peculiar” on 11 March. A fisherman was not able to tie up at the wharf at 9.30 a.m on 11 March because of the heavy surge. By 5 p.m. the surge had been accentuated and was emptying a small bay at Leigh Cove, leaving the bed of the sea “dry” and then filling it to depth of seven feet.The roar of the surge could be heard 400 yards away. Launches were buffeted and strained at their moorings as the tide receded. The phenomenon gradually subsided. Effects at Matheson Bay were "not very pronounced" [q.v.]. (NZ Herald 12 March 1957)
Effects at Matheson Bay were "not very pronounced" compared to effects at Leigh and Leigh Cove [q.v.] (NZ Herald 12 March 1957)

Fluctuation began on the night of 10 March. The water was rising and falling about 18 inches to begin with, but it did no damage On 12 March, the water was rising and falling about six inches in two and a half minute periods. (Auckland Star 11 March 1957)

Heavy fluctuations recorded on the tide gauge in Napier harbour from 18:00 on 10 March. The fluctuations were about 10 minutes apart. Fluctuations were still being recorded on the morning of 11 March. (Daily Telegraph (Napier) 11 March 1957)

(Per Press Association) First fluctuations were shown on the gauge at 22:00 10 March. Harbour Board tide gauges showed a rise of one foot, lasting for half an hour, as the peak of the waves passed through between 01:00 and 02:00 on 11 March, followed by wide fluctuations. The effects of the recurring waves were still being recorded on 11 March. (Daily Telegraph (Napier) 11 March 1957; and other newspapers)

“An abnormally high tide was observed at Cape Reinga but there was no obvious tidal wave”. (Northern Advocate (Whangarei) 24 May 1960); At low tide on May 25, surges came back over the exposed rocks and reached the high-tide mark – something never been seen before, even in storms. (Northern Advocate (Whangarei) 25 May 1960); At Cape Reinga an unusually high tide for this time of the year was noticed. (Northland Age (Kaitaia) 24 May 1960)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), LW at 01:11 May 24 NZST (-0.86), 13:34 May 24 NZMT (-1.10 m ),and 01:54 (-0.88) May 25. If low tide was truly observed then it would hardly have been in the middle of the night May 25 when the paper was published, ie it was May 24 or the tide was not actually low but at the ebb of one of the tsunami waves, indicating a peak-trough to about 2 m (LW to HW as described) on May 25,. This suggests also that the maximum would have been greater. Note that the expected first arrival occurred on an ebbing tide.

source_material: At 1200 May 24 waves had not been noticed at Awanui or Houhora. (Northern Advocate (Whangarei) 24 May 1960); No noticeable effect at Awanui, Houhora or Parengarenga harbour up to am May 25 . (Northern Advocate (Whangarei) 25 May 1960); Nothing yet reported from Houhora. (Northland Age (Kaitaia) 24 May 1960); No noticeable effect at Awanui, Houhora or Parengarenga harbours. (Northland Age (Kaitaia) 27 May 1960)

No sign of anything unusual in Awanui Harbour until about 1000 May 24., when it was found that the ebbing tide had stopped. It then rose again about 1 ft. Nothing yet reported from the Awanui River. (Northland Age (Kaitaia) 24 May 1960); There was no noticeable effect at Awanui, Houhora or Parengarenga harbours. (Northland Age (Kaitaia) 27 May 1960); At 1200 May 24 waves had not been noticed at Awanui or Houhora. (Northern Advocate (Whangarei) 24 May 1960); No noticeable effect at Awanui, Houhora or Parengarenga harbour up to am May 25. (Northern Advocate (Whangarei) 25 May 1960)

A lad was about to push a fishing boat into the ebbing tide when the water suddenly rose a foot., and then continued to rise. (Northern Advocate (Whangarei) 24 May 1960); Surges struck the East Coast of Northland evening of May 23; continued at Mangonui and Kaimaumau on morning of May 24. Only damage recorded in area up to May 24: a bridge undermined at Tutukaka. (Northland Age (Kaitaia) 24 May 1960)

placename: Tokerau Beach, NORTH AUCKLAND? [location uncertain, correct within 5 km only]
source_material: “Two or three days ago [May 24-25] there was a big tide at the beach.” (Northern Advocate (Whangarei) 27 May 1960)

Launches dragged anchors and were swept down harbour. Fish stranded. (NZ Herald May 25 1960); First noticed evening of May 23, continuing am on May 24. 4 ft rise and fall in 10 minutes [time not stated]. Some launches belonging dragged their moorings night May 23/24 and were found, undamaged, half way down the harbour. May 24, recurring surges alternately covered and exposed the extensive mudflats. (Northern Advocate (Whangarei) 24 May 1960); 2.5 ft rise & fall between 0740 and 0800 May 25; small movements continuing. Only damage reported: underwater telephone cable running across the harbour and serving 10 or 12 settlers on the eastern side broke on May 24, either as a result of the heavy tidal scour or from the anchors of the launches which dragged down harbour. At the height of the surges on May 24, the harbour said to be a raging mass of discoloured water and as the tide receded, it was seen that the shellfish beds were heavily scoured. (Northern Advocate (Whangarei) 25 May 1960); Surges struck the East Coast of Northland evening of May 23; continued at Mangonui and Kaimaumau on morning of May 24. Only damage recorded in area up to May 24: a bridge undermined at Tutukaka. At 0800 May 24, a 4 ft rise and fall in 10 minutes recorded at Mangonui. Two launches dragged their moorings, and were found am May 24 half way down the harbour. This rise and fall continued on May 24, reducing to 2-3 ft. Fish stranded on the mud-flats. (Northland Age (Kaitaia) 24 May 1960); [same information as Northern Advocate] + surges still occurring on May 25. At 1000 on May 24, water rose to "ordinary tide level" at the wharf and then within minutes fell to low spring tide mark. (Northland Age (Kaitaia) 27 May 1960)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), HW at 18:30 May 23 NZST (0.77), LW at 00:33 (-0.70), HW at 06:38 (0.81), LW at 12:57 (-0.90), HW at 19:15 (0.81) May 24 NZST. Tsunami waves could have been higher at the time of low tide during the night of May 23-24, ie with a tidal range to HWS approaching 2 m this zero-peak at low tide would not have exceeded HW.
obs_damage: Boats dreagged moorings, underwtaer cable broken, shellfish beds scoured

source_material: Boat suddenly left high and dry. (NZ Herald May 25 1960); At Whangaroa a boat owned by a commercial fisherman, was suddenly left high and dry. When it was refloated by a returning “tide,” A boat that set off up harbour at half-throttle could hardly make way against the tide, which should have been running with it. (Northern Advocate (Whangarei) 25 May 1960)

Waves ran up tidal creek. (NZ Herald May 25 1960); At Cape Reinga an unusually high tide for this time of the year was noticed on the West Coast. This seems to have been the only effect on the West Coast, as nothing at the time of going to press was noticed at Ahipara. (Northland Age (Kaitaia) 24 May 1960)
First surge swept away beacon off Russell town point. (NZ Herald May 25 1960)

On night of May 23 and May 24, swift runs seen in the Waitangi River, causing strange boilings and swirlings of currents in the narrower confines. The two small-boat anchorages – below the golf clubhouse and beside the Waitangi wharf – received the full force of the currents. A 16-foot runabout was dragged from its mooring below the clubhouse and cut in two against a pylon of the estuary bridge. Other boats strained at their moorings and bumped on the bottom but were not damaged. A launch/boat [normally?] in 10 feet of water touched bottom in the deepest part of the lower wharf anchorage. (Northern Advocate (Whangarei) 25 May 1960); Pipi bank at entrance to Waitangi River damaged. (NZ Herald May 25 1960); Opua, Bay of Islands, NZ – From local reports of small boat owners the first effects of the tsunami were noticed at Waitangi River entrance at 2230 May 23, 1960, when the river was subjected to strong flow and ebb currents in rapid succession. At Opua the same effect occurred at 2200. Normal tidal currents in the harbor ceased. Flood and ebb changes occurred at intervals of 20-40 minutes, with shorter periods in Opua Basin. Change of direction of current was suddenly accompanied by formation of whirlpools. Water level changed 3-4 feet in a matter of minutes; however, the highest level was not unusual. (Berkman & Symons, 1964)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), HW at 18:17 May 23 NZST (0.77), LW at 00:21(-0.69), HW a 06:25 (0.80), LW at 12:44 (-0.90), HW at 19:03 (0.81) May 24 NZST at Waitangi River entrance. Tsunami waves could have been higher at the time of low tide during the night of May 23-24, ie with a tidal range to HWS approaching 1.6 m this zero-peak at low tide would not have exceeded HW.

source_material: At 0930 May 24, tide receded leaving car ferry/barge stranded on the concrete ramp at Deeming’s Point. As the barge was approaching the Opua end, run of water so fierce that the barge was almost forced into the ramp stanchions. The pilot managed to edge the barge away and run it aground on the small shingle beach beside the Opua wharf. At 0630 May 25 the tide was full in at Opua. Less than an hour later it had fallen 2 feet. Force of the waves worked free a flashing–beacon channel pile off Okiato point, near Opua. The recurring surge am on May 25 made it hazardous to load the Bay of Islands Harbour Board’s 30ft pile frame on to a barge and the task of replacing the broken pile has been deferred. By 0800 tide was full in again. (Northern Advocate (Whangarei) 25 May 1960); Opua, Bay of Islands, NZ – From local reports of small boat owners the first effects of the tsunami were noticed at Waitangi River entrance at 2230 May 23, 1960, when the river was subjected to strong flow and ebb currents in rapid succession. At Opua the same effect occurred at 2200. Normal tidal currents in the harbor ceased. Flood and ebb changes occurred at intervals of 20-40 minutes, with shorter periods in Opua Basin. Change of direction of current was suddenly accompanied by formation of whirlpools. Water level changed 3-4 feet in a matter of minutes; however, the highest level was not unusual. (Berkman & Symons, 1964); Ferry with two cars on board left high and dry when water surged out. (NZ Herald May 25 1960)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), HW at 18:22 May 23 NZST (0.79), LW at 00:25 (-0.72), HW at 06:30 (0.82), LW at 12:49 (-0.92), HW at 19:07 (0.83) May 24 NZST at Opua. Tsunami waves could have been higher at the time of low tide during the night of May 23-24, ie with a tidal range to HWS approaching 1.9 m this zero-peak at low tide would not have exceeded HW.
obs_damage: flashing–beacon channel pile moved, ferry grounded

source_material: No noticeable effect at Awanui, Houhora or Parengarenga harbour up to am May 25 . (Northern Advocate (Whangarei) 25 May 1960); No noticeable effect at Awanui, Houhora or Parengarenga harbours. (Northland Age (Kaitaia) 27 May 1960)

Water rose over the bridge at Tutukaka at 0700 May 24. Parts of its stone facing on bridge carried up to 80 yards up the tidal creek. Bridge closed to heavy traffic. Surges kept rushing up the basin from 2100 May 23. Big surges hit at 2200 May 23 and 0400 May 24, rose 9 ft up to the decking of the jetty. Waves eased off at ~2400 May 23. Regular surges every 15 to 30 minutes swept up the creek am May 24. NZBS broadcast of the tidal wave in Chile heard at 2100 May 23, and almost immediately the surges started at Tutukaka, according to witness. An “outboard motor had been picked up out of the tide” [?]; two boats dragged their anchors. Tutukaka’s fleet of big-game fishing boats is remaining in harbour. Boatmen were awake all night watching mooring lines. Pleasure fishing trips cancelled because of conditions. Before the first wave came, the water receded, then came back in a slow wave that mounted 9 ft within minutes. Surges continued at 20-minute intervals, the waves dying down to about 3 ft, before growing again to 9 or 10 feet as high tide approached and the water swept across the low filling beside the estuary bridge. PHOTO AVAILABLE. (Northern Advocate (Whangarei) 24 May 1960); Early pm May 25, tidal surges still occurring. Tide at a low ebb surged in every 20 minutes or so and reached high water mark. Boats moored in shallow water heeled over as their keels rested on the bottom. (Northern Advocate (Whangarei) 25 May 1960)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), HW at 18:04 May 23 NZST (0.76), LW at 00:08 (-0.68), HW at 06:12 (0.78), LW at 12:31 (-0.88), HW at 18:50 (0.80) May 24 NZST at Tutukaka Harbour.

source_material:
Waves surged to 9 and 10 feet during night of May 23/24 and morning of May 24 at Tutukaka and Ngunguru. A cottage (J Main’s), situated low on the foreshore opposite the Ngunguru Hall was inundated and five rooms inundated at 0530 May 24. Occupant awakened by terrific noise, found water one foot deep over the veranda, which edges the beach. The water entered cottage, saturating the carpets. Veranda further inundated from 5.30 till 8 a.m. Veranda not “completely covered” by tide in 27 years. Water roared, only half-tide at time. NOTE: Photograph available (Northern Advocate (Whangarei) 24 May 1960); Water surged through 5 room cottage to 1 ft deep.(NZ Herald May 25 1960)
PHOTO CAPTION: The scene on Mr Jim Main’s veranda at Ngunguru this morning. Water swept over the veranda into the house at 5.30 a.m., inundating five rooms. The carpet was taken outside to dry, and household furniture was carted out so that others could help clean up the interior. Mr Main said that in his 27 years at Ngunguru this was the first time the tide had “completely covered” his veranda. (Northern Advocate (Whangarei) 24 May 1960)
discussion: See Tutukaka
obs_damage: Cottage inundated to 0.3 m depth, contents damaged

source_material: Water rose in swells 3 ft high in the Town Basin at Whangarei. No damage was done to moored boats. (Northern Advocate (Whangarei) 24 May 1960); Rise and fall of 5 ft in Whangarei Harbour evening of May 23, when the main wave first struck. (Northland Age (Kaitaia) 24 May 1960); On May 26, the tide thought to be low for longer than usual, and then it seemed to rise in fits and starts. At ~1700 it surged in quite swiftly in several streams whose effect could be seen as boats moored side by side swung in different directions. On morning of May 27, the harbour was calm, though it seemed to be high tide about 0830, an hour or two too soon. (Note probably continuation of May 23 tsunami rather than second event predicted to arrive on May 26). (Northland Age (Kaitaia) 27 May 1960)
Water came over the road at Urquhart’s Bay during the night and swirled round Mr Fred Reynolds’ house at Taurikura, but no damage was reported. (Northern Advocate (Whangarei) 24 May 1960)

Noticed on the morning of May 24 that waves had come in 6-8 ft higher than normal [during the night], and whole of the beach had been covered up to the bank and the foot of the sandhills. (Northern Advocate (Whangarei) 24 May 1960)

A ‘mighty’ rush of water towards the inner harbour occurred at about 2130 May 23, followed by a sudden surge outwards like a river in flood. The occurrence was repeated at frequent intervals until 0130 May 24. At times there was no water at all under the wharf. Extra ropes were fastened to fishing boats. The rudder was smashed on one boat. Several boats on moorings in the stream were also resting on the bottom. For safety, two of the vessels left the harbour for the open sea. They found no surge at the mouth of the harbour. Two fishing boats broke their mooring ropes. By 0045 May 24, all fishing boats had left the harbour. As the water receded a horrible smell was noted. By 0130 May 24, the velocity of the rush of water had gradually moderated. One boat went under about 0230 May 24. Later it was raised; it was dismasted but not very badly damaged. Turbulent harbour waters were covered with driftwood and rubbish and the tide had a 4-5 ft ‘lift’ at 0700 May 24. 8 feet of water in the harbour one minute and none the next. Said to be fortunate that disturbances occurred on the falling tide. (Rodney and Otamatea Times, Waitemata and Kaipara Gazette (Warkworth) 25 May 1960); At Leigh, the water dropped eight feet in a few minutes. Boats on harbour moorings drifted away but none has been reported damaged. (Northern Advocate (Whangarei) 24 May 1960); On May 24, “Shelter Harbour was a hazardous trap of swift-running, ever-changing currents and settlers on the north shore risked their lives in rowing dinghies across to the township. An alternative track was at times under water and the supports of a frail bridge were washed away”. After a 4 ft surge swept up and down Leigh harbour, 6 fishing boats were either hauled up or taken to the safer anchorage of Whangateau (Northern Advocate (Whangarei) 25 May 1960); Surging began at about 21.30 May 23 and could be clearly heard 150 m from the shore. Surging grew steadily worse, and boat owners warned to look at their moorings. Fishing boats went to sea. Boats in the harbour bumped on the bottom. At 23.30 when tide at lowest ebb, surging started to abate. (NZ Herald May 24 1960) Narrow track to homes along edge of Leigh harbour inundated by several feet of water several times and track bridge damaged. Boats removed to safer place after a 4 ft surge up Leigh harbour. (NZ Herald May 25 1960)
obs_damage: boats damaged, small bridge on track damaged

source_material: Waves surged across roads at Tryphena late pm May 24. (NZ Herald May 25 1960)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), LW at 23:51 May 23 NZST (-0.72), HW at 18:33 (0.83) May 24 NZST at Tryphena. Roads assummed to be at least 1.2 m above HWS (~0.9 m above MSL), i.e. if inundation aoccurred at high tide, water elevation may only be a little over 1.2 m. Given that large waves occurred elsewhere on the night of May 23, heights on May 24 are a minimum.

source_material: Disturbances experienced at the Ti Point wharf, but reportedly not as severe as at Leigh. Boats remained safe at moorings. (Rodney and Otamatea Times, Waitemata and Kaipara Gazette (Warkworth) 25 May 1960)

Disturbances occurred along the Mahurangi coastline on May 24 ‘in between tides’. Several launches dragged their moorings or broke away from them at the Sandspit shortly after 1200 May 24. Mahurangi River was disturbed on the night of May 23/24, with at least one launch found broken away from its mooring. On afternoon of May 24, Mahurangi River experienced “several tides”; i.e. several swirling inrushes of water, which after a period of some 20 minutes, flowed out again just as rapidly. The turbulence of the water stirred up the mud and silt deposits and small fish, including sprats and tiny flounders, were stranded. (Rodney and Otamatea Times, Waitemata and Kaipara Gazette (Warkworth) 25 May 1960)
obs_damage: boats dragged moorings or set adrift, fish stranded.

source_material: Water bubbled in whirlpools. (NZ Herald May 25 1960)
Three waves swept inland, flooding paddocks [during night of 23-24 May]. Each time the sea receded to the low-water mark. (NZ Herald 24 May 1960)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), LW at 23:36 May 23 NZST (-0.67), LW_HW range ~1.4-1.6 m at Kennedy Bay. Assume paddocks at least 1.2 m above HW.

source_material: Phenomenal tides experienced as a result of the tidal wave. "The tide was seen to go out at 4ft 6in and then came in and out again several times." No damage reported. (Coromandel and Mercury Bay Gazette (Whitianga) Wednesday 1 June 1960)
Sandbanks in Mercury Cove exposed where deep water existed minutes before. (NZ Herald May 25 1960)

Most boats in the Harbour broke away from moorings at about 2100 May 23 when surges swept Buffalo Beach and the Whitianga Harbour. The effect was of a very high and very low tide at half-hourly intervals throughout the night of May 23/24, the water swirling like a large mill-race. Strong currents in the river. Water inundated up to 50 m beyond HWM at times. No serious damage done, with exception of one launch thrown up on the road, another thrown onshore. One launch was slightly damaged, and the telephone cable across the harbour was ripped out. Along the coast quantities of fish were lying on the highway. Much damage was done along the coastline and the beach was scoured. At 0900 May 24, conditions were still abnormal and the sea was still surging up and down the river. (Coromandel and Mercury Bay Gazette (Whitianga) 25 May 1960); Results of survey on damage caused by tsunami: Buffalo Beach badly scoured, the sand entirely removed in places, exposing patches of ballast rock left by the old sailing ships back in the kauri days. At other spots huge logs were deposited on the highway. Although many boats broke their moorings and others were carried out into the Bay with moorings still intact all were eventually recovered with little damage done. On May 24, line of debris was left up as far up as the old power house and at several other points. At times the water stood at high tide level one moment and a few minutes after had raced out to extreme low water mark. The normal ebb and flow, which covers a period of 12 hours, was completed time and again in a matter of minutes. So low was the water at times, that the remains of the wreck of the “Buffalo” and remains of the piles of the old kauri wharf were visible. Five missing dinghies were found out in the bay and several more among the mangroves well up the river. Ferry service across the river was suspended from May 24-26. Telephone communications across the river were disrupted owing to the break in the submarine cable caused by the dragging boat moorings. (Coromandel and Mercury Bay Gazette (Whitianga) Wednesday 1 June 1960); Waves on May 23-24 created huge cavities in the beach. The current on May 23 was so great that vessels with their engines steaming full speed ahead moved backwards. Every boat at the Whitianga anchorage broke their moorings in the heavy seas and the salvage vessel “Three Kings” worked throughout the night rescuing boats. The boats did not return to Whitianga until May 25. One bach on the Whitianga shoreline had its front smashed in by heavy waves and at the Blue Dolphin motor camp seas carried away timber and other building materials left on the side by a contractor. Buckets were washed away from cowsheds and six families at the northern end of Buffalo Beach were evacuated from their homes while others made hasty preparations for evacuation if the tidal forces became greater. One person almost drowned when tipped from dinghy. A fairly large rock, “snapper rock”, a favourite spot for fisherman just opposite the Whitianga Wharf disappeared. Big waves rolled in at about 1000 on May 24 and residents feared that another surge with such force would carry away the wharf. One of the huge tidal surges at Buffalo Beach unearthed the 120 years old wreck H.M.S. Buffalo yesterday. People rushed out to the wreck to search for relics but it was abandoned after about 20 minutes when the seas began to return. (Thames Star (Thames) 25 May 1960); A surge of up to 7 ft on morning of May 24. Other surges. Launches were alternately stranded and riding high at their moorings while others broke away but were recovered. (Bay of Plenty Times” May 24th, 1960); On May 24, boats broken away from moorings. No major damage, although rise was 6-8 ft above normal and 2-3 houses on beach front were flooded. (Bay of Plenty Times May 25 1960); 11 small craft swept out to sea, gardens and the airport hangar flooded, and fish left stranded on the shore road and in gardens. Sea surged through the narrow river entrance, swept over the road and flooded foreshore gardens. The aerodrome was flooded and water covered the wheels of aircraft in a hangar. Estimated that river ran out at 25 knots at one time. (Auckland Star May 24, 1960; similar in Evening Post May 24th, 1960)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), LW at 23:37 May 23 NZST (-0.66), HW at 05:43NZST (0.71), LW at 12:01 NZST (-0.79), HW at 18:20 NZST (0.71).
obs_damage: Houses ,boats, road, damaged. Coastal and seabed erosion, saltwater inundation

source_material: The disturbance began between 9 o’clock and 10.30 [general, no location specified]. Waitemata Harbour was unusually ruffled for about an hour and a half. The passenger ferry Toroa, in approaching the ferry basin at Auckland, was thrown off-course by the force of the waves.Water poured under Queen's wharf like a torrent. At 2240 (May 23) ferry Toroa caught in current and struck Devonport wharf causing minor damage to ferry. The harbourmaster’s office at Auckland reported no unusual readings on the tide gauge. (NZ Herald May 24); At 2200 (May 24) tide suddenly dropped 3 ft. "Great tide reversals" during the day (May 24). According to tide gauge records water rose and fell 2 ft 6 in. (NZ Herald May 25 1960); 10 surges of tide up to 3 ft during the night of May 23/24. No damage done (Auckland Star May 24, 1960); Abnormal wave surges up to 3 ft began between 18:00 and 19:00 May 23 and continued at irregular intervals until 9.30 May 24. No damage to shipping but many ships put out extra moorings as a precaution. A passenger ferry slightly damaged when thrown against Devonport wharf on night of May 23. Many pleasure craft in Tamaki boat harbour dragged their moorings. Incoming tide on afternoon of May 24 estimated at three times normal speed. No signs of further tidal waves. Low tide in the Auckland harbour at 12.31 p.m.[May 25] was 1¼ ft below the predicted level. (Auckland Star May 24th, 1960); Harbour was unusually ruffled for about 90 minutes on night of May 23. A passenger ferry in approaching the ferry basin at Auckland was thrown off-course. On the 10:40 pm run to Devonport the ferry was again caught in the disturbance, slewed around and struck Devonport Wharf, and was slightly damaged. There were 10 tide surges in the harbour between 18:00 May 23 and 09:30 May 24, some 3 ft high. No damage to shipping was reported. (Evening Post May 24 1960)

At about 08:00, ½ hr after predicted high tide at 07:30, water rushed out stranding barge and 2 launches laying cable from Beachlands to Howick. Sand bared for 1 mile from the beach (Auckland Star May 25 1960); At Beachlands, cable laying barge was left stranded not long after sunrise on May 25 before predicted high tide at 0730. Water receded leaving mud flats within 1/4 mile of shore within a few minutes. The barge was not refloated until late pm May 25 as surges came in and out. During one 15 minute period water rose and fell 2 feet, followed by smaller surges. (NZ Herald May 26 1960)

On May 24, fluctuations of water levels occurred at Shortland Wharf, and in the Waihou River. No serious effects recorded. Fluctuations occurred later than at Whitianga. At 0600 May 24 tide was dropping, then turned and came in. Tide was three quarters of the way out at 0745 May 24, and at an exceptionally high tide mark a ¼ hour later. In the river [Waihou?] boat in 8 ft of water grounded, then water returned as quickly as it had receded. (Thames Star (Thames) 24 May 1960); Tidal disturbances still evident on the Thames Coast on May 25. Four tides at Thames on May 24, another freak tide rising at 1400. On May 25 at 1030, ebbing tide reversed and came in again to rise about two feet, but then went straight out again. Thames fisherman have been undisturbed by the phenomena, and this morning every boat of the fleet was out fishing as usual, except one confined to port with engine trouble. Most serious result damage was the loss of two net anchors when a surging rise lifted the nets and broke the anchor bridles. Only other problems were tangled nets. (Thames Star (Thames) 24 May 1960);
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), LW at 00:07 May 24 NZST (-1.13), HW at 06:14 NZST May 24 (1.24), LW at 12:31 NZST May 24 (-1.35). Higher waves may have occurred during the night when low tide experienced. Tides are also approaching Springs level.

source_material: Pipi bank exposed by surges. (NZ Herald May 25 1960); Report of similar conditions as at Whitianga, craft seriously buffeted but no damage reported. (Coromandel and Mercury Bay Gazette (Whitianga) 25 May 1960)
Report of similar conditions as at Whitianga, craft seriously buffeted but no damage reported. (Coromandel and Mercury Bay Gazette (Whitianga) 25 May 1960)

"Widely varied fluctuations recorded" during night and morning, more obvious at Mount than 3 miles into Tauranga Harbour. Watchhouse keepers at the Mount Maunganui wharf first noticed the tidal fluctuations at 22:00 May 23. They began moderately and were followed by a surging 2 ft rise at 24:00, followed by drop of 2 ft by 01:15 rose again to the same level in the next hour; then it made a series of falls of 2 ft followed by minor fluctuations to 03:45 when it rose 3 ft. Between 03:15 and 04:30 the tide dropped 3.5 ft and between 04:30 and 05:00 fluctuations ranged up to 4.5 ft. Then tide rose and fell 2 ft every hour. According to Capt Carter, normal range in 6-hr period was 5 ft, but from 00.00-07.00 range extended over 7 ft. (Bay of Plenty Times May 24 1960)

A succession of tidal rises and falls unequalled in the memory of the harbourmaster. Tauranga Harbour Board tide gauge at the northern end of the railway wharf recorded sudden rises and falls of between 3 ft 4 in and 1 ft during night of May 23-24. The gauge was unsettled at 12:00 May 24. Considerable scouring at Sulphur Point, Tauranga Harbour (Bay of Plenty Times May 24, 1960; similar in Evening Post May 24, 1960); Tides in Tauranga harbour still irregular, but fluctuations not as large as May 24. Tide gauge at 23:30 on May 24 showed a fall of 2.5 ft in 30 min. (Bay of Plenty Times May 25, 1960); From tide gauge records: first arrival 08:23 UT 20:23 NZST May 23, Initial wave period 50 min, initial rise 0.9 m, following fall 0.3 m, max rise & Fall bgeinning at 16:13 UT May 23 04:13 NZST May 24, duration 24 min, height 1.2 m (Berkman & Symons, 1964)
tidal_records: Y, poor quality reproduced in Berkman & Symons (1964)

source_material: Surges at Maketu on May 24 reported to have speeded up erosion on the Maketu domain and carved 4-5 ft off the sea front according to Tauranga drainage engineers. More serious damage done at the Kaituna River mouth a portion of rock causeway at Ford's Cut washed away. Minor damage to temporary work at the pumping station at the end of Ford's Rd. A recording taken at the river mouth at 02:30 May 24 showed a rise to 2 ft above the normal HWM. Between 04:00 and 07:00 May 25, four peaks were recorded, 1.5 ft above the normal HWM. (Bay of Plenty Times May 25 1960); On May 23, tide rose and fell 3 times in space of 1 hour, taking 4-5 ft (deputy-engineer for the Tauranga County Council’s estimate) to 3 yds from the Maketu reserve and greatly speeding up the previous gradual erosion. Water came in much further than usual, covering a part of the reserve, and sweeping some boats in the harbour up the estuary, including one launch that had been sitting on a trailer by the edge of the water. Damage was also done to the cut forming the new mouth of the Kaituna River. Part of the rock causeway that prevents the river from following its old course to the sea was washed away and a little damage was done to the pumping station nearby. A recording taken at the mouth of the cut on afternoon of May 24 showed the ride to be two feet higher than normal full tide. (Te Puke Times (Te Puke) 27 May 1960)Little said to remain of recreation area. (NZ Herald May 25 1960)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), LW at 23:29 May 23 NZST (-0.60), HW at 05:34 NZST (0.68), LW at 11:53 NZST (-0.76), HW at 18:12 NZST (0.69).
obs_damage: Severe erosion. Minor damage to pumping station and causeway on Kaituna River.

source_material: During May 24, tide appeared to be running out faster than usual but no excessive movement apparent, and small craft moorings were not disturbed. (Bay of Plenty Times May 24, 1960); Tides erratic at the Heads on May 24. Water dropped 1 ft in 5 minutes, then rose 1.5 ft in next 5 min. (Bay of Plenty Times 25 May 1960); On May 25: at ~ 1600, the ride rose from ½ to about ¾ tide (from normal level up to knee level) in approximately 10 minutes, then receded. The groyne of rocks leading out from the sea wall toward the bar that were usually some 18in to two feet out of the water at low tide were completely covered by the rise. (Bay of Plenty Beacon (Whakatane) 27 May 1960)

Disturbances affected Opotiki over a brief period early on May 24. Small craft in the river estuary were hit by one bore which rose to a height of 5ft., but there was no damage to shore properties or installations. A launch moored in the estuary was thrown up on a silt-bank, and as the tide receded was left high and dry. A yacht was overturned, but apparently suffered no damage, and a small boat was overwhelmed by the surge and sank. Tidemarks left overnight (May 23/24) on the Opotiki waterfront suggest that there were other surges through the hours of darkness, and it was fortunate that the sea was calm. (Gisborne Herald Tuesday 24 May 1960); Several boats were cast up on the river bank. At 0700 May 24 a bore went up the river. It was 2 feet higher than the river level at the time at the Waioeka Bridge. (Crosswell, 2002)
discussion: Higher waves may have occurred during the night when low tide experienced.

source_material: According to Tolaga Bay Harbourmaster, the Tokomaru Bay-Waima road, on the sea front at northern end of Tokomaru Bay, was flooded during night/morning of May 23/24, and debris and stones were swept across the road. It was open again by morning of May 24. The strongest tidal surge occurred at about 0500 May 24, when the sea reached 8ft above the normal high water mark. The surge was accompanied by a heavy roaring sound. Ninety feet of wooden protective sea walling was broken. One dinghy was damaged. The sea reached 40 ft up Waima Creek. The greatest disturbance reportedly took place at high tide. No one was forced to evacuate their homes and no damage was done to stock [live? Or shop?]. At am May 24, surges, although decreasing, continued, reportedly at regular intervals, the “water mark was altering by about 3ft or 4ft in three-quarters of an hour”. (Gisborne Herald Tuesday 24 May 1960)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), HW at 04:52 NZST May 24 (0.6) at Tokomaru Bay. Higher surges may have occurred before 05:00 may 24 at the time of low tides
obs_damage: wooden sea wall damaged, one dinghy damaged

source_material: The proprietor of the Tolaga Bay motor camp was alerted by the pounding and surging of the sea and its hitting strongly against the breastwork at about 2030 May 23, making him wary. He was aroused at 0415 May 24 by the sound of water against the side of his cottage near one of the boundaries of the camp, on the side facing the harbour board sheds. He transferred his wife and family to higher ground within the camp. The water was up to about the level of the veranda of his cottage and it also went through his store, also on the lower level. The water was also in the cookhouse in the camping grounds. It rose and fell fairly regularly. The proprietor said that the peak of the surging appeared to be past at about 0530 May 24. The camp was flooded by the sea and also by the effects by the surge running back into the Uawa River, which rose and fell sharply during the surge periods. At the rear of the motor camp was a small creek running out into the Uawa and water rushed up this creek as the sea swept up the Uawa. When he went to work cleaning out the cookhouse in the camp this morning, Mr. Clark found that … had penetrated the … of about a … as a layer … about two … harbour … said that when low water was reached, it was as low a tide as he had seen at Tolaga Bay. According to Captain Mander, there were surges at intervals of about a quarter of an hour from about 0400 May 24, with the sea pounding up on to the beach. By about 0900 May 24 surges were easing with the receding tide. “A protective wall, made up of large trees, on the harbour side of the wharf was broken up and trees and other debris were washed up on to the road near the harbour board sheds close to the camp, the sea coming up with a rush. The surge rushed up a creek almost two miles from Tolaga Bay and flooded an orchard, dog kennels becoming awash and the dogs forced to swim until the surge receded. (Gisborne Herald Tuesday 24 May 1960)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), LW at 22:41 May 23 NZST (-0.53), HW at 04:47 May 24 NZST (0.58), LW at 11:04 May 24 NZST (-0.65), HW at 17:23 May 24 NZST (0.60).
obs_damage: Camp ground buildings flooded,severe erosion, land flooded 3 km up Uawa River

source_material: At about 2045 May 24, a truck standing on the beach at Pouawa being loaded with sand, nose-down towards the surf, was swamped. At the peak of the succession of surges, water almost filled the cab of the vehicle. When rescued on May 25, the truck was unharmed except for sand in the engine and transmission. (Gisborne Herald Tuesday 25 May 1960)

Heavy surges entered Gisborne’s rivers periodically reaching levels well above normal spring tides and, flowing out again, stripping silt banks and sand-shoals in the lower reaches. No damage was reported, other than the loss of one or two light craft swept from moorings in the rivers. Disturbances first noted in rivers at about 2030 May 23, when a 4ft bore raced up the Waimata and Taruheru Rivers with a roar. Bore described as a wall of water sweeping swiftly past, capped with foam and tossing on its crest quantities of light driftwood. The noise resembled that produced by a heavy wind squall in trees. According to one observer, the first bore was followed upstream by a swell which raised the level of river by about 5 ft. Within 15 mins the inrush of water ceased, and by 2100, the water in the river receded to below the level prior to the first bore, baring mudflats. The outflow the river was carrying a good deal of driftwood, including some heavy logs, picked up from the banks. Surges continued at approximately half-hour intervals until daylight May 24 reducing in violence. The height the water reached was evident in deposits of silt and small timber along the lower slope of the esplanades adjacent to the junction of the Waimata and Taruheru Rivers. Disturbances were more obvious in the Taruheru River than in the Waimata River. The outflow in the Taruheru was extremely fast, resembling past floods. Silt-banks in the channel in the Taruheru were heavily scoured. Similar effects occurred in the diversion cut. [Photo caption] Water poured into the shed on the fishermen’s wharf in the harbour basin, reaching a height level with the lock on the door. (Gisborne Herald Tuesday 24 May 1960) Thirty-six hours after the first effects, rivers in the Gisborne district still pulsed on morning of May 25. Rivers were heavily charged with silt. Far beyond the normal range of tidal flow, the banks of rivers and streams displayed depth-marks at unusual levels, and their beds were scoured, revealing timber and other debris long hidden from sight, but no serious bank-scouring or damage affecting the district’s communications and river-control works occurred. There was no damage to riverside property or to approaches to bridges over on the Tauheru River. Many light structures such as jetties and boatways, projecting into the river, survived the surges without damage. Others had suffered to some extent, and some riverside homes had lost jetties which floated away from insecure moorings. The effects were not considered significant compared to past floods. (Gisborne Herald Tuesday 25 May 1960)
obs_damage: Minor scouring of banks, a few jettieswashed away

source_material: A fisherman who experienced the March 1947 tsunami heard over his short wave radio warnings being issued to ships of possible unusual sea conditions, and kept watch during the night of May 23-24. He observed a low tide well below normal and a fall of about 9ft. in about a minute and a half. The sea at Tatapouri* reached the top of retaining banks, but did not spill over. (Gisborne Herald Tuesday 24 May 1960) [*Note some confusion over location – said to be at his parent’s house at Tatapouri but parent’s house was at south end of Pouawa beach in 1947. However, other accounts (where?) indicate parents moved to Tatapouri after 1947]

The disturbances were first noted by riverside residents at about 8.30 o’clock May 23, when a 4ft bore raced up the Waimata and Taruheru Rivers with a roar . At 0010 May 24, 365-ton coastal trader rose an estimated 20 ft from being grounded in shallow water in the harbour basin. Disturbances prevented ship departing on schedule. The rate of the rise and ebb said to vary considerably, sometimes going up 8 ft in 15 minutes; sometimes much faster. Peak level shown on photograph. According to fishermen, water at the fishing wharf rose 18 feet in ten minutes at about 0100 May 24, to with 1 ft of top of a harbour wall separating the harbour from the river Then the water level dropped as fast as it had risen with a roar. One observer reported that the worst rise was about 0500 May 24, when it looked as though the water was going to sweep up over the wharf. Some fishermen moved their cars out of the way. Some minor damage done to “planing” on the fisherman’s wharf, and to a launch trapped under the wharf by rising levels. At about 0800 May 24 currents powerful enough to propel large tree trunks upstream. Considerable flotsam in harbour. [Photo caption] Water poured into the shed on the fishermen’s wharf in the harbour basin, reaching a height level with the lock on the door. (Gisborne Herald Tuesday 24 May 1960); Watched by large crowds of people on the evening of May 24, water levels reached their highest in the Gisborne harbour since the surging in the Turanganui River and the harbour basin began on May 23. Although the water was above bank level at some points it did not reach the level of the wharf and the roadway skirting the Kaiti basin. When the peak was reached, the water was about 15 in. from the top of the wharf. Apart from fishing vessels which had been moved from their own wharf to berthages at the main wharves, there was no shipping in the basin at the peak tide. Late on May 24 people travelling over bridges spanning the Taruheru River heard hear a roar from the receding water. The Turanganui river looked to be well up at 0800 May 25, but later in the morning it appeared to be back to normal. The underground conveyors used in bringing frozen meat from low level chambers up to the lighters at the Gisborne Refrigerating Company were immobilised by the surging waters. Electric motors driving the conveyors were saturated and gratings were clogged with debris. Some departments at the freezing works were immobilised when suction pumps drawing water from the river, sluicing equipment and other equipment were put out of action. At high tide on evening of May 24 water level was 2 ft above normal, remained at its peak for about 20 minutes, and then surged quickly seawards again. At about 1715 May 24 there was some evidence of spill-over in the Taruheru river on to low-lying riverside sections. Water was only about 1ft. from deck level of the Botanical Gardens footbridge. Water swept into the premises of J. Wattie Canneries, Limited, near the junction of the Waikanae Creek and the Turanganui River, but only floor level was reached and there was no interruption to production. At 1730 May 24 a small footbridge over the Waikanae Stream, near the factory, was under water. (Gisborne Herald Tuesday 25 May 1960) At 2000 May 23, 1960, a 3 foot bore was observed coming up the channel, and a similar bore again at 2200 During the night of May 23-24 the period of rise and fall was about 20 minutes. Initial range was 12-14 feet and later diminished to 4 feet on May 24. Fluctuations continued through May 25 and tides returned to normal late on May 26. (Berkman & Symons, 1964).
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), LW at 22:34 May 23 NZST (-0.53), HW at 04:40 NZST (0.57), LW at 10:57NZST (-0.63), HW at 17:15 NZST (0.59) NZST May 24.

source_material: A small yacht [shown in photograph] that had been moored off the beach was washed up on Kaiti Beach during night of May 23/24. (Gisborne Herald Tuesday 24 May 1960); The surging sea covered the Kaiti Beach road with water at intervals and left debris on the roadway. (Gisborne Herald Tuesday 25 May 1960); See Gisborne, Port also.
Water reached the foot of sandhills on morning of May 24, but there were no reports of any scouring or of any excessive surging by the sea. (Gisborne Herald 24 May 1960)

Slight stock losses were reported from some properties and a road running down to the Muriwai side of the Waipaoa River was reported to be under water on May 24. The level of the Waipaoa River in the vicinity of the large railway bridge at 1700 yesterday was reported to be about 2ft. above normal. (Gisborne Herald Tuesday 25 May 1960)

Very little, if anything unusual occurred along the coast line at the Wairoa Heads at any time on May 24, unless it occurred during the night around 4 a.m. Nothing abnormal was noticed in the flow of the river, and Whakamahi Beach unlikely to be affected because high waves would be needed to overtop coastal banks/dunes. (Wairoa Star (Wairoa) 25 May 1960); The effect of the tidal wave was not seen in Wairoa. The river levels were reported this morning to be normal. (Daily Telegraph 24 May 1960)
As at morning of May 24, no disturbances seen at New Plymouth Port. (Taranaki Herald (New Plymouth) 24 May 1960)
Nothing unusual occurred along beaches in the locality on the morning of May 24. (Gisborne Herald Tuesday 24 May 1960)
Surging of the sea was noticeable. (Daily Telegraph 24 May 1960)

A series of surges, the largest at 02:15 May 24, swept into the Ahuriri channel and Scapa Flow boat harbour, creating havoc among the boatsheds and pleasure craft in the tidal basin and smashing a 50-yard gap in the 100-yard-long footbridge giving access to West Shore. The waves were said to build up before they boiled through into Scapa Flow boat harbour. The backwash wrenched dozens of small craft from moorings and swept them down the channel and out to sea. After sweeping through the Scapa Flow boatshed compound of the Napier Sailing Club, the waves swirled against the embankment approach to the new west shore bridge, which was under construction. This was said to have turned the waves back and had a double effect on the boatsheds and pleasure craft. Some sheds, containing boats and gear, were lifted completely off their foundations and hurled against other sheds. Old boilers, tanks and power poles were flung against the buildings, while inside the sheds boats, gear, furniture, and other material was left in chaos. The waves smashed away a 50-yard section of the old wooden footbridge on the western side of the new traffic bridge under construction. The bridge carried the gas main and telephone cables to Westshore, and these were severed when the bridge section was carried away. The waves surged across the foot bridge several feet above the decking and swept on up the Ahuriri lagoon tidal channel spreading out into a vast lake. Gear from the pleasure craft, sections of the shattered footbridge, and even small dinghies, were carried far up the channel, some beyond the main Westshore traffic bridge a mile inland. In the Scapa Flow boat harbour itself, pleasure launches dragged their moorings and craft were rammed against each other by the force of the water. Many owners of small craft went to the boating club’s grounds at daylight this morning to discover that their yachts and dinghies had been swept out to sea. High water marks on the boat sheds showed that the largest wave had swept through the area at some 10 to 15 feet above the normal high water mark. Not one boatshed in the area had escaped damage, and one building had been badly damaged when large drums of petrol had been hurled around inside as the waves swept through the building. Apart from some scraping against the breastwork, Napier’s fishing fleet trawlers berthed along West Quay were undamaged. The waves surged to within a couple of feet of the Meeanee Quay roadway at Westshore. Pleasure craft on the slipways on that side of the harbour were torn free and hurled high up on the beach. Fish were strewn all over the area, as well as on the decking of the old footbridge and the new traffic bridge. The Napier Sailing Club’s new rescue launch, swept away from the slipway, was located off the Bay View beach– badly holed. The open sea off Napier was lettered with floating objects early am May 24. Boats, oil drums, and wreckage bobbed several miles out to sea. First warning of a disturbance was received by the Napier Harbour Board from Gisborne where the disturbance prevented the departure of a ship. The first indication at Napier was a minor fluctuation of the tide about one foot shortly after midnight. The fluctuations increased from then on until there was a maximum fluctuation of 10 feet at 2.15 a.m. On the backwash the water level went to three feet below zero on the board’s tide gauge. The sea levels were the lowest and the highest ever recorded at Napier and at the lowest low water level the remains of long sunk fishing vessels and small craft were uncovered rocks probably never been seen before were visible. The surges appeared to be at about 10-minute intervals. The sea was rushing in and out through the Ahuriri channel at the bridge site like a river in full flood. Throughout the morning the surging was taking place and the outgoing water gouged a deep channel in the silted up old inner harbour area. Another surge at 05:00 May 24 was 6 ft high in the channel, causing a car and a shed, with a man on its roof, a small distance. At 01:15 on May 24, water struck a caravan, in which three people were asleep, in the Napier Sailing Club’s grounds at Scapa Flow, filling it to chest-deep in water. They had been awoken by a roar, and found water rushing past the caravan. Successive waves battered, lifted and turned the caravan. Between surges the group made their way to a nearby building (the Clubhouse) in waist deep water in the dark. Another surge arrived as they got to the clubhouse, and this lifted the building off its foundation. In one of the succeeding recessions, the group ran 50 m in water to an embankment against which water surged. (Daily Telegraph 24 May 1960; parts repeated in Central Hawke’s Bay Press (Waipukurau) 24 May 1960); Surges of varying intensity were continuing on May 25. At 7 am large surge swept into the Napier Sailing Club’s grounds at Scapa Flow, Ahuriri, and moved some boatsheds which had been lifted off their foundations during May 24’s waves. Gas, water and telephone services to Westshore – severed when a section of the footbridge was swept away on May 24 were restored by May 25. (Central Hawke’s Bay Press (Waipukurau) 25 May 1960)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), LW at 22:14 May 23 NZST (-0.56), HW at 04:19 NZST (0.59), LW at 10:35 NZST (-0.66), HW at 16:53 NZST (0.63), and LW at 23:02 NZST May 24.
obs_damage: Gas & water main severed, bridge damaged, boats washed away, boats damaged, boatsheds damaged/moved

source_material: Eight people (Maori; 5 adults, 2 children) asleep in their tents near the shore were swept out of their tents and up against a fence at Te Awanga camping ground (Burden's) when the tidal wave struck along a half mile front at 2.30 a.m.The first wave was followed by two smaller waves. Dinghies were tossed across the waterfront roadway, a launch moored on the foreshore at the bottom of the camping ground was washed out to sea, and seaside cabins were battered and gardens along the waterfront littered with driftwood. The party in the camping ground later recovered most of their possessions. The affected area stretched from a small bridge across the western end of the lagoon to a short distance on the eastern side of the Maraetotara stream. The approaches at each end of the bridge were completely washed out. Mr P.M. Burden’s camping ground close to the sea was one of the worst affected areas. Three acres of land were still under water on morning of May 24. A dog was drowned. (Daily Telegraph 24 May 1960; similar information in PA reports in Auckland Star May 24 1960, Evening Post May 24 1960 and prob. other newspapers); Waves that struck Te Awanga along a half-mile front on the morning of May 24 swept eight Maoris out of their tents, and washed them up against a fence, which was falttened, tossed dinghies across the waterfront roadway, washed a launch out to sea, battered seaside cabins and left a letter of driftwood in gardens along the waterfront. The first wave swept in at about 2.30 a.m. and was followed by two smaller waves.The area affected was from the small bridge across the western end of the lagoon to a short distance on the eastern side of the Maraetotara Stream. The approaches at each end of the bridge were completely gouged out. Several small boats moored in the lagoon were flung on to Wellwood Terrace and one dinghy was left against the front fence of one of the houses. The water surged up two side streets leading off Wellwood Terrace. It left driftwood 50 yards along Leyland Road. One of the worst affected areas was Mr. P. M. Burden’s camping ground, close to the sea. Three acres of land were still under water am May 24. A launch that was moored on the foreshore at the bottom of the camping ground, apparently washed out to sea. A five-ton truck on the camping ground was shifted 10 feet. A dog which was chained up, was found dead. (Central Hawke’s Bay Press (Waipukurau) 24 May 1960)
obs_damage: boats damaged or lost, bridge approaches damaged, houses damaged

source_material: The waves swept across the Clifton Domain early on morning of 24 May and entered the house of the Domain caretaker. The caretaker heard a noise like a high wind blowing during the night, but it was not until morning morning that he found that water had entered his house. It was fortunate that it was the off-season for campers and that the domain was empty, for the waves came in with such force that fence-posts in a protective fence on the seaward side of Mr Stanley’s house, which is about 10 feet above sea level, were broken off at ground level. (Daily Telegraph 24 May 1960)

Earlier this week” [i.e. May 24-25] harbour level fluctuations of up to 18 inches, occurred. At 1000 on May 25 at scheduled high water peak, the level on the wharf side gauge was 7ft 9in.
Twenty minutes later, when the ebb should have been running, the level had surged to 9ft 7in.Then, it dropped away quickly. (Wanganui Herald 26 May 1960)

Inquiries made Porangahau and Pourerere, revealed that although high seas were running early on morning of May 24, there was no damage. Many residents were unaware of the tidal waves until radio broadcasts were heard. (Central Hawke’s Bay Press (Waipukurau) 24 May 1960)

No coastal disturbances were reported at Porangahau or Herbertville up to morning of May 24. People living near the beach at Porangahau said there was nothing unusual about the behaviour of the tides there on morning of May 24. (Evening News (Dannevirke) 24 May 1960); Inquiries made Porangahau and Pourerere, revealed that although high seas were running early on morning of May 24, there was no damage. Many residents were unaware of the tidal waves until radio broadcasts were heard. (Central Hawke’s Bay Press (Waipukurau) 24 May 1960)
Residents at Foxton and Himatangi beaches noticed nothing unusual in wave patterns or tide movements during May 24. (Wairarapa Times-Age (Masterton) 25 May 1960)
Residents at Foxton and Himatangi beaches noticed nothing unusual in wave patterns or tide movements during May 24. (Wairarapa Times-Age (Masterton) 25 May 1960)

No coastal disturbances were reported at Porangahau or Herbertville up to morning of May 24. At Herbertville the sea was reported to be calming after southerly winds on May 23. (Evening News (Dannevirke) 24 May 1960)

An exceptionally high tide occurred at Castlepoint on morning of May 24. The water rose up to 3 feet and came up around the footbridge in the lagoon, followed by sea rising and falling at half-hourly intervals with an even, barely-perceptible motion. Reportedly, the sea did not rise high enough to cause damage to property on the coast in the Riversdale-Castlepoint area.. (Wairarapa Times-Age (Masterton) 25 May 1960); Lighthouse keepers at Castlepoint and Cape Palliser on May 24 noted a wave pattern of a long slow wave sweeping in at half-hourly intervals all day and raising the water level about two feet. The sea was fairly calm. (Dominion 25 May 1960); See also Orui Station and Riversdale.
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), LW at 21:53 May 23 NZST (-0.54), HW at 03:58 NZST (0.56), LW at 10:13NZST (-0.62), HW at 16:31 NZST (0.60).

source_material: 1960 Tsunami - was recorded in Hokitika by "the tide coming in and out 3 to 4 times in an hour up to 3 feet above the normal level". (Unknown, recollection by a local resident who now lives in CHCH given to J. Goff, 2004.)

Sea very low at” lunch time” but within a very short time it had risen and was again high up the beach. (Wairarapa Times-Age (Masterton) 25 May 1960) (Wairarapa Times-Age (Masterton) 25 May 1960); See also Riversdale

“A tremendous sea” reported on May 25, the sea was rising several feet higher than usual and then receding out beyond the usual low tide mark. This movement was first noticed morning of May 24 when the sea swept high up the beach from an exceptionally high tide. At 1200 May 24 the sea receded to far beyond the low water level. Reportedly, the sea did not rise high enough to cause damage to property on the coast in the Riversdale-Castlepoint area. (Wairarapa Times-Age (Masterton) 25 May 1960). See also Orui Station.

Unusual tidal occurrences experienced. At 0600 on May 24 the tide was flooding at the port and would normally have continued to run in until 0900, but at about 0700 the flood stopped and the tide remained constant for half an hour before flowing in again. The gauge then showed a foot higher than the expected high-water peak at 0900. The tide turned suddenly at 0900 and reached an ebb flow of about five knots compared with the usual run of between one and two knots. At 0930 the ebb flow stopped and an inward surge began for half an hour. Fluctuations of ebb and flow continued at half-hourly intervals until conditions returned to normal at 1500. There were some further fluctuations but by 2030 May 24 conditions appeared to return to normal. Shipping at the port was not affected. (Nelson Evening Mail 26 May 1960)

The fluctuating tides stranded a number of herrings on the beach at Paremata evening of May 24, but they were quickly reclaimed by the sea. A local resident reported herrings had been left by two of four tides between 8.30 and 9.30 . The last tide swept the fish back into the sea. (Dominion 25 May 1960)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), HW at 21:51May 24 NZST (0.55). Fish deposited near time of high tide.

placename: Tory Channel: near whaling factory (location unknown)
source_material: At ~1330 on May 24, water level receded about leaving craft moored in shallow water stranded, the sea level returning to normal 5 minutes later.. In a matter of five minutes the vessel was floating again, with the level of the sea back to normal. The sea level dropped three or four times at intervals of five to seven minutes. (Marlborough Express 25 May 1960)

Unusual tidal conditions recorded on the Harbour Board’s gauge at Port Nelson early on morning of May 24. A rise of 14 inches was marked on the 24-hour chart at 0245, 45 minutes before low water. Between the sudden rise at 0245 and low water the tide gauge showed a fall at 2ft 6in. The rise on the chart was then marked by uneven recordings which indicated the generally disturbed state of the tides. (Nelson Evening Mail 24 May 1960); The line on the tidal graph automatically recorded in the office of the harbourmaster, Captain R. Murphy, at Port Nelson followed a zig zag pattern over the 24 hours May 24/25, still continuing unsteady up to mid-afternoon of May 25. The peak was at 0245 May 24 when a rise of 14 inches was recorded. At one stage on an outgoing tide on May 24 there was a sudden change from the ebb to an inward surge, running at between four and five knots. This continued for nearly an hour before the normal tide pattern resumed. No trouble experienced with vessels. (Nelson Evening Mail 25 May 1960)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), HW at 20:42 May 23 NZST (1.39), LW at 02:50 NZST (-1.36), HW at 08:58 NZST (1.43), LW at 15:09 NZST (-1.51).

source_material: Violent fluctuations of the tide during night of May 23 and morning of May 24. Wellington Harbour Board tide gauge recorded its lowest ever sea level, followed by a rise of nearly 6ft in 1.5 hrs before midnight. Fortunately, the violent fluctuations in the sea level occurred during the low tide period. One rise brought the level up to normal high-tide level during the low-tide period. Crews put on standby. The tide fell 1ft 9in below the MLWM. LW expected at 21:36 May 23 last night, but rise started from about 20:00 for one hour; level fell by 4ft in ¾ hr to record low, 3in below the previous record taken in 1903. The tide then rose by 5.5 ft in 1 hr to reach 9in above MHWM at a time when it should have been just starting to flood after low tide. The gauge was still fluctuating up about one or two feet and then down again each hour before 12:00 on May 24. Sea failed to reach top of the wharves, despite reports to contrary. The lowest Wellington wharf, Glasgow Wharf, was 6ft above normal high tides, and as the fluctuation occurred at low tide in the harbour there had been a good clearance above the highest sea level on May 23. Diagram: The effect of the Chilean earthquake on tidal records of Wellington Harbour last night is shown by this Harbour Board tide graph. At bottom are normal low and high tides. The shaky, jagged line shows the abnormal tidal fluctuations caused by waves which sped at up to 500mph from Chile to Wellington throughout yesterday. Horizontal figures are feet, and vertical figures hours. (Evening Post May 24, 1960); Wellington tide gauge at the Wellington Harbour Board is still fluctuating hourly [i.e. on May 27], at surges of up to one foot. On Monday [May 24], 12 hours after the earthquake at Chile, the lowest tide ever at Wellington was recorded, being a depth of 1.9ft below mean water. (Evening Post May 27, 1960); From tide gauge records: first arrival 07:45 UT 19:45 NZST May 23, Initial wave period 28 min, initial rise 1.5 ft [0.45 m], following fall 1 ft [0.3 m], max rise beginning at 10:24 UT May 23 22:24 NZST May 23, duration 20 min, height 3.1 ft [ 0.95 m] (Berkman & Symons, 1964)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), LW at 21:21 May 23 NZST (-0.40), HW at 03:25 NZST (0.41), LW at 09:39 NZST (-0.43), HW at 15:59 NZST (0.44). According to LINZ website, MHWS 0.71 m , MLWS -0.6 m, MHWN 0.38 m MLWN -0.37 m HAT 0.77 LAT -0.71 (all relative to MSL). No damage as tsunami largest fluctuations and peak level at low tide. Recommend that tide gauge record is digitised as rises and falls have been read by eye by Berkman & Symons (1964) without subtraction of tidal variation, and without attempting to differentiate between zero-peak and peak-to-peak measurements, and effective peak-to peak (which gives a peak-peak closer to 1.7 m, as recorded in database)..
tidal_records: Y, poor quality reproduced in Berkman & Symons (1964)
obs_photographs: Photograph of tide gauge record in paper available at LINZ? In Berkman & Symons

source_material: Sea disturbances not so marked as in other areas. It was noticeable during low tide on May 25, when the water receded a considerable distance from the foreshore. (Marlborough Express 26 May 1960)

Unusual tidal behaviour reported. Level of the sea at times during few days prior to May 26 was at least five feet higher than usual between tides. On many occasions there was a sudden ebb and the water level became very low, revealing rocks that residents had not previously known about. (Marlborough Express 26 May 1960)

Seas higher than in recorded memory of Lake Ferry Hotel licensee. At low tide the sea was higher than the usual high tide level and at high tide waves washed over the spit, this never having been seen before. [time of the above not noted]. The sea rose and fell calmly since morning of May 24 but on May 25 sea became rough with very high rollers and waves breaking over the Spit, despite light northerly conditions [on May 25]. (Wairarapa Times-Age (Masterton) 25 May 1960)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), LW at 21:34 May 23 NZST (-0.53), HW at 03:39 NZST (0.54), LW at 09:52 NZST (-0.60), HW at 16:11 NZST (0.59). Given timing of strong effects at low tide in Wellington before midnight on May 23,the first description in this extract probably refers to May 23, ie the peak to trough from LW to above HW.

source_material: A log, not previously seen was found “well above spring tide level” on the beach on morning of May 24 – local resident assumed it was deposited overnight. A considerable swell would have been required to deposit it where it was found. No damage reported in Marlborough Region up to morning of May 24. (Marlborough Express (Blenheim) 24 May 1960); A sudden surge travelled up the Wairau River for some distance between 1500 and 1600 on May 24, carrying a dinghy which had been left well up above high water mark out into the river. The surge rose in about 15 minutes. (Marlborough Express 25 May 1960); Between 1600 and 2015 on May 25, at least tour “high” tides were recorded. The sea surged from 12 to 15 inches – the gauge one minute would read 4ft 3in and 10 minutes later would show a reading 12 inches lower only to rise again in a further 10 minutes. The normal high tide reading is 4ft 3ins.The sea conditions seemed to have settled back to normal on morning of May 26. (Marlborough Express 26 May 1960)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), LW at 22:48 May 23 NZST (-0.39), HW at 04:52 NZST (0.41), LW at 11:07 NZST (-0.48), HW at 17:30 NZST (0.48). At Port Underwood and at Cape Campbell, to east and west of Wairau, MHWS is 0.6 m above MSL. It is not unreasonable to expect, strong effects at the Wairau Bar at a similar time as thiose in Wellington, ie 21:30-24:00 on May 23 when low tide also occurred at Wairau Bar. Max height reached at the limit of inundation relative to expected sea level at time (m) is LW-HWS (1 m) plus 1-1.5 m on top of this

source_material: Surging seas washed up three whales, 20 feet long, washed up on night of May 24/25 [differs from other accounts] at Ngawi, just west of the Cape Palliser lighthouse. (Wairarapa Times-Age (Masterton) 25 May 1960); Stranding of whales May 25 not attributed to surges by Museum director. ((Wairarapa Times-Age (Masterton) 27 May 1960);

Lighthouse keepers at Castlepoint and Cape Palliser yesterday noted a wave pattern of a long slow wave sweeping in at half-hourly intervals all day and raising the water level about two feet. The sea was fairly calm. (Dominion 25 May 1960)
Nothing exceptional noticed in tide levels during night of May 23/24. (Marlborough Express 24 May 1960); Seas were normal at Cape Campbell on May 26. (Marlborough Express 26 May 1960)

The tidal disturbance that set in along the Marlborough east coast early on morning of May 24 and continued throughout most of the day, with exceptional variations in the level of the sea at high and low tides, moderated by evening of May 24. On May 25, all areas along the coast reported near-normal conditions. . (Marlborough Express 25 May 1960) {Taken from Blenheim] Nothing exceptional noticed in tide levels during night of May 23/24. (Marlborough Express 24 May 1960); On May 26[?, possibly May 25] very high seas reported to be equivalent to those running in a strong southerly. (Marlborough Express 26 May 1960)

Unusual tidal behaviour reported on morning of May 24. There was no heavy sea – just a “boiling effect” with water surging in and out among the rocks. During night of May 23/24, tide believed to have been much higher than usual, as all the driftwood and kelp had been washed away. For about 2 ½ hours from 10.30 on May 24, sea was disturbed with four or five abnormal low tides. At the wharf the level dropped so low that rocks which had never been seen before broke through the surface. At about 0830 floats left on a landing four feet above water were found floating shortly afterwards. There were no waves – just a phenomenal surge. The sea around the wharf and the rocks nearby was “turbulent. (Marlborough Express 24 May 1960; A big surge over the lighthouse reef was observed between 1330 and 1400 on May 26 – assumed by local resident to be tail end of main event not the event for which a warning was given on May 26. (Kaikoura Star (Kaikoura) 30 May 1960); Conditions almost back to normal on May 25. The high tide pm on May 24 reached a higher level than spring tide, and within half an hour it dropped by about six feet. There were still small fluctuations in the tide on morning of May 25. (Marlborough Express 25 May 1960)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), LW at 21:25 May 23 NZST (-0.58), HW at 03:30 NZST (0.59), LW at 09:43 NZST (-0.66), HW at 16:02 NZST (0.65). At Kaikoura, MHWS is 0.7 m above MSL. Too little detailed information on timing and height of maximum effects to attempt reliable entries in database. Given effects around Christchurch and in the southern North island, maximum probably occurred at low to mid tide.

source_material: Water lay around the cottages adjoining Saltwater creek, and near the floodgate traffic had to pass through 12 in of water on the roads for a distance of several chains. (The Press (Christchurch) 25 May 1960)
discussion: See tides for Kaiapoi
obs_damage: road flooded with 0.3 m water, houses surrounded with water

source_material: The stick gauge at the Cam bridge near the woollen mills registered almost 3ft above sea level [expected at the time? or mean sea level?] at about 0015 May 24. It was estimated that the greatest height of the tidal bore had not exceeded four feet. (The Press (Christchurch) 24 May 1960); Five high waters occurred at Kaiapoi before 1800 May 24. The river ran high throughout the day and a wave 4 ft in height swept up the river at about 1500 May 24, when the pilot launch was lifted on to the beach and remained stranded until the afternoon high tide (expected at 1550) lifted it off. A particularly high tide occurred after the normal afternoon tide. The normal tide reached its peak at 1550, ebbed and started to come in again at 1615, reaching a level of 3 ft above the normal spring high tide mark at 1645. At 1715, the level of the Cam river measured at the gauge stick near the Kaiapoi mills was 6-7ft, said to be 2ft 6in above what could be expected from a normal spring high tide. (The Press (Christchurch) 25 May 1960);
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), LW at 21:10 May 23 NZST (-0.74), HW at 03:14 NZST (0.77), LW at 09:28 NZST (-0.86), HW at 15:46 NZST (0.82) off shore from the Waimakariri River.

source_material: At the Kairaki camping grounds water lapped at the stopbanks and council employees sandbagged the banks at 16:30 May 24. It had reached a height of nearly 3ft above normal. This had not been seen previously. (The Press (Christchurch) 25 May 1960);
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), LW at 21:10 May 23 NZST (-0.74), HW at 03:14 NZST (0.77), LW at 09:28 NZST (-0.86), HW at 15:46 NZST (0.82) off shore from the Waimakariri River.

placename: Spencer Park, estuary of Waimakarir River [Default location: Spencerville]
source_material: Water reached at the gates of Spencer Park in the early hours of May 24, after travelling almost half a mile up the road from the beach. The sea, which came up through the mudflats on the left-hand side of the park may have been in the trees at the back of the park, but the park was not covered by water. (The Press (Christchurch) 25 May 1960);
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), LW at 21:10 May 23 NZST (-0.74), HW at 03:14 NZST (0.77), LW at 09:28 NZST (-0.86), HW at 15:46 NZST (0.82) off shore from the Waimakariri River. Inundation occurred early am when near mid-tide, tide level at about MSL.

source_material: During the early am May 24, the water rose about two to three feet above normal at the Opawa bridge. Near the Heathcote bridge water ran swiftly and was expected to rise even higher by high tide. Water almost reached the decking opposite the Mount Pleasant store. (The Press (Christchurch) 24 May 1960)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), LW at 21:08 May 23 NZST (-0.75), HW at 03:12 NZST (0.75), LW at 09:26 NZST (-0.87), HW at 15:44 NZST (0.84). If the peak at Ferrymead occurred within an hour or two of the peaks at the entrance to the estuary, i.e. between 00:00 and 01:00 then the tide was not above mid-tide level.If it was later than 01:00, then the tide would be somehat higher. Whatever the time, it is reasonable to infer the 2-3 ft above normal that was observed was relative to high tide mark, otherwise it would not be remarkable.

source_material: Two waves, the first about 23:10 May 23 and the second at 23:40. rushed across the bar at Shag Rock and into the Christchurch Yacht Club pavilion [at Moncks Bay], sweeping several boats adrift and carrying two dinghies on to the Main road. This was the only part of Sumner and Redcliffs where the water came over the sea wall. An 18ft cabin cruiser moored off Beachville road, Redcliffs, was overturned and damaged by the first wave. At least five dinghies and a yacht came adrift at the Yacht Club, sweeping out at high speed over the bar as the waves receded. At Shag Rock the waves were about 12ft high, but because the tide was only half in at the time they did not reach the road. The water reached halfway up the window of the lifeboat shed there. The waves dashed against the sea wall at Sumner, but retreated without breaking over the top, leaving the beach covered in white scum. At Scarborough the water reached boats on the slips but did not disturb them. Half an hour after the first wave the water began to recede from the Estuary and in a few minutes it began to race past Shag Rock at a speed estimated at more than 10 knots. Residents of Beachville road said that at half tide, the height of the water in the Estuary was similar to full tide. [Note photos of water level changes in paper.] The sea crossed the main road at Moncks Bay and debris was deposited high on the foreshore. Resident at 6 Cliff street, Moncks Bay, estimated the rise in water level to be 17 feet. Early am May 24 tide rose and fell continually in swift fashion—about five feet in five minutes. At 0200 violent surges of water covered the road behind the boat shed and bigger surges to a depth of two feet could be seen on the far side of the main road near Cliff Street. Earlier in the night many of the smaller craft at the boatshed had been severely damaged. Between the Sumner lifeboat shed and Shag rock the incoming waves were producing spectacular crests and were beginning to slap across the road, accompanied by a steady roar. The worst effect occurred at 0239. when the water entered beachside gardens. At 0315 May 24, the Main Road, Bayview road, Wakatu Street and Cliff Street had extensive surface flooding. Several houses in Cliff Street were surrounded by water. The tide was still rising and falling rapidly. At 0300 water was flowing on to the south end of Rocking Horse road but did not reach houses. (The Press (Christchurch) 24 May 1960)(The Press (Christchurch) 24 May 1960); About 30 small yachts and dinghies from the Estuary and sheds and slipways in Lyttelton were swept to sea and damaged. A churning torrent of white-capped sea water raced up the Estuary at 15 miles an hour on afternoon of May 24, climaxing several hours of uncanny tidal phenomena. The peak at 1600, within eight inches of the top of the Redcliff’s sea wall protecting the Christchurch-Lyttelton highway, was below that of the high tide in the early hours of May 24. The water was above road surface on the seaward side but only a little seeped through into stormwater channels. When the sea was on the make in the final minutes before the predicted high tide the Estuary between Redcliffs and Brighton spit had the appearance of the Waimakariri river in full summer flood. The top rate of speed—15 miles an hour—was measured by a motorist driving along Beachville road keeping pace with debris being tossed along in the spate. Freak tidal movements in the early hours of May 24 scoured an abnormally deep channel past Shag Rock and through the Sumner bar at the mouth of the Estuary and at low tide time the level was a good four feet below the normal mark. The disturbances left a mess of smelling foam and scum, debris of small stones and sticks and sea lettuce thrown by the sea on foreshore roadways from Mount Pleasant to Clifton beach. At 06:00 May 24 boards that had come from the building works at the Christchurch Yacht Club’s pavilion in Moncks Bay were found between the hill end of Moncks Bay and Whakatu Avenue .The sea came right across the roadway at the Clifton side of Cave Rock in the morning of May 24, but the sea wall from Cave rock to Scarborough to the east was not topped by either the surging waters or grey scum and debris which it deposited against it on the seaward side. Landward, the newly-laid lawns, the earth gardens and autumn plants were untouched. The rises at Shag Rock during evening of May 24 varied from one to four feet and took place within seconds. (The Press (Christchurch) 25 May 1960)
