discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), LW at 21:08 May 23 NZST (-0.75), HW at 03:12 NZST (0.75), LW at 09:26 NZST (-0.87), HW at 15:44 NZST (0.84) at New Brighton. Inundation levels assumed to be same as at Moncks Bay.

obs_damage: ~500 m length of road inundated, gardens flooded, boats washed away and damaged

source_material: Access to more than 20 holiday cottages and a caravan at Taylor’s Mistake was cut off when the wooden footbridge leading over the creek to the holiday cottages area on the east side of the bay was torn from its concrete foundations. None of the cottages was inundated, but water lapped a permanently occupied residence protected by a 5 ft wall [uncertain if it topped wall], but no damage reported. The Taylor’s Mistake Surf Life-saving Club’s pavilion was surrounded by water. (The Press (Christchurch) 25 May 1960);
obs_damage: Bridge damaged, inundation of housing area

source_material: The disturbance was first noticed about 2200, when the water first fell eight feet below zero on the tide gauge and then rose to eight feet above the normal high tide mark. Although several small vessels grounded, no damage was apparent on evening of May 23 [up to 0350 May 23] The Harbour Board’s two tugs, the grab dredge Te Whaka a passenger launch, most of the trawlers, and some yachts were also aground. The water rose to deck level of Gladstone Pier, and covered the low level breastwork. It topped the caisson at the dock and spilled into the dock without however, disturbing the coastal vessel Parere, which is in dock. Because the water was reaching the electric mains under the wharves all power was switched off on the waterfront. Ships at the wharves, all of moderate draft, did not touch the bottom. The ship Persie (13,000 tons) which arrived was ordered to sea by the harbourmaster about 2300 May 23 as a precaution. Inspection during night of May 23/24 indicated there was no serious damage to new harbour works. At 0245 May 24. an hour before predicted high tide, the surging tides had lessened to a considerable degree. . (The Press (Christchurch) 24 May 1960); At 1600 May 24, 17 hrs after first waves, another surge swept in pouring into the graving dock and sweeping over the lower breastwork beyond No. 7 wharf. It was the eighth rise and fall of the tide beyond normal spring limits since 2200 May 23, and was only 2.5 in lower than the first onrush. Although little damage was done to the eastern harbour extensions or to shipping, the efficiency of the port was reportedly seriously impaired, with water damage to the capstans on the wharves. Between the time an overseas ship was piloted into the inner harbour and reached No. 7 wharf west an hour before high tide the tide dropped 10 ft, grounding the ship at the stern for a minute or two. More than 30 small yachts and dinghies from Lyttelton, Charteris Bay and the Estuary were recovered—many of them badly damaged—during the day by trawlers and Harbour Board vessels. Between 2200 May 23 and 1600 May 24 many violent and rapid changes of tide levels were recorded. At 2245 May 23 the tide was so low that the bed of the inner harbour close to the Banks Peninsula Cruising Club’s house was exposed between “Rotten Row”. At the lowest tide on May 23 all the trawlers at the breastwork were aground, but as the tide rose the skippers and crews took them away from the wharf and all night drifted in and out with the tide in the inner harbour keeping close to the tug Lyttelton. High and low waters were recorded in the harbour every two hours. At 1200 on May 24, the water was dead low in the harbour, and 30 minutes before at the predicted high tide at 1550, the tide was again dead low. Trawlers left the wharf to avoid grounding. At 1600, a surge resulted in the fishing wharf being under water to a depth of nearly three feet in a few minutes. The lockers of members of the cruising club on the ground floor of the clubhouse were again flooded. Surges put winches on the slipway of J. Miller and Company near the dock out of action twice. Forty five of the 54 capstans, which were used for hauling railway trucks along the wharf and were located three feet below the wharf decking, were water-damaged. Some were fully under water and others were immersed to a depth of six inches. Water entered the graving dock twice within 17 hours, and a vessel was in danger of refloating, the level on the night of May 23 being 2.5 in higher than that soon after 1600 on May 24.By night of May 24, waters of the harbour were more settled. The low tide was lower than usual, but all vessels were off the bottom. Two hours later the tide was making its regular rise. Watches were kept on the waterfront by harbour board employees and most trawlers were manned in readiness for any further emergency. About 30 small yachts and dinghies from the Estuary and sheds and slipways in Lyttelton were swept to sea and damaged. (The Press (Christchurch) 25 May 1960); Although still erratic water levels at Lyttelton on May 25 were not so high or low as on May 23 and May 24, and shipping was able to enter the port. The two earliest arrivals met with some difficulty from the set of the current at the entrance to the moles. At 0500 May 25., the tide rose one foot in two minutes to a height of 5ft 3in above normal low water mark. By 0518 the tide was at normal high water level and it crept erratically up to a mark 2ft 8in above normal high, only to drop six inches in the next two minutes. (The Press (Christchurch) Thursday 26 May 1960);Water levels were still erratic on May 26. Just after 1510, the tide began an unusual flow. In half an hour, it rose five feet and then began to drop more slowly that it had risen. The peak was far below the two freakish high levels of May 24 and May 25. It was four feet below the level of the decking of the main wharves. [Note that this was after a warning had been issued of a second tsunami arriving from a major aftershock in Chile] (The Press (Christchurch) 27 May 1960); Tides at Lyttelton on May 27 were almost normal, for the first time since the night of May 23/24. (The Press (Christchurch) 28 May 1960);From tide gauge records: first arrival 08:12 UT 20:12 NZST May 23, Initial wave period 40 min, initial rise 0.4 m, following fall 0.03 m, max rise & fall not given. Reproduced tide gauge record has gaps where water level falls below zeroon the gauge and where it exceeds above max. limit of gauge; from ~10:00 and 10:45 [below zero on gauge] and 11:30-21:00 GMT May 23 (above 12 ft on gauge) [i.e. between 22:00- 22:45 and from 23:30 NZST May 23 to 09:00 NZST May 24].(Berkman & Symons, 1964)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), LW at 21:12 May 23 NZST (-0.78), HW at 03:16 NZST (0.82), LW at 09:30 NZST (-0.91), HW at 15:48 NZST (0.87). According to LINZ website, MHWS 1.09 m , MLWS -1.09 m, MHWN 0.67 m MLWN -0.68 m HAT 1.31 LAT -1.27 (all relative to MSL). Zero on the tide gauge in 1960 appears to have been LAT.
tidal_records: Y, poor quality reproduced in Berkman & Symons (1964); the levels newspapers give relative to the tide gauge are taken as tide gauge readings.
obs_first_arrival_comments: Note that this time is later than tide gauge record; most observations taken at wharf, some are relative to tide gauge levels; hence, see tide gauge readings

source_material: The underwater main that conveyed the water to Diamond Harbour from Lyttelton was fractured about 230 yards from the Diamond Harbour side, by a surge early am on May 24. (The Press (Christchurch) 25 May 1960);
discussion: See Lyttelton and other Lyttelton harbour entries for effects nearby.
obs_height_max_at-inundation_comment: Unknown, note damage & water levels at Lyttelton

source_material: Heavy stock losses occurred on low-lying inundated farm land owned by Mr Foley at Allandale. at the head of Lyttelton Harbour. As at evening of May 24, it was estimated that between 120 and 140 sheep had been drowned. Most of the sheep were carried from of the paddocks in which they were contained into another nearby property. The sheep on this property had been shifted to high ground on May 23. A stone fence near the water on Mr Foley’s land was destroyed, and the fences brought down in many places. Ditches surrounding the paddocks were covered by the water, with each successive high tide causing the water to become deeper as it could not escape down the drains. Eels and flounders were stranded in farm paddocks yesterday. [Photo of eel stranded at Teddington available] (The Press (Christchurch) 25 May 1960);
discussion: See Lyttelton and other Lyttelton harbour entries, especially Charteris Bay and Teddington, for effects nearby.
obs_height_max_at-inundation_comment: Unknown, note damage & water levels at Lyttelton
obs_damage: 120-140 sheep lost, stone and other fences damaged or destroyed, large area inundated, fish stranded

placename: Purau and Port Levy, Banks Peninsula [default location: Purau]
source_material: Properties on the waterfront at both Purau and Port Levy were damaged during surges on May 24 and 25. At Purau, part of the road was covered, and a builder’s shed on a section where a house is being erected, was overturned. At Port Levy a holiday cottage near the beach was flooded. When the tide receded from the flats at the head of Port Levy hundreds of fish mostly flounders, were left stranded. A Port Levy farmer, racing along the waterfront road in an endeavour to beat the rising water, had to abandon his utility vehicle and scramble to higher ground. (The Press (Christchurch) Thursday 26 May 1960; In the first surge on May 23 a bach on the seafront at Purau was washed inland for about one hundred yards. A surrounding 6 ft paling fence, fixed on concrete posts, was completely flattened. Most of the household effects were salvaged on May 24, but while they were drying, another wave came and washed over the section. (Christchurch Star 24 May 1960)
obs_damage: Road, several building damaged or flooded, fence damaged, fish stranded

placename: Charteris Bay, Lyttelton Harbour, Bank's Peninsula
source_material: Of the three houses at Charteris Bay that were damaged, one was lifted from its foundations and tilted to one side [photo available], another close by was also inundated and had furniture floating around in the rooms, and a third lying on low ground close to the Gebbies Pass road was inundated and surrounded still by a huge pond when the tide receded late on the afternoon of May 24. Water in the first house reached to waist level, kitchen utensils and food from the pantry floated in the front garden and the garage, with car, was half submerged. The estimated cost of damage to the car, house and property was several hundred pounds. The three houses, their contents, and gardens were also damaged with silt. Four dogs chained to their kennels at one house and two at another were lost, presumed drowned. The club house of the Charteris Bay Yacht Club house was inundated with two feet of water, and a number of small boats floated about inside. Outside other boats floated about. Many private boatsheds on the foreshore at Charteris Bay and Church Bay contained boats which were floating behind locked doors. The jetty at the club (known as Smart’s Jetty) collapsed on the afternoon of May 24. It was later recovered. (The Press (Christchurch) 25 May 1960)
discussion: See Lyttelton and other Lyttelton harbour entries for effects nearby.
obs_height_max_at-inundation_comment: Unknown, note damage & water levels at Lyttelton
obs_damage: 3 houses & other building inundated up to 1m depth, 2 dogs drowned, jetty destroyed

source_material:
Many sheep were reported drowned, mud and debris covered a large area and fences and uprights were flattened. Early am May 24 farmers attempted to evacuate sheep on to dry land 
Mud and water was reported to have entered the Teddington Hotel, as well as possibly and some houses in the vicinity. (The Press (Christchurch) 24 May 1960); The ground floor of the Wheatsheaf Hotel was flooded to a depth of three feet, furniture was floated, and the surrounding land and hotel were covered in silt. The hotel was inundated at least twice. Nearby, a cottage was also inundated during the night of May 23/24, resulting in badly damaged household contents. These were the only residences to receive damage. Repeated invasions of the tide during May 24 hampered the clean-up. With water covering it to a depth of four feet at the peak, the main road from Teddington to Charteris Bay was impassable for long periods on May 24. Several cars were trapped by the speed of the advancing tide, and some drivers had to wait more than two hours before they could take their cars through the shallow water. Some cars endeavoured to beat the tide to Teddington, but in three cases the drivers failed in the attempt and had to sit marooned while the water rose. When the tide rose high at 1610 May 24 eight vehicles were stranded on the road about three miles short of Teddington. In most cases the trouble is only water affecting the engine, but in some instances salt water is in the petrol tanks. (The Press (Christchurch) 25 May 1960); Most of the damage in the Peninsula bays on Lyttelton Harbour was concentrated at Teddington, where Mr M. J. Foley’s flat off the highway was inundated and an estimated 140 sheep drowned. A lot of the bodies were swept on to Mr W. G. Witte’s land adjoining. Mr Witte himself lost no sheep, his son, Mr Leon Witte, having moved them to higher ground the day before. The Wheatsheaf Hotel was flooded to a depth of 3ft, furniture floated about and floor coverings were ruined. Several cars were stuck on the road between Teddington and Charteris Bay. (Akaroa Mail 27 May 1960); Interviews in ~2004 with eyewitnesses indicate water reached to base of hills in valley to the west of the Wheatsheaf Hotel.
discussion: See Lyttelton and other Lyttelton harbour entries for effects nearby.
obs_height_max_at-inundation_comment: Unknown, note damage & water levels at Lyttelton
obs_damage: Livestock lost, fences damaged, cottage and hotel inundated to 0.9 m depth with contents damage, road inundated to 1.2 m depth, cars inundated

source_material: The wave struck at approximately the same time as at Okain’s Bay [0230-0300 May 24]. There had been a minor surge earlier. Soon after 0230 May 24 water inundated a home 60 yds from the seafront and flooded the grounds to a depth of 5-6 feet and the house to a depth of more than 3 feet. The impact of the water forced the solidly-built old house of one and a half storeys backwards on its foundations for a distance of four inches. On the same property, a farm shed collapsed and the side of a woolshed was damaged. Extensive damage was done to furniture and appliances in the house. At another property, a small bach was lifted off its foundations and floated 110 yards inland. (The Press (Christchurch) 25 May 1960); Heaviest personal loser was Mr Orlan Gilbert, whose house stood close to the waterfront. At about 2300 May 23, there was a heavy surge in the creek, giving some cause for alarm, but it was not the four hours later that the real trouble arrived. A wave that might have been eight feet high struck the house square on, burst its way in and shifted the building back 4in on its foundations. As the wall of water rushed between the house and the farm buildings adjacent to the creek, a shed was ripped out and left lying in the creek, while one side of the woolshed collapsed. Farm gear was scattered far and wide. Not far from Mr Gilbert’s was a 24ft x 12ft three-roomed bach, owned by Mr E. Dickie, of Christchurch. It was floated off its foundations and deposited 110 yards upstream so gently that according to one resident of the bay, a glass could be seen still standing upright on a bench. Two boats were swept out to sea, others were deposited over the bay flat or stranded in fences. Piles disappeared from under the jetty shed, and the jetty itself was estimated to have been under about 2ft of water. Some damage was done to the main bridge. The road was not washed away, the wave apparently being concentrated in the west side of the bay. (Akaroa Mail 27 May 1960); first wave at about 22:30 rushed up creek and caused alarm, but wave at 02:30 much larger and did all the damge. A number of waves after first, in which water went out to base of wharf and returned to reach toes of observers [on waterfront? 1-1.5 m above HW?] House hit by wall of water at 02:30, left splashes 8 ft high in lounge, occupants up to knees in water, but house tilted from back to back by force of wave. Floorboards split as house settled on foundations with retreat of wave. Other cottage not tied to its foundation and shed transported inland. Fence destroyed. Trees at front of house showed inundation mark at 7 ft. (Mayo recollections, 2004)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), LW at 21:12 May 23 NZST (-0.78), HW at 03:16 NZST (0.82), LW at 09:30 NZST (-0.91), HW at 15:48 NZST (0.87) at Lyttelton. According to LINZ website, MHWS 1.09 m , MLWS -1.09 m, MHWN 0.67 m MLWN -0.68 m HAT 1.31 LAT -1.27 (all relative to MSL) at Lyttelton. Tides at Little Akaloa similar, earlier by a few minutes. Maximum impact occurred near high tide - earlier wave at low tide may have been comparable. Note contrast with Lyttelton.
obs_damage: 2 houses inundated one damaged,one shifted 100 m inland, sheds and fences damaged. Boats washed away.

source_material: A wave, estimated to be between eight and 10 feet high demolished the main bridge, and burst into a house only 50 feet from the edge of the stream. The resident, who escaped in his night attire, was awakened by the roar of water about 0230 May 24 and at 0300, and in the darkness escaped to higher ground with water swirling all around him. His household effects were ruined and evidence showed that there had been a foot of water in the refrigerator. The bridge, a pile structure, crossing the stream on the road between Okains Bay and Chorlton, lost an entire set of piles while another three sets sank and allowed the centre of the bridge to drop by about 10 feet. One end of the decking tore away from the approach and canted three feet above road level. Telephone communications in the area were interrupted when the main cable supported by the bridge was severed. (The Press (Christchurch) 25 May 1960); Principal damage was to the Main Bridge, which was wrecked. One set of piles disappeared, others sagged and the centre of the bridge fell by about 10ft. One end of the structure was tilted up 3ft above the road level. Mr B. Bartrum, whose house is almost on the bank of the creek, awoke to find a foot of water in his bedroom. He got away in his night attire, and returned in the morning to find his possessions ruined. Mr W. Spurr, who lives nearby, had his house surrounded by water. A heavy bridge across the stream was turned out and dumped in a paddock some distance away. The school grounds were flooded by a depth of 8in to 9in, and fence posts were floated off. The flood topped Mr J. Harris’ bridge and the Schoolhouse Bridge and there was slight flooding round the store, where the water came through the tennis courts. (Akaroa Mail 27 May 1960)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), LW at 21:12 May 23 NZST (-0.78), HW at 03:16 NZST (0.82), LW at 09:30 NZST (-0.91), HW at 15:48 NZST (0.87) at Lyttelton. According to LINZ website, MHWS 1.09 m , MLWS -1.09 m, MHWN 0.67 m MLWN -0.68 m HAT 1.31 LAT -1.27 (all relative to MSL) at Lyttelton. Tides at Okains Bay are similar, earlier by a few minutes. Maximum impact occurred near high tide - earlier wave at low tide may have been comparable. Note contrast with Lyttelton.
obs_damage: Several bridges damaged or destroyed, house inundated, fences damaged

source_material: The approaches to the new bridge being constructed on the waterfront at Pigeon Bay were scoured out. Two boatsheds were torn off their foundations and damage was done to the jetty. (The Press (Christchurch) 25 May 1960); A boathouse was lifted bodily with its concrete foundation intact and dumped on the road. Another shed was demolished, and damage was done to the wharf, the convenience being left tilted at an angle. Water went up the bay to Mr D.C.Hay’s gate. The approaches to the new bridge were scoured out. The old bridge was completely covered by the wave. (Akaroa Mail 27 May 1960)
obs_damage: Bridge approaches scooured out, boatsheds torn from foundations, jetty damaged

source_material: Sand was carried about 500 yards up the creek, and a small bridge was washed out. (Akaroa Mail 27 May 1960)
Water just barely over the road. (Akaroa Mail May 27 1960)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), LW at 20:32 May 23 NZST (-0.80), HW at 02:37 NZST (0.80), LW at 08:49 NZST (-0.88), HW at 15:05 NZST (0.87) on May 24 at Akaroa.

source_material: No damage in the bay reported, and baches on the foreshore were said to be protected by a line of sandhills. (The Press (Christchurch) 25 May 1960); Le Bon’s, with its cottages on the seafront, escaped damage, the sandhills protecting them, but a big bar was created at the creek mouth. (Akaroa Mail 27 May 1960)

placename: Robinson's Bay, Akaroa Harbour, Bank's Peninsula
source_material: No water over the road [on May 24]. (Akaroa Mail 27 May 1960)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), LW at 20:32 May 23 NZST (-0.80), HW at 02:37 NZST (0.80), LW at 08:49 NZST (-0.88), HW at 15:05 NZST (0.87) on May 24 at Akaroa.

source_material: Minor inundation of foreshore, photograph available [approx. 0.5 - 1 m inundation; presumed to be May 24, time unknown] (personal recollection, 2003)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), LW at 20:32 May 23 NZST (-0.80), HW at 02:37 NZST (0.80), LW at 08:49 NZST (-0.88), HW at 15:05 NZST (0.87) on May 24 at Akaroa.

source_material: In contrast to minor effects at Duvauchelle and Robinson’s Bay, there was “a house-swamping deluge at Takamatua” on May 24. Extensive flooding on the seafront occurred, with a house being flooded and furnishings ruined. (Akaroa Mail 27 May 1960)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), LW at 20:32 May 23 NZST (-0.80), HW at 02:37 NZST (0.80), LW at 08:49 NZST (-0.88), HW at 15:05 NZST (0.87) on May 24 at Akaroa.

source_material: Water levels reached six to seven feet higher than usual, and fences were swept away. Water encroached 200 to 400 feet on to paddocks. A substantial stone wall was flattened. (The Press (Christchurch) 25 May 1960);
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), LW at 21:52 May 23 CIT (-0.31), HW at 04:16 CIT (0.35), LW at 10:37 NZST (-0.29), HW at 16:37 CIT (0.23)) at WAITANGI. Note that the surge at Waitangi (not to be confused with Waitangi West) occurred at about 01:00 CIT May 24 and at about 10:00 occurred at mid-tide level. "Above normal" assumed to mean above normal HW.
obs_damage: Fences swept away, stone wall demolished.

source_material: The sea rose to an estimated 6ft to 8ft above normal and there was a good deal of damage. In the bay at The Glen, half a mile from the centre of the town, the water from its marks, appeared not to have risen by anything like the same amount. The wave only really broke through at one point on Akaroa’s waterfront – at the end of Viard Street, and along the dump frontage. According to residents, two waves came through within a short time of each other some time before high tide at 0240 May 24. One of these waves flooded the Recreation Ground to an estimated depth of 18in, tore out the fence erected along the Croquet lawn sea frontage three months ago at a cost of £439, flooded a house on the corner of Viard and Jolie Street and entered B.P. Stores’ shed opposite. Gardens on Lavaud Street were flooded and the water spread along the main street for more than a quarter of a mile. A dead cat, fish and masses of rubbish from the sea and the refuse dump littered the recreation Ground and the surrounding streets. The lawn at the Akaroa Bowling Club’s green was flooded also. Water entered the Boatsheds, but no boats were lost. Strangely enough, the wave did not appear to cover the Main Wharf, though it must have come very close to it. None of the fishing boats was affected. Surges continued throughout May 24 and May 25 in Akaroa Harbour, and at high tide on the afternoon of May 24 and again in the early hours of May 25, the Recreation Ground was partly flooded, adding to the scouring on the croquet lawn. Water also came over to a much lesser extent at the corner of Jolie Street south and the Esplanade, and flooded round the bowser corner and just over the floor of the Kowhai Tea-rooms. (Akaroa Mail 27 May 1960); The surge in the harbour “whipped to and fro over the main wharf like a river in flood at an estimated speed at the peak of the surges of about 10 miles an hour.” One surge just after 2400 May 23/24 fell 5 ft in as many minutes and was succeeded about five minutes later by another similar surge. At their ebb, the surges were of a considerably lower level than normal low tide. Fishing craft swung at their moorings but were not damaged. (The Press (Christchurch) 24 May 1960).; Akaroa affected by surges between 0200 and 0300 May 24 Some time before high tide at 0300 a wave estimated to have been at least six feet high broke over the foreshore at the end of Viard street and flooded the recreation ground and streets in the vicinity. A new corrugated iron fence off the sea frontage of the croquet lawn was flattened, the playing area was smothered in debris and the Akaroa Bowling Club’s green was flooded. A house at the corner of Jolie and Viard streets, had water marks two feet up from its foundations. A grocer’s store shed opposite was partly flooded. No harm came to any of the fishing boats. On the afternoon of May 24 as the tide made to fall, there were again surges, but of only up to about three feet. (The Press (Christchurch) 25 May 1960);
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), LW at 20:32 May 23 NZST (-0.80), HW at 02:37 NZST (0.80), LW at 08:49 NZST (-0.88), HW at 15:05 NZST (0.87) on May 24 at Akaroa. Reconnaissance suggests that the Recreation Ground is about 1.2 m above HW, ie 2 m above MSL
obs_damage: Several homes and gardens flooded, fence damaged.

source_material: Wainui suffered little or no damage. (Akaroa Mail 27 May 1960);
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), LW at 20:32 May 23 NZST (-0.80), HW at 02:37 NZST (0.80), LW at 08:49 NZST (-0.88), HW at 15:05 NZST (0.87) on May 24 at Akaroa.

source_material: No damage reported along the coast near Ashburton. (Ashburton Guardian 25 May 1960)

The sea broke over the retaining wall of the Hotel Chatham at Waitangi, Chatham Islands, at 0100 May 24 CIT [i.e. 0015 NZST], but no damage was caused to the hotel. At 1000 May 24. there was a phenomenally low tide—the lowest in the memory of a resident of the island for 60 years—and a few minutes later the normal high level was reached when the tide would normally be low. (The Press (Christchurch) 25 May 1960); [The following is a recollection] First observed surge at 0630 CIT [0545 NZST]. Water rushed up the Waitangi River, making a great noise and producing the effect of a flood except that the water was going upstream. At its maximum it would have been six or seven feet above normal. When it receded it brought down all sorts of debris. There was evidence that the waters had all but reached the deck of the bridge over the river, but this was not observed. Large quantities of kelp draped over the wharf. All morning [presumed to be May 24] the sea kept coming in like a very high tide and then receding far out, exposing large areas of sand and rock for many chains out to sea. Little damage was caused. (Holmes, 1993)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), LW at 21:52 May 23 CIT (-0.31), HW at 04:16 CIT (0.35), LW at 10:37 NZST (-0.29), HW at 16:37 NZST (0.23)). Note that the surge at about 01:00 and at about 10:00 occurred at mid-tide level. "Above normal" assumed to mean above normal HW.

source_material: Residents along the coast at Wakanui indicate little effect. One resident said during the night of May 23/24[?] seas had gone up to the cliff and some water had crossed the bar into the lagoon, indicating a higher tide than usual. (Ashburton Guardian 25 May 1960)

Water levels reached approximately 12 feet above normal. The island’s wharf was damaged and a dinghy was swept away. Neither the master trawler Coromel, which was anchored off the east coast of Pitt Island during the night, nor the master trawler Miro, which was off Owenga, reported anything unusual. (The Press (Christchurch) 25 May 1960);

A surge with a range of 7ft was experienced in the Timaru harbour at 0200 May 24, i.e. the level was raised 4ft and then quickly dropped 7ft from this mark. It was high tide at that time and no damage was done to shipping. Boats were moved to deeper water on receipt of a warning from the police. A succession of minor surges continued until about 0400. After a lull of a few hours other unusual disturbances were noticed, eg a fishing boat was unable to gain entrance to the harbour because of a strong current. (Oamaru Mail (Oamaru) 24 May 1960); The remains of the Ben Venue, which was wrecked off the Timaru coast in 1882 were completely exposed in surges on May 25. At 1030 May 25, a party of dairy factory workers stood obtained a clear view of the keel and iron ribs sticking out of the sand from the top of the Benvenue cliffs. Previously parts of the wreck had occasionally been seen out of water at neap tide. (The Press (Christchurch) Thursday 26 May 1960)

Heavy tide surges, with fluctuations of up to seven feet in five minutes were experienced in the Oamaru Harbour on morning of May 24. The first surge came shortly after 03:00 and there was a rise and fall in the harbour level of 10 to 11 feet every two hours. Surges increased from 4-5 ft to 12 to 14 feet shortly after 0300. The biggest surge was between 04:00 and 05:00 May 24 with another big surge at 08:00 May 24. The surges were extremely erratic. The second big surge drained the harbour more than the first one, but did not come up so high. At first the surges were taking from half to three-quarters of an hour from high to low level, and vice versa. Later in the morning of May 24 they were more erratic and there was not such a great difference in height, but the variations were more frequent. A check on the rise and fall gauge from 22:00 May 23 was maintained and the recorded rise and fall was between 10 and 13 feet every two hours. The lowest point was 3 ft below the normal spring water level. The highest point reached by the water was about three feet from the embankment in front of the petrol installations. At its lowest level it was possible to walk out to the end of Holmes wharf. Water rushed out of the mouth of the harbour at a rate of about four or five knots. Police issued a warning to the harbourmaster at 02:00 on May 24, resulting in the entire fishing fleet, with one launch under tow, putting to sea within half an hour of the order from the harbourmaster. The fishermen did not notice any erratic movement of the sea when a few miles from the coast, and returned to port shortly after daybreak. No damage was caused to the installations in the port. (Oamaru Mail (Oamaru) 24 May 1960); Oamaru fisherman, put on the alert at 03:00 May 24, left for sea to avoid the possibility of damage from the tidal disturbances. The coaster Tawanui, berthed at the Oamaru wharf, was battered down and precautions were taken to provide for any serious surge. At its highest point the sea reached the top of the stone seawall in the harbour basin, but no damage was reported. The survey launch H.M.N.Z.S. Takapu stayed in the harbour, with the crew keeping a watch on the automatic tide gauge: surges of 7ft and 12ft, lasting up to 20 minutes, occurred at hourly intervals. At first they were small, beginning at 22:00 May 23, but gradually building up. A large surge would occur, and while at the high-level several smaller ones would come. The same thing happened when the water receded. The harbour master, Captain J. E. Hancox, said he had never seen the water in the harbour so low. It was rushing out of the mouth about four to five knots. The largest surge was between 04:00 and 05:00 May 24, and another big surge at 08:00. Eyewitnesses reported that there was a continuous swirling of water in the harbour entrance, although inside and outside the sea was like glass, with only a slight swell showing. (Otago Daily Times (Dunedin) 25 May 1960); Oamaru, NZ – Fluctuations in the tide level began at about 2100 May 23, 1960, increasing in range to over 1 foot until 22:05 when, after rising 2 feet, the level dropped over 5 feet in 30 minutes, remaining until 23:00, when it rose 6.5 feet in 10 minutes. These fluctuations of 3-9 feet for 10-20 minute periods continued for the next 30 hours. (Berkman & Symons, 1964); Note tide gauge readings available (irregular time intervals from 10 up to 90 min)- these indicate max zero-peak 1.7 m at 06:50 max peak to trough 3.1 m at 04:50-06:00. (REFERENCE?)
tidal_records: Heights recorded at irregular intervals (10 min+).

source_material: There was no damage to properties at the Spit when the wave hit at 3.15 a.m., causing a rise estimated by residents at 3ft to 4ft. (Otago Daily Times (Dunedin) 25 May 1960).

placename: Tayler Point [Default location for Taylor's Point]
source_material: From tide gauge records: first arrival 07:40 UT 19:40 NZST May 23, Initial wave period 18 min, initial rise 0.6 m, following fall 0.3 m, max rise & Fall beginning at 08:53 UT May 23 20:53 NZST May 23, duration 18 min, height 0.9 m (Berkman & Symons, 1964)
tidal_records: Y, poor quality reproduced in Berkman & Symons (1964)

source_material: Nothing observed up to 00.50 May 24 . (Otago Daily Times 24 May 1960); At Port Chalmers, Harbour Board employees maintained a watch on the dry-dock in case water went over the gates and endangered the Union Steam Ship vessel Wairimu. (Otago Daily Times (Dunedin) 25 May 1960); From tide gauge records: first arrival 07:50 UT 19:50 NZST May 23, Initial wave period 40 min, initial rise 0.1 m, following fall 0.2 m, max rise & Fall beginning at 09:15 UT May 23 21:15 NZST May 23, duration 18 min, height 0.4 m (Berkman & Symons, 1964)
tidal_records: Y, poor quality reproduced in Berkman & Symons (1964)
obs_height_max_at-inundation_comment: NOT OBSERVED except on tide gauge

source_material: Ships and fishing vessels in the Port of Otago were put on the alert early when reports of the tidal wave were received by the harbour master, Captain F. Mackenzie. The first report that the wave was approaching was given by the fishing vessel Norseman, north-east off Timaru which was spun around by the sea disturbance. The wave hit the Port of Otago at about 0325, causing a rise and fall in the water level of between one foot and two feet in 30 minutes. (Otago Daily Times (Dunedin) 25 May 1960); From tide gauge records: first arrival 08:35 UT 20:35 NZST May 23, Initial wave period 240 min, initial rise 0.1 m, following fall 0.2 m, max rise & Fall beginning at 15:40 UT May 23 03:40 NZST May 24, duration 35 min, height 0.35 m (Berkman & Symons, 1964)
obs_first_arrival_comments: Note:earlier arrival on  tide gauge records

source_material: Disturbance at Brighton was similar to that at Taieri mouth. Described as like "the whole ocean rushing in". Water surged up the Brighton Stream, overturning a small wooden jetty, and lifting a large dinghy onto a rock damaging it. (Otago Daily Times 25 May 1960); The early morning disturbance on May 24 similar at Brighton as that at Taieri River mouth. Water surged up the Brighton Stream, overturning a small wooden jetty and lifting a large dinghy on to a rock causing damage to a number of its planks. (Otago Daily Times (Dunedin) 25 May 1960).
obs_damage: Wooden jetty damaged, large dinghy damaged

source_material: Two commercial launches ripped from their moorings and crushed in the inrush against the beams of the road bridge which spans the estuary, badly damaging the superstructure of the boats. The tidal disturbance was noticed up and down the Otago coast, but struck most severely in tidal estuaries of rivers and streams south of Dunedin. A warning to Taieri Mouth fishermen from Port Chalmers came too late. No one was about to gauge the extent of the freak tide, but estimates later placed the rise in the water at about 5ft. Many people were awakened by the roar created by the inrush of water across the bar and its loud hiss as it poured past the boatshed and jetty piles. Large launches bucked at their moorings, heavy ropes snapped, and dinghies either dragged from their anchorages or were picked up by the water surging along the banks and bobbed about on the current like corks. The deckhouse extending almost the entire length of the 35ft commercial pleasure craft Kiwaka was wrecked completely, as the launch was forced beneath the road bridge. A smaller fishing launch, the Matarua was dismasted. Its cabin was badly damaged when it struck the beams. Ropes were also snapped on other boats and about a dozen dinghies and other boats swept from mooring places. Some gardens were also flooded and water lapped against the sides of houses. The rise and fall along the Otago coast continued during the day of May 24. Another major upsurge at Taieri River mouth on the peak of high-water soon after 1400 [May 24], but by this time all floating craft were out harm’s way. As it continued up the Estuary the surge rose to form a swell which broke about 5ft up the banks, throwing water cross low-lying sections of road, and, at one point, into the front yards of a number of houses. (Otago Daily Times (Dunedin) 25 May 1960).
Awarua Radio received no reports of abnormal conditions from Puysegur Point lighthouse. (Southland Times (Invercargill) 25 May 1960.);

Tide surges first arrived in the early hours of May 24. The arrival was not observed, but debris found at daylight. Seaweed and gravel was found along the waterfront, the beach road as well as the high ground across the road. In some places, the debris was a foot deep. Water was found to have reached up to baches on the high ground. (Southland Times (Invercargill) 25 May 1960.);
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), HW at 23:17 May 23 NZST (0.96), LW at 05:28 NZST (-1.01), HW at 11:41 NZST (1.01), LW at 17:50 NZST (-0.95)). According to LINZ website, MHWS 1.07 m , MLWS -0.46 m, MHWN 0.66 m MLWN -0.66 m HAT 1.35 LAT -1.45 (all relative to MSL) at Bluff. MHWS at Colac Bay are assumed to be similar, ie roads and huts were probably at least 1 m above MHWS, and hence at least 2.1 m above MSL. If inundation occurred at high tide the height above sea level at time is just over 1m. CHECK THAT THIS AREA IS QUITE LOW AND GETS WET IN HIGH TIDES AND WIND?

source_material: Waves at Fortrose were bigger than usual at about 1700 May 24 (Southland Times (Invercargill) 25 May 1960.);

Sharp fluctuations in the tide recorded in the 12 hours up to 1200 May 24, but insufficient to cause alarm or damage. Four low waters were experienced at Bluff within a short time. From the ebb tide about 0200 up to 1100, 16 surges were recorded. These caused rises at times up to 2ft, the water dropping once nearly 2ft in 25 minutes. Warnings were received at Bluff shortly after midnight by the Bluff police and the harbourmaster. All vessels in port were alerted to the possibility of tidal waves of sufficient force to run vessels aground. It was expected the tidal wave should hit Bluff about 6.30 a.m. Anchors and ladders were made secure and crews prepared for possible trouble. (Southland Times (Invercargill) 24 May 1960.); On may 24, tide regularly rose and fell approx. every half hour on May 24, superimposed on the regular rise and fall of the tide. Between 1215 and 1500 May 24, when it would be normal slack water, the tide rose and fell seven times. About 1630 when a six-knot tide was running out of the harbour, the inflow from the tidal wave was sufficient to stop the normal ebb tide. This prevented the Union Steam Ship Co’s vessel, Kaitoke from berthing, as it would be too dangerous to navigate the narrow entrance to the port. The waves have been regularly pounding through Foveaux at half-hourly intervals, with the normal waves superimposed on this. It was only the narrow entrance to the port that kept the rise and fall down to about six inches [0.15 m]. (Southland Times (Invercargill) 25 May 1960.)

placename: Stewart Island [default: Half Moon Bay, Oban]
source_material: At Halfmoon Bay, Stewart Island, erratic tides and a heavy rise and fall were experienced. The disturbance at Stewart Island was apparently at its worst during the night when several dinghies were washed off the beach. Two were subsequently recovered in Foveaux Strait. Debris and kelp left an exceptionally high level on the foreshore. At high tide on May 24, about 12.15 p.m., there was still evidence of a heavy tide range. At the height of each range, the main wharf decking was only about two feet from the water. The tide ebbed erratically, falling five feet and rising four. (Southland Times (Invercargill) 25 May 1960);
discussion: The height of the first arriving waves is not recorded; waves may have been larger during the night of May 23-24.
obs_damage: Several dinghies above HW washed away.

placename: Cook Arm, Port Pegasus Harbour, Stewart Island
source_material: A fishing vessel was marooned in Cooks Arm of Port Pegasus Harbour at Stewart Island by water level fluctuations for five days, the water level in this time not rising sufficiently high to refloat the boat. (Auckland Star May 28, 1960; also in Southland Daily News 28 May 1960))

placename: Campbell Island:Meteorological Station near Mount Beeman, Perseverance Harbour
source_material:
Tsunami first noticed between 0300 and 0400 May 24, when generator in a shed on the wharf cut out and investigation found that it have been reached by water and water to knee height was found covering an area of the foreshore that should have been dry. Most of the stacked stores, including a 44 gallon drum of engine oil, on the foreshore were found to have been washed away, and everything was in disarray. Water was running and dripping everywhere, but a short time after 0400 the water had receded. Water just reached one of the two ionosphere machines in a shed on the wharf, which was then moved to higher ground after 0400 as the water started rapidly rising again. Awarua Radio, and subsequently Civil Defence were alerted via the emergency frequency. It was estimated that at its height the water reached about 9 feet [2.7 m] above normal high tide. As the tide gauge had been dismantled [months? previously], no records were available. During May 24, the tide kept oscillating at regular intervals becoming less in height and duration as the day wore on, but it was several days before it settled into a normal pattern. The water rose and fell smoothly, and at no time formed a wave, rising till it reached its limit, pausing, and then falling. During the normal high tide, said to have occurred or expected between 1400 and 1600 hrs on May 24, several rises covered the foreshore to a depth of 15/16 inches. Later, it was much less noticeable at low tide.
Settlement received warning of another tsunami on 26th May and all the essential parts out of the mechanics’ workshop were shifted to high ground. Cameras were made ready, but nothing happened. (Poppleton, 2000)
discussion: According to NIWA tide Forecaster, HW occurred at about 00:34 NZST (0.42 m) and at 13:00 NZST (0.53), LW at 06:41 NZST (-0.50) 24 May. At the first observed arrival time between 03:00-04:00the tide would have been ebbing and 0-0.2 m below mean sea level. Maximum height seems to have occurred at this time. However, there seems to be a discrepancy between the calculated time of high tide (1300 NZST) and that expected at Campbell Island (between 1400-1600), which is not accounted for by possible adoption of "local longitude time" on Campbell Island (which would in fact make the expected time earlier than NZST). Normal tidal range is ~ ±0.4 m

placename: Campbell Island: Tucker Cove, Perseverance Harbour [within 3 km of  Meteorological Station (default location)]
source_material: When inspected on May 25, it was found that one wall of the boat shed at Tucker Cove was washed away, and on the opposite side of the shed the weather boards up to two feet from the bottom plates were ripped out. Many fish and other marine plants and organisms stranded. Late in the afternoon of May 25, a surge came in and washed right over the top of the Old Stone Jetty, up to the floor of the boat shed. Men caught on the causeway by a surge but managed to get onto a rock. A further surge also reached the men. Many fish and other marine plants and organisms stranded. (Poppleton, 2000)
discussion: See comments for Campbell Island:Meteorological Station near Mount Beeman, Perseverance Harbour

placename: Campbell Island: Camp Cove, Perseverance Harbour [within 3 km of "Beeman" Meteorological Station (default location)]
source_material: When inspected on May 27, it was estimated that the water level must have risen 12-14 ft [~3.6-4.2 m] – and the shallow foreshore was silted up. The creek had been backed up about a hundred yards, the Galathea Memorial had been knocked over, a Sitka spruce had debris draped in its foliage to a height of four and half feet. Some small fish and shrimps had been washed ashore. (Poppleton, 2000)
discussion: See comments for Campbell Island:Meteorological Station near Mount Beeman, Perseverance Harbour
obs_damage: memorial stone damaged, fish etc stranded

placename: Campbell Island: Garden Cove, Perseverance Harbour [within 3 km of "Beeman" Meteorological Station (default location)]
source_material: When inspected on May 25, it was estimated that water reached up to 16 feet [~4.8 m] [presumably above normal high water as in other parts of source document], attributed to the long shelving beach. The creek had been scoured out up to about two hundred yards, a 44 gallon drum was wedged in a narrow part at 150 yds, and other parts were scoured out. The whole beach was silted up to 14 inches depth, with the usual high windrow of weed, krill, small crustaceans, heaps of mussels, and quite a few long spiralled monopods. Thousands of worms - marine centipedes, and sea lice – were stranded. (Poppleton, 2000)
discussion: See comments for Campbell Island:Meteorological Station near Mount Beeman, Perseverance Harbour
obs_damage: scouring of beach, fish etc stranded

placename: Campbell Island: Lookout Bay, Perseverance Harbour [within 3 km of Meteorological Station (default location)]
source_material: When inspected on May 29, it was found that the sea had gone up the creek and left debris hanging in the Dracophyllum scrub indicating that it had reached about 10 to 12 feet [~3- 3.6 m] above normal high water. (Poppleton, 2000)
discussion: See comments for Campbell Island:Meteorological Station near Mount Beeman, Perseverance Harbour

placename: Campbell Island: Boyack Point, Perseverance Harbour [within 3 km of Meteorological Station (default location)]
source_material: When inspected on May 29, the great heaps of bull kelp and other weed that were found were attributed to the tsunami. (Poppleton, 2000)
discussion: See comments for Campbell Island:Meteorological Station near Mount Beeman, Perseverance Harbour

placename: Campbell Island: eastern side, de la Vire Point, Perseverance Harbour [within 3 km of Meteorological Station (default location)]
source_material: When inspected on May 29, an amount of gear missing from the meteorological station (q.v.) was found - 17 drums in all, some full, others partly full and a few empties as well as the remnants of the Tucker boat shed doors, and parts of what I took to be the bow of an old whaler. A lot of other minor stuff was heaped quite high and obviously left by the receding tide as the eastern side of the point was clear of all debris. It was very noticeable that the tide had not reached anywhere near the height on the eastern face of the point that it had reached at the head of the harbour, so it must have increased in height and velocity as the bottom shelved. The little isthmus was no more than eight to ten feet [2.4-3 m] above normal high water at any part, and the tide did not get to even half that height. (Poppleton, 2000)
discussion: See comments for Campbell Island:Meteorological Station near Mount Beeman, Perseverance Harbour

source_material:
On one of the two days on which tsunami effects were felt as a result in New Zealand of the 1960 Chile earthquake, Magnitude 9.5, i.e. either May 24th or May 25th , Jimmy Daniels was at work at the Ngakawau Powerhouse. He cannot recall which day of the week it was specifically.
Jimmy was one of two staff on the dog shift between midnight and 8.00am. He was the shift engineer and his compatriot was Bob McGregor who acted as fireman, keeping the coal up to the boilers. 
The powerhouse needed a steady supply of water for operation of the steam turbines and they had two sources, both from the Ngakawau River about 100 metres away. The first drew water from the main flow from mid tide to high tide level (the river being tidal) and the other took water from the main channel mid river, once the tide dropped to mid-tide and below. The reason for this was to try and avoid getting sediment and leaves in the water-supply (even though they had screens). The two uptakes were about 7 feet (just over 2m) in vertical height apart, and both had pumps to send the water into the powerhouse.
On the night in question, early on in the shift (Jimmy thinks 2-3.00 am), the upper level pump (they called it the sump pump) was in action as the tide was in the high zone. So it was with some alarm that Jimmy suddenly noticed that the steam used from the boilers to drive the turbines, was exhausting to air. Normally the system operated in a vacuum and exhausting to air did not occur unless the sump pump was not working. 
Jimmy rushed down to the river to see what the story was and found that instead of it being high tide (and therefore the water being drawn in by the pump OK), the river was almost out of water altogether. The tide was OUT! Then while he was standing there watching it all started coming back in again, surging and welling up and up. However he couldn’t wait to see more of this strange activity as it was crucial to get the water back on and ensure the powerhouse kept operating. 
It was only later that that he put two and two together and realized that the strange ‘tidal’ behaviour was actually what was then called a tidal wave. (pers. comm. Mary Trayes June 25, 2010)
discussion:
Despite it being 50 years on, Jimmy was an excellent witness with good recall (other than the exact date). At outset he said he would tell it as he observed and did this very clearly. At the end I asked him if had felt an earthquake at about the same time as the event he observed (thinking of the Mag 6.3 Fiordland EQ recorded at 2.46am on May 25th and which was felt in Dunedin, Gore, Haast and Greymouth as per Greymouth Evening Star accounts of May 25th and 26th). He said no, he had not. M Trayes then explained that there had been an earthquake at 2.46am on May 25th felt in many places in the lower South Island (epicentre later pinpointed off Big Bay) which was followed at 3.00am by a noticeable 3 foot high wave up the Grey River. As it seemed that Jimmy’s experience correlated well with the observations made about as wave up the river in the Greymouth, she was interested to hear too if he had felt the earthquake.

Mary Trayes comments that in hindsight this tsunami would not needed to have been great (maybe 1-2m) for it to have had this effect in an estuarine area like that of the Ngakawau River, particularly as it corresponded with a normal a high tide. Tsunami effects are compounded by embayments and estuaries and often a surge wave carries upriver at least as high as spring high tides do.

source_material: Lighthouse keeper noticed nothing obviously unusual, except that water only 2/3 out at the time it should have been a low spring tide. (Northland Age 31 March 1964; similar in Northern Advocate 30 March 1964)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW occurred at about 09:12 NZST (1.20 m) LW at 15:25 NZST (-1.19) 29 March 1964. Observational data suggestthe tide level was of the order of 0.5 to at most 1 m higher than expected, about 9 hours after the expected first arrival.

source_material: A fishing boat moored at Houhora wharf broke its moorings but was secured before it could collide with smaller craft. (Northland Age 31 March 1964)

placename: Houhora Heads [default location for Pukenui Heads]
source_material: At noon on March 29, the tide, which had been falling, suddenly rose, covered the banks [uncertain if this means banks of harbour or sandbanks?] to a depth of two feet, and then ran out again. (Northland Age 31 March 1964)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW occurred at about 08:38 NZST (0.96 m) LW at 14:51 NZST (-0.95) 29 March 1964 at Houhora River Entrance.

placename: Kaimaumau [default location for mouth of Awanui Harbour]
source_material: At 11.30 am March 29 the tide was about half out. Shortly after the water rose to high spring tide level. (Northland Age 31 March 1964); On Awanui harbour a surge swept in about 11 am and a motorist who was driving on the hard sand near the mouth had to take quick action to avoid it. ( Northland Advocate 30 March 1964)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW occurred at about 08:38 NZST (0.96 m) LW at 14:51 NZST (-0.95) 29 March 1964 at Houhora River Entrance.

placename: Tokerau Beach [exact location uncertain, correct within 5 km only]
source_material: "The water came well up to the sandhills at Tokerau Beach." (Northland Age 31 March 1964); "The tide also rose higher than usual at Tokerau Beach." ( Northland Advocate 30 March 1964)

Three tides were experienced on morning of 29 March. These scoured out huge quantities of mud, which discoloured the harbour - this was not clear by 30 March. Tide rose 2 ft above normal at 09:00 March 29. Mud flats at the head of the harbour were exposed three times during the morning of 29 March as waves rolled up and down. Fish were left stranded. The mooring lines of one boat were broken. The fluctuations were spectacular to watch, as water poured through the gap between the wharf and Butler's Point like a river in flood. No damage to roading or to the yachts in Mill bay. When tide was right out it should have been 1/3 full on 29 March. On morning of 30 March, harbour was again muddy and water rose about 2 feet at 09:30 & then fell again with a normal tide crest arriving 1/2 hour later. (Northland Age 31 March 196; similar in Northland Advocate 30 March 1964); About 9 am [March 30] approaching high tide there was a sudden surge out dropping the level about2 ft and half an hour later the water came back in again. At 1.30 pm the tide was described by local residents as about back to normal again. (Northland Advocate 30 March 1964)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW occurred at about 08:34 NZST (0.96 m) LW at 14:47 NZST (-0.95) 29 March 1964. Although a rise of 2 ft above HW seems to have been the highest level reached, the statement that the tide was fully out when it should have been 1/3 full, prob. at about 11:00, suggests a fall of 1-1.3 m. A similar rise just before or after this would have matched the level at 09:00. See also Waitangi entry, which suggests the tide started ebbing prior to morning HW , consistent with a higher elevation than the 2 ft recognised at this time.

source_material: "... yachting had finished on a full river before it began to sweep out of the entrance like water out of a bath." (Northland Age 31 March 1964); "Yachting races had just finished on the narrow estuary on the Taipa River when the tide began to sluice out through the entrance like water down a plug hole." (Northern Advocate 30 March 1964)

In Whangaroa Harbour a fisherman anchored in about three feet of water in the morning found his boat suddenly high and dry. He walked to the shore and then looked back, seeing his boat was afloat again. (Northland Age 31 March 1964; similar in Northern Advocate 30 March 1964); + No boats were damaged. (Northern Advocate 30 March 1964)

placename: Ahipara [default location for Ninety Mile Beach]
source_material: Although spring tide expected, tide stayed high much longer than usual, forcing cars driving along the beach to drive right up next to the sandhills in some places . (Northland Age 31 March 1964) "Driving along the beach itself was more hazardous than usual and it was necessary to keep right up to the dunes in some places where usually there are two or three hundred yards of hard sand as the tide falls." (Northern Advocate 30 March 1964)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW occurred at about 10:08 NZST (1.39 m) LW at 16:19 NZST (-1.37) 29 March 1964 near Ahipara.

source_material: "In the Bay of Islands tides of 10 knots were estimated where they usually run at three knots. The effect was most noticeable in the Waitangi Estuary and at Opua wharf. Three times during the day the tide began to ebb and then come in again, and at Opua the noise of the upsets was quite noticeable. Only damage was to the navigational beacon at Okiato Point but it was not put out of action." (Northland Age 31 March 1964); Tides of up to 10 knots were experienced in the Bay of Islands on March 29. The morning tide started ebbing half an hour earlier than scheduled, and the level of the tide then dropping very suddenly by two feet. The effect was most noticeable in the Waitangi estuary and at the Opua wharf. Three times during the day the tide began to ebb, stopped and became a flood tide. The noise of the tidal upsets was most noticeable at Opua. The navigational beacon off Okiato Point was damaged but not put out of action. No damage to boats. (Northern Advocate 30 March 1964)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW occurred at about 08:22 NZST (0.95 m) LW at 14:36 NZST (-0.93) 29 March 1964.

source_material: "In the Bay of Islands tides of 10 knots were estimated where they usually run at three knots. The effect was most noticeable in the Waitangi Estuary and at Opua wharf. Three times during the day the tide began to ebb and then come in again, and at Opua the noise of the upsets was quite noticeable. Only damage was to the navigational beacon at Okiato Point but it was not put out of action." (Northland Age 31 March 1964)

"People at Parengarenga Harbour did not notice anything unless the fact that the fish did not bite could be attributed to the waves." (Northland Age 31 March 1964); "It was not noticed at Parengarenga apart from the fact that the fishing was poor." (Northern Advocate 30 March 1964)

"In the Whangarei harbour there was about one foot variation in the morning tide observed about 10 o’clock yesterday at the Whangarei harbour Board’s marine terminal at Marsden Point. There was little or no variation up harbour at Port Whangarei." (Northern Advocate 30 March 1964)

"There was about a foot variation in the tide at Marsden point in Whangarei Harbour at 10 am on Sunday [March 29]." (Northland Age 31 March 1964); "In the Whangarei harbour there was about one foot variation in the morning tide observed about 10 o’clock yesterday at the Whangarei harbour Board’s marine terminal at Marsden Point. There was little or no variation up harbour at Port Whangarei." (Northern Advocate 30 March 1964)
"At Port Fitzroy, Great Barrier Island the tide fell about 2 ft in 10 minutes at 9.30 am, while at the same time at Great Mercury Island the tide rose about 2 ft." (Northern Advocate 30 March 1964)

"At Port Fitzroy, Great Barrier Island the tide fell about 2 ft in 10 minutes at 9.30 am, while at the same time at Great Mercury Island the tide rose about 2 ft." (Gisborne Herald 30 March – 5 April 1964 )
"A tidal variation of 3 ft in a matter of minutes was noticed at Whitianga at 8 am yesterday [Mar 29]." (Gisborne Herald 30 March 1964; similar in NZ Herald)
"Auckland had 18 inch fluctuations" (Daily Telegraph 30 March 1964)
discussion: "Fluctuation" assumed to refer to peak to trough measurement.

source_material: "Tauranga had 6 inch fluctuations" (Daily Telegraph 30 March 1964)
discussion: "Fluctuation" assumed to refer to peak to trough measurement.

source_material: The Gisborne Herald contains no reports of local effects. (Gisborne Herald 30 March - 5 April 1964)
Although a watch was kept on the tide gauge, no unusual movement was recorded. (Daily Telgraph 30 March 1964)

On tide gauge at Nelson: time of arrival - indefinite; period 1st to 2nd crest -indeterminate; initial rise - indeterminate; following fall - indeterminate; Time of beginning of maximum rise or fall - incomplete record; duration of max. rise or fall - incomplete record; height - incomplete record. Copy of record is included in the paper. (Berkman & Spaeth, 1967)
discussion: Reinterpretation of the partial tide gauge record reproduced in Spaeth & Berkman (1967) by picking peaks and troughs allows a rough estimate of a peak-to-trough and zero to peak measurements not given in Spaeth & Berkman (1967) because of the incomplete record. See Excel plots. A comoplete record should be searched and if not available, the trace given in Spaeth & Berkman (1967) should be digitised and analysed.
tidal_records: LINZ? Tide gauge record reproduced in Spaeth & Berkman (1967)

source_material: Wellington Harbour Board reported no discernible variations in tide heights up to morning of 30 March. (Daily Telgraph 30 March 1964); Gilmour's (1990) investigation of the response of Wellington Harbour to the 1964 tsunami by analysing tide gauge records implies a small tsunami occurred but was not recognised at the time.
tidal_records: Probably lodged with LINZ. Records analysed for amplitude and period by Gilmour (1990)

source_material: During the night of 29 March and again on the morning of 30 March, water inundated the shore for 50 yards inland above normal high water mark, flooding around houses fronting the lagoon and around Victoria Lagoon, and submerging two low jetties. Although high water was due at 11 am March 30, the tide started to rise rapidly about 9.20 am and within 20 minutes, the two low lying Settler’s Wharves in front of the Wharfinger’s Office on the Picton Foreshore were submerged. The water rose at a rate of an inch a minute and after reaching its peak, which was held for a few minutes only, ebbed as fast as the rise. Shortly after 10 o’clock the tide ebbed suddenly, an hour before its normal time. The tide came well up over the Picton Foreshore, swept up the new launching ramp, and down into the car park area. No appreciable damage was done, but large numbers of jellyfish and other marine life were deposited. Water was around one small cottage to a depth of more than a foot, and to a depth of a few inches around a second house, some distance away, facing Waikawa Road that was "quite a height above sea-level". Residents who had been in Picton for more than 50 years said they could not remember the Settler’s Wharves ever being awash. Not long after 8 pm March 29, a 12-foot runabout left well above high water mark on the Foreshore was set adrift. it was found wedged under the Victoria Domain bridge, some 300 yards away, at 11.30 pm. (Marlborough Express 30 march 1964; briefer version in Oamaru Mail 30 March 1964)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides)), HW was at 22:23 29 March NZST (0.73), and again at 10:34 30 March NZST( 0.78 ) at a User defined location near Picton. MHWS at Picton is 0.74 m and Highest Astronomical Tide (HAT) is 0.88 m above MSL (LINZ Website). While the tsunami impact was greatest within an hour of the MHWS level, the tide was not an exceptionally high spring tide and cannot account for the inundation. Assuming the houses are at least 0.3 m above HAT, inundation level must have been at least 0.8 m but probably no more than 1.5 m. Note that the highest level seems to have occurred 42 hours after generation and 27 hours after expected first arrival.

source_material: Nothing unusual has been noted in the seas or tides at Wairau bar, and the river was normal, up to morning of 30 March. (Marlborough Express 30 March 1964)

On tide gauge at Greymouth: time of arrival - indefinite; period 1st to 2nd crest -indeterminate; initial rise - indeterminate; following fall - indeterminate; Time of beginning of maximum rise or fall - 05:27 GMT March 29 (rise); duration of max. rise or fall - 20 min (rise); height 1.2 ft. Copy of record is included in the paper. (Berkman & Spaeth, 1967)
discussion: Visual interpretion of the tide gauge record reproduced in Spaeth & Berkman (1967) indicates the maximum rise listed for Greymouth is a trough to peak measurement rather than zero to peak. Digitising the trace is needed to better interpret the record.
tidal_records: LINZ? Tide gauge record reproduced in Spaeth & Berkman (1967)

source_material: Yacht racing on the Waimakariri was disrupted by the changing of the tides. Surges came up the river after a race with 78 boats started mid-afternoon when there was no wind and the tide was rising. The water then ebbed, sending tremendous torrents of water tumbling out to sea". In the absence of wind, the boats were at the mercy of the current. Many were beached, and some towed to safety. (The Press 30 March 1964); During the yacht race on March 29 the ebbing current threatened to carry yachts down towards the surf breaking on the bar, but none were damaged, some were deliberately beached. The only loss was a marker buoy which was taken out to sea. A second surge and rapid ebb occurred during the last race. (The Press 31 March 1964)

The sea at Sumner on the afternoon of March 29 was reportedly rough, but not regarded as particularly unusual. Although the sea came up about 1ft higher than usual for the time of the year, and had run further up the beach. (The Press 30 March 1964)

On tide gauge at Lyttelton: tiMe of arrival - 22:10 GMT March 28; period 1st to 2nd crest - 12 min; initial rise - 0.2 ft; following fall - 0.2 ft; Time of beginning of maximum rise or fall - 06:00 GMT March 29 (fall) ; duration of max. rise or fall - 40 min (fall); height 4.1 ft. Copy of record is included in the paper. (Berkman & Spaeth, 1967); The Lyttelton Harbour Board’s duty officer who reported erratic surgings at the harbour throughout afternoon of Mar 29, said that the heights of the tides were not unusual for the full moon period, but the rapidity of change was a striking feature. At 1.45 pm on March 29 the tide at Lyttelton was 1 ft 3 in above mean low water spring tide level, but by 2 pm this had risen a further 2 ft 4 in. The tides then rose and fell slightly until reaching a height of 4 ft 6 in at 5 pm, then rising sharply to a high tide of 8ft 4in by 5.45 pm. Yachtsmen and launch owners reported discoloured water and mud up and down the outer harbour on afternoon of March 29. (The Press 30 March 1964); "Lyttelton had 3 ft fluctuations at 20 minute intervals" (Daily Telegraph 30 March 1964)
discussion: According to NIWA Tide Forecaster (http://www.niwa.co.nz/services/free/tides), HW occurred at about 05:09 NZST (0.92 m) LW at 11:23 NZST (-0.91) HW at 17:35 NZST (0.85) LW at 23:43 NZST (-0.84) 29 March 1964. According to LINZ website, MHWS 1.09 m , MLWS -1.09 m, MHWN 0.67 m MLWN -0.68 m HAT 1.31 LAT -1.27 (all relative to MSL). Reinterpretation of the tide gauge record reproduced in Spaeth & Berkman (1967) suggests and earlier arrival at approx. 20:30 GMT 08:30 NZST March 28, and significant differences in peak-to-trough measurements and first arrival time. These are used here rather than Spaeth & Berkman (1967) measurements. At its highest the tsunami only exceeded the HAT by a mere 0.2 m. See Excel plots
tidal_records: LINZ? Tide gauge record reproduced in Spaeth & Berkman (1967)

source_material: The tides were ‘most erratic” in Diamond Harbour. A four or five knot current ran out during the afternoon when the tide was rising. (The Press 30 March 1964)

placename: Purau and Port Levy, Banks Peninsula [default location: Purau]
source_material: At Port Levy, a 37 ft cutter with a 6 ft draught grounded 100 yds offshore less than two hours after low water on March 29. The boat heeled over and righted again. A 26ft sloop also went aground 120 yds offshore in the same area.(The Press 30 March 1964)
discussion: Consistent with effects at Lyttelton when an 0.6 m fall to about 0.1 m below LW occurred at this time. See Lyttelton entry and Excel plots. Fall may have been greter and comparison with the Lyttelton record suggests that another grounding may have occurred later in the day.

source_material: "In the upper reaches of the harbour around Teddington, the water was up into the drains in the late afternoon [on March 29]." The Press 30 March 1964
discussion: See Lyttelton entry and Excel plot - water levels at Lyttelton reached a maximum of 0.4 m above MHWS at 17:40 March 29.

source_material:
"A surge which lifted the level of the water in the Timaru harbour by about 6 ins shortly after 3 am [or pm?] yesterday was the effect of the tidal wave which followed the Alaskan earthquake.
The rise, which was of very short duration, caused no damage to small craft in the harbour. Harbour officials said the surge would not have been noticed had not a watch been maintained for it" (Gisborne Herald 30 March 1964)
Although effects elsewhere are reported, no local effects are mentioned in the Oamaru Mail, which was searched up to 3 April.
No noticeable tidal variations were observed at Bluff or other points on the Southland coast. (Dominion 30 March 1964)
see source event
see source event

Surge at 08:40 [NZ Daylight Saving Time; 07:40 NZST] broke loose a yacht from its anchorage, sweeping it into other boats, breaking some mooring ropes. An 0.2 m rise lasting 5-6 minutes came in as a "great big whirlpool" that moved at an estimated 8 knots. Second surge at 09:20 [08:20 NZST]. (NZ Herald 16 January 1976); Several yachts were damaged in a 0.75 metre tidal surge at the Tutukaka boat harbour at about 8 am [07:00 NZST]on 15 January. (Bay of Plenty Times 15 January 1976)
Small oscillations were recorded. (de Lange & Healy, 1986)
<0.1 Auckland port (Table 1 in de Lange & Hull (1994), citing de Lange & Healy (1986), Tsunami Newsletters and Civil Defence as sources for the Table.
Slight fluctuations on tide gauge at Salisbury Wharf, Mount Maunganui. (Bay of Plenty Times 15 January 1976); Note: de lange & Healy (1986) list this location as Tauranga.

Maximum reported wave height of 0.15 m. (De Lange & Healy (1986) citing IOC Tsunami Report 1977-79 and NZ Seismological Bulletin E-159.); Max water height: 0.15 (Type 2= tide gauge measurement); Travel time: 04:02; period of first cycle: - (NGDC Tsunami Database, April 2009)
discussion: This measurement is identified in NGDC Tsunami Database (April 2009) as a tide gauge measurement, and th given " maximum water height" is defined as "half the maximium height (minus the normal tide) of a tsunami wave recorded at the coast by a tide gauge".

source_material: On high tide (10.50 am NZST) on 10 October 1978, 2 fishermen on their boat, about 1 km off North Canterbury coast near Mt Vulcan (Fig 1), saw a large block of the back-beach slope slide into the sea. They reported that the slide continued for about a minute, pushing out the beach surface in front of it, and causing a large wave, which, by the time it reached the boat, had reduced in height to 15-20 cm. Fifteen sheep that travelled on the slide were recovered later in good health by the farmer. (Smale & van der Lingen, 1982)
see source event

This is an important difference, and it would appear that data in the NGDC Tsunami database are incorrect.]
