source_material:
Marsden Point is strongly affected by far infra gravity waves, which are modulated with the tide, being higher at high tide. However, FIG waves tend to have periods of 6 to 20 min, so the very long waves in mid-morning of 4 May, may be the first tsunami waves. The large waves at high tide could be a superposition of FIG and tsunami waves. Marsden Point is in direct line with Tonga, so for the sites under consideration, the tsunami would be expected to reach here first. (www.mulgor.co.nz/TongaTsu06/); "Derek Goring, of Mulgor Consulting, who monitors tide gauges at some NZ ports, has posted his analysis of the records for tsunami for 4-5 May on www.mulgor.co.nz/TongaTsu06/ Derek notes that he has excluded some where nothing apparently happened, and that in many cases, the tsunami was obscured to a greater or lesser extent by long waves (infra-gravity or far-infragravity) produced by weather systems and swell. 
The greatest peak-to-trough measurements were observed at Kaingaroa-Chatham Island (0.35 m), Gisborne (0.30 m) and Lyttelton (0.25 m), and probably Timaru (0.3 m), Napier (0.2 m) and Marsden Point (0.15 m)....
The first arrival at Kaingaroa, 3.5 hours after the earthquake, is consistent with William Power’s movie (see below). The first arrivals recorded in the North and South Islands were at Moturiki-Mt Maunganui (5.1 hours) Marsden Point (5.5 hours), Gisborne (6.0 hours), Otago Harbour Entrance and Lyttelton (~ 6 hours), Napier (~ 6.4 hours), Port Taranaki (~ 8 hours). The Timaru waves arrived quite late at 9 hrs after the earthquake. While the first waves arrived at Lyttelton around 6 hrs after the earthquake, the peak was at about 18 hrs after the earthquake – this very late peak is interesting and its cause probably requires investigation. " (Downes et al, 2006)
tidal_records: Digital: Land Information New Zealand (LINZ), National Institute for Water & Atmosheric Research (NIWA); Analysis: Mulgor Consulting

source_material:
"The highest wave heights measured in NZ territories were measured on the east coast of Chatham Island (NE side of island) at Kaingaroa at 0.35 m (crest-to-trough) or about 0.19 m above the tide level at the time. This compared with other gauges in the North and South Islands that only registered wave heights up to 0.25–0.3 m at some sites (e.g., Mt. Maunganui, 0.25 m and Timaru, Lyttelton discussed below)) but most other gauge sites experienced smaller waves that were <0.2 m (crest-to-trough) and barely distinguishable from background seiching or weather-related long waves. 
Appendix 1 shows the sea-level traces for Moturiki (Mt Maunganui), with the first arrival at ~ 5.2 hours, and Kaingaroa (Chatham Islands) which recorded first arrival at ~ 3.5 hours after the earthquake." (Downes et al. 2006)
tidal_records: Digital: Land Information New Zealand (LINZ), National Institute for Water & Atmosheric Research (NIWA); Analysis: Mulgor Consulting

source_material: For 2 weeks prior to the Tonga tsunami a digger was working in the Whangamata Harbour, opening up a badly blocked stream. On 4 May between 10.00am and 11.00am the operator noticed significant surges in the water levels; something he hadn't seen previously. It was on the incoming tide, when suddenly the tide rushed out, then came in again; then repeated this over again. The machine was working about 1 km up the harbour and wouldn't be influenced by swells. (Verbal communication via several people from Roger Spooner, 2006, reported in Downes et al. (2006))

"Gisborne has ubiquitous infra gravity ( IG ) waves of 33 s period that are aliased by 1-minute sampling, thus causing the noisy signal leading up to 4 May. The tsunami waves are easily identifiable, having much longer periods. The first waves arrived in mid-morning, about 6 h after the earthquake." (www.mulgor.co.nz/TongaTsu06/); Marsden Point is strongly affected by far infra gravity waves, which are modulated with the tide, being higher at high tide. However, FIG waves tend to have periods of 6 to 20 min, so the very long waves in mid-morning of 4 May, may be the first tsunami waves. The large waves at high tide could be a superposition of FIG and tsunami waves. Marsden Point is in direct line with Tonga, so for the sites under consideration, the tsunami would be expected to reach here first. (www.mulgor.co.nz/TongaTsu06/); "Derek Goring, of Mulgor Consulting, who monitors tide gauges at some NZ ports, has posted his analysis of the records for tsunami for 4-5 May on www.mulgor.co.nz/TongaTsu06/ Derek notes that he has excluded some where nothing apparently happened, and that in many cases, the tsunami was obscured to a greater or lesser extent by long waves (infra-gravity or far-infragravity) produced by weather systems and swell. 
The greatest peak-to-trough measurements were observed at Kaingaroa-Chatham Island (0.35 m), Gisborne (0.30 m) and Lyttelton (0.25 m), and probably Timaru (0.3 m), Napier (0.2 m) and Marsden Point (0.15 m)....
The first arrival at Kaingaroa, 3.5 hours after the earthquake, is consistent with William Power’s movie (see below). The first arrivals recorded in the North and South Islands were at Moturiki-Mt Maunganui (5.1 hours) Marsden Point (5.5 hours), Gisborne (6.0 hours), Otago Harbour Entrance and Lyttelton (~ 6 hours), Napier (~ 6.4 hours), Port Taranaki (~ 8 hours). The Timaru waves arrived quite late at 9 hrs after the earthquake. While the first waves arrived at Lyttelton around 6 hrs after the earthquake, the peak was at about 18 hrs after the earthquake – this very late peak is interesting and its cause probably requires investigation. " (Downes et al, 2006)
tidal_records: Digital: Land Information New Zealand (LINZ), National Institute for Water & Atmosheric Research (NIWA); Analysis: Mulgor Consulting

source_material:
"Port Taranaki is exposed to the high energy Tasman Sea. Strong far infra gravity ( FIG ) and infra gravity ( IG ) waves occur regularly. The period leading up to the tsunami was uncharacteristically quiet. The tsunami excited the 15-minute seiche-period of the embayment. The waves started arriving about 7 hours after the earthquake and peaked about 9 hours after the earthquake. Subsequently, a small FIG event occurred that obscured the tsunami waves." (www.mulgor.co.nz/TongaTsu06/); "Derek Goring, of Mulgor Consulting, who monitors tide gauges at some NZ ports, has posted his analysis of the records for tsunami for 4-5 May on www.mulgor.co.nz/TongaTsu06/ Derek notes that he has excluded some where nothing apparently happened, and that in many cases, the tsunami was obscured to a greater or lesser extent by long waves (infra-gravity or far-infragravity) produced by weather systems and swell. 
The greatest peak-to-trough measurements were observed at Kaingaroa-Chatham Island (0.35 m), Gisborne (0.30 m) and Lyttelton (0.25 m), and probably Timaru (0.3 m), Napier (0.2 m) and Marsden Point (0.15 m)....
The first arrival at Kaingaroa, 3.5 hours after the earthquake, is consistent with William Power’s movie (see below). The first arrivals recorded in the North and South Islands were at Moturiki-Mt Maunganui (5.1 hours) Marsden Point (5.5 hours), Gisborne (6.0 hours), Otago Harbour Entrance and Lyttelton (~ 6 hours), Napier (~ 6.4 hours), Port Taranaki (~ 8 hours). The Timaru waves arrived quite late at 9 hrs after the earthquake. While the first waves arrived at Lyttelton around 6 hrs after the earthquake, the peak was at about 18 hrs after the earthquake – this very late peak is interesting and its cause probably requires investigation. " (Downes et al, 2006)
tidal_records: Digital: Land Information New Zealand (LINZ), National Institute for Water & Atmosheric Research (NIWA); Analysis: Mulgor Consulting

source_material:
"At Napier Port, strong far infra gravity waves are ubiquitous. They excite seiche both at embayment and at harbour scales. The waves that arrived on 4 May are indistinguishable from the regular FIG waves that occur, except for the time when they began to get larger, which happened to be a few hours after the earthquake." (www.mulgor.co.nz/TongaTsu06/); "Derek Goring, of Mulgor Consulting, who monitors tide gauges at some NZ ports, has posted his analysis of the records for tsunami for 4-5 May on www.mulgor.co.nz/TongaTsu06/ Derek notes that he has excluded some where nothing apparently happened, and that in many cases, the tsunami was obscured to a greater or lesser extent by long waves (infra-gravity or far-infragravity) produced by weather systems and swell. 
The greatest peak-to-trough measurements were observed at Kaingaroa-Chatham Island (0.35 m), Gisborne (0.30 m) and Lyttelton (0.25 m), and probably Timaru (0.3 m), Napier (0.2 m) and Marsden Point (0.15 m)....
The first arrival at Kaingaroa, 3.5 hours after the earthquake, is consistent with William Power’s movie (see below). The first arrivals recorded in the North and South Islands were at Moturiki-Mt Maunganui (5.1 hours) Marsden Point (5.5 hours), Gisborne (6.0 hours), Otago Harbour Entrance and Lyttelton (~ 6 hours), Napier (~ 6.4 hours), Port Taranaki (~ 8 hours). The Timaru waves arrived quite late at 9 hrs after the earthquake. While the first waves arrived at Lyttelton around 6 hrs after the earthquake, the peak was at about 18 hrs after the earthquake – this very late peak is interesting and its cause probably requires investigation. " (Downes et al, 2006)
tidal_records: Digital: Land Information New Zealand (LINZ), National Institute for Water & Atmosheric Research (NIWA); Analysis: Mulgor Consulting

source_material:
"Lyttelton is in a sheltered harbour. The harbour has a seiche period of 11 minutes and although the open coast is strongly affected by far infra gravity waves, only waves with periods of around 11 minutes penetrate the harbour to the tide gauge. The tsunami arrived about 6 h after the earthquake, but the peak waves did not arrive until 18 h after the earthquake. The tsunami caused harbour resonance at 11-minute periods and this is probably why the longer period waves in the tsunami are not apparent. They are there, but they have been swamped by the harbour resonance." (www.mulgor.co.nz/TongaTsu06/); "Derek Goring, of Mulgor Consulting, who monitors tide gauges at some NZ ports, has posted his analysis of the records for tsunami for 4-5 May on www.mulgor.co.nz/TongaTsu06/ Derek notes that he has excluded some where nothing apparently happened, and that in many cases, the tsunami was obscured to a greater or lesser extent by long waves (infra-gravity or far-infragravity) produced by weather systems and swell. 
The greatest peak-to-trough measurements were observed at Kaingaroa-Chatham Island (0.35 m), Gisborne (0.30 m) and Lyttelton (0.25 m), and probably Timaru (0.3 m), Napier (0.2 m) and Marsden Point (0.15 m)....
The first arrival at Kaingaroa, 3.5 hours after the earthquake, is consistent with William Power’s movie (see below). The first arrivals recorded in the North and South Islands were at Moturiki-Mt Maunganui (5.1 hours) Marsden Point (5.5 hours), Gisborne (6.0 hours), Otago Harbour Entrance and Lyttelton (~ 6 hours), Napier (~ 6.4 hours), Port Taranaki (~ 8 hours). The Timaru waves arrived quite late at 9 hrs after the earthquake. While the first waves arrived at Lyttelton around 6 hrs after the earthquake, the peak was at about 18 hrs after the earthquake – this very late peak is interesting and its cause probably requires investigation. " (Downes et al, 2006)
tidal_records: Digital: Land Information New Zealand (LINZ), National Institute for Water & Atmosheric Research (NIWA); Analysis: Mulgor Consulting

source_material:
"Kaingaroa, on the north eastern tip of Chatham Island, was not affected by meterologically generated long waves at the time of the event, so the tsunami waves stand out. The arrival time of the first waves was 06:50 NZST, 3.4 h after the earthquake, indicating that the waves took a direct route south from Tonga." (www.mulgor.co.nz/TongaTsu06/); "The highest wave heights measured in NZ territories were measured on the east coast of Chatham Island (NE side of island) at Kaingaroa at 0.35 m (crest-to-trough) or about 0.19 m above the tide level at the time. This compared with other gauges in the North and South Islands that only registered wave heights up to 0.25–0.3 m at some sites (e.g., Mt. Maunganui, 0.25 m and Timaru, Lyttelton discussed below)) but most other gauge sites experienced smaller waves that were <0.2 m (crest-to-trough) and barely distinguishable from background seiching or weather-related long waves. 
Appendix 1 shows the sea-level traces for Moturiki (Mt Maunganui), with the first arrival at ~ 5.2 hours, and Kaingaroa (Chatham Islands) which recorded first arrival at ~ 3.5 hours after the earthquake.... Derek Goring, of Mulgor Consulting, who monitors tide gauges at some NZ ports, has posted his analysis of the records for tsunami for 4-5 May on www.mulgor.co.nz/TongaTsu06/ Derek notes that he has excluded some where nothing apparently happened, and that in many cases, the tsunami was obscured to a greater or lesser extent by long waves (infra-gravity or far-infragravity) produced by weather systems and swell. 
The greatest peak-to-trough measurements were observed at Kaingaroa-Chatham Island (0.35 m), Gisborne (0.30 m) and Lyttelton (0.25 m), and probably Timaru (0.3 m), Napier (0.2 m) and Marsden Point (0.15 m)....
The first arrival at Kaingaroa, 3.5 hours after the earthquake, is consistent with William Power’s movie (see below). The first arrivals recorded in the North and South Islands were at Moturiki-Mt Maunganui (5.1 hours) Marsden Point (5.5 hours), Gisborne (6.0 hours), Otago Harbour Entrance and Lyttelton (~ 6 hours), Napier (~ 6.4 hours), Port Taranaki (~ 8 hours). The Timaru waves arrived quite late at 9 hrs after the earthquake. While the first waves arrived at Lyttelton around 6 hrs after the earthquake, the peak was at about 18 hrs after the earthquake – this very late peak is interesting and its cause probably requires investigation. " (Downes et al, 2006))
tidal_records: Digital: Land Information New Zealand (LINZ), National Institute for Water & Atmosheric Research (NIWA); Analysis: Mulgor Consulting

source_material: "There were surges at the Chathams, it got quite sloppy in fact. " (Communication from Rana Solomon, Emergency Manager, reported in Downes et al. (2006)

"Timaru is on the open coast and is strongly affected by far infra gravity ( FIG ) waves. However, FIG waves tend to have periods of around 10 minutes, so the long-period waves that start about noon are most likely to be the tsunami. Unfortunately, the instrument failed on 5 May, trucating the record." (www.mulgor.co.nz/TongaTsu06/); "Derek Goring, of Mulgor Consulting, who monitors tide gauges at some NZ ports, has posted his analysis of the records for tsunami for 4-5 May on www.mulgor.co.nz/TongaTsu06/ Derek notes that he has excluded some where nothing apparently happened, and that in many cases, the tsunami was obscured to a greater or lesser extent by long waves (infra-gravity or far-infragravity) produced by weather systems and swell. 
The greatest peak-to-trough measurements were observed at Kaingaroa-Chatham Island (0.35 m), Gisborne (0.30 m) and Lyttelton (0.25 m), and probably Timaru (0.3 m), Napier (0.2 m) and Marsden Point (0.15 m)....
The first arrival at Kaingaroa, 3.5 hours after the earthquake, is consistent with William Power’s movie (see below). The first arrivals recorded in the North and South Islands were at Moturiki-Mt Maunganui (5.1 hours) Marsden Point (5.5 hours), Gisborne (6.0 hours), Otago Harbour Entrance and Lyttelton (~ 6 hours), Napier (~ 6.4 hours), Port Taranaki (~ 8 hours). The Timaru waves arrived quite late at 9 hrs after the earthquake. While the first waves arrived at Lyttelton around 6 hrs after the earthquake, the peak was at about 18 hrs after the earthquake – this very late peak is interesting and its cause probably requires investigation. " (Downes et al, 2006)
tidal_records: Digital: Land Information New Zealand (LINZ), National Institute for Water & Atmosheric Research (NIWA); Analysis: Mulgor Consulting

source_material:
The Spit at the entrance to Otago Harbour is sheltered from far infra gravity waves, so the tsunami waves stand out. They started arriving about 6 h after the earthquake and peaked about 12 h after the tsunami. The outer embayment from the harbour has a seiche period of 25 minutes and this seiche appears to have been excited by the tsunami." (www.mulgor.co.nz/TongaTsu06/); "Derek Goring, of Mulgor Consulting, who monitors tide gauges at some NZ ports, has posted his analysis of the records for tsunami for 4-5 May on www.mulgor.co.nz/TongaTsu06/ Derek notes that he has excluded some where nothing apparently happened, and that in many cases, the tsunami was obscured to a greater or lesser extent by long waves (infra-gravity or far-infragravity) produced by weather systems and swell. 
The greatest peak-to-trough measurements were observed at Kaingaroa-Chatham Island (0.35 m), Gisborne (0.30 m) and Lyttelton (0.25 m), and probably Timaru (0.3 m), Napier (0.2 m) and Marsden Point (0.15 m)....
The first arrival at Kaingaroa, 3.5 hours after the earthquake, is consistent with William Power’s movie (see below). The first arrivals recorded in the North and South Islands were at Moturiki-Mt Maunganui (5.1 hours) Marsden Point (5.5 hours), Gisborne (6.0 hours), Otago Harbour Entrance and Lyttelton (~ 6 hours), Napier (~ 6.4 hours), Port Taranaki (~ 8 hours). The Timaru waves arrived quite late at 9 hrs after the earthquake. While the first waves arrived at Lyttelton around 6 hrs after the earthquake, the peak was at about 18 hrs after the earthquake – this very late peak is interesting and its cause probably requires investigation." (Downes et al, 2006)

source_material: Glacier watchers on the Tasman Lake had an experience of a lifetime yesterday. Two guides and 16 passengers were on two boats on the lake when the 6.3 magnitude Canterbury earthquake hit, triggering tsunamis and causing a massive ice calving off the glacier. Aoraki-Mt Cook Alpine Village Ltd general manager tourism Denis Callesen said the guides were radioed from the village as soon as the earthquake was felt, so were able to prepare for the event. Mr Callesen said the boats endured 30 minutes of tsunamis, up to 3.5 metres high. Staff are trained for the event, knowing to turn the boats towards each tsunami and motor gently forwards. About 30 million tonnes of ice calved – 1200 metres across the face, 30 metres above the lake and more than 250 metres below the surface to the bottom of the lake and back for about 75 metres. Mr Callesen said it was either the third biggest, or second-equal biggest event in Tasman Lake's history. http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/christchurch-earthquake/4692057/Earthquake-causes-glacier-to-calve

Tsunami currents caused by the massive earthquake in Japan snapped anchor ropes on marine farms in the Marlborough Sounds, tangled mussel lines and damaged mussels ready for harvest, marine farmers say. The damage could tally up to hundreds of thousands of dollars. Farmers in Port Underwood and Croisilles Harbour have been worst affected, with more than 100 lines damaged by strong, erratic currents caused by the magnitude 9 earthquake off the east coast of Japan on Friday… Hebberd Marine Farm Services owner Maurie Hebberd, who owns about 100 lines of mussels in Croisilles Harbour, said the tide had come in and out every 15 minutes from late Saturday afternoon. "A guy was unloading his boat at the boat ramp and by the time he got back from parking his trailer the water had left the boat behind." The currents had broken or twisted anchor ropes on about 15 of his mussel lines, with about 15 lines damaged on other farms in the area. The "tangled mess" could take up to 10 days to fix. "This is worse than about six years ago [after the Indonesian tsunami] that did damage to six mussel lines." http://www.stuff.co.nz/marlborough-express/news/4773798/Tsunami-mauls-mussel-farms

Tsunami currents caused by the massive earthquake in Japan snapped anchor ropes on marine farms in the Marlborough Sounds, tangled mussel lines and damaged mussels ready for harvest, marine farmers say. The damage could tally up to hundreds of thousands of dollars. Farmers in Port Underwood and Croisilles Harbour have been worst affected, with more than 100 lines damaged by strong, erratic currents caused by the magnitude 9 earthquake off the east coast of Japan on Friday. Repairs may take up to 10 days. Port Underwood mussel farmer Bruce Hearn said he watched as strong currents surged into the area from about 3pm on Saturday until about 2pm on Sunday. "The tide was running in and out several metres and I knew exactly what was going to happen. I was watching whole lines move around in enormous forces. "Parts of it [the sea] looked like the entrance to Tory Channel when the tide is running. The water was sort of boiling. "It looked a bit like a washing machine with currents coming from all sorts of angles. The currents are so strong they take silt off the bottom." About 70 mussel lines were damaged, including 15 of his own, Mr Hearn said. The eastern arm of Port Underwood and nearby Kaikoura Bay were worst hit and the area was still getting unusual currents, he said. http://www.stuff.co.nz/marlborough-express/news/4773798/Tsunami-mauls-mussel-farms
Geonet survey response: "we noticed an unusal sound….[strong currents noted] reversed tidal flow and large eddies around rock" roger rog.peters@xtra.co.nz

Geonet survey response: "Somewhat underwhelming as I expected greater changes in currents etc, however, tide changes we observed were real…..approx 50cm (?) change in tide level over approx 15mn period. Tide was coming in but stopped and currents backed up for a period before coming back in again.

Geonet survey response: "The entrance of Oamaru harbour 300 strait out was very murky……The Oamaru Harbour had unusually rough water from the channel about 300m out of the harbour directly in line with the channel. People down at the harbour said the sea looked like it was acting weird. I was at a height but it would have been from the harbour surging.......I was going to take the boat fishing but decided not to go. Many boats still went out. It was meant to hit when we would be retrieving the boat."
Katy Brett 03 326 4788

Geonet survey response: "water level varied between the low tide and high tide marks over a period of about 8 minutes….[strong current observations] no. We got out of the water during the initial surges, and then after 1 hour, began swimming again." Robert Lindsay 021 376 761
Geonet survey response: "The estuary and water was a lot lower than what we normally observe
Geonet survey response: "Didn't see any noticeable change"

Geonet survey response: "It was very unusual sighting and we wondered what was going on. I have not doubt it was caused by the tsunami and am very grateful that nz didn't get affected by the tsunami or we would have been thigh high surf casting our rods into the bay and been washed away completely unaware from not seeing the news what had gone on in the pacific......It was large ripples spread accross anakiwa bay like an enormous wake of a boat that lasted a good 10 minutes

Geonet survey response: "Incoming tide picked up speed to possibly double the normal rate at around 10.30 AM and there was very noticable surface disturbance. This continued for maybe 15 minutes until the incoming tide ceased movement altogether which was very unusual given that the tide was roughly halfway in at the time. It then began to flow back out for a short period before returning to its normal flow rate. This entire episode would have lasted for perhaps 30-45 minutes and there were periods afterwards when the tidal flow did appear to be running faster and slower but not as assertively as the initial episode." Robin Patmore. rob-man@xtra.co.nz

Geonet survey response: "Similar experience to Feb 2010 Chillean EQ and 1960 Chillean EQ. But this time, more extreme and lasted longer. Tides ran for 3 days, strong. Mussel farms experienced damage to mussel lines. Water extremely dirty on Sat/Sun and started to settle Monday-Wednesday. Ususal tides were not strong for this time of the month. It was all Tsunami related......surging from hightide to lowtide on beach.... 'Boiling' tide round rocky point. Like rapids." Narelle Guard ph 03 5799461 email - danems06@gmail.com
obs_damage: Damage to mussel lines in mussel farms

source_material: Geonet survey response: "The tide came in and out then in and out again in the space of 50-55 minutes….[sea] murked up particularly around estuary entrance…...[strong currents] around estuary entrance.......the sea went from very high tide level to very low tide level in about 55 minutes, and fluctuated inbetween this time. in and out about 2 times." Beth Davy, 07 866 5798

Geonet survey response: "Water level advanced approximately 3 metres, remained for about 2 minutes and then dropped back to where it was before....My assumption is that this had something to do with the Tsunami as there were no other boats or activity in the water to cause this. The advance of the water took a few minutes to rise up, not like one wave but a rapid creeping of the water level. We noticed as we had to move our towels back and the kids sand castles were washed away and then the sea retreated back to where it had been." Kate Galloway kateygal@hotmail.com
Geonet survey response: "i saw nothing unusual"

Geonet survey response: "Water level increase was up to about 1.5m against the tide gauge on the piling at the off-loading wharf and the pilings at the entrance to the harbour.....Within the greater Tutukaka habour, the bottom mud had been disturbed. All the water within the marina (proper) was disturbed and carrying a full fine sediment load. Nearshore, outside the harbor, the sea looked like the fines had also been stirred up. This discoloration went out about .5mile and extended up and down the coast......Strong currents came in sets and the strongest currents were about 6 to 8 hrs after the expected 1st arrival. Very strong at the restricted entrance to the marina. A gyre or internal circulation was set up within the marina basin. Boats were pulling strongly on mooring lines. 2 pilings along the main entrance channel were broken (in the 2009 tsunami 1 piling was broken in the same line of piles). Strong currents were also observed in the harbour around the points/headlands and shallow areas. Strong currents were also observed at the headlands visible from our house (looks out over Te Waite bay)/.........It's valuable for people to observe and experience a tsunami in a safe situation because it's a learning opportunity. Tutukaka harbour is susceptible to damage from tsunami because of it's location and particular configuration. I believe that Tutukaka harbour should be closed during tsunami events: close the launch ramp (reports of problems at the ramp and a fishing contest continued on the day); evacuate boats from the commercial wharf (too much extra strain on the structure); close the fuel docks (they are at the entrance and in the main current); evacuate all the boats on pile moorings along the entrance channel (3 piles broken in 2 events); close the marina to vessels coming in or going out (we watched several boats nearly get into serious trouble with the currents at the entrance), unless emergency vessels and until 2 hours after the last strong surges. I have observed 3 tsunamis at Tutukaka in the 18 months." Darlene Buckley (09) 434-4268
obs_damage: Boats pulled strongly on mooring lines and 2 pilings broke in Tutukaka Harbour

source_material: Geonet survey response: "[surges were] slightly greater than high/low tides……[sea colour] was murky, more sediment.…..It was an experience to see tidal changes so regularly throughout the day"
Geonet survey response: "water was faster moving than normal and in the wrong direction"

Geonet survey response: "SEA SURGES AROUND HALF A METRE IN HEIGHT. SEA WOULD COVER THE ROCKS THEN RECEDE TO NORMAL TIDE HEIGHT EVERY HALF HOUR. NEIGHBOUR SAYS THIS WAS MORE PROMINENT FROM 11AM ONWARDS. HEAVY SILTING DISCHARGES FROM MONGONUI HARBOUR OBSERVED.......On holiday up at Cable Bay with three friends. We all saw the tidal surges that day. It was very noticeable and seemed to occur every half hour." Brian Cook Helena Bay Northland.

Geonet survey response: "50cm to 75cm above and below the normal tide……[sea colour] sandy brown...Watched the tide suck in and out of the Marsden Cove Marina 2 times. See Link http://youtu.be/PkcO4LwfQKc" macsway@xtra.co.nz

Geonet survey response: "Went on boat from matarangi to mercury islands late morning, noted murky waters, some wave action on the way out and fairly strong currents observed by divers in our party. we tried to park up at one bay that is usually dead still but had to abandon efforts due to decent sized waves and strong currents. at the next bay the boat had to be moved frequently which apparently is not the norm in the area. standing thigh high in the water I noted a strong pull back out to sea. we left late afternoon and I didn't take note of anything else on the way home....Extremely murky water around estuary in matarangi, murky close to shore at mercury islands.....Had to leave one bay due to waves and currents. strong current back out to sea from beach.."
Geonet survey response: "[sea colour] Brown coloured…….[observed] Eddies only, tide seemed confused"

Geonet survey response: "Tidal surges ranging up to 60 metres within a 5 minute period - sea would remain at that level for 30 minutes before reversing position……[strong currents] No. The Hector's Dolphins appeared to be unusually active. Three separate family pods seen in or near the breakers, lots of acrobatic leaping and tail slapping." Amanda Watson 021 895 577

Geonet survey response: "There were consistent tidal movements along the Ohope Beach - generally moving out to around the half tide mark and then coming back to the High tide mark In the afternoon The rocks around Otawairere Bay became fully exposed, slightly below the normal low tide mark. The water would then come back in covering the rocks and up to around the normal high tide mark. This happened around 6-7 times in the time we were there to observe it......[strong currents?] yes - the water rose back to the HT mark within minutes from below the LT mark. strong currents were visible around the rocks........The wave amplitude was mildly increased on the day along Ohope Beach when the surges were incoming. This was also true at Otawairere Bay. A person who had been fishing most of the day at Otawairere said the tide had been coming in and out all day every 15 - 20 minutes - surges had come up beyond the HT mark in the morning apparently (due to it being HT at the time I guess guess)."

Geonet survey response: "[surge height was] Close to normal HW but not coincident with HW which had occurred earlier. Wave amplified in channel tributary to Waitemata Harbour: amplitude > 0.5 m.....unusual degree of turbulence, velocity, change of level and short period wave sloshing had stirred bed silts into a distinctive grey-coloured suspension......[strong currents?] Yes - flow velocities in the cross section exceeded normal ebb tidal velocities at that particular water stage by a factor of 2 or more........Have a doctoral degree in estuarine hydrology and had followed the event from the initial quake on the Honshu shelf. The Meola Creek observation was made during a tour of the Waitemata shoreline to look for waves superimposed on the ebbing tide. The elevated water level, extreme turbity and accelerated water velocity was unmistakably evidence of a short period tsumami wave in the upper Waitemata Harbour." Walter Jenks w.jenks@ags.school.nz Home telephone 09 815 1941

Geonet survey response: " [we heard the] Sound of rushing water .. weak…Sediment was carried out of the bay, discoloured the adjacent bay......[strong currents?] Retreating water generated an increase in tidal flow, upto 1.4 kts was showing on log.......We experinced 3 arrivals, the second generated about 0.6m of water level change over 20mins, dpeth varied from around 3.8 to 4.4m on the depth sounder." Brad Scott Wairakei 027 444 7246 07 3748211

Geonet survey response: "Sudden changes of tide that were ongoing since I saw it on the other side of the harbour near the Main Road into Tairua at 10.30am. At the bar entrance it roared in & create a giant whirlpool, several boats fought to control and the 2 courtesy moorings suddenly got swept below water level at great speed, fish leaping out of the water fighting the sudden currents and surges....The tide seemed to roar from the water noise near the bar entrance........There were very strong currents near the bar, 3 stupid young men were swimming on the Pauanui side against the strong currents created at the bar entrance, one almost got sucked into the whirlpool.......It was very sandy, mud-coloured and foamy when the surges happened.......It made me realise I should be totally prepared because if it was much larger we are very very vulnerable inside the harbour and the coast. It was powerful for the size. I was well uphill to be safe when I watched the surges through the bar entrance." Kathy Thompson Mobile 0274 758 588
Geonet survey response: "Nothing of note" Sherralynne Dewhirst, 021-834492

Geonet survey response: "Went from dead low tide to high tide in a few minutes.....[we heard] loud rushing water sounds....Sea remained clear until it all rushed out then it got very stirred up with sand & weed....Very strong currents!!.......I have been holidaying at our crib on Tautuku peninsula for 50 years and the only other times I have seen such extreme tidal surges was during very large southerly storms but on this occasion the sea was calm with little if any noticable swell." Ross Ollerenshaw 12 Tsukigawa Tce Balclutha Ph 03 4182009 E-mail rossolly@xtra.co.nz
Geonet survey response: "Didn't notice anything different."

placename: Tikao Bay (Akaroa Harbour, Canterbury) and Governers Bay (Lytellton Harbour, Canterbrury)

source_material: Geonet survey response: "Very strong undertow when we were at the sea. It was so strong that we decided to end our boggie boarding."

Geonet survey response: "estuary went from low to mid tide - noticed outflowing tide then went to high tide mark within minutes (hours before high tide due)......tide seemed to go out before 8am then suddenly at high tide mark which was noticable by a large brach (2m vertical height) left upright in the sand form where the high tide had been marked days previously by campers. Branch would still be there now. Seconds prior to noticing tide at branch it would have been a good 50m from brancd incoming and outgoing at regular intervals...Diving later during the day water definitley not the visibility of the previous day - fish lfe very much less abundant. No big fish, significant and unusual numbers of garfish and small fish around rocks and reef......Currents unusual. outgoing tides when suppose to be approaching. our inflatable boat carried in unusual directions compared with expected tides. Out on water after 1pm. At one stage (possibly around 3pm noticed massive wave coming over reef which almost made us return to shore as the current suddenly became unusually strong and made paddling impossible.........Experienced several different aspects including estuary fill, wave action on beach and in a rocky bay and also in water currents, surges and aquatic life. Interestingly enough were the only peoply to move to higher groung in entire camground once informed by civil defence that there was a tsunami warning in place. Left tent after an hour of discussion and drove to point overlooking both beach and estuary to sleep until returning to beachside at 8am." Felicity Keenan 1850 State Hwy 1 Marton 4787 phone 063274465

Geonet survey response: "At the beach at 0830hrs, waves about 0.5m appeared out of a calm sea. At small estuary at east of the beach, at1400hrs, incomming surges of about imetre were noted on the out going tide....At estuary (above), tide receded some 20m between surges.....Much turbulence with suspended sand at estuary during surges, coastal sea [colour] no change.....[strong currents?] Only at the estuary (above).......On the coastal beach, little or no impact other than unusual small waves out of a calm sea. At the beach estuary, very strong surges at approx 20 minute intervals noticed over the afternoon." Phill Freeman, 10 Korau Rd, Tikipunga ,Whangarei.ph 09 4372465 work email phillip.freeman@northlanddhb.org.nz

Geonet survey response: "I saw the water come gushing up the river, moving very fast. Fishermen had to move up the riverbank some distance. I saw 3 major pushes, about half an hour apart, and lasting for about 10-20min each.....I noticed that the inshore water was very dirty. A LOT of sand was deposited on the beach. The wreck referred to above was partly exposed in the morning, but by the late afternoon it was almost submerged. The sand was soft. The depth deposited would have been maybe 1 metre of more......At estuary (above), tide receded some 20m between surges.......The current up the Mokihinui River was very strong. At its height (about 1.30pm, or 2pm) the water covered a groin, that doesn't get covered in high tide.......The peak seemed to be about 1-2pm. Thereafter the surges got gradually weaker, until about 5pm there was little surge. When I went back later it was low tide and there was little different activity, although I noticed a very slight surge." Frida Inta, frida@paradise.net.nz

placename: Badleys Beach, Millons Bay, Tauwharanui peninsula
source_material: Geonet survey response: "Badleys beach is a shallow tidal bay. The tide should have been dropping from high tide - but it looked like a very high tide at the waves height - a metre off the sea wall, The tide dropped to low tide within 10 minutes. The tide rose and fell at least three times within a half hour - each time the difference between in and out was smaller......We don't usually get much sea noise but the sound was the first thing I noticed. The water sounded turbulent....The water was thick and dark brown black with sediment.....The sea receeded to the edge of the bay, not sure of the distance but 600 or 700metres. The reef in the middle was fully exposed. Two kyakers took their boats down to the beach with the sand exposed and within a few minutes the tide came in and they rode the tide out again....The currents in the bay were strong - my son stood out on the bay as the tide came back in and though the water only came to his knees he felt he could have been knocked over had it been much higher........Our bay filled and emptied throughout the afternoon. The biggest tide was about 1.30pm and over the afternoon the difference became less as the tide proper dropped. The current running up into the mangroves and creeks was enough to knock over children playing. We did film a small amount of video." Raewyn Rasch murahidy@xtra.co.nz

Geonet survey response: "The water level at high tide was unusually high - like a king tide.......Unusual amount of sediment discoloration in the river - much like after heavy rain when sediment is washed into the river......[strong currents?] Yes. Although the tide had only just passed high tide, at around 12.50pm, the water started flowing down the river at a great rate. The current was flowing at around 4 or 5 knots - sufficient to move the jetty and strain the ropes on the boat which we had tied up at the time. This lasted for about 10 or 15 minutes........The strangest phenomenon was the sight of the water flowing back upstream on the Wairoa River nothwithstanding there was an outgoing tide. Around 2.00 pm, I noticed the river stopped flowing out towards the sea ( on the outgoing tide) and the water was actually flowing in as if the tide was coming in. It was clearly evident as debris in the river which had gone past the jetty downstream was now flowing back past the jetty upstream. We left before the surge upstream halted, so didn't observe the subsequent outflow. The Clevedon Cruising Club is probably 3 or 4 km upstream from the river mouth. We had returned from a trip to Great Barrier. We left the Barrier at 8.00am and did not notice anything unusual there or on the trip back. It wasn't until we were back up the river that we noticed the surges." Chris Lynch c.lynch@inderlynch.co.nz
Geonet survey response: "There was no change in the usual pattern of the ocean."

Geonet survey response: "When i first heard about it, it came up live on all channels. I think it had happened and hour or so before it came on NZ television. i logged on to geonet and could see on the main quake drum, a large quake (we knew it was in japan) had registered on every seismic station throughout N.Z about an hour and a half before. this was followed by another bump in the lines (running from top to bottom of all drums) a strong aftershock. these were obviously different from the readings from canterbury. Im sure you understand what i mean. I inmagine it would have registered here around mag 1, under 2? When the last tsunami reached n.z from another large quake a few years back (?), we observed in Hokitika a larger than normal wave that came up the beach higher than the rest, into the tussock area. they never came that high again. I suppose it must of happened here again this time, but you wouldnt notice it unless you knew what you were looking for." Zody Ensor 2/43 Hinchy Lane Greymouth 7805 zody1@windowslive.com
Geonet survey response: "I noticed nothing different"

Geonet survey response: "From where we were at Blucks Pit Rd, there wasn't a noticeable tsunami as such. But the sea certainly wasn't normal. When we returned home to Gisborne on Sunday around 1pm we live by the Waimata river, and noticed it surging quite dramatically again like it did when we had the last big tsunami warning March 2010. During mid afternoon we noticed the greatest surges, approx 10-15 min in, then a couple of minutes of no movement, then 10-15 min out before repeating, this happened most of the afternoon....[we heard] not really an unusual noise, but the day was fairly calm with only a light breeze, yet the beach was choppy and surging like it does in a storm....The water was murky and brown - to about 100m from the beach. The day before the water was blue right up to the beach......[strong currents?] Yes, we were fishing with an electric kontiki, and it was continually swept down the beach to the south.." Tim Colvin, 43 Riverside Rd, Gisborne. 021 413452
Geonet survey response: "The beach seemed normal in all aspects." Katie Oliver 03 382 5134

Geonet survey response: "Curious observers around me remarked that the water receded some distance tide rising and falling over minutes . No waves just watched the water level increase on the beach , water pushing in , stayed elevated for about 5-10 minutes then began to fall....[sea colour] Brown streaks prior to the rsing and falling water.....[strong currents?] Yes at the harbour entrance marked waves and currents especially as the harbour basin emptied" Chris Raine 021323580

Geonet survey response: "the tide was fluctuating , when i arrived it was going out, 10 minutes later it had come back in by about 10 metres up the beach, this behaviour continued until it came in very high and stayed in ……….The sea was simply strange"

Geonet survey response: "I heard it in the news by looking at a warning that is on Google on Friday night. I did not feel it or notice anything unuseal going on Wellington Harbour." Simon Atkinson. 10 Harold Denton Place St Albans Christchurch 8014 (027 458 2249)

Geonet survey response: "Sea was quite flat - waves less the 200mm - each wave drove higher and higer, without receding. for 10mins. then retreated producing (almost) standing waves. Photos were taken a various stages...water appeared sligthly dirty..." Geoff Cloake - geoff@cloake.co.nz

Geonet survey response: "High tide and low tide levels - extra high tide about 2.5m (should have been 2-2.1mtre and super low level around the 0.2m mark - should have been that day about 0.7m….[strong currents?] Yes at times;" Gabriella - 021 1053971
Geonet survey response: "[sea colour] mud swirls [observed]……..[strong currents?] yes water speeding out like a speed boat"

Geonet survey response: "There were possible times of wave activity on top of existing low swell, which appeared to repeat maybe every 10 mins. The sea level at beach didn't appear to change during observed time. No obvious waves or sea level when viewing out to horizon. Sea calm."

placename: Sandy Bay Road, North Shore, Auckland
source_material: Geonet survey response: "[sea receded] 250 meters - but it's a very slight gradient beach (that's why I chose that beach).....At 1:46 you could hear the water flowing out like a creek and a slight sucking noise. I wont mention the slapping of the fish on the mud when they got stuck... :).....The mud was getting stirred up by the strong currents......Whirlpools could be seen out in the deeper channel.......Personally - mind blowing. The energy released to move all that water really is... well - mind blowing. All the members of the public whom I spoke with had no idea what was going on. One pair even went beach seining only to find themselves neck deep in water 20 min later. The lack of education among the general population is outstanding. I can provide time stamped photos if requested." Darren McManaway 0210411 850

Geonet survey response: "The waves seemed to be closer together than noramal and as each wave hit the shore, the water looked like it was boiling….No unusual colour but the water looked like it was boiling after each wave came ashore….[strong currents?] Yes, noticed that there were alot of rip's that morning"
Geonet survey response: "changes in usual current flows & fast movment off shore water levels….more sand movment in water……[strong currents?] strong pull in shore water up coast" greg campbell

impact_summary: Tsunami surges of less than 0.5m observed in Tutukaka

source_material: Hello, I live in the Northern Buller. On Wednesday evening, the 6th February I was at the Mokihnui River mouth. Contrary to what the Harbour Master of Westport reported (that there was no sign at all of any raised sea levels due to the Solomon's tsunami), My frined and I saw evidence of tsunami conditions. I believe the Harbour Master was not very observant. What my friend and I saw were waves breaking much further out to sea than normally in such fine weather. There was wave agitation along the shore, with a lot of wave reflection. There were impressive surges and chaotic water at the river mouth, the sea was obviously in turmoil. About one kilometre up river, where it is still tidal, and the high tide was at about 20:10, at 21:20 the tide was still at peak. I went back to the same areas last night (the 7th) to confirm our findings. By 21:20 the tide was on the turn (wet sand above the water level), even though the tide was an hour and 8 minutes later. Also, the river mouth was a lot calmer, with no wave reflection on the adjacent beach, but a steady influx of well-spaced, well-formed waves. The river mouth was a lot calmer, with little surge. Waves were forming a lot closer to shore than the night before. (pers. comm. Frida Inta 8 February 2013)
impact_summary: Lay, T., Ye, L., Kanamori, H., Yamazaki, Y., Cheung, K.F. and Ammon, C.J., 2013. The February 6, 2013 Mw 8.0 Santa Cruz Islands earthquake and tsunami. Tectonophysics, 608, pp. 1109-1121.

source_material:
A suspected mini tsunami that surged onto Papamoa Beach over the weekend knocked a fisherman off his feet and washed up kontiki fishing lines.
Tauranga real estate salesman Grahame Lindsey was fishing with his kontiki at 5.30am on Saturday morning when he was rocked by a one metre high surge.
"It gave me the willies, it was quite scary," Mr Lindsey told the Bay of Plenty Times.
The surge at low tide swept up the beach to reach the high tide line, stayed for several minutes and then drained out in a big vacuum. It was up to the waist of a nearby surf caster and swept another fisherman off his feet.
"It was a hell of a volume of water. I have never seen anything like it, it was unbelievable."
Mr Lindsey said it did not behave like a freak wave because of the way the way remained up the beach for so long.
There was so much force that several kontiki lines washed up parallel to the beach and broke his line on his winch.
However the Bay of Plenty's Civil Defence emergency management group controller Clinton Naude said nothing was detected by GNS Science that could have contributed to a tsunami hitting Tauranga's coastline.
What was described would have needed a magnitude six distant source and GNS Science registered nothing that could have contributed to it.
"We would have still have picked it up on seismograph earthquake monitoring, even if it was a close-in source."
GNS Science have monitoring buoys that detect incoming tsunami and are linked to the Pacific Tsunami Warning Centre.
Mr Naude noted that some big swells were running in the weekend. He agreed the Mr Lindsey's description of the surge did sound like a tsunami. http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11163077

Graeme McDonald of Northland Regional Council provided the following description by email on Friday 4th April 2014: "As outlined, the Tutukaka Mariner at Tutukaka had some unusual wave activity at around 9.00 a.m. on Thursday 3 April following on from the Chile earthquake that occurred on Wednesday 2nd April.  The report came from the Mariner Manager who is familiar with the mariner and the tidal state at the mariner. Over a period of several hours from 9.00 a.m. onwards there was a 20 minute cycle of lift and fall within the mariner estimated to be between .5 to .7 of a meter. A yacht entering the harbour had difficulty when it got caught in one of the wave cycles.   No damage was caused.  The mariner has a warning system, a yellow light, that was activated to alert vessels of the problem. By 2.00 pm the tidal state had settled down and the warning light was turned off."

The tsunami triggered by a powerful earthquake off the coast of Chile last week has caused minor damage to marine farms in Nelson and Golden Bay, which could now be hazardous for boaties. Tasman District Council harbourmaster Steve Hainstock has issued a navigation warning for users of Tasman district waters around marine farms, including those in Golden Bay and Tasman Bay, after exceptionally strong currents dislodged elements of the farms. Hainstock said marine farms had reported line breakages and damage to navigation aids. Later inspection revealed half-tonne mooring blocks had been dragged around on the sea floor. There were now loose mussel farming "backbone lines" in the water and navigation lights were either out or missing, Hainstock said. The lines are anchored to the seabed at one end only, with a buoy on the other and they may present a hazard, particularly to yachts and motorised vessels. Hainstock was surprised at the damage, particularly as no tsunami warning was issued for New Zealand. Contractors working on the farms reported sudden, intense currents that were strong enough to pull the light buoys under the water, one by one, he said. "A contractor on the farm at Collingwood, which is not far off shore, was out doing monitoring work when a surge arrived. He said it was the strongest current he'd ever seen." The contractor watched parts of the farm get sucked under the water, Hainstock said. "He watched the light buoys disappear one by one under the water. Some popped back up but others didn't. That's quite a significant current.”

Observation of a 2.5 m fall in the level of the GeoNet Kaik¯oura tide gauge over 24 min prompted a widespread tsunami warning; the reported water level then rose to 1.5 m above normal, though both of these figures are not corrected for ∼1 m of uplift that took place at the gauge location during the earthquake. A railway bridge at Oaro ∼18 km south of Kaik¯oura was hit by the tsunami, and has suffered significant damage due to tsunami and/or earthquake shaking. Elsewhere on the Kaik¯oura coast, debris lines suggest tsunami runup heights of up to about 5 m occurred in some areas, but runup rarely reached above the pre-earthquake storm beach line. (Kaiser et al., 2017)

Residents of Oaro recalled marine fauna and debris scattered on top of, as well as along the seaward bank of the railway at the southern end of Oaro. Stranded Aldrichetta forsteri and marine pebbles were also observed on the landward side of the railway. A survey was conducted on the 9th of December. Maximum run-up heights above tide level are estimated to be 5.3 m +/- 0.3 m and 4.5 +/- 0.3 m at the southern and northern ends of Oaro, respectively. Marine and freshwater flora and fauna were observed scattered across the Oaro River floodplain, extending some 250 m from the high tide mark on the day of the survey. This distance is likely to be an underestimate. (Power et al., 2017).

A survey was conducted on the 9th of December, 2016. Marine debris, stranded subtidal fauna, H. iris, O. catharus and flora, H. banksii as well as unconsolidated beach material were scattered well above the reach of the high tide and storm berms. Maximum runup is measured at 5.5 m +/- 0.3 m and 6.9 m +/- 0.3 m at the southern and northern ends of Goose Bay, respectively. (Power et al., 2017). Traces of bull kelp were scattered across the banks of the Otemakura Stream and necklace varieties of seaweed were seen draped from tree branches overhanging the stream as far as 170m from the high tide mark, implying an inundation distance of that much. This is also likely to be an underestimate. Power et al. (2017)

Surveyed 2.5 months after the earthquake. Local residents pointed out that a line of debris containing abundant kina, limpets, whole crayfish, subtidal molluscs and a conger eel had stranded on the morning after the earthquake. The skeleton of the conger eel was used as the approximate tsunami run-up which is 1.9 m above tide level at the time. (Power et al., 2017).

Surveyed 2.5 months after the earthquake. An anomalous, poorly sorted gravel layer was observed on the beach and this contained three fish skeletons. This was taken as probable evidence of a tsunami, despite the length of time since the earthquake. The fish were surveyed at 2.5-2.6m above tide level. (Power et al., 2017).

On the south side of the peninsula seaweed, driftwood, gravel and shells were washed up over a walking track. Runup 3.65 m above tide level. The pre-earthquake high tide strandline was not eroded or scoured at this location, suggesting that the deposit may have been deposited before the tsunami, and therefore is considered a tentative record of tsunami runup. (Power et al., 2017).

The location was surveyed on the 1st of December. Poorly sorted gravels with up to cobble size clasts, driftwood and seaweed were deposited onto the verge and road of the quay. This was unlikley related to the post-earthquake storm as it was a sheltered area. Run-up height was 3.3 m above tide level. (Power et al., 2017)

Surveyed 19 November 2016. Showed some evidence of inundation just beyond the regular high storm-tide mark with the possibility of a small surge overtopping the beach berm and penetrating a short distance upstream. The run-up reached approximately 2.6 m above NZVD 2016. Lane et al. (2017)

The tsunami badly damaged a historic cottage at Little Pigeon Bay in Banks Peninsula, where water marks inside the cottage indicated water levels up to 1 m. The front door and wall were pushed in, the western side of the cottage was lifted off its foundations, the southern deck was completely removed and deposited on the beach, and the northern deck was partially removed, and fine sediment was deposited throughout the house. (Kaiser et al., 2017). A survey was conducted on the 16th November 2016 (followed by surveys on the 19th and 30th November and the 15th January). Evidence of two waves, both of which inundated the cottage were found. The first reached a run-up height of 3.7 m above NZVD2016 and travelled 140 m inland (based on ainundation lines characterized by seaweed and organic debris) and the second wave reached a height of 3.1 m above NZVD2016 and travelled 100 m inland. Modelling suggests that the highest wave arrivals happened 150 min after the earthquake. (Power et al., 2017) (Lane et al., 2017)

At Decanter Bay there was no evidence that the tsunami reached any further than the high tide debris line. There was, however, evidence of some seawater intrusion up the stream. A conversation with the local landowner revealed that this was a common occurrence, and that the tsunami cleaned out seaweed left by the last storm-tide event (David Miller, pers. comm., November 2016). The run-up reached approximately 2.6 m above NZVD2016. Lane et al. (2016).

Water inundated low-lying parts of the road in Pigeon Bay. One resident reported that the sea came in and retreated several times (possibly up to 4-5 times) between about 1:30am and 4:30am (Evan Parry, pers. comm.). The first sign was an outrush of water which then surged back in around 2:00am-2:30am. About an hour later (3:30am-4:00am) a second uprush was observed which caused a visible surge up the stream and inundation of a low-lying section of the road. At daybreak, low-lying parts of the campground were also seen to have been inundated. Lane et al. (2017)

A local resident observed 'the sea rushing off the shore platforms immediately after the earthquake', which was followed sometime later by the sea 'pushing back into the marina and rising to a level equivalent to the top of the boat ramp.' (M. Posa, pers. comm., 2016) in Power et al. (2017). This person also suggested that significant inundation had also occurred in the low-lying boat trailer parking area to the north of the marina, however little evidence of this inundation remained when the surveyers arrived on the 1st of December. (Power et al., 2017).

Observed 12 days after the mainshock. The tsunami runup was measured at nine locations up to 800 m north of Needles Point. Prominent strandline composed of abundant inter- and subtidal seaweed, well-preserved subtidal fauna and gravels with anomalous grainsize and sorting. The strandlines are interpreted to represent evidence for tsunami runup and unlikely due to post-earthquake storms. (Power et al., 2017). 3.5-4.5 m above tide level.

Time-lapse video shows the tsunami surge at Wellington's Lyall Bay after the 7.5 earthquake.John Young reckons his hill-top view of Wellington Harbour is pretty nice. The self-professed "IT-geek" who works for Weta Digital has a permanent camera pointed over Lyall Bay from his Melrose home, which he livestreams to the world via YouTube. I thought it would be a nice thing for people around the world to see Wellington," Young said. "It's a bit of an IT geek experiment." Usually he gets one or two viewers tuning in live at a time. But at around 1.26am New Zealand-time, viewers around the world heard the news about the country's magnitude 7.5 earthquake. They began tuning into watch Wellington live via Young's YouTube channel, and suddenly, he had 6000 viewers watching the small tsunami surge washing in and out of Lyall Bay. Source: NOAA
